Despite arms treaties, good will between Moscow and Washington and promises of hundreds of millions of dollars of American financial and technical aid, Russia has made slow progress, and in some cases no headway at all, in destroying some of its most deadly weapons. A1 

FEAR OF SPREADING ATOMIC ARMS
Of all Russia's weapons, its huge arsenal of nuclear warheads is of greatest concern. The risk that strict controls might break down or that some of them might be sold or stolen is a major worry for Western officials trying to stop the spread of nuclear weapons. A16

HEADLINE: An Underground Railroad From Projects to Suburbs

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCHAUMBURG, Ill.

 BODY:
Over the last two decades, a small Chicago program has reached a kind of legendary stature by helping the black residents of public housing quietly flee to a suburban world that promises more jobs, better schools and safer streets.
This modest variation on the Underground Railroad is now about to go national. The Federal Government is planning to spend $234 million in the next two years to help about 6,200 poor families move to middle-class neighborhoods. 
 The national program, though limited in size, cuts against decades of Federal housing policy that has helped isolate poor minorities in increasingly dangerous and desperate areas. And it comes as leaders from President Clinton on down are searching for solutions to the inner-city poverty and violence that he discussed recently in a Memphis speech.
Admirers of the Chicago effort say it is one of the few answers that has actually passed a field test. They point to an encouraging, though limited, body of research that suggests that families who receive rent subsidies that allow them to live in the suburbs earn more and do better in school after leaving the cities.
But with the expansion come questions about whether the program has really accomplished as much as its supporters suggest and whether its achievements can be duplicated.
 
Winning Stout Support
 Among the believers is Tachon Evans. She left a public housing unit with a bullet hole in the window on the South Side of Chicago for this suburb an hour to the northwest.
The move was not as easy as it might seem. Ms. Evans has been unable to find a doctor to accept her Medicaid card, and grocery clerks sometimes fuss about her food stamps. She has received anonymous notes of complaint from a neighbor, and her daughter has been chased home from school by classmates who call her names.
But despite bouts of loneliness and racial insult, Ms. Evans, a single mother of three, said the move was one of the best things to befall her.
"I would never move back to Chicago," said Ms. Evans, who is studying at a community college to become a nurse. "I plan, when I finish school, to buy me a house. And it'll be out here."
Henry G. Cisneros, the Housing Secretary, visited the Chicago program earlier this year and said he hoped eventually to start a similar effort in every major city. "I'm very impressed with what they're doing," he said.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development is considering applications from about 10 cities, including New York, and will finance programs in Los Angeles and five other cities.
 
Some Major Differences
 The workability of a national program remains to be proven. Part of the Chicago program's success comes from the unusual devotion of the organization that runs it, the Leadership Council for Metropolitan Open Communities. The group, founded in the wake of the 1966 open housing campaign by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Chicago, has decades of experience in fighting residential discrimination.
And the national program, called Moving to Opportunity, differs in at least one significant way: rather than help blacks move to white suburbs, it will help poor people move to middle-class neighborhoods, regardless of race.
Some critics fear that without explicit racial criteria, the program may either fail to enroll black families or simply help them move from one type of segregated neighborhood to another.
"I don't think that it addresses the major evil in American society today," said Florence Roisman, a Washington specialist in housing law. "The basic evil is racial segregation."
The Chicago program grew from a 1966 lawsuit filed on behalf of Dorothy Gautreaux, a black resident of the city's public housing. Ms. Gautreaux died before the suit was decided. But the Federal courts upheld her contention that the Chicago Housing Authority had discriminated against black tenants by confining them to projects in black neighborhoods.
 
Registration Draws Calls
 The Gautreaux program, as it is called, was part of the court-ordered solution. It seeks to desegregate subsidized housing by giving black families rental subsidies, if they move to private apartments in white areas of a six-county region.
The program has proved so popular that the leadership council now confines registration to a single day a year, when as many as 15,000 telephone calls flood the office.
Those who get through, like Ms. Evans, often travel to suburbs simply to call, since the circuits jam in parts of the city where public housing is dense. The leadership council registers the first 2,000 families who call and provides the subsidies, called Section 8 certificates, to about 400 new recipients a year. Most families can renew the certificates indefinitely.
Like many applicants, Ms. Evans sought the subsidy simply because she wanted to leave public housing, not because she wanted to live among white people. Her plan was to stay in the suburbs for only a year, as required, then transfer the subsidy to a private apartment in Chicago.
 
Relishing New Setting
 The families move one at a time as inconspicuously as possible to avoid provoking opposition. Still, when Ms. Evans moved two years ago, she heard racial insults flung from passing cars, and one neighbor in an adjoining townhouse left complaining notes, including one that said, "You people walk too loud."
Ms. Evans recalled, "When I first moved, it was a relief to see another black person."
But she came to relish suburban safety, especially after four years in Dearborn Homes, a public housing project so violent, she said, she had to watch television in the dark to avoid attracting gunfire.
"When people come out here, I always joke, 'Don't speed, because the police don't have anything better to do but give you a ticket,' " she said.
For now, Ms. Evans is living on a $414 monthly welfare check plus food stamps. The subsidy program requires her to contribute 30 percent of her income toward shelter costs. So she spends about $125 a month for part of the utility bill, while the Government sends her a $69 utilities supplement and pays the $887 rent for her three-bedroom townhouse.
 
Daughter Is Ambivalent
 Whether the move will raise her earnings remains unclear, but Ms. Evans professes confidence that she will find work after finishing her studies. In contrast to the city, she said, jobs are plentiful in Schaumburg. "For you to be out here and not have a job, it's only because you don't want one," she said.
Ms. Evans's 9-year-old daughter, Marchonda, is more ambivalent about the move. She said she had exchanged the fear she felt in the projects for the loneliness that came from being the only black student in her class.
Last year she was chased home and pushed to the ground by taunting classmates. This year she transferred to a new school, for unrelated reasons, but the name-calling has resumed. "This girl does it every day," she said. "She calls me 'bad breath,' 'stink breath' and all that stuff."
While Marchonda is convinced that the harassment is racial, her mother argues that children are picked on everywhere and probably less so in the suburbs than in the projects. "She was the new girl, and they were going to mess with her," Ms. Evans said.
 
Study Shows Strong Results
 James Rosenbaum, a sociologist at Northwestern University, argues that the moves not only bring more safety but also higher earnings and more education, especially for the children.
Mr. Rosenbaum has compared some Gautreaux program families with similar families who stayed in Chicago.
He found that 54 percent of the suburban students went to college, and 27 percent attended a four-year school. By contrast, 21 percent of the city students went to college, and 4 percent were enrolled in four-year schools.
Mr. Rosenbaum found that the suburbs provided a similar increase in employment. Of those youths not in school, 75 percent of the suburban group had jobs, while 41 percent in the city had them. In addition, 21 percent of the suburban youths were earning more than $6.50 an hour, while 5 percent in the city did so.
Typical job-training programs almost never make such a difference. "It's quite dramatic," he said.
But a research collaborator, Leonard S. Rubinowitz, a law professor at Northwestern University, took a more cautious view. He noted that the study had looked at only 52 suburban families. And it excluded those who had grown discouraged and moved back to the city, perhaps skewing the outcome.
 
'These Are Hard Moves'
 Mr. Rubinowitz also questions whether forced integration is a good thing. "These are hard moves to make," he said, arguing that poor black families might find just as much economic opportunity, and less harassment, simply by moving to better black neighborhoods.
Since 1976, the program has helped more than 2,000 poor black families move to white suburbs. Several families have been attacked, but none have suffered serious injury.
That record is partly the result of the leadership council's vigilance. It screens applicants through credit checks and home visits and scatters them to avoid a concentration in one town that might provoke opposition. And it refuses to work in towns like Cicero and Berwyn where the white opposition is thought to run especially deep.
"This is not an easy issue politically," said Paul B. Fischer, a professor at Lake Forest College who has studied several variations of the Gautreaux program, including those in Dallas and Cincinnati.
Mr. Fischer said that whites often feared that an influx of poor black families would drive down property values. And he said that black business owners and politicians have accused the programs of siphoning off the lifeblood of the inner city. Some, he said, have even accused the programs of "committing genocide."
Mr. Fischer said the economic and racial integration of America's neighborhoods could do much to solve urban problems. But, he cautions, "I don't know if there's the political will, the political resources, the political skill to make it happen."

HEADLINE: Tax Revenues Rise but Fail to Fill Budget Gaps in New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New strength in the economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has helped spur tax collections, but the increases are so slight that they fall far short of providing the states and their localities a painless way of closing their budget gaps.
The increased collections have come largely from growing profits in the financial service industry, particularly on Wall Street and among the region's banks, and from surprisingly strong retail sales. Although early holiday sales have been strong, merchants have been disappointed too often to pronounce this season a success. 
 For this year, tax collection increases of less than 4 percent are forecast in all three states and in New York City. In Connecticut and New York State, that would mean tax collections would grow more slowly this year than last. And across the region, the growth will be much slower than it was in the mid-1980's, when tax receipts leaped by 10 percent a year or more, before flattening after 1988.
 
Barely Exceeding Inflation
 Because the increases barely exceed the rate of inflation, which has run 2.6 percent a year in New York and New Jersey, the rising cost of social services, mass transit and other programs wipes out most of whatever extra money could be spent elsewhere.
In Connecticut, officials said they collected $231.4 million more in taxes than expected in the year ended June 30. But that windfall is less than a third of what they would need to pay off $706 million in bonds sold to bridge a deficit in 1991.
New York State said receipts ran higher than expected for the first six months of this fiscal year, which ends next March, prompting it to forecast $251 million in additional tax reciepts for the full year. But public assistance and school aid have also run higher than anticipated, and the state now expects to spend $213 million more than it had forecast for the full fiscal year. So all but $38 million of the greater tax yield is already absorbed.
"The increase in revenues is minimal," said Rudy F. Runko, the New York State Budget Director. If current forecasts are correct, this fiscal year the state would have a surplus of $38 million. That is minuscule compared to the shortfall of more than $1.5 billion that is projected for the fiscal year beginning next April.
Nevertheless, any increase in the taxes that ebb and flow with the economy offers welcome, if tentative, glimmers of hope for taxpayers, politicians and government agencies, after four years of budget cuts.
In New Jersey and New York City, the region's two newest political leaders, Gov.-elect Christine Todd Whitman and Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani, both face the prospect of huge budget deficits in their first year in office, but have nonetheless pledged to eliminate some taxes and reduce the rates of others.
 
Facing Shortfalls
 In New York State, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo must for the fifth year in a row find ways to prevent a budget shortfall. He has been criticized for using fiscal stopgaps, including his decision in 1991 to take the equivalent of a second mortgage on Attica State Prison. His fiscal policies are likely to become an issue if he runs for re-election in 1994.
In Connecticut, fiscal problems also seem likely to be a central issue in the race for governor next year. Although Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has said he will not seek re-election, he will pass to his successor a debt that now stands at $706 million. The debt was created by selling notes to investors in the 1991 fiscal year to eliminate a deficit.
 
Case for Slow Growth
 The slow growth contrasts sharply with the rate of growth in most of the nation's states and cities, where an accelerating recovery has begun to pump up government coffers.
"These states bring up the rear," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States, a research concern in Albany.
In a report yesterday, his group found that tax collections by states across the nation had increased 6.2 percent from July through September, the biggest quarterly increase since monitoring began in 1990.
New York fared better than the national average, with a 7.3 percent increase. Connecticut fared worse, with only 1.7 percent. New Jersey was close to the average, with 6.4 percent.
"I don't think these states will keep up with the rest of the country during the rest of the year," Mr. Gold said. Employment growth in the region "is just too weak to support a rapid increase" in tax collections, he said.
Still, analysts note that slow growth is better than none.
"Whenever you are coming out of a recession, the indicators are going to be mixed, but there are some clear indications the decline is over," Michael Johnston, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service, said of property tax collections. Moody's monitors the fiscal health and credit status of states and cities.
The biggest fiscal challenge awaits Mr. Giuliani, who has said he would cut some of New York City's taxes on business. His first targets, he has said, are the city and state taxes on hotel room occupants, which adds a little more than 20 percent to the price of rooms, and the city's 6 percent commercial occupancy tax, one of several city taxes assessed businesses that rent space.
Mr. Giuliani argues that by cutting taxes, he will stimulate business, increasing receipts from the taxes that remain in place.
 
Revised Deficit Projection
 City records show that tax collections have been rising at a painfully slow rate, meaning that business conditions would have to flourish to help Mr. Giuliani's fiscal strategy. Over all, the city's Office of Management and Budget says, collections increased 3.7 percent in the fiscal year ended in June, compared to 7.9 percent the year before.
Worse for the new Mayor are projections by the Dinkins administration of tax collections for the next four years. Property tax collections bring in $8 billion a year, or nearly half the city's overall tax receipts. They rose only 1.6 percent last year, and will decline by 3.4 percent this fiscal year, the Dinkins administration says. Collections will rise by no more than 4.1 percent a year for four years.
Perhaps the biggest setback for Mr. Giuliani came on Nov. 22 when Mayor David N. Dinkins released a revised projection of the city's deficit for the next fiscal year. He said it would be $1.73 billion, $450 million more than forecast in June.
Some officials maintain that Mr. Giuliani cannot hope to close the projected deficit without increasing taxes, and they point to property taxes as the most logical candidate. "It would give him the most bang for the buck," said an analyst on Mr. Dinkins's staff, who insisted on anonymity.
Mr. Giuliani has not commented on property taxes since his election. His spokeswoman, Cristyne Lategano, said last week that he intended to move quickly to reduce the hotel occupancy tax, but she declined to comment on the property tax rate.
Although raising taxes on commercial and residential property would be unpopular, such a move could provide the new mayor a quick way to cut the deficit. Property taxes account for the biggest portion of the city's budget, so a small increase produces a great deal of revenue.
 
Brighter State Outlook
 Mr. Dinkins announced a four-year freeze on rates last year, while assessments were being lowered. Lifting the freeze would require the approval of the City Council, but not the State Legislature, as would be the case if Mr. Giuliani wanted to raise the city's sales or income taxes.
For New York State, tax collections have accelerated more quickly in recent months and prompted a brighter fiscal outlook than for New York City.
In a report released this month, the state said its total tax collections for the first seven months of the fiscal year were $16.74 billion, a larger-than-expected 5 percent increase over the like period the previous year.
The state's taxes on bank and insurance company earnings rose more than 8 percent from the previous year and sales taxes rose 4 percent.
In New Jersey, where Mrs. Whitman has pledged to cut income taxes, she must first contend with a budget deficit next year that state officials have estimated at $800 million or more. Like Mr. Giuliani, she has based her fiscal plan on cuts in government spending. She also cannot count on recent increases in tax collections for much help.
New Jersey financial officials said overall state tax collections rose less than 1 percent, to $14.5 billion, in the fiscal year that ended in June. The state forecasts an increase of about 3 percent this fiscal year.
Current New Jersey figures show a mixed bag of improving and declining tax receipts. The state's Treasury Department said that in September, the latest month for which data are available, income taxes fell 7.8 percent from September a year ago. Sales tax receipts, unchanged in September, jumped 12.7 percent in August, the department said.
 
Surplus in Connecticut
 In Connecticut, the near-term fiscal future is complicated by sharp changes in its tax structure during the last three years.
The state said its overall tax collections for the fiscal year that ended on June 30 rose 8 percent, to $5.58 billion, with the biggest increases in personal income and corporate taxes. State officials also reported a jump in corporate tax collections, enabling it to finish the 1993 fiscal year with a $10 million surplus.
A year ago, Connecticut's tax receipts shot up by 23 percent, but only because it was the first year the state collected personal income tax. Receipts declined in some other tax categories, including sales taxes.
William J. Cibes Jr., Connecticut's Commissioner of Policy and Management, said in an interview that sales tax revenues for September 1993 jumped by 10 percent or more, reflecting a marked increase in economic activity. Figures for October have not been tabulated.
Over all, the state forecasts an increase of less than 1 percent in tax collections for the current fiscal year, ending next June.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Mexico Spar Over Limits of Intervention

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Minutes before Vice President Al Gore arrived here tonight to meet with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the man whom Mr. Salinas has chosen as his long-governing party's candidate to succeed him conveniently flew out of town.
For both Governments, the triumphant return of the candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, to his birthplace near the border with Arizona was a nice way to avoid his having to meet or not meet with Mr. Gore, and the speculation that might come either way about United States support for the governing party's candidate. 
 But the dance of jets on the airport tarmac also illustrated the onset of what foreign policy analysts describe as a complex and uncertain new phase in the political relationship between the two countries that has been ushered in by the approval this month of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
Pact Called Catalyst for Change
 In selling the pact to skeptical congressmen, the Clinton Administration endorsed the party that has governed Mexico for 64 years as the logical vehicle for democratic political change. It also promoted the accord vigorously as the catalyst for that change.
To the complaints of many congressmen about the lack of political freedom in a country with which the United States will begin to free its trade on Jan. 1, Administration officials responded by promising, essentially, that they would be able to intervene more and with greater leverage if the agreement was passed.
"Mexico is not yet a full democracy," Mr. Gore argued in his televised debate on the accord with Ross Perot. "They do not yet have full protection for human rights. But they've been making tremendous progress, and the progress has been associated with this new relationship with the United States.
"The question," said Mr. Gore, who is to meet twice with Mr. Salinas on issues related to the trade pact, "is whether or not we will have the ability to influence what they and their Government decide."
More recently, though, Mexican officials have said that their Government, still sensitive about the many concessions it made to win American approval of the pact, will reassert tougher limits to what has long been considered intolerable interference by the United States in their country's politics.
 
Emphasis on Sovereignty
 Mr. Salinas seemed to hint at this in an interview with Newsweek magazine after the approval of the trade agreement, saying he would remind Americans who might try to use it to push for political change in Mexico: "The only thing we negotiated was free trade." Mr. Colosio, while describing himself as deeply democratic, said in accepting his party's nomination on Sunday, "The great battle of Mexico is for sovereignty."
United States officials have indicated that their belief in the trade agreement's positive impact on the democratization of Mexico is not based on any provisions of the agreement itself. Their conviction derives instead from the expectation that more economic development and United States influence under the accord will inevitably push Mexico toward political liberalization.
In Chile, they say, economic changes like those made by Mr. Salinas helped bring an end to the military dictatorship in 1989. They also cite a link between economic development and greater democracy in northern Mexican states like Chihuahua.
But those assumptions are sharply debated among experts on the Mexican political system.
 
Parallel Drawn With China
 Some analysts argue that Mexico may in some ways prove more like China, where authoritarian, one-party rule has defied the pressures that are often linked to the country's growing prosperity. And by virtually all accounts, the immediate political effect of the trade pact's approval has been to strengthen the Salinas administration as it turns to the presidential and legislative elections scheduled for Aug. 21.
"Have the people in the Clinton Administration thought this through?" asked Sidney Weintraub, an expert on Mexico at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas, who supported the trade agreement. "I don't think they have. They are taking it as an article of faith."
The Administration's embrace of the Salinas Government as a force for political change is notable in part because many Mexicans had feared that the opposite might ensue after Mr. Salinas angered some Clinton aides with his scarcely veiled support for the re-election of President Bush. Some Mexican officials had also worried when the Clinton Administration promised that it would make democracy and human rights the core of policy toward Latin America.
In arguing for the trade agreement before the Senate Commerce Committee on Oct. 21, the State Department counselor, Timothy E. Wirth, said, "We can reject a closer relationship with Mexico on the grounds that Mexico has not changed enough, or we can promote even more profound changes through deeper bilateral ties."
 
Scrutiny vs. Resistance
 But neither Mr. Wirth nor other officials have been very clear about how the United States might take advantage of the trade agreement to promote that change, or how they might navigate Mexico's deep sensitivity to foreign intervention.
In part, American officials have argued that the trade agreement will bring Mexican politics under increased scrutiny from abroad.
But some analysts predict that having won passage of the agreement, Mexico will stiffen its resistance to such outside pressure. Having lost, others say, opponents of the agreement in the American Congress and labor movement may also lose much of their relatively new interest in issues like Mexican democracy and human rights.
Some experts say the Clinton Administration's more persuasive argument is the one that Mr. Salinas himself has offered throughout his five years in power: that political change will inevitably follow economic change, but only gradually, and only insofar as political stability is not threatened.
"Any political evolution has its own pace, beyond which it can't go without threatening serious instability," the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Alexander F. Watson, said of Mexico in an interview. "The real question for serious reformers is where that point lies."
 
No Answer Yet
 For the most part, though, the Salinas administration has equated the political stability of the country with its party's continued hold on power, and Mr. Watson's question is one that the Clinton Administration itself has not yet answered.
While Mr. Salinas has overseen a series of changes to the political system, many analysts believe they have been intended more to help his party to keep power rather than to put it up for grabs. And although the Government has ceded some of its traditional control over labor, business and political patronage, they have not necessarily heightened the public clamor for democracy.
Indeed, many experts say the paradox of Mexico's reform has been that while opinion polls show wide dissatisfaction with the political system and a deep desire for change, they also show strong support for the governing party. On most surveys, moreover, Mexicans rank the need for democracy well below other concerns like poverty, corruption and pollution.
In the end, whether the United States heightens its pressure for change in Mexico may have less to do with policy planning than with events.
So far, for instance, Mr. Watson said the United States had repeatedly raised its desire for Mexico to allow foreign election observers, but had been refused. But as Mr. Gore arrived, the governing party was facing new protests in the southeastern state of Yucatan, where opposition politicians were asserting fraud in elections held on Sunday.
"The Clinton Administration is accepting the orthodoxy, which is gradual change in Mexico," said John Bailey, a professor of Government at Georgetown University. "But the Administration has not yet been tested by an election in which the issues of fraud and unfair competition have come up."

HEADLINE: U.S.-French Trade Compromise Foreseen Soon

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration suggested today that it saw new room for compromise with France in a lingering standoff that has been the major obstacle to an international agreement on lowering trade barriers.
With negotiations on the accord, under the aegis of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, entering a final phase, conciliatory signals from both the United States and France contributed to a new sense of optimism among delegates that a settlement might be reached by a deadline that is now two weeks away. 
 "There is an increasing belief that the round not only has to be, but will be, concluded," Peter Sutherland, the Director General of GATT, said at the organization's headquarters in Geneva today.
And in an interview published today in The Washington Post, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France said his Government was willing to relax its rigid stance in an agricultural dispute with the United States that has been the main stumbling block to the agreement. American officials quickly welcomed the statement, and both Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said the Administration would be willing, in turn, to show flexibility of its own.
Mr. Kantor expressed hope that the United States and the 12-nation European Community could now reach agreement on at least the outline of an accord in two days of discussions that resume Wednesday in Brussels.
"I'm not pessimistic," he said before flying to Europe for talks with Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's trade commissioner. There is "a lot of flexibility" in the American position, Mr. Kantor added.
The global free trade talks have foundered for most of the seven years since they began in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986. But they were lent urgency this year when Congress gave President Clinton a Dec. 15 deadline, by when his officials must either conclude a treaty or he would lose his special powers to conduct expedited negotiations.
Because this deadline was set only in one country, a failure to reach agreement by then would not necessarily mean the end of the talks. But most trade experts fear that it would compound the difficulties of winning American approval of any agreement, since it would require new action in an already reluctant Congress.
If an accord is concluded by Dec. 15, Congress is not now permitted to amend it when voting on approval. If it is not completed by then, Mr. Clinton would be required to seek renewal from Congress of his "fast track" authority -- meaning that the lawmakers would be asked to vote on a secondary trade-related matter at a time when the broad issue of trade is politically awkward, given the bruising fight required to gain approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Administration has portrayed the global accord being negotiated as one whose economic benefits would dwarf those of the North American agreement. So far, however, Mr. Clinton and his aides have remained relatively circumspect in campaigning for a GATT accord, attaching none of the apocalyptic warnings about the consequences of failure they sought to impart in the Nafta battle.
In explaining this subdued approach, officials said the global accord's terms had not been resolved and this made it awkward for Mr. Clinton to support it with a vigor similar to his efforts for the North American pact. They also noted that it was still being debated in other nations, making it more delicate for the President to weigh in than on a purely domestic matter.
But on a day when he also met with Central America's leaders to underscore his pledge to expand free trade beyond North America, Mr. Clinton and his top advisers sought to leave little doubt about their commitment to winning agreement on the global accord before Dec. 15.
At a joint news conference with the Central Americans this morning, the President described the task as his "preoccupation." And while Mr. Kantor emphasized that the United States sought "a good agreement, not just any agreement," he also issued a new reminder about the stakes.
Contending than an accord could be worth as much $6 trillion worldwide in the next decade, Mr. Kantor said, "Obviously, the Uruguay Round will have far more economic impact than the Nafta will have."
The comments by Mr. Balladur were significant because they suggested that France would be willing to back off from its demand for renegotiation of a deal struck last year as part of the GATT talks that would impose strict limits on the subsidies a country can pay to its farmers. Mr. Balladur said changes to that agreement could be termed clarifications or amplifications.
The French Government has expressed bitter opposition to limiting farm subsidies, but the United States refuses to renegotiate the draft agreement. Now, with both countries moving toward flexibility, a senior Administration official predicted that Mr. Kantor would spend the next two or so "trying to hammer out a comprehensive deal with the Europeans."
Among other signs pointing toward a possible breakthrough on trade issues, officials said, were indications that Japan might agree to open its rice market to foreign suppliers, a goal of American trade policy through the years of talks.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Guide to GATT"
 
THE TRADE TALKS
The United States is negotiating with 115 other nations on a sweeping rewrite of the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which have governed most of the world's trade.. GATT was created in 1948 to expand the world economy by eliminating trade barriers. Trade ministers have successfully completed seven previous rounds of talks to broaden the original agreement. The current negotiations began seven years ago in Uruguay.
 
THE TIMETABLE
After years of delay, there is a growing sense that the trade talks may be headed for a conclusion. The talks have lagged mainly because of disputes between the United States and Europe over farm subsidies. Last summer, Congress gave special negotiating authority to President Clinton to clinch a deal by December 15. If a deal cannot be done by then, the Administration will have to ask Congress for an extension, which could prove difficult given the recent fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Since last June when GATT appointed a new director general, Peter Sutherland of Ireland, Mr. Sutherland has effectively forced the international trade community to view Dec. 15 as a final deadline.
 
WHAT'S AT STAKE
The Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development, a Paris-based group of 24 wealthy nations, estimates that completion of the talks would mean that the world economy would be $270 billion greater by 2002. The extra economic output would come from the more efficient use of labor, capital and other resources.
 
EFFECT ON THE U.S.
Some American economists, industry groups and labor unions say that the trade agreement would benefit other countries, at least in the short run, more than it would help the United States. Still, most economists believe that over the course of many years, free trade allows each country to specialize in products that it can make most efficiently.
 
THE OUTLOOK
There is a widespread exasperation among American, European and Japanese officials over the twisted course of the talks. But there is also a new willingness by the French to limit Government farm subsidiesand a perception that American officials are willing to cut deals leading to a less ambitious agreement.

HEADLINE: A Long-Silent Pritzker Speaks Up

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
People with a billion dollars usually have trouble keeping their mouths shut. Something about all that money must loosen their tongues. Not Robert A. Pritzker.
For years he has run the industrial half of his family's Chicago-based business empire in relative obscurity to his better-known brother Jay, whose deal-making forays resulted in their ownership of Hyatt hotels, Ticketmaster and, briefly, Braniff airlines. 
 But now, Mr. Pritzker speaks, and it is years of Washington economic policy that has brought him out. And as the intensely private Mr. Pritzker said he had discovered, after decades of silence, when he finally got the chance, he had a lot to say.
Frustrated by some of the directions the Clinton Administration has taken on business issues, the shy billionaire was recently coaxed into speaking out to help manufacturers make their case in Washington. "I don't aspire to be Donald Trump or a movie actor," Mr. Pritzker, 67, said. "It's just not my style. I'm a Midwestern engineer."
And not a bad businessman. Mr. Pritzker has squeezed a profit out of the 60 or so companies that make up his $4 billion Marmon Group every year since 1955. Like a grandfather ticking off the names of his grandchildren, he can name every one of those companies. "I can do better than name 'em," he bragged. "I can tell you what machinery they have, who runs them, who their largest customers are."
It is apparent that he loves this stuff. This is a man who has a clear passion for all things nerdy, and after listening to him talk about bearings, valves and regulators, it is easy to forget that he is one of the richest men in the world. (His family is worth more than $4.4 billion, according to Forbes magazine.)
He relishes his weekend discussions with his 9-year-old daughter, Liesel, about physics -- this week's was about gravity -- and talks like an engineer, even describing himself at one point as "dumb-squared," for missing an important point. He has been known to ask job applicants to explain how a car works as a test of their mettle.
But what he really wants to talk about these days is the country's industrial policy. Mr. Pritzker took over as the chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers on Oct. 8 -- his net worth surpasses that of many of the group's 12,500 corporate members -- and has been using the association as a bully pulpit for his fairly conservative views on Washington's role in economic matters. In an interview in Manhattan, he touched upon everything from health care to trade.
"I'm devoted to the idea that manufacturing and engineering are important to the U.S.," he said, noting that heavy industry paid better and had better benefits than other jobs.
Still, what would make a billionaire swap his much-cherished coat of privacy for the hurly-burly of Washington politics escapes his friends. "They said, 'You always squawk about these things, why don't you do something about it?' " he said. Mr. Pritzker said he was tired of watching Washington administrations strangle business with regulation. "It's not newsworthy, because it's a creeping affair," he said. "Congress sees a problem and tries to pass a law to solve it. But you've got to be careful about the downstream consequences."
He congratulated Mr. Clinton on the way he pushed through the North American Free Trade Agreement. "It took a lot of courage to stand up to the unions, one of his constituencies,"' he said.
 
Shares Concerns
 But he said he shared the concerns of many business people about the health care package. "This is either going to burden business or the Government's coffers," he said, skeptical that cost containment alone would work.
Mr. Pritzker said he was "modestly optimistic" about the economy. He said he was less optimistic about Washington's ability to curb its tendency to inject itself into the business of business.
He said the Administration should jealously safeguard free trade in all cases except those where national defense might be jeopardized. He said he had little sympathy for the recent efforts by the aluminum producers to lobby Washington for some relief against low-priced Russian metal. "Look, if you have a pebble in your shoe, what's going on in Afghanistan is of no concern," he said.
"I don't believe in industrial policy, and you can't have it both ways," Mr. Pritzker said. "As businessmen, you can't ask them to stay out of your hair and then ask for help."

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Aid to Bosnia, but No Plan to End War

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced today that the United States would send more aid to help the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina survive the winter, but he made clear that Washington would do nothing to end the 19-month war.
In a speech to the 53-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mr. Christopher reflected the Clinton Administration's new hands-off approach to resolving the Bosnian crisis by portraying it as a human tragedy about which very little can be done by outsiders. 
 "This winter, the snows have come early to Bosnia and the humanitarian crisis has deepened," Mr. Christopher said. "Whatever we do to help, it will not be enough. So long as the armed conflict continues, it is not humanly possible to end the suffering of the people of Bosnia."
According to the State Department's estimate, 2.7 million people in Bosnia and Herzegovina are "at risk" this winter from fighting, disease, malnutrition and lack of shelter.
 
Relief Crisis Eases
 But even as Mr. Christopher was delivering his words, one of his senior aides told reporters that the relief crisis in Bosnia had eased since last August, when the United States led an initiative in NATO to threaten air strikes if the Serbs continued to prevent the delivery of food and other aid to Sarajevo and other cities.
"We think the situation is significantly improved in the areas in question since August," the official said.
Perhaps what was most remarkable about Mr. Christopher's speech was what it did not say. Gone was the lofty rhetoric of February when Mr. Christopher, in unveiling the Administration's Balkan policy, said that Washington's response to the war "tests our commitment to the nurturing of democracy and the support of environments in which democracy can grow and take root."
Mr. Christopher did not discuss the Administration's proposal last spring to arm the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government to make the war what he then called a "fair fight," and he did not repeat the Administration's appeal last summer to win support for NATO air strikes.
 
Urges Negotiated Settlement
 Rather, Mr. Christopher made clear that the only way to end the war is for the parties to sit down and cut a deal among themselves.
"The only answer is to bring the fighting to an end and the only means to that end is a negotiated settlement," he told the Foreign Ministers of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe on the first stop of a 13-day visit to Europe and the Middle East.
To help ease the pain of winter, Mr. Christopher said the United States would spend an additional $150 million in relief aid, much of it to defray the cost of flying Air Force planes. The United States has already contributed $400 million in aid for Bosnia.
"Our goal is to increase the food, winterization supplies, refugee assistance and medical aid reaching the people of Bosnia," he said. Mr. Christopher added that the United States would be prepared to begin airlifting supplies to the airport at the Government-held northeastern city of Tuzla.
"Thus far, the Bosnian Serbs and Croats have made it impossible to use the field for that purpose," he said. "We call upon all warring parties to stop their unconscionable conduct that blocks the delivery of critically needed supplies through this facility."
 
No Specific U.S. Plan
 Mr. Christopher did not offer any specific American assistance as a means of opening the airport.
Mr. Christopher did not criticize a European initiative that offers to gradually suspend economic sanctions against Serbia if the Serbs, Croats and Muslims sign a peace treaty and if the Serbs agree to give the Bosnian Government a bit more land.
"With respect to the lifting of sanctions, I am very concerned that there be no premature lifting of the sanctions," Mr. Christopher told reporters before his speech. "Sanctions are our only real leverage at the present time over Serbia. I think the Europeans agree with the United States on this point and so we'll be watching that issue very, very closely."
Until now, the United States has taken the lead in pressing for tighter sanctions and finding new ways to enforce them, and when Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany and Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France unveiled the plan to suspend them, in a letter on Nov. 19, the United States initially dismissed it. But without its own alternative for bringing peace to Bosnia, the Administration decided to let the Europeans try out their own plan.

HEADLINE: Consumers Now Singing a Merrier Tune

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers, who had been feeling rotten about the economy earlier this year, have lately been sounding a bit more upbeat. The Conference Board, a business research organization, said yesterday that its survey of consumer confidence jumped 11 points in November to 71.2, the highest level since last January, when post-election euphoria started to fade.
November's spurt followed earlier rebounds in two other consumer surveys -- the University of Michigan's and ABC/Money magazine's -- and a host of cheery retail reports. 
 "It's heartening to get this kind of reading just before Christmas," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research, although he added, "This is a long way from euphoria."
Judging by their recent actions, consumers have actually been more sanguine than earlier surveys indicated. Their spending rose solidly this spring and summer, retail sales spurted in October, home sales are way up, consumers are borrowing more freely, and car sales have been strong recently. However, most forecasters expect consumers to pull back a bit after December.
What's making consumers see the glass as half full is no mystery. Many of the 500 households surveyed by the Conference Board think the economy is going to keep improving. The expectations index zoomed to 79.2 last month from 66.7 in October. Fewer households than in previous months thought that jobs would get scarcer or that their income would shrink.
At the same time, 15.8 percent of the households thought business conditions were good, up from 13.9 percent in October.
"Consumers are getting more optimistic for good reason," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "Though jobs and income growth aren't all they could be, they are better.
"I'd be the last person to say that creating 170,000 jobs a month is optimal, but it's better than last year's pace."
At this point, most forecasters are warning retailers not to get too giddy and to avoid piling up too much inventory. Many, like DRI/McGraw Hill, expect spending growth to dip to a rate of 2 percent or less in the first quarter of 1994 from under 4 percent this quarter.
"Last December was a strong month for consumption," Chris Probyn, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, recalled. "But it got taken out of the first quarter."
For one thing, spending has been growing at an average rate of 3 percent, as consumers have bought new cars and furniture and spruced up their wardrobes. But income has been growing at just 1.7 percent, and spending cannot outpace paychecks for long.
For another, the saving rate fell below 4 percent this summer, a level that most economists think is too low to last. As Mr. Probyn put it, "If it's a great Christmas, retailers will pay the price in the new year."

HEADLINE: Apple Denied a Tax Break

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30

 BODY:
Commissioners of a Texas county refused today to give a real estate tax abatement to Apple Computer Inc., citing the company's policy of granting the same health benefits to partners of gay and lesbian employees that it does to heterosexual spouses.
The decision means that Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., will probably not build an $80 million complex in Williamson County, just north of Austin, that would have employed 700 people. 
 "We're going to regroup and review our operations," an Apple spokeswoman, Lisa Byrne, said. "It is unlikely we will locate in Williamson County."
Apple had sought a $750,000 tax abatement over a seven-year period for the complex, but county commissioners rejected it by a 3-to-2 vote.
Debate on the tax break for several weeks focused on Apple's domestic partner policy.
"I cannot in good conscience extend that benefit to them because of the conviction I have that same-sex partners is wrong," Commissioner Greg Boatwright had said earlier.
Advocates of gay and lesbian rights derided the commission's decision. "This is the first time that a panel of this kind has used its authority to punish a company that has independently decided to treat its gay and lesbian employees fairly," said David Smith, of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force.
After the vote, Charlie Culpepper, the mayor of Round Rock, the largest town in Williamson County, said he disagreed with the commissioners.
"I don't agree with the idea of same-sex marriages, but government needs to stay out of business," he said. "Families need jobs."
Mr. Culpepper said it was too early to tell if the vote would hurt economic development. The area around Austin has been a leading destination for high-technology companies because of the city's educational base and low tax, real estate and labor costs.

HEADLINE: Sunil K. Roy; Indian Diplomat, 73

 BODY:
Sunil K. Roy, a retired Indian diplomat and former Consul General in New York, died Monday in New Delhi. He was 73.
The cause was prostate cancer, said a friend, David Challinor of Washington. 
 During the 1960's and 70's Mr. Roy served India in a variety of international posts: Ambassador to Poland, then Mexico, and High Commissioner to Nigeria, as well as Consul General here about 30 years ago.
Before his service here, he had been a foreign affairs expert in the Government of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. He later served as India's director of tourism and wildlife. In recent years he had served as an environmental consultant to the World Bank.
He is survived by his wife, Aruna Roy, and a daughter, Inca Roy, both of New Delhi.

HEADLINE: It's Official: The Winner Is Whitman

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
As the Board of State Canvassers met today to give the weight of law to the voters' choice of Christine Todd Whitman as New Jersey's next Governor, the Governor-elect was closeted with Federal and state investigators, trying to put to rest what has come to be known as the "Rollins incident."
Moving to get her transition planning back on track, Mrs. Whitman also announced the appointment of an eight-member transition budget review committee -- a group that includes the co-authors of the controversial tax cut plan that was the heart of her economic platform during the campaign. 
 Mrs. Whitman said she met for about an hour this afternoon with the United States Attorney for New Jersey, Michael Chertoff, and with James R. Zazzali and George F. Kugler, the two former New Jersey Attorneys General who are heading the state investigation into allegations that Republicans bought off black ministers and Democratic workers to help assure her victory.
"The meeting was cordial and the discussion candid," Mrs. Whitman said, without giving details of the talk. "While I hope that the issue is resolved as rapidly as possible, I understand fully the necessity for the investigation to be as thorough as possible. I support those efforts because only a full and complete review of the allegations will answer any and all of the questions which have been raised and that is important to the State of New Jersey."
 
Economic Advisers
 In naming a team to help develop the spending plan that she must deliver to the Legislature within weeks after taking office on Jan. 18, Mrs. Whitman enlisted two economic advisers from her campaign: Lawrence A. Kudlow of Manhattan, chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company, and Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. of Bedminister, president and chief executive of Forbes Inc.
The co-chairmen of the group will be Candace L. Straight of Bloomfield, a principal of John Head & Partners, a merchant banking firm in New York City, and Andrew Chapman of Short Hills, senior vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer of Elizabethtown Water Company
The timing of today's announcement was as important for symbolic reasons as it was for the urgency of developing her first budget.
The euphoria of Mrs. Whitman's upset victory over Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, was doused and most of her time in recent weeks has been consumed by the controversy touched off by Edward J. Rollins Jr., her chief political strategist and campaign manager.
During a Nov. 9 breakfast meeting with reporters in Washington, Mr. Rollins boasted that Republican operatives had offered money to unnamed black ministers to keep them from supporting Mr. Florio from the pulpit and that some Democratic workers had been paid to stay home on Election Day.
The allegations prompted a string of lawsuits and investigations by Federal officials, the State Attorney General's office and the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission.
Much of the pressure on Mrs. Whitman was lifted on Monday when the Democrats announced that they were abandoning a lawsuit to try to overturn the election because they had found nothing to prove that she won because of any efforts to suppress voting.
Today the Board of State Canvassers gave the weight of law to the voters' choice of Mrs. Whitman. According to the official count, Mrs. Whitman defeated Mr. Florio by 26,093 votes -- 1,236,124 to 1,210,031 -- out of nearly 2.5 million votes cast for 19 gubernatorial candidates. It was the second closest margin of victory in a governor's race in modern state history.
But no one directly involved in the controversy and its aftermath has escaped completely unscathed, including the State of New Jersey, which again finds itself linked with the stereotype of a state prone to political scandal.
For Mrs. Whitman, who has won bipartisan praise for her response to the Rollins comments, the episode will add an indelible footnote to her place in state history as the first woman to be Governor.
For Republicans, in general, the Rollins controversy -- with little regard to whether his initial comments were true or untrue -- renews an image of a party prone to dirty tricks, a reputation that goes back to the days of the Watergate scandal.
The prospects are equally troubling for the Democrats.
Their dogged pursuit of their lawsuit against the Republican State Committee and the Whitman campaign over the last two weeks has soured relations not only with the incoming Governor but with the Republicans who will still control both chambers of the Legislature.
 
Look Under the Rocks
 "The Democrats were in a difficult position," said Mr. Rabovich, "they had to file the lawsuit just to maintain their own political credibility. It was role playing and it was a morality play, but the Democrats did what they had to do."
The controversy and the Democrats' lawsuit also brought unaccustomed public attention to some of the less pristine aspects of politics, especially the use of street money -- the huge caches of cash kept on hand for Election Day operations.
The widespread use of street money had been almost the exclusive practice of the Democratic Party, which once could count on urban areas as their political redoubt. In fact, it was Mr. Rollins's boast that he had beaten the Democrats "at their own game" that led up to his initial story of Republicans amassing $500,000 in street money to finance an elaborate scheme to suppress the vote in urban, mostly black, areas.
Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a Republican, has already proposed legislation that would ban cash payouts on Election Day and force campaigns to pay workers with checks. It is likely that the Republican legislative majority will propose even more far-reaching restrictions in a bid to erode further the Democratics' urban vote.
"One thing for sure will come out of all of this," said Larry J. Sabato, a government professor at the University of Virginia. "Consultants will come up with new names for street money. There will be a new, sophisticated, suburban name for street money."

They were, from left, Assemblyman Richard C. Kamin, State Senator John H. Ewing and Assemblyman John S. Watson. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
The Nail Salon of the 90's: Massages for the Clothed

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
DEAR Diary,
While walking on Third Avenue spotted new store called Great American Backrub near 57th Street. Looked in to see what was being sold. Saw people getting their backs rubbed by men and women in red and blue jackets. Appears that store is a massage parlor that actually offers massages. What will they think of next? 
 Went inside and inquired about a back rub. Woman at desk said basic offering entailed kneading of shoulder, neck, upper back, lower back, arms and hands by licensed personnel. Entire operation, she said, takes exactly eight and a half minutes and costs $7.95. Told receptionist she had a deal. She smiled and turned me over to man introduced as Paul.
Paul led the way to a special stool, a well-padded prie-dieu. He instructed me to lean forward and place my forehead on a spongy rest. Paul put on latex gloves. Tried not to take it personally. These days everybody seems to be putting on latex gloves. Thought this probably very good for the Malaysian economy.
As Paul started kneading, stopped thinking. Heard New-Age strains on store speakers. Heard Paul ask if anything hurt. Heard unconnected fragments of distant conversations. Heard joints go snap, crackle and pop at much closer range. For exactly eight and a half minutes Paul probed, pounded and twisted. He stretched sinews, chopped flesh, snapped joints, and elbowed points of accumulated tension. He hammered vertebrae as if they were notes on a glockenspiel.
He stopped. Felt well manipulated. Asked Paul if ever rubbed anyone the wrong way. He said no. Thanked him and asked about the back rub business. Said he had been working at Great American Backrub since store opened last month. Like his fellow rubbers he was a licensed massage therapist. He is 28 years old and lives in Bayside. Last year he graduated from an 18-month program at the New Center for Holistic Health in Nassau County. Said working at Great American Backrub was a trip. Said he has done as many as 30 back rubs a day. Most customers come in off the street. Many have been shopping. Paul said customers divide pretty evenly between men and women. Generally he does not talk to customers while working on them but many volunteered that they never had a massage before coming in to the store.
Asked Paul whether he thought opening of store represented a deciding moment for massage marketing. Would Great American Backrub succeed in attracting clientele more used to relieving tension in bars? Instead of hoisting a few brewskies after work, would office and construction workers of the near future run over to their local chop shop for a bit of a pounding? Paul suggested questions be put to Bill Zanker, the owner and conceptualizer of the Great American Backrub.
Mr. Zanker, who is 39, said that was exactly what he thought might happen. He said the store was the first of what he envisions as a nationwide chain of off-the-street back-rub establishments. "The 90's are about health, about taking care of yourself, about pampering yourself a little," he said. "The 80's were about nails. You remember when there were no nail salons anywhere? Now they are on every block. I think the same thing will happen with back rubs."
Mr. Zanker has guessed right before. Back in the early 80's, when education and self improvement were maybe even bigger than nails, he developed the Learning Annex, an adult-education establishment where paying customers attended lectures on anything from how to meet a woman to how to meet a man. It was after he sold his interest there that he conceived of back rubs as the next big thing.
"I always loved massages," said the dapper and trim entrepreneur. "But they were always a big deal. It was like going to a doctor. You had to go somewhere, get undressed, get dressed, and come back. It could take three hours. Then a couple of years ago, in a California park, I saw a bearded, grimy guy giving back rubs and charging $1 a minute. His hands were dirty. He wasn't very good but still people were lined up. Right then I knew this thing had possibilities."
"To get Americans to buy massages I realized you had to solve three problems," Mr. Zanker said. "You had to come up with something that was quick, inexpensive and most important, you had to find a way to do it without asking people to take their clothes off."
The questions of time and money were resolved by having an expert develop the 8 1/2-minute program, based on Swedish massage, and by the $7.95 basic fee. As for keeping clothes on, Mr. Zanker said he worked with designers to come up with the padded chair. "You keep your shirt or blouse on, you put your forehead on the guard and it won't even muss your makeup."

HEADLINE: Living, and Dying, for Love and Family in East Harlem

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Nilma Rivas's family, much of it clustered within a few blocks of her East Harlem apartment, represented her life, her work and a bulwark of comfort and support against the crowded and dangerous city they had moved to from her native Puerto Rico. But most precious of all to her was her 5-year-old grandson.
Every day she walked the little boy, Geraldo, to school, picked him up to walk him home and shuttled him back and forth in the evenings between her apartment on East 122d Street and her daughter, Janice's, on East 111th Street. "The boy was like a little companion," said Mrs. Rivas's sister, Aida Brushman. "She lived for him." 
 She also died for him. Mrs. Rivas, 52, was walking her grandson from her daughter's apartment to her own on Monday night when she was hit by a stray bullet in a shootout. She was the latest casualty among unintended victims, a phenomenon that is one of the sharpest sources of terror for New York City residents, yet numbingly common. Mrs. Rivas became the 323d bystander to be shot in the city this year, according to the police. This category sets a pace slightly ahead of the 342 bystanders shot in all of 1992, but far behind the 535 people struck by stray bullets in 1991.
 
'People Who Knew'
 Residents of the area where Mrs. Rivas was killed say that shootings are commonplace. "People who knew what to do ran," said Jose Rivera, 25, who said he witnessed the killing. "Those who didn't know what to do stood around."
Witnesses said that at 7:45 P.M., a group of men in a car sprayed gunfire for several seconds at pedestrians on the northwest corner of 118th Street and Second Avenue. The police said a bullet severed an artery in Mrs. Rivas's leg, causing her to bleed to death.
Mr. Rivera said that the gunmen appeared to be aiming at two men walking near Mrs. Rivas and Geraldo, but that the two men fled, unharmed. A woman standing nearby carried Geraldo to safety, he said.
Neighborhood residents guessed that the shooting was an attempt by drug dealers to eliminate competitors. Sgt. John Raftery, commander of the 25th Precinct detective squad, said it was "a dispute over turf," adding that the police are requesting help from the public in solving the case.
"This has got to stop," said Mrs. Brushman, Mrs. Rivas's sister. "Some people are hurt, some people are dead, and the drug dealers are walking the streets."
Sitting in her apartment in the Taino Towers complex where Mrs. Rivas lived, Mrs. Brushman and another sister, Milagros Almodovar, who lives in the Bronx, struggled yesterday to voice their emotions. Mrs. Rivas, who was unemployed and had three grown children, was a quiet woman who "devoted her life to family only," Mrs. Brushman said.
Mrs. Rivas continued to look after her children even after they were grown, her sisters said, and spent nearly every evening in the company of her daughter and grandson.
The surviving sisters said the hardest-hit is Geraldo. Despite the family's efforts to distract him with toys and playmates, he becomes hysterical each time he sees a picture of his grandmother, they said. "Geraldo is traumatized," Mrs. Brushman said. "He's in shock."
"It's a very hard area," she said. "Almost every day, you hear the gunshots, especially at night."
At the site of the shooting there was a makeshift memorial yesterday. In front of the yellow police tape marking the site, in front of a gutter littered with crack vials, two devotional candles burned next to a bunch of flowers.
A man walking by, Jose Torres, marveled at the random nature of what had occurred. He said that he, his wife and children had crossed the spot where Mrs. Rivas died not five minutes before the shooting began.

HEADLINE: Mexican Company Agrees To Acquire U.S. Bus Maker

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
The largest truck and bus manufacturer in Mexico said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Motor Coach Industries International Inc., a major United States bus maker whose customers include Greyhound Lines Inc., for $336.6 million in stock.
The proposed buyout of Motor Coach by a new United States subsidiary of Consorcio G Grupo Dina S.A. of Mexico City will create the largest bus manufacturer in North America. The companies have combined annual revenues of $1.4 billion. 
 The transaction is one of the biggest deals announced between United States and Mexican companies since the North American Free Trade Agreement was approved by the House of Representatives on Nov. 17. The deal also affects the third country covered by the trade agreement: Motor Coach has a Canadian subsidiary, Motor Coach Industries Ltd.
Motor Coach, based in Phoenix, was formerly part of the Dial Corporation, which once owned Greyhound Lines. The bus maker was spun off in August as part of Dial's strategy to focus on the soap and consumer products business.
While the free trade agreement was expected to benefit the companies because it would lift many restrictions on cross-border transactions, it was not the driving force behind the decision to merge, said Craig R. Lentzsch, Motor Coach's executive vice president of finance.
"It's our view it was a good business decision if Nafta was approved and it was a good business decision even if it wasn't," Mr. Lentzsch said.
He noted that the proposed merger would give the two companies "substantial economies of scale" in purchasing raw materials and parts.
"Nafta does help the economy in Mexico, which helps the sales of Grupo Dina in Mexico," Mr. Lentzsch said. "We think they also have products that apply in our markets" in the United States and Canada.
Dina is banned from exporting trucks to the United States under an agreement with the Navistar International Corporation, a Chicago-based maker of heavy-duty trucks and diesel engines, analysts said. The acquisition of Motor Coach will give Dina a way to sell buses in the United States.
Motor Coach's customers include Greyhound and smaller regional companies. The company makes intercity coach buses at plants in Pembina, N.D., and Winnipeg, Manitoba. It also makes transit buses in Roswell, N.M., and has a transit bus remanufacturing plant near Schenectady, N.Y. The company employs about 3,300 people, 1,000 of whom are in the transit bus business, which Motor Coach plans to sell.
 The merger agreement comes a few weeks after Motor Coach began a tender offer to acquire the minority interest in its Canadian subsidiary. Motor Coach currently holds about 69 percent of the Canadian affiliate. If the tender offer is successful, the Canadian subsidiary will be included in the merger with Dina.
The agreement calls for Motor Coach shareholders to receive $16.72 worth of a new class of Dina stock for each share of Motor Coach common stock. Motor Coach had about 20.1 million shares outstanding as of Sept. 30. Dina plans to apply for a listing of the new shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Shares of Motor Coach closed yesterday at $14.75, up $1.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Dina's American depository receipts -- the equivalent of shares for many foreign companies on American exchanges -- closed at $22, down $1.875, on the Big Board.
Mr. Lentzsch said the company hoped to execute a definite agreement in several weeks.

HEADLINE: Army Corps Starts Big Erosion-Control Project on Jersey Shore

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Army Corps of Engineers is set to begin a major project to control beach erosion that eventually could stretch 33 miles along the New Jersey shore from Sandy Hook to Barnegat Inlet, officials said today.
The first phase of the $1.2 billion project, which will begin next year, includes sand replenishment from Sea Bright to Monmouth Beach, two communities hit hard by severe winter storms in recent years. 
 "It's taken a long, long time, but the protection this will provide to the area is unbelievable," said Bernard Moore, administrator for the state Division of Engineering and Construction. "There will be no more closing of Highway 36 because the ocean has come over the sea wall."
He spoke at a meeting of the Jersey Shore Partnership, an alliance of coastal counties, municipalities, businesses and individuals that was formed after the "Halloween Storm" of 1991 because of concerns about shoreline erosion and its effect on the state's $9 billion shore tourism industry.
Storms in 1991 and 1992 caused more than $250 million worth of damage in New Jersey.
 
Several Small Projects
 The Corps' coastal preservation projects are financed jointly by Federal money and a $15 million annual state allocation, which was established by last year's Legislature with money from taxes on the sale of property.
The Federal Government contributes 65 percent of the cost, with the remaining 35 percent coming from the state and affected municipalities.
Some of this year's state allotment will be used for several small municipal projects, including beach replenishment at Sea Isle City, Cape May City, Harvey Cedars and Union Beach, and other work at Atlantic City and Spring Lake.
Mr. Moore said the Corps' project to replenish the 12-mile section from Sea Bright to Ocean Township with more than eight million cubic yards of sand should be completed in five years. The entire 33-mile project could be under way by 1999, he said.
Many officials attending the conference said they were pleased by the plans outlined by the Corps.
"I think we're going to see the beginning of a new era of cooperation between those of us who have strong environmental beliefs and the belief that they can be accomplished without hurting the economy of the area," said Martin Chomsky, chairman of the Monmouth Water Resources Association.
The Corps has also designated virtually the rest of the state's coastline, including the Delaware Bay region, for studies to determine if additional preservation projects are needed.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Yields Rise on Latest Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After four days of modest rebounds, the bond market sold off yesterday in the face of stronger-than-expected economic data. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.30 percent.
The selling was quick after the Conference Board reported that its November confidence survey jumped to 71.2 from a revised 60.5 in October. The November level was far above the expected level of around 60. 
 At the same time, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said that its index of manufacturing conditions for November rose to 65.3 from 57 in October, also a little stronger than anticipated.
While there have been small dips in between, the yields on Treasury securities from the 30-year bond to the two-year note have been on an upward trend since mid-October. The yield on the 30-year bond is still below its recent high but the yield on the 2-year note is now at its highest level since June.
 
 
'A Bit Oversold'
 "I can't imagine the news being worse," Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles, said. But, he added, he still thinks the market sold off too much yesterday, given the current level of yields and the underlying economic fundamentals.
"I think the market got a bit oversold and I think it will take a lot of effort for the market to go down from here," he added, referring to price levels.
Two forces are driving the market right now, seeming to fight it out in each day's trading. One is that the basic economic fundamentals underlying this year's push downward of long-term interest rates to their lowest levels in 25 years are still intact. These fundamentals include low inflation, with the Consumer Price Index rising at an annual rate of less than 3 percent this year, and moderate economic growth.
Some forecasters expect this moderate growth and low inflation to continue next year despite a pickup in growth in the fourth quarter of this year.
 
 
Economic Growth
 The second force is that with the pace of economic growth picking up in the last three months of the year, many investors are now worried that it will continue into the new year. If that does happen, inflation would become a concern again and it is likely that the Federal Reserve would decide to raise its target for short-term interest rates, which has been at 3 percent for more than a year.
The selling since mid-October, when interest rates reached their recent lows, has been a hedge against the possibility of strong growth continuing into next year and the fact that many money managers have sold to lock in the huge profits they have already made this year.
The uncertainty about the outlook vying with the factors that are supportive of interest rates around their current levels makes for a volatile trading environment. "The market is getting overbought and oversold to the extremes," Mr. Goldinger said.
This week there will be more economic indicators that traders and investors are likely to react to, topped off Friday with the employment data for November. Today, the Commerce Department announces its first revision of the gross domestic product for the third quarter. The G.D.P. was initially reported to have grown at an annual rate of 2.8 percent from July through September.
 
 
Secondary Market
 In trading in the secondary market around 5 P.M., the price of the 30-year bond was down 30/32 of a point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.30 percent, from 6.23 percent Monday. In volatile trading since mid-October, the yield on the 30-year bond has been as high as 6.38 percent. The yield fell to a 25-year closing low of 5.78 percent on Oct. 15.
The price of the two-year Treasury note was off 4/32 as the yield rose to 4.22 percent, from 4.15 percent Monday. The yield topped its recent high of 4.21 percent.
The performance of longer-term Treasury securities was affected by the expectations on inflation. The yield on short-term Treasury notes is rising more because of the belief that the Federal Reserve will push short-term interest rates higher to resist any spurt in economic growth that would unleash new inflationary pressures.
Treasury prices got a small boost in the early afternoon after it was reported that the Federal Reserve had made a routine purchase of Treasury notes and bonds. The Fed regularly does such buying as part of its monetary policy operations to assure that bank reserve levels are high enough so that its overall policy will not be more restrictive than the central bank intends.
In the corporate bond market, $2.2 billion of new debt was sold yesterday, according to Bloomberg Business News. The Korean Development Bank sold $200 million of 5-year notes and $200 million of 12-year notes. The 5-year notes were priced to yield 5.905 percent, 74 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the 5-year Treasury note; the 12-year notes were priced to yield 6.797 percent, 98 basis points over the yield on the 10-year Treasury note.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances on Signs Of an Improving Economy

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most leading European currencies yesterday on signs that the American economy is gaining momentum.
But it slipped against the Japanese yen, which benefited from a slight recovery in the Tokyo stock market. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices rose. Gold for December delivery gained 40 cents, to $369.80 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
The dollar rallied against the German mark and other European currencies after reports suggesting sharply improved consumer confidence and expanded manufacturing activity.
The Conference Board, a private business group, said its consumer confidence index soared to 71.2 in November from a revised 60.5 in October.
 
 
Manufacturing Activity
 Separately, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said its index measuring activity in the key Midwestern manufacturing region climbed to 65.3 percent in November from 57.0 percent in October.
The dollar's rise was limited, however, as participants remained cautious ahead of Friday's employment report.
"The numbers were strong, but the improvement cannot be sustained without continued jobs growth," said Ken Nixon, corporate sales officer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in New York.
The dollar climbed to 1.7155 marks in late New York trading from 1.7091 marks on Monday. But it eased to 109.10 yen from 109.20 yen.
The dollar had risen against the yen recently as Tokyo stocks plummeted to lows not seen in more than a year. But the dollar shed some gains yesterday after Tokyo stocks rebounded.
Meanwhile, the pound firmed against the mark as the market applauded the British Government's proposal for larger-than-expected spending cuts and lower increases in taxes. But the currency lost ground to the dollar. The British pound closed in New York at $1.4860, down from $1.4890 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.4985 Swiss francs, up from 1.4894; 5.9295 French francs, up from 5.9025; 1,707 Italian lire, up from 1,696, and $1.3351 (Canadian), down from $1.3357 (Canadian).
