HEADLINE: U.S. Raises Pressure for Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Amid optimism that a new world trade agreement may at last be near, France and the United States engaged in a contest of diplomatic posturing today intended to nudge each other into making important concessions.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher called on officials of the European Community here to elevate the 116-nation talks to the political level, warning that failure to reach agreement in the next two weeks would mean economic disaster for Europe and other areas of the world. 
 Mr. Christopher arrived at European Community headquarters as top trade officials from the community and the United States tried again to reach agreement on some of the sensitive issues that have aligned the French against the Americans and also against some of Paris's usual European partners, creating one of the big obstacles to agreement.
The hope here is that if the differences can be smoothed over by the end of this week, a bargain struck between the United States and the European Community could pave the way for a successful conclusion of the broad negotiations being held under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by a Dec. 15 deadline.
But in Paris, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur seemed to edge back from conciliatory published remarks that had evoked praise in Washington. Mr. Balladur said in a speech to the French National Assembly today that progress still had to be made on four important areas of the proposed trade agreement, including satisfying France's concerns about new limits on farm subsidies.
At the same time, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's trade commissioner, tried to address the sticking points in the long negotiations. The talks here will continue through lunchtime Thursday; still, senior State Department officials said they could not predict whether the United States and the 12-nation European Community would be able to produce something acceptable to the French.
Mr. Kantor, before leaving Washington on Tuesday, said the United States might make unspecified concessions to bring the seven-year trade talks to a successful end. And before leaving Washington for Brussels today, Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy said that a slower introduction of lower new farm subsidies was "something obviously we've got to look at."
Mr. Christopher, by sitting in on the Brussels talks today and detailing the stakes at a news conference, sought to strike a balance between toughness and conciliation, hoping to make it easier for each side to give a little.
 
Catalogue of Benefits
 Calling the stakes "absolutely immense," the Secretary of State said an agreement would spur economic growth on both sides of the Atlantic, increase business confidence, expand the world economy and create jobs.
"Failure will threaten economic recession in Europe, the United States and indeed the world as a whole," added Mr. Christopher, who, like President Clinton, repeatedly calls economic security a cornerstone of American foreign policy.
He appealed for trade-offs, acknowledging that "none will be easy," and adding that all the countries involved had a "responsibility to meet flexibility with flexibility." He praised Mr. Balladur's remarks reported in The Washington Post on Tuesday, in which the Prime Minister said that France was willing to relax its hard stance in dealing with the United States.
As part of what seemed like an intensifying American public relations campaign for a GATT accord, Mr. Christopher also gave two television interviews later that an aide said had been scripted with Mr. Kantor "to send the message to Europe."
But Prime Minister Balladur, responding to former leaders from his center-right coalition parties who had urged him to show political courage and strike a trade deal, told the French legislators that it would be false courage to accept a bad deal in fear of being isolated.
He listed four broad areas remaining in dispute: France's call for a new body to supervise world trade; its demand for specific rules to protect its audio-visual industry; the disagreement over market access, and the differences over textiles, steel, financial services and agriculture.
"We have recorded no progress on these four points," Mr. Balladur said. "We are resolutely determined, in liaison with our German partners and all our other European partners, to obtain satisfaction on all the points I listed, which will make it possible to safeguard the long-term interests of our country. If we obtain them, we can give our accord. If we don't obtain them, then of course we can't."
 
Germany Attempts Mediation
 The Prime Minister made his remarks after returning with President Francois Mitterrand from Bonn, where Chancellor Helmut Kohl had tried and failed to broker an agreement between France and the United States over the French opposition to cutting subsidies for farm exports.
Senior Clinton Administration officials sought to explain away Mr. Balladur's remarks, calling them necessary gestures to the French public and arguing that Mr. Mitterrand sounded more positive.
"We must keep on always making a real effort to reach a compromise that will allow the signing of an international accord," Mr. Mitterrand said at a news conference with Mr. Kohl after their two days of talks. "We are ready to make these efforts."
However, no country should be left feeling it was being treated unjustly, he said, adding, "France sometimes has this feeling, as we have explained to our German friends."
And Mr. Kohl said, "We should not create the impression in Europe or elsewhere that our French friends are being maneuvered into a corner in these negotiations."
Part of the American strategy to gain an agreement is to insist that Dec. 15 is a date that cannot be missed. "There will be no Dec. 16," Mr. Christopher says.
However, even though the Dec. 15 deadline is also being pressed hard by GATT's Director General, Peter Sutherland, there is nothing magic about it. The global free trade talks have sputtered along for most of the seven years since they were begun in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986. Congress compressed the negotiating time this year when it gave Mr. Clinton the Dec. 15 date by which either to conclude the agreement or lose his special powers to conduct expedited negotiations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
SEAGRAM CO. (N)

 BODY:
Orange juice was the one bright spot for the Seagram Company in the third quarter.
With several European economies in the doldrums, sales of the company's wines and spirits were flat. And a huge restructuring charge at Du Pont forced Seagram's, which owns 24.3 percent of the company, to take a $239 million charge on its third-quarter books. Seagram's, based in Montral, also lost $85 million in revenues earned abroad because of currency conversions. 
 The company said yesterday that those factors produced a loss of $100 million in the third quarter, although it had operating income of $197 million.
An increase of 14 percent in sales of Tropicana products was the "one bright spot," according to Brian T. Lomas, a consumer products analyst at Scotia McLeod in Montreal, who said the company was doing a good job of introducing Tropicana Twister fruit drinks in several countries.
He warned that there might be one more piece of bad news ahead. With oil prices falling, investors who were counting on Du Pont to quickly turn around as the American economy improved might have to be patient because of Du Pont's ownership of Conoco, the petroleum company.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. Likely to Cut Several Thousand Jobs

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
A.T.& T., struggling to maintain its profit margins in the long-distance calling business, is drawing up a two-pronged attack that could eliminate several thousand jobs.
The cuts contemplated are in the company's consumer-communications services division, which currently employs 32,000 people, about a tenth of A.T.& T.'s payroll. 
 Company executives said yesterday that the job reductions would range across the division, involving blue- and white-collar jobs and union and nonunion workers.
They also said details of the cuts, including their number, would not be decided for at least a month. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would cut 4,500 consumer communications jobs.
A.T.& T.'s stock closed yesterday at $54.25, down 37.5 cents, with 2.9 million shares traded.
 
Efficiencies Sought
 "We can clearly find more efficient ways of doing things," Alex J. Mandl, executive vice president of A.T.& T. and chief executive of its communications services group, said yesterday in a telephone interview from Seattle. "We have some opportunities to manage more efficiently, to use technology better, to eliminate functions not necessary in today's environment, to thin the layers of management."
But he added: "Staff reductions don't solve our cost problems. We have to go after them in many ways."
Mr. Mandl said access charges paid to local telephone companies cost A.T.& T. $14 billion a year, and purchasing costs an additional $17 billion. Both areas, he said, need a hard look. A.T.& T. is talking to both Federal regulators and the local companies about cutting the access charges, he said.
Tim Cain, an analyst with Fitch Investor Services, said he expected the Federal Communications Commission to provide relief from the charges, which he said were more significant to A.T.& T.'s costs than the size of the company's work force.
Lower costs aside, Mr. Mandl said, he was determined to find a way to push up revenues. "We want to grow our earnings at least 10 percent, both for the parent company and for our group," he said.
 
Industry Growth Tops 5%
 Revenue growth in long-distance calling is expected to be 5 percent to 6 percent a year for the industry as a whole, but the MCI Communications Corporation is enjoying growth at three times that rate.
Next month or in February, he said, A.T.& T. will announce a new marketing strategy and discount plans to replace its "i plan," which it has ended. That plan -- the "i" stands for individual -- involved discounts and incentives that A.T.& T. tailored to customers' calling patterns. But in competition with MCI's "Friends and Family" discount plan and Sprint's "the Most," the i plan came up short.
Mr. Mandl would say only, "It was not as robust, as strong as we wanted to be."
Mr. Cain of Fitch said, "It just didn't resonate with customers," because compared with the competitors' it was harder at a glance to see what discounts were being offered.
 
Little Leeway for Price Rises
 Because of pressure from MCI and Sprint, A.T.& T. has little leeway to raise prices, although Mr. Cain suggested that some selective increases in international and operator-assisted calls might be possible.
Mark Siegel, an A.T.& T. spokesman, noted that the company had recently announced increases in operator-handled and calling card calls, directory assistance and some overseas calls that are expected to produce $336 million a year.
In effect, the division is a cash cow that provides some cover for more competitive operations like personal computers, manufacturing of equipment and credit cards.
A.T.& T. previously announced plans to cut 7,500 jobs at its NCR Corporation, which makes computers, and to cut its force of 18,000 operators and supervisors about a third in the next few years.

HEADLINE: Where the Jobs Are: At the Top

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
While many Americans believe that most new jobs are going to hamburger flippers and Wal-Mart clerks, the reality is surprisingly different: more than three-fifths of the new jobs created over the last year have gone to managers and professionals.
As thousands of former middle managers at I.B.M., General Motors and other corporate giants can attest, white-collar workers were hit especially hard in the recent recession. But Government statistics now show a steady climb in the hiring of white-collar workers. 
 Even though managers and professionals like physicians and accountants make up only 27 percent of the American work force, they have landed more than 60 percent of the 2.2 million net new jobs created over the last year. At the same time, the hiring of blue-collar employees has been largely stagnant.
 
Pent-Up Demand for Managers
 The way economists and corporate executives put it, so many companies squeezed out so many managers during the recent slump that as the economy -- and corporate America -- expanded over the last year, the demand for managers rebounded.
"Because of the recession, there was pent-up demand for managers," said Patrick Pittard, managing partner of Heidrick & Struggles, one of the nation's largest executive search firms. "Many companies that did without executives for a year or two couldn't stand it any more. They had to fill that slot they left unfilled for so long."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said this pickup in white-collar hiring pointed to profound economic changes that bode ill for unskilled workers, because such a high percentage of new jobs require college degrees, M.B.A.'s or other sophisticated training.
"The recent recession had unusually high levels of unemployment for white-collar workers," Mr. Reich said. "But white-collar jobs are coming back. Long-term demand is shifting in favor of people with greater skills."
 
Wachovia, a Case Study
 Typical of this trend is what is happening at the Wachovia Corporation, a bank-holding company in Winston-Salem, N.C. It has hired 250 management trainees over the last year and plans to hire another 250 next year, even as it lays off some tellers and data processing personnel whose work has been automated.
Kenneth Torreyson, Wachovia's director of human resources, said many trainees were being hired to work on mutual funds and information systems. He said his company was adding these trainees because "it looks like a few years out things will get a lot better."
He added, "In the last part of the decade and the first 10 years of the new century, this country should be doing pretty well."
Even though white-collar hiring is one of the few bright spots in the employment picture, it is not chugging along as fast as in previous recoveries. For example, in the 31 months since the 1990-91 recession ended, the number of white-collar jobs -- including not just professionals and managers but also some sales, technical and administrative people -- has grown by 3.8 percent. In contrast, white-collar employment jumped by 8 percent in the 31 months after the 1982 recession.
 
Blue-Collar Blues
 Blue-collar employment presents a more dismal picture, up just three-tenths of 1 percent since the recession ended, far lower than the 9.2 percent jump in blue-collar employment in the 31 months after the 1982 recession.
"I take issue with the notion that white-collar workers are an advantaged class of Americans who are enjoying open-ended prosperity in the 90's," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist with Morgan Stanley & Company. "In an absolute sense, white-collar workers are doing better than blue-collar workers. But compared to past recoveries, the white-collar job machine is in a different gear."
The unemployment rate for white-collar workers is 4.2 percent, while for blue-collar workers, it is just under 9 percent. Even so, white-collar unemployment jumped by 70 percent during the recent recession, an unusual development. In contrast, in several postwar recessions white-collar unemployment did not rise.
"The typical recession is very much blue-collar oriented," said Lawrence H. Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist. "This one was much more egalitarian. Both white collars and blue collars got hit." The overall jobless rate is 6.8 percent, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics will issue its November employment report on Friday.
 
Professional Prosperity
 Over the last year, one of the biggest jumps in employment has been the 400,000 leap, to 11.9 million, in the number of professionals at professional service industries, including lawyers, accountants, architects, registered nurses and engineers.
This jump was evident at Arthur Andersen & Company, the Chicago-based accounting and consulting firm. In the last year, it has expanded its work force by 2,000, to 29,000 workers; most of the newly hired have degrees in accounting, computer science, engineering or mathematics.
"We hire people according to what we think our workload will be," said Dennis Reigle, managing director for recruiting at Arthur Andersen. "The work is there right now."
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there has been a 150,000 jump, to 2.1 million, in the number of managers in finance, insurance and real estate over the last year. The number of managers in construction has jumped by 100,000, to just short of a million. And in manufacturing, the number of management jobs is up 110,000, to 2.4 million.
As a result, managers accounted for a greatly disproportionate share of new jobs -- they represent 13 percent of all employed Americans, but got 37 percent of the net new jobs over the last year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Record imports fueled by an improving American economy combined with stagnant markets overseas to push the United States merchandise trade deficit to a six-year high in the third quarter.
The Commerce Department said today that the gap swelled by 5.5 percent, to $36.3 billion, from $34.4 billion in the April-June quarter. It was the largest imbalance since the deficit totaled $39.6 billion in the final three months of 1987. 
 Analysts said Americans had more purchasing power now that the United States economy was improving modestly. But analysts noted the economies of many leading United States trading partners were stagnant -- if not in recession. That inhibits foreign buying of American-made goods.
As a result, imports rose five-tenths of 1 percent, to a record $148.2 billion, in the third quarter, up from $147.5 billion in the previous three months. Exports, however, dropped 1.1 percent, to $111.9 billion from $113.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Stocks Surge in Week's Best Performance

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks advanced broadly yesterday, gaining momentum from a firm bond market and rallies on the Tokyo and London exchanges.
In its best performance this week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.13 points, to 3,697.08, trading above 3,700 for most of the session before fizzling at the close. High-technology stocks and issues sensitive to the economic recovery gained in a rally that also embraced retail, banking and airline shares. 
Gains in Tokyo and London before trading opened in New York set the tone. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 index gained 4.38 percent, and in London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100 index was up 2.09 percent.
But Patrick J. Moriarity, the chief investment officer for Bank Julius Baer, New York, was cautious about the overseas gains, especially those in Tokyo.
"The Japanese rally was a short-term reversal and will not be there in the immediate term because the Government is concentrating on political reform and not economic reform," he said.
 
Disney Makes Gain
 Gene J. Seagle, the director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, said he was not surprised by the market yesterday. "The best five months of the year historically starts in November," he said. "I think we may test the 3,800 range by year's end."
Shares of Walt Disney, which rose 7/8, to 40 3/4, in active trading, accounted for about 17 percent of the advance of the Dow. Traders said the gain was tied to a strong performance in Paris by shares of Euro Disney. Traders said European news reports that the entertainment company planned to inject $500 million into its financially troubled affiliate had helped Euro Disney.
The Nasdaq composite, spurred by a push in high-technology issues, rose 9.42 points, to 763.81. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 293.9 million shares, up from 290.3 million on Tuesday. Gainers outnumbering losers by 1,315 to 804.
Economic data released yesterday were mixed, with an upward revision in third-quarter gross domestic product that was weaker than expected, offset by gains in the purchasing managers' index for November and construction spending in October. The initial reaction in the bond market was muted, but prices closed higher and interest rates fell.
 
Auto Stocks Rise
 Shares of General Motors rose 1/2, to 53 1/4, as the auto maker announced that it would discontinue its 10-day sales reports to cut costs. The market expects Ford to follow; Chrysler discontinued the practice two years ago. Chrysler rose 1 1/4, to 54, and Ford rose 1 7/8, to 62 5/8.
High-technology issues were led by Intel, which rose 1 1/4, to 62 3/4. The company, with Viacom and General Instrument, will develop technologies to allow personal computers to access information services over cable television lines. Microsoft, rose 1 1/2, to 81 1/2; Hewlett-Packard gained 3/4, to 74 1/2, and Compaq Computer gained 3/4, to 73 1/8.
Some retail issues moved higher in anticipation of the Christmas selling season. Sears, Roebuck & Company gained 5/8, to 55, and Woolworth added 5/8, to 23 3/4.
Snapple rose 2 3/8, to 23 3/8, after Paine Webber gave the beverage company a "buy" recommendation from "attractive."
The resumption of discussions between United Airlines and union representatives about a possible employee buyout moved the stock of UAL, the airline's parent, up 2 1/2, to 151.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. to Stop 10-Day Sales Reports, Ending a Detroit Rite

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 1

 BODY:
For decades, the General Motors Corporation and other auto makers have reported vehicle sales every 10 days, prompting journalists and Wall Street to scrutinize the numbers to determine which company is up and which company is down, and what that may mean for the economy.
No longer. General Motors announced today that it would report sales only at the end of each month, in part to streamline its operations. The sales reports would begin in the new year. The Ford Motor Company said today that it would likely follow G.M.'s example. 
 Most professional analysts sighed with relief that one of the Motor City's most arcane, grueling and, most of all, dubious insider rituals was at last being laid to rest.
"About time," said Ronald A. Glantz, an auto analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco. "I'm overjoyed."
Analysts who track the sales reports said they were often unreliable in drawing trends, because of seasonal fluctuations, incomplete reporting by dealers and other factors.
 
 
Chrysler Stopped in '91
 For reasons similar to G.M.'s, the Chrysler Corporation stopped reporting sales every 10 days in January 1991. Since then, journalists and analysts have relied on estimates of Chrysler's sales that are often skewed.
Further muddying the 10-day reports, many importers also issue their sales figure only monthly, and few news reports estimate their 10-day results.
Ford said today that it would probably eliminate the sales reports because 10-day reports were not very useful, even as a management tool.
"It's part of the culture in this part of the world to go crazy every 10 days trying to figure out what's happening," said Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, in a meeting with reporters today.
But, he said, "My main interest in looking at the 10-day scores is to wonder what you guys are going to say about the 10-day scores and figure out how I'm going to respond to your analysis of random variation."
While Mr. Trotman said he received daily sales reports, he said he intended to stop looking at those soon.
 
 
Flawed Data Better Than None
 Not everyone was pleased by the news. "I'd rather have a somewhat inaccurate number than no number at all," said David A. Wyss, research director for DRI/McGraw-Hill. "I found them a useful gauge, particularly of consumer confidence, because people don't buy cars unless they're feeling pretty good about themselves."
In a statement, General Motors said, "A monthly report more accurately reflects sales trends within the U.S. marketplace and is less subject to the impact of localized conditions." The company also said it would save money by reporting only monthly, although it did not disclose how much.
While General Motors reported 10-day sales off and on in the 1950's, it did not begin doing so regularly until January 1966, said John Maciarz, a company spokesman.
Internally, it began gathering sales reports from dealers every 10 days in 1924. Alfred P. Sloan, the auto maker's visionary chairman, insisted on the practice after poor inventory accounting led to huge overproduction. Before the new system, inventory controls were so weak that Mr. Sloan discovered the production problem only by visiting dealers.
"It is not often that the chief executive of a large corporation himself discovers visible overproduction by a physical check of the inventory," Mr. Sloan wrote in his memoir, "My Years with General Motors." "But automobiles are big units easy to count."
Several factors make the 10-day reports misleading, analysts said. For example, they said, news reports often omit important factors like storms or strikes that depressed sales during the comparable period a year previous. As a result, a sales increase in the current year may seem enormous.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Money managers aren't rushing in yet for bargains in Japan.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
EVEN though Japanese stocks have taken a severe beating over the last month or so, few international portfolio managers say they are ready to start buying suddenly cheaper Japanese equities. "Wait and see" may be the best strategy for now, managers say.
They contend that share values have farther to fall in Japan. Perhaps more importantly, prospects in other markets, such as Europe, are more compelling. The managers can afford to be sanguine because, despite the recent plummet, most Japan funds are ahead for the year. 
 Still, in a market as broad and diverse as Japan's, some portfolio managers noted the price decline might yield opportunities in certain sectors.
William F. Wendler, a vice president at Rowe Price-Fleming in Baltimore, said, "The market is now settling in at levels where we will begin looking again." Rowe Price-Fleming manages around $12 billion in international mutual funds.
Some of Japan's big exporting companies, names like Sony and Matsushita, are beginning to look attractive, according to Mr. Wendler. So are companies tied in to the changing structure of Japanese society, companies like Sumitomo Forestry, a manufacturer of prefabricated houses, and Aoyama Trading, a discount retailer of men's suits.
But most managers are not even in the "just looking" stage of stock assessment.
"I don't think portfolio managers should be doing anything," said Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management in New York. "At some point they should be thinking about buying, perhaps when the Nikkei index is around 14,000."
Such a level implies a fall of more than 20 percent in the world's second-largest stock market. Since the Nikkei index is currently at around 17,100, Mr. Biggs clearly thinks prices have not touched bottom. But the 14,000 level was seen only a year ago, and when it sank that far, only then did portfolio managers start to notice.
"Back in August 1992, the market was spiking down toward 14,000 on the Nikkei index, and there were some pretty positive attitudes in Japan," said John R. Hickling, who manages a Japan fund at Fidelity Investments.
Through yesterday, the seven Japan mutual funds followed by Lipper Analytical Securities were up an average of 22.9 percent since the start of the year.
Japanese stock prices have been -- and still are, in the eyes of many -- overpriced, and the economic prospects suspect. In a world of free-flowing capital, there have been more attractive places to invest.
"We have been underweighted in Japan relative to the rest of the world for probably five years," Mr. Biggs said. "The first two weren't much fun, but the last three have been."
Elizabeth Allen, who manages Scudder Stevens & Clark's $500 million Japan fund, said that to protect against the downward spiral seen in the Japanese market recently, the fund had been "fairly conservative" in what it bought.
"A full 10 percent of it is invested in convertible bonds," Ms. Allen said. "We don't have a lot of bank exposure or real estate exposure. We have been out of a lot of the very volatile sectors. I think prices have about bottomed out."
Others have less positive things to say. Concerned about high valuations and possible downward revisions in earnings, Merrill Lynch & Company started pulling its clients out of Japan at the end of August, said Douglas Johnson, a senior international-equity strategist.
"Given the opportunities we see in Europe, we would be more interested in devoting our attention there," he said.

HEADLINE: New Gains Bolstering 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Three upbeat economic reports suggested yesterday that the fourth quarter might turn out to be the strongest of the year, as many economists and executives have been predicting.
A widely followed survey of 300 manufacturers showed that the nation's factories continued to rebound in November. The Government reported that construction spending rose solidly in October. 
 And the Government's second look at third-quarter economic growth revealed a healthy rise in corporate profits and even more robust spending by consumers and business than initially estimated.
"Business is very strong," said Alan Hall, a materials purchasing manager for Playtex Apparel in Winston-Salem, N.C. "We haven't had enough capacity to make product and we've hired a lot of people."
 
Moderation Still Expected
 But while many forecasters think the economy could be growing at a 4 percent rate or better this quarter -- substantially faster than in the summer -- they also expect growth to moderate again in early 1994.
"We do see a slight decline in the new year," Mr. Hall said, "but it's not a deep trench."
The National Association of Purchasing Management, which conducts the monthly survey of industrial companies, said its index rose to 55.7 in November from 53.8 in October, suggesting that the economy was growing at its fastest pace since last winter. A reading over 45 indicates that the economy is expanding, while a reading over 50 suggests that the nation's manufacturers are growing as well.
The industries that have most to gain from low interest rates are among the peppiest: furniture, business equipment and industries like rubber and plastics that supply auto makers. New orders for all manufacturers jumped for the third month running. The backlog of unfilled orders, a key gauge of future production, is higher now than it has been all year.
What is more, inventories continued to shrink as sales kept growing faster than factory output, a sign that production should keep heading higher this month.
"There's a healthy combination of high backlogs and low inventories that means sales all through the supply chain," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the association's survey committee. "All that equals likely continuing improvement, which will probably make the fourth quarter the strongest of the year."
 
Caution Is Evident
 Companies in the survey have not started adding jobs yet and, by and large, managers are displaying more caution than they did a year ago.
Back then, retail sales also took off and factories were churning out goods at a fast rate. When bad weather arrived and consumers decided to take a breather, retailers got stuck with piles of inventories, orders dried up and manufacturers spent months retrenching.
This time around, manufacturers say they are basing their plans on some slowing of sales after the current surge.
"We're cautiously optimistic about next year, but we control inventories very tight," said Troy Hoskins, materials manager at Wilson Sporting Goods in Fountain Inn, S.C. "We won't be doing anything different in the future."
Mr. Bretz, who is a purchasing manager at Pitney Bowes, added, "The improvement will carry over into the new year, but not at the same rate as this quarter."
Meanwhile, a report from the Department of Commerce underscored that lower interest rates and improved state and local finances are helping to revive the construction business. Builders of everything from single-family houses to schools to sewers increased spending 2.5 percent in October to a $414 billion annual rate. That followed a gain of 1.5 percent in September, twice as strong as originally reported.
 
Third-Quarter Revisions
 The Commerce Department also took another look at how well the economy performed in the third quarter. Growth was a shade slower than the Government first reported, advancing at a 2.7 percent rate against the original estimate of a 2.8 percent rate. But there was more good news than bad in the revised estimates.
For one thing, spending was stronger. Consumer spending rose at a hefty 4.4 percent rate against 4.2 percent. Business investment in new equipment, especially computers, also turned out to be stronger, rising at a 10 percent annual rate compared with the previously reported 9 percent.
For another, profits continued to perk up. Corporate profits, which finance everything from dividends for shareholders to new business ventures, rose a handy eight-tenths of a percent this summer, after spurting 5.2 percent in the spring.
The most positive portent for the current quarter, economists said, was the leaner look of inventories. Business stocks rose nearly $2 billion less than the Government initially estimated. Leaner inventories usually mean that new orders will translate directly into more production and more income for factory workers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Possibility Germany Will Reduce Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most European currencies in quiet trading yesterday as investors reacted to more upbeat American economic news and the possibility of a German interest rate cut.
Traders said the dollar gained strength against European currencies on hopes that the Bundesbank's Central Bank Council would decide on an interest-rate cut at its meeting today. 
 A rate cut could help revive Germany's flagging economy, but would reduce the return investors would receive from mark-denominated deposits.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7235 marks, from 1.7150 marks on Tuesday. But despite its strength against European currencies, the dollar slipped to 108.80 Japanese yen from 109.10 yen.
The dollar picked up some support after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported a rise in its monthly index, traders said. The index, which tracks economic growth, registered 55.7 percent last month, up from 53.8 a month earlier.
"The numbers speak for themselves," Angelo Evangelista, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, said.
Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, said some economists had expected the number to be stronger, after Chicago-area purchasing managers reported a jump in their index a day earlier. However, she said, the result fed expectations of improvement in other United States economic figures.
"The dollar itself may be supported by the view that Friday's unemployment report will be supportive," she said.
The dollar also hit a seven-year high against the Italian lira, finishing at 1,719 lire, compared with 1,703 on Tuesday.
The lira has been battered by political turmoil in Italy, where a vast corruption scandal has devastated the parties that have governed since World War II.
Meanwhile, the British pound fell to $1.4780, from $1.4860 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4980; 5.9460 French francs, up from 5.9230, and $1.3343 (Canadian), down from $1.3357 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Up Sharply On Strong Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold and silver futures prices rose sharply yesterday in reaction to reports showing stronger economic growth.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery jumped $5, to $374.80 an ounce. December silver rose 22.8 cents, to $4.648 a troy ounce. 
 Yesterday, a widely followed survey of 300 manufacturers showed that the nation's factories continued to rebound in November.
Also, the Government reported that construction spending rose solidly in October. And a second look by the Government at economic growth in the third quarter showed a healthy rise in corporate profits and consumer spending.
Many economists predict that brisk housing and retail sales and rising consumer confidence will produce further improvement during the final three months of the year.
 
Foreign Sales a Factor
 Precious metals futures were also driven up in part because of strong demand from foreign investors, said William O'Neill, senior strategist for Merrill Lynch Futures.
"Today's economic data was significant because it points to what the real focus in gold is going to be as we move into 1994," he said. "The metals are telling us that we're at the bottom of the inflationary cycle and next comes global growth."
On other commodity markets, oil prices continued to stabilize after their sharp fall in the last week in reaction to OPEC's failure to bring oil production under control.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for delivery in January settled 5 cents higher at $15.48 a barrel. January heating oil was 0.60 cent lower at 47.18 cents a gallon. January gasoline was 0.22 cent higher at 42.60 cents a gallon, and January natural gas was 4.5 cents lower at $2.198 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain futures prices moved marginally higher while soybeans were narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. The markets were helped by Russia's $148 million payment on its United States debt.
"Their credit is still shaky, but at least it's alive," said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
Wheat was helped by news of Egypt's purchase of 599,000 metric tons of wheat from the United States.
Wheat for delivery in December rose 3 cents to settle at $3.51 1/4 a bushel. December corn was 1/4 cent higher at $2.79 3/4 a bushel. December oats rose 1 1/4 cents, to $1.28 3/4 a bushel, and January soybeans were up 1/4 cent at $6.71 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
More Cuts Announced By Boeing

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, still hurting from the continued weakness of the global airline industry, said yesterday that it would further cut production of commercial jets, resulting in the loss of 2,000 to 3,000 jobs in 1994.
Boeing said companywide employment levels for 1994 were still being assessed and would be announced early next year. The Seattle company had about 139,000 employees as of October. Earlier this year, Boeing announced plans to eliminate about 20 percent of its work force, or 28,000 jobs, by mid-1994. About 18,000 positions in Washington and Kansas were expected to be cut this year. 
 Boeing shares closed today down 75 cents, to $37.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Move Was Expected
 Analysts said that the cutbacks were expected because of the continuing malaise in the airline industry and that Boeing had hinted for some time it could not maintain 737 and 747 production at current rates. They said that production of Boeing's new 777 jetliner, scheduled to begin next year, could help offset the cuts but that revenues would likely be flat in 1994 and 1995.
"While there are some signs of improvement in the air travel market, losses or inadequate profits continue at many airlines," Ron Woodard, executive vice president of Boeing's commercial airplane group, said in a statement. "Until more customers are in a position to order new airplanes, we must reduce our production, as painful as that is for our employees, for our suppliers and for our communities."
Boeing said it would reduce production of its 737 jetliner to 8.5 a month in November 1994 from the current monthly rate of 10. Just last month, Boeing lowered its 737 production rate to 10 from 14 a month.
It said it would also cut production of its long-range 747 jet to three a month in February 1994 from the current five, and then to two planes a month, beginning in January 1995. The company said the production cut announced yesterday was not tied to any particular customer; Boeing changes production rates as overall order levels dictate.
 
More Cuts Seen as Possible
 William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle, said there could be more production cuts if the worldwide airline recession continued.
"People see some recovery in the domestic airlines, but internationally, the industry is still in the tank," he said. "Until we get a worldwide recovery, there is continuing risk of production rate cuts." Predicting flat sales in 1994 and 1995, he added, "The big question is what happens in 1996?"
Boeing said last month that it had received an order from Southwest Airlines for 63 of its 737-X family of jetliners, the next generation of its best-selling Boeing 737. But delivery of those planes will not begin until 1997, so they will not offset the current production cutbacks.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Optimism grows that Clinton can nail down a world trade deal.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
REMEMBER the children's song about the bear who climbed over the mountain? It must have unfortunate resonance these days for Bill Clinton, who scaled one peak -- the North American Free Trade Agreement -- only to face another equally tough ascent: completion of the so-called Uruguay Round of world trade liberalization under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by the Dec. 15 deadline.
The President may yet be forced to ask Congress for an extension of his negotiating authority -- or settle for a stripped-down accord that fudges the tough issues. Strikingly, though, few trade analysts are advocating a face-saving deal. More striking still, many are optimistic that Mr. Clinton can nail down a deal that weeks ago seemed impossible. 
 A word of explanation for those who experience an uncontrollable urge to nap on reading the phrase "General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade." Pedestrian as it may seem, agreement on new rules for international trade and investment could provide the psychological spark that reignites the recession-dimmed world economy.
At very least, according to the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the "draft final agreement" would add some $270 billion annually to world income by the year 2002. That translates into lower prices on goods ranging from sweaters to rice, and higher returns on global investments in everything from computer software to life insurance.
The vague outlines for a deal have been apparent for years. Industrial countries would get global access for the export of services, as well as legal protection for such "intellectual property" as drug patents. In return, they would end the protection of goods for which cheap labor gives third world countries a cost edge, and they would phase out subsidies that artificially depress world prices for food. Everyone would also be required to bend a little to the commonweal, playing by international rules on what constitutes unfair dumping and domestic purchase preferences.
But getting from here to there has proved no small feat. The draft agreement falls short of the brave new free trade world envisioned in the 1980's. And in one of the most politicized areas, agricultural subsidies, France has rejected even the weakened provisions negotiated on its behalf by the European Community.
That led some analysts to argue that a simple agreement, one lowering tariffs but putting off all the tough stuff, made sense. As recently as last month, there were quiet calls for the principals to sign something (anything), declare victory and cut their political losses.
All that has changed, however, in part because the deadline has forced the negotiators to examine the consequences of punting. Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University and an adviser to GATT, argues that the draft agreement is "a carefully balanced thing." Stripping it down, if only with the objective of making it less offensive to muscular special interests, would thus be very difficult. Indeed, C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics fears that a hollowed-out agreement would actually encourage protectionist backsliding.
Robert Lawrence, an economist at Harvard, sharpens the point. Honoring the Blair House deal -- Europe's agreement to split the remaining differences with Washington on agricultural subsidies -- is critical, he says. To make further concessions to France now, Mr. Lawrence argues, "would undermine the credibility of the European Community to negotiate for Europe."
Much of the change in outlook, however, follows from the Administration's newly discovered skills at realpolitik. The North American Free Trade Agreement demonstrated to the world that President Clinton was willing and able to take on the liberal wing of the Democratic Party on trade issues. As important, the victory on the trade accord was followed by the tirelessly publicized Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Seattle, leaving Europeans to fret that America would abandon the dream of global free trade in favor of regional trade pacts.
Fortress America, an integrated economy stretching from the Hudson Bay to Tierra del Fuego, is hardly a credible threat to the vastly more important trade and investment ties between North America and the European Community. And while a free trade area including Japan, China and North America might indeed divert commerce from Europe, Mr. Lawrence points out that bread-and-butter issues ranging from foreign investment in Japan to fierce protection of the domestic American apparel industry will make it impossible to realize the ambition anytime soon.
Used skillfully by free traders, though, the psychological threat of a regional alternative might make the difference as the GATT negotiations approach the witching hour. Indeed leaks of France's new flexibility on agriculture are appearing right on schedule. "I am optimistic the Administration can pull it off," Mr. Bergsten concludes. "If Clinton succeeds, he'll restore American leadership in global economic policy."

HEADLINE: Pregnant Teen-Agers Are Outcasts No Longer

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
IN the "old days" of the 1960's, 50's and 40's, pregnant teen-agers were pariahs, banished from schools, ostracized by their peers or scurried out of town to give birth in secret.
Today, pregnant teen-agers are even beginning to be viewed by some of their peers as role models. No longer are they shunned or ridiculed, but supported and embraced in their decisions to give birth, keep their babies, continue their educations and participate in school activities. Some adults, however, including many who in their youth considered the treatment of pregnant girls detestable, are nevertheless shocked by these attitudes. 
 "When I was in high school, girls got pregnant and they disappeared," said Richard Schuldt of Eau Claire, Wis. "Now, my pregnant daughter goes on 'The Montel Williams Show.' " Mr. Schuldt's daughter April was elected homecoming queen at her high school last year when she was five months pregnant. "I'm glad the old days of wearing the scarlet 'P' are gone," Mr. Schuldt, the father of six, added, "but today, teen pregnancy is being treated like it's no big thing, like it's the norm."
Indeed, in interviews with dozens of teen-agers around the nation, a picture emerged of a generation with more tolerant attitudes about teen-age pregnancy. By no means is the change in thinking universal, although it is defended by youths from diverse socioeconomic, racial, regional and academic backgrounds.
The new attitude was reflected in the words of Adina Madden of Washington, who is 18 and a freshman at George Washington University. "You look at a girl who's pregnant or has a baby and think, 'She's a better person than me, someone who is strong,' " she said. "There's no reason to mistreat a girl who is pregnant, like she has some contagious disease."
In each of the last five years, a little more than one million teen-agers became pregnant, according to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit research organization specializing in reproductive-health issues. In 1989, the last year for which figures were available, 49 percent of teen-age pregnancies resulted in birth, 37 percent in abortion and 14 percent in miscarriage, the institute said.
A 1972 Federal law made it illegal for schools that receive Federal funds to expel students or to prohibit them from participating in school activities because of pregnancy or parenthood. Although legal experts say some schools are ignoring the law and trying to shift pregnant students into special classes, some pregnant teen-agers are standing their ground, as in these cases:
* In Hempstead, Tex., high school officials were forced to reverse a decision last month to bar pregnant girls from the cheerleader squad after several students protested that it was punishment. The National Organization for Women threatened a lawsuit against the district.
* At Chelsea High School in Manhattan two years ago, the president and the secretary-treasurer of the student council both became pregnant and were encouraged to remain in the posts. Although some students protested, several called the girls role models and said their leadership resulted in the first prom at Chelsea.
* At Eau Claire Memorial High School in Wisconsin a year ago, the principal resigned and three assistant principals were disciplined for tampering with a student election to prevent Ms. Schuldt from becoming homecoming queen.
"If you look at the last 30 years, as a culture we have removed any form of being judgmental about out-of-wedlock pregnancy, as well as a host of other things," said Gary L. Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council, a social policy research organization in Washington. "While at first glance that may seem to be kind, the fact is that when a society has increasing rates of illegitimacy, it is headed for the rocks of decline."
Alexander Sanger, the president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood of New York City, said he is trying to answer questions like: How much compassion and understanding should society show toward pregnant teen-agers, and when does compassion become a license to do as one pleases?
"You know, we policy makers really don't understand young people," Mr. Sanger said. "It's inevitable that one person's compassion becomes another person's incentive. We want to take care of the child and the teen mother, but that can lead to teens looking at it as an incentive, a ticket out of the home. Their apartment is paid for by the city, they receive welfare and food stamps. So how do we do one without the other? We are all wrestling with that."
The prevailing attitude among the teen-agers interviewed, boys and girls, was that girls who choose to have their babies deserve more credit and respect than those who elect to have abortions and that society should let them enjoy whatever moments of glory come their way, like being a cheerleader or homecoming queen.
They eschew age-old standards that place the responsibility for childbirth primarily on the girl and that brand girls for life for what many teen-agers view as a mistake. And they point out the inconsistency of Hollywood images that glamorize sex and celebrities who have had children out of wedlock but maintain their status as pop-culture icons.
"As society perceives it, abortion is socially correct," said Heather Haynes, a 17-year-old who works after school as a peer counselor at the Planned Parenthood center in the Bronx. "Ethically, it's not correct. But you get the sense that it's the preferred option because it gets rid of the problem quick."
Carmen Colon, 21, another peer counselor at the center, said: "Life doesn't have to stop just because you're pregnant. As long as a girl is in school, why shouldn't she be able to take part in school activities. There are a lot of girls who aren't pregnant who are worse role models than some who are."
In many ways, the youths' opinions reinforced the notion that there are no simple answers and quick solutions to the problem of teen-age pregnancy.
"I know of girls who won't take birth control because it means they're planning to have sex," said Teresa Moore, 16, of Milwaukee. "Then, if it happens -- sex -- you have the excuse that you weren't planning to do it, you just got overwhelmed by the moment. That way, it's less of a guilt trip if you get pregnant."
While most of the young people interviewed said they believed that support for pregnant teen-agers is good, they expressed concern that too much support may give the wrong message.
" 'Welfare' backwards is 'farewell,' " said Ms. Haynes of the Bronx. "Welfare has become a life style for some teen mothers. I believe they should be helped, but there should be a limit to that help."
When asked what limits she would impose, Ms. Haynes said, "Welfare would be provided for the first child you have out of wedlock, not the second or third, unless the mother or father worked to support their baby."
Her proposition sounded strikingly similar to one offered by Charles Murray in "Losing Ground: The Coming White Underclass" (Basic Books, 1984). Mr. Murray, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, has called for a return to the mores of the past. As incentive, he proposed in a recent essay in The Wall Street Journal an "end of all economic support for single mothers" by government, including subsidized housing and food stamps.
In his radio address on Saturday, President Clinton also expressed concern about the number of out-of-wedlock births, adding, "We have to be concerned that without the structure, the discipline, the love of families, too many children face a future stripped of hope."
Tom Sartwell, 21, of Minot, N.D., who lives in the state with the lowest teen-age pregnancy rate in the nation, according to the Centers for Disease Control, agrees with the need for structure. "My boys snickered when I told them my girlfriend was pregnant," he said. "They told me this was going to tie me down. But I have to respect her decision not to have an abortion and to try to stay in school. I got a job and I'm supporting my baby. That's the way it should be."
But Tina Woolever, a 15-year-old sophomore at Hempstead High School, where the controversy over pregnant cheerleaders took place, said girls who are pregnant must also learn or be taught to be more responsible. "And that may mean they have to give up activities like cheerleading," she added.
Ms. Schuldt, 18, who gave birth to a son last year and graduated with her class, said: "There were people who felt I would have been a bad role model being up there as homecoming queen pregnant. But maybe some young girl would have seen it differently. Maybe, she would have seen a pregnant girl, continuing school, planning to raise and care for her baby and being supported by other students."
A 1986 study -- the latest such conducted -- by the Alan Guttmacher Institute found that the high school completion rate of women who became mothers at 17 or younger nearly tripled, from 19 percent in 1958, to 56 percent in 1986..
These and similar findings have prompted several school districts to establish on-site day care and to offer private tutoring and other assistance to encourage pregnant girls to continue their educations.
In North Dakota, for example, pregnant teen-agers can be tutored at home until they give birth or can attend an alternative high school in which students work at their own pace toward graduation.
"We know most of these girls don't want to get pregnant, and we don't want to look down on them when they do," said Kathy Hauser, a teacher who is director of the Souris River Campus, the alternative school in Minot. "In a way, some people view the help we provide as making pregnancy more acceptable, and I can see their point."
Nearly all the teen-agers interviewed, regardless of how they viewed out-of-wedlock pregnancy, shared a common belief: society must get its own act together on the issue.
"It is kind of a mixed message circulating out there," said Ms. Schuldt, who plans to enter college next fall. "It's different when you're older and have money to take care of a child. I can understand that. But if you can treat some unwed mothers with respect, then why not do the same for others.
"Just because you're young, unmarried and pregnant doesn't mean you're less of a person."

GRAPHIC: Photo: April Schuldt, chosen homecoming queen when pregnant, with her parents, Richard and Cecelia, and son, Natawhis. (Dan Reiland for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Finding Reliable Picture Developers

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
THESE days, choosing where to have holiday photographs developed can be as tough as deciding where to go on vacation. Film processing has become a basic neighborhood service, with new photo-finishing labs as ubiquitous as greengrocers. But the quality of their color prints can vary greatly, making comparison shopping essential.
As camera prices have dropped strikingly, film processing time has been cut in half and the quality of prints has been improved by technological innovations. The processing of negatives, once handled by operators of varying motivation and training, is today done by computers, which read negatives with more precision. Once negatives are produced, state-of-the-art printers can automatically make customized corrections to a photograph in a process called balancing. 
 People are taking more pictures -- and demanding more for their money. About 17 billion photographs were taken in 1992 in the United States, up from 11 billion a decade ago, said Harold Martin, editor of the Wolfman Report, which follows the photographic industry. Yet, he added, "many consumers still don't realize how good their pictures could be with good processing, nor how bad most processing can be."
In most major cities there are four ways for amateur photographers to get film processed.
MINI-LABS: These process film on the premises, usually within the hour. According to the Wolfman survey, there are about 21,000 mini-labs in the United States, compared with 3,000 in 1982. Despite rapid turnaround, mini-labs generally do more careful work than huge photo-finishers. You can actually watch them cleaning the negatives and making adjustments on computers; perhaps this accounts for the improved quality.
But they do not generally charge a flat rate, and their price lists can be confusing. Cost is based on a developing fee -- usually $3 or $4 -- plus a per-print rate (usually 30 cents to 40 cents apiece), which totals $12 to $16 for a roll of 36 exposures. Increasingly, mini-labs offer premiums like free rolls of film, enlargements or an extra set of prints. Opt for the prints; getting reprints later will be more expensive because of the extra labor costs.
If you are using a lab for the first time, you might wish to stay the hour to observe how the work is done. At the least, ask whether the lab uses fresh, high-grade paper by Kodak, Fuji or Agfa.
"If a print turns out badly, a person assumes that it is something they have done wrong," Mr. Martin said. "In fact, it might be that economizing was done at the finishing end." For instance, he said, every lab should refresh chemicals regularly.
Inspect each print before paying. A blurred image, perhaps caused by the photographer's poor focus, cannot be fixed. But poor contrast in a photograph often can be improved. Most labs will remake poorly color-balanced photos for free. The Fromex chain in Manhattan, for example, allows customers to bring back photographs at any time, said Wendy Mirabal, assistant manager of the Fromex mini-lab at 182 East 86th Street.
Even when everything is done conscientiously, different brands and batches of film can create problems.
"It's like the best chicken soup: everybody loves it one year, and the next holiday it can come too salty," said Cliff Strome, who owns Clicks and the Pro-Print 1 Hour Photo, two mini-lab chains in Manhattan. "Film made in Singapore may differ from film by the same manufacturer in Argentina."
Mr. Strome said he invested $700,000 in new equipment last April to compensate for differences in film batches. He charges between $15 and $16 for a roll of 36 exposures.
CAMERA STORES: These are also good places for processing film, several editors at Popular Photography magazine said. The owner may be prepared to redo work to your satisfaction; $12 is typical for a roll of 36 prints.
OFF-SITE LABS: Camera stores may also sell prepaid mail-in envelopes for you to send film to out-of-town manufacturers' labs like Kodak or Fuji (you pay for the processing in advance). Depending upon the mail, it may take up to two weeks to get prints, but the cost drops to between $8 and $10.
Beware of the lure of bargain-basement prices, sometimes under $4 a roll. Many discount labs provide mailers intended to resemble those used by Fuji or Kodak but instead route film to enormous wholesale processing mills producing tens of thousands of prints a day. Some work with outdated machinery. Occasionally a photograph comes back looking good, but after a few months the colors have changed or faded, a sign that cheap, out-of-date or exhausted chemicals were used. Assuming you could still remember where you sent the mailer (generally a post office box out of state), the odds are minuscule that you could find someone to correct the problem. Tracking down someone to request a refund might cost more in telephone charges than the original developing costs. And there's always the gamble of losing photographs through the mail.
LARGE-SCALE WHOLESALE FINISHERS: These are the middle ground between the most expensive and least expensive processing. They are usually more accountable and capable operations than the discount mass-volume finishers. They rely on collection points (candy stores, pharmacies, video-rental stores) where customers drop off film. The finishers retrieve it and return processed photographs anywhere from 7 to 24 hours later. Typically, 36 exposures cost $8. Bonuses are common; sidewalk placards advertise free photo albums, frames or film.
But to afford such give-aways some finishers may be cutting costs in processing that might diminish the quality of the prints, Mr. Martin said. And even a willing candy-store owner cannot do much to improve your photographs or trace film that went astray.
The most important thing is to build a relationship with an accountable supplier, whether it's in your own neighborhood, close to work or through the mail.
Above all, don't send essential pictures to a new supplier. If your photographs contain your baby's first steps, for example, you might want to consider custom labs that offer a full range of services for professional photographers and generally do work as good as -- if not better than -- that of the other options mentioned.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Film being processed and printed at Clicks, a mini-lab in Manhattan. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Hero or Villain, Magic Just Wants to Play Ball

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCKFORD, Ill., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Magic Johnson received a hero's front-page welcome to this northern Illinois city today. He was also ripped by local AIDS activists.
Such is the psychological paradox that the basketball superstar's post-National Basketball Association life has become. In one breath, someone calls out, "We love you, Magic." In another, he is challenged to explain what in the world he is doing here in the first place. 
 On World AIDS Day, Johnson, who is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, was here not to preach, only to play. "I love ball," he said at a news conference to kick off his tour of five Continental Basketball Association towns. "I'm just a basketball player."
Arguably the greatest team player in the history of the sport, holder of five N.B.A. championship rings, Magic and his peripatetic all-stars beat the Rockford Lightning, 129-119, tonight. Next stop on Magic's tour: Hartford, Thursday night, to challenge another entity from the N.B.A.'s developmental league for the love of a run and the split of the gate.
 
Reporters Applaud
 Tonight's game sold out Rockford's Metro Centre (capacity: 8,900), where the Lightning averages 3,500 fans. Tickets went for as much as $30, which is usually the cost of a C.B.A. night out for a family of four. "One of the most significant sports events in the city's history," said the Lightning's public relations man, Dan Bernstein.
Many members of the local news media stood and applauded when Johnson walked into the small gymnasium on the campus of Rock Valley College for the news conference Tuesday afternoon. He dressed down for the occasion. He wore a wool hat and gray coat over a blue sweatsuit, which had "Magic All Stars" in white lettering on the front of the shirt. His agent and bodyguard wore black jackets with "Magic Johnson Legends Tour" insignias on the back and "Pepsi" embroidered on the front.
So why was this tour's one actual legend really here, in subfreezing temperatures time zones from his home in sunny Los Angeles? He gave no one a palatable answer. He hinted, sometimes unwittingly, at many.
The crowds. The news media. His sponsors. The locker room. The guys. The game.
The grim reality of H.I.V.
 
'Trying to Be Magic'
 The lead headline on the front page of today's Rockford Register Star read: "Magic: I don't dwell on AIDS." He said that only when he takes his medicine, twice a day, does his condition usually cross his mind. "My theory is that if you think about it, that's all there's going to be," said Johnson. "Meanwhile, everything is still happening all around you."
So on and on he goes, just "trying to be Magic."
It is two years since Johnson announced he was infected with H.I.V. and quit the Los Angeles Lakers after 12 seasons. He said then that his new job would be as a spokesman for the fight against H.I.V. Tonight, a Rockford AIDS activist, John Olson, held a candlelight vigil in the rain outside the Metro Centre. And he lit into Johnson for not participating in local World AIDS Day activities.
"This man, who walked out of the Presidential AIDS Commission because it wasn't doing anything, has no intention of supporting AIDS awareness," Olson said.
Johnson did try being a spokesman for H.I.V. He just wasn't very good at it. He started by telling schoolchildren that he would beat the disease, a scientific impossibility and, critics complained, the worst message for kids. He aborted his heralded N.B.A. comeback last November in the face of player opposition, practically insuring that other players who might be infected would keep their mouths shut. Tuesday, minutes after reiterating that discrimination in the workplace against H.I.V. must stop, Johnson decided it didn't really exist in the N.B.A.
"The players who complained had been trying to beat the Lakers for years and couldn't," he said. "So if I'm out, then they get that chance.
"See, I've been real, so you be real about your reasons. Don't come with, 'I don't want to play the game,' because you've been playing against me and with me for three months. Come on. That was a joke."
 
The Smile Disappears
 There was no trademark Magic smile now. No follow-up laughter. The more Johnson talked about the comments made by Utah's Karl Malone, among others, the more detectable his bitterness was. He wanted to play. He still does, but the N.B.A. situation, for him and everyone else, gets much too complex. Better to toy with the inevitable question of another possible return:
"If the Lakers were in a position where they could win it all. . . ."
"If Michael Jordan were to come back. . . ."
Better, for now, to meet the pressures of getting exposure for the sake of endorsement deals by creating his own Magic show time. He found unemployed veterans like Reggie Theus, Earl Cureton and John Long, and there are always young players looking for exposure on ESPN2, which will televise Thursday's game in Hartford, and the chance to run with the best point guard of them all.
He appeared to lack the resolve to make what activists saw as the ultimate anti-discrimination statement for H.I.V. by staying with the Lakers last fall. But Johnson's insistence on finding other places to play must count for something. He hears that he ought to be home every night with his wife, with his young son. It's his business, he said. He's out there. His statement, ultimately, is that he's not about to let others set his priorities.
"If this is what Magic wants to do, what's the disgrace?" said Rockford Coach Mauro Panaggio, a 65-year-old grandfather of 11. "You see what the gate is. People still want to see him play."
 
Too Quiet for Magic
 If he could get his competition fix another way, Johnson would. Jordan and Larry Bird have golf. Golf is a private game in a quiet setting. Too quiet for Magic Johnson.
Trying to make the point that he doesn't need the cheers, the attention, he only made a more convincing case that he does. "I went to a concert the other night and the guy made me stand up two times," he said, as if his arm had been twisted. "The crowd kept cheering, cheering."
Crowds follow him everywhere when he goes on vacation or plays abroad. "If I needed that, I would just play in Europe, where I'm more popular than here," he said. But, of course, his coming South American tour is sold out, he noted. And then it's all aboard for eastern Asia.
He was not too proud to whoop it up tonight with Theus, who scored 40 points, many off Johnson's 21 assists. It would be no humiliating comedown, he said, to bring the ball upcourt tonight against the Lightning's Jay Taylor. If not Taylor, then it would be some sharp-elbowed lawyer at his sports club in L.A. He was going to get himself a game, one place or another. This, at least, was structured, safer, and it still made him feel like an ambassador for the sport, a master of the crowd.
He mugged for courtside snapshots. He high-fived kids when the game ended. He grabbed the public-address microphone. "Please say a prayer for all those with H.I.V," he said, his words a reminder that in the playing arena he always did make the right call.
This wasn't the N.B.A. but it was still very much his element.
"I'm not here to prove anything, just to get the thrill of being out there, knowing I've got to push the button or I could be embarrassed," he said. "For them, the opponents, there's the challenge of trying to take me, beat me, that whole thing.
"I think," Magic Johnson said, unconvincingly, "they get more out of it than me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Magic Johnson at the Metro Centre in Rockford, Ill., where the Magic All Stars began a five-game tour last night. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Ad Spending Rise Forecast for 1994

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Media spending next year will grow by 7 percent, or 2 percent after inflation, according to a study released yesterday by Myers Reports in Parsippany, N.J., an advertising, marketing and media consulting company.
The report said a strong national television market -- stimulated by home shopping, infomercials and other forms of electronic marketing -- would fuel that growth, with little change in spending in most other media. 
 The annual report by Myers forecast a 10 percent rise in broadcast network television ad spending and a 14 percent gain in broadcast syndication ad spending. By comparison, magazine ad spending is expected to rise 5 percent to 6 percent, while spending in newspapers is expected to rise 4 percent to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kendall in Shake-Up of Top Officers

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
The supercomputer maker Kendall Square Research stripped its chief executive of his title yesterday and demoted two other top executives as the company sought to contain a financial crisis and salvage its credibility with the investment community.
Kendall Square also restated its financial results for the last year and a half, disclosing a significantly higher loss for 1992 than was previously reported. The company also indicated that it did not know whether the slim profit initially reported for the first half of 1993 would remain, once all the adjustments had been made. 
 The financial revision was forced by the company's announcement on Monday that its auditor, Price Waterhouse, could no longer vouch for the company's previous financial reports. That news had sent Kendall Square's stock plunging 33 percent on Monday, but yesterday the shares edged up 12.5 cents to close at $7.875 in Nasdaq trading.
Yesterday Kendall Square, based in Waltham, Mass., announced that Henry Burkhardt 3d, the company's founder, would be replaced as chief executive by William I. Koch, the company's chairman and largest stockholder. Mr. Koch, probably better known as the skipper of the high-tech yacht that won the America's Cup in 1992, will serve as acting chief while a search for a new chief executive is conducted. Mr. Burkhardt will remain as president.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Burkhardt acknowledged that Kendall Square "made a number of mistakes" in recording its revenues, particularly in sales to universities. Kendall Square had previously insisted that its revenue bookkeeping had been accurate during the last two years, despite questions raised by analysts. "We sure thought we had it under control," Mr. Burkhardt said. "But a lot of sales to universities were inappropriately recorded because the underlying financing from third parties was not contractually in place at the time."
The company said Peter Appleton Jones, executive vice president of the technical products group, and Karl G. Wassmann 3d, chief financial officer, were both being stripped of their titles. Mr. Burkhardt said both would remain as employees to offer advice to Mr. Koch but were no longer officers of the company. Mr. Jones's duties will be handled by Robert Rockwell, vice president of marketing and Far Eastern sales. Ray Fortune, Kendall Square's, chief operating offficer, will serve as interim chief financial officer, until a replacement can be found.
Kendall Square had announced on Monday that Price Waterhouse had withdrawn its auditor's report on the company's 1992 financial results. Kendall Square said yesterday that an internal audit showed that the compay's 1992 sales were actually $4.2 million less than originally reported and the net loss in earnings for the year was actually $4.5 million higher, resulting in a loss of $17.2 million for 1992, instead of the $12.7 million previously reported.
Kendall Square said the new figures might still be subject to adjustment because Price Waterhouse had yet to review them.
For the first six months of 1993, the company had previously reported sales of $24.7 million and net income of $1.3 million. Yesterday, the company said it was estimating sales for the first nine months of only $10.6 million and declined to predict whether the revised numbers would result in a profit or loss for the first nine months.
Kendall Square told industry analysts that the company might end up deleting more than $30 million in 1993 revenues that it thought were on the books. The company said it might have to take a financial charge against its inventory of KSR1 supercomputers and therefore did not want to speculate on the impact on earnings.
Kendall Square issued its findings today in order to "dispel uncertainties raised by these accounting issues and to permit the company to move forward with its business plan," the company said in a news release.
The company also reviewed its assets and said that its capitalized software would be $2.4 million as of Sept. 25, instead of the $6.5 million reported as of June 26.
