HEADLINE: Clinton Welfare Planners Outline Big Goals Financed by Big Saving

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton's task force on welfare reform has translated his pledge to "end welfare as we know it" into a plan to spend significant new sums on child care, work and job training programs. But the plan provides few specifics about the financing and says its ambitious goals can be paid for entirely by cuts or savings in welfare or other programs for the needy.
A draft of the plan was completed 12 days ago and is subject to revisions before it is presented to Mr. Clinton. 
 A copy of the confidential document suggests that, in its broadest outline, the program seems less the radical departure that Mr. Clinton's oratory has suggested than an expansion of the current law, as embodied in the 1988 Family Support Act.
 
Training and Then Work
 That law provides money for job training and education programs, and requires some welfare particpants to enroll in them. The Clinton plan would expand those training opportunties, and add tougher work requirements at the end.
"We see the Family Support Act as a really core foundation for anything we do," said David T. Ellwood, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services who is one of three leaders of the task force drafting the bill.
The plan reiterates Mr. Clinton's pledge to impose a two-year limit on welfare benefits, after which recipients would have to enroll in a work program or face financial penalties.
 
An Unanswered Question
 But it holds open the possibility that the work program could be temporary, and it does not resolve the ultimate question: What would then happen to poor families who still could not find private jobs?
One Administration official drafting the plan called that "the $64,000 question" that after nearly a year in office, the Administration has still not answered.
The plan suggests that those who exhaust their temporary jobs could simply recyle back onto the welfare rolls, perhaps with reduced benefits.
The working group member, speaking on the condition of anonymity, characterized the plan as "a first draft" and said it underscored the amount of detailed work still to come before one of the President's primary campaign pledges is converted to legislation.
Like the people who devised the Admininstration's initial ambitious health care proposals, the welfare planners did not say how much the plan would cost or specify which program cuts would finance it. So it is hard to gauge the true extent of its ambition.
But some welfare experts voiced skepticism that a serious welfare plan could be financed simply by cutting current programs.
 
New Services Required
 Mr. Ellwood acknowledged that many decisions remain. "The whole question of how exactly the jobs will work is still very much under discussion," he said.
The financing remains a central political difficulty. Many members of Congress, Democrats and Republicans alike, think the time limit can save money and court favor with the public. But the plan makes the time limits contingent on the Government's providing expensive new services, like job training and child care and the working group members are searching for ways to pay for the services. The Administration wants to phase in the program slowly, to reduce the initial costs.
For now, the White House is in the midst of a vigorous internal debate over the timing of the plan. Some see the need to fulfill political promises quickly, particularly with Congressional Republicans pushing a time-limit plan of their own. Others are warning that fast action on welfare will produce political and financial conflicts for the health care bill, which must travel through the same Congressional committees.
The 29-page plan served as the basis of a Nov. 20 meeting of the working group, which has 32 members. The Administration has recruited some of the nation's leading academic experts on welfare, including Isabel V. Sawhill, a White House budget aide, and Mr. Ellwood and Mary Jo Bane, both assistant secretaries at the Department of Health and Human Services.
But so far they have provided more slogans than specifics about how they plan to tackle the challenge of moving five million poor mothers, mostly with few skills, into an economy with nine million unemployed people.
The document from the Nov. 20 meeting gives the first clues. In addition to calling for expanded child care, training, and work programs, it also endorses a national campaign to reduce teen-age pregnancy. It calls for "dramatic improvements in the child support enforcement system" and acknowledges "there is considerable division" within the group over whether the Government should make the payments itself if it fails to collect them.
 
Both Fathers and Mothers
 The plan indicates an enthusiasm for expanding training programs so that they include absent fathers, as well as mothers. Such an expansion could help fathers earn more, and therefore pay more in child support payments. But such an expansion would also add large new costs.
The document also acknowledges the considerable political challenges that surround revamping the welfare system and which, in the past, have defeated ambitious plans by Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Jimmy Carter. "Ugly, racist, and mean-spirited images are sometimes loudly proclaimed," the paper said.
Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program, costs about $23 billion a year. Food stamps and Medicaid for welfare families costs about $40 billion more. But the volatility of welfare debates is always larger than numbers alone suggest, because the issue touches on race, class and even sexual morality.
Mr. Clinton's plan is similar to Mr. Carter's in one crucial respect: his insistence that any welfare overhaul pay for itself by offsetting cuts or savings in other programs. That is a major reason Mr. Carter's plan failed in Congress.
Bruce Reed, a White House domestic policy aide who is a co-chairman of the task force, expressed confidence that the financing would not similarly stall this plan. "The cost depends how gradually it's phased in," he said.
One way to phase it in, he said, is to start in a limited number of states. Another possibility is to have the new requirements apply only to new welfare applicants, not to those already on the program.
 
Skepticism on Fiscal Claim
 But one Congressional aide who is an expert on welfare expressed skepticism that an ambitious plan could be financed from wringing the fat out of existing programs. "When they tell you it's going to be deficit neutral and they don't know where the money is coming from, I get real skeptical that this is going to be as significant change in policy," he said.
As described in the plan, each welfare recipient would be required to join a social worker in designing a contract that "would detail the obligations of both the recipient and the state."
The state would be required to provide the education, training, or child care a welfare recipient needed to find a job. The welfare recipient would be required to attend the programs.
In general, the work preparation would not exceed two years "for employable persons." But the plan would allow states to grant extensions for people who had not finished high school or needed other kinds of training. The number of extensions each state could issue would be limited.
In the event the state did not have the money to provide the training or child care, the "state would be prohibited from imposing time limits." That is why the extent of Government financing is crucial in determining the extent of the program.
The plan does not specify who would be exempt from the time limits. The Family Support Act already requires welfare recipients to participate in work or training programs.
But it exempts about half of the five million families on the rolls, including, for instance, the mothers of infants. And the current law only requires 15 percent of the rest to be in a program.
 
Some Would Be Incapable
 The Clinton plan envisions "a substantial increase" in the $1.3 billion a year now being spent on the training programs. It would also require less in the way of state matching money.
The Clinton plan acknowledges that not everyone on welfare is physically or mentally capable of holding a job, and argues the system "must be sensitive" to granting them exceptions. Instead of job training, such people might get health or housing assistance or aid, the plan says.
The plan outlines two options for creating the work program that would begin after a welfare recipient reached the two-year limit. Under one option, checks would be distributed by employers; under the other, checks would be distributed by the welfare system, in exchange for work.
The second option is generally considered harder to enforce, because court decision have provided for extensive appeals before a welfare check can be reduced.
In either event, the plan calls for money to finance the jobs from the Federal Government, distributed to states according to a formula. And Federal money would include financial incentives to place people in private jobs, rather than Government jobs.
Such incentives could include payments to the employers who hired welfare recipients, or to personnel concerns that found them jobs. The details would vary by region and be determined by some sort of a public-private council.
 
Jobs Are Transitional

 Mr. Reed, the task force co-chairman, said the jobs are likely to be temporary. "We see these as transitional jobs, not permanent jobs," he said.
That raises the question of what comes next for families that, at the end of the program, could still not find work.
The task force leaders say no decisions have been made. But the plan discusses an option to give states the choice of reducing the benefits "to recipients who had spent at least 18 months in work assignments."
Task force members would not publicly specify how much annual spending they envision when the program is fully in effect. But one member, speaking on the condition of anonymity, noted that the Republicans' plan proposed spending $6 billion a year on child care and training and said "we'd look silly" with a smaller plan.
Where will the officials find the savings? A task force member, also anonymously, said the group was examining welfare, child care, and disability programs for changes to save money. Melissa Skolfield, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said, "I'm ruling out Medicare and Social Security."
 
Expanded Care for Children
 The plan calls for expansions of child care programs that would cover not only families on welfare but also those of the working poor. Otherwise, it said, "it will be impossible to insure that working people avoid poverty."
It contemplates three ways of doing that: consolidating and expanding current programs, creating a new block grant program or creating a refundable tax credit. It gives no cost estimate.
The plan also calls for a change in the way an important tax credit program is administered. It would give the low-income workers advanced payments on the tax refunds, rather than making them wait until the end of the year.
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Ellwood argued that the importance of the plan was not in its immediate financial scope but rather in the signals it sends. He said it would change welfare offices from places that mail checks to those that find people jobs.
The document reiterates that vision throughout, arguing the Clinton plan will reinforce "the traditional values of work, family, support, and responsibility."

HEADLINE: U.S. AND EUROPEANS REPORT KEY STEPS TO A TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The top trade negotiators for the United States and the European Community said today that they had made important, potentially decisive progress on a range of issues, including the nettlesome matter of farm exports, that could lead to a world trade accord.
"We have agreed upon an approach to all major issues that would pave the way to the completion of a substantive and comprehensive Uruguay Round," the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said here, referring to the negotiations on updating and broadening world trade rules that began seven years ago in Uruguay.
 
A Way to Break Recessions
 The talks, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are widely seen as crucial for both economic and political reasons. Success could help revive moribund economies in Japan and Europe, and stimulate uncertain economic recoveries in the United States and Britain. 
 On a political level, a failure to reach a trade agreement would put further strains on the postwar alliance between Western Europe and the United States that is adjusting imperfectly to the end of the cold war.
Neither Mr. Kantor nor his European counterpart, Sir Leon Brittan, gave significant details in public of the progress they said was achieved in two days of talks, and the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, whose Government has most strenuously objected to the agricultural provisions proposed, later sounded a note of caution.
 
Farm Trade Is Central
 "The basis of an overall agreement has not yet been laid," Mr. Juppe said. Nonetheless, he added that "we have emerged from the deep chill that had descended on relations between the community and the United States."
Officials close to the discussions said the most important progress was made on agriculture, where France's objections to the Blair House accord of last year, calling for a 21 percent cut over six years in the volume of community exports of subsidized grain and other food, have wounded relations with the United States.
Today, Mr. Kantor said, "We have formulated an approach which would successfully remove all the issues in the area of agriculture."
Behind large measures of posturing among delegations here is a complex and politically sensitive negotiation that has entered its decisive phase. It seemed clear that Mr. Kantor's visit had generated significant momentum toward an agreement, particularly in the long-contested area of farm trade -- though without achieving final resolution of any issue.
The American trade negotiator said he would return to Brussels on Monday, after conferring with President Clinton, for what he and Sir Leon portrayed as conclusive negotiations. "We are, I hope, in the final strait," the European trade chief said.
All those taking part in the talks are pushing to conclude an agreement by Dec. 15 because of an effective deadline set by Congress early in the summer. The lawmakers gave Mr. Clinton "fast track" authority -- a deal struck by Dec. 15 can be put to an up-or-down vote in each house of Congress with no amendments allowed. The same practice was followed in approving the North American Free Trade Agreement.
On the ticklish farm export issue, the proposal being carried to Washington and European capitals reflects the sort of horse trading typical of the final stage of a negotiation.
The United States would grant concessions on the timing and nature of European export reductions, in return for improved access to European markets for a range of American farm products.
 
More Time and Flexibility
 Thus, community officials said, the gradual reductions leading to the overall 21 percent cut required by the Blair House accord would be concentrated at the end of the six-year period, giving European farmers more time to adjust. And greater flexibility would be permitted in the mix of products used to achieve the 21 percent cutback.
The Clinton Administration would also reinforce its guarantees that after a GATT accord, it would not initiate legal action against European farm trade practices, officials said.
Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, who accompanied Mr. Kantor, cited other gains. "We have found a way," he said, "to insure that our farmers will benefit from significant new market access opportunities in Europe in commodities like grain, meat, dairy products and other crops."
The Europeans, officials said, have tentatively agreed to convert some of their quotas on farm imports into low tariffs, as Washington demands.
One of the main effects of the compromise reached today would be on subsidized European wheat exports. The Europeans agreed earlier to reduce these exports to 13.4 million metric tons in 2001, from the current 22 million metric tons. But the pace of the cutbacks would be more gradual than first planned. Instead of falling to 16.4 million tons by mid-1996, the subsidized exports would drop only to 20.6 million tons by then.
Greater access for American farm products is crucial, though, and it is apparently unresolved. The arrival in European markets of big quantities of American grain would presumably enrage the French; a lot more American fruit would trouble the Italians; substantially more American beef would bother the Irish. For such reasons, European foreign ministers, who met after Mr. Kantor left today, were uniformly guarded about the overall prospects for an accord.
"We have the conviction that we are making progress, but it would be dangerous at this stage to draw any conclusions," said Foreign Minister Willy Claes of Belgium, currently president of the community's Council of Ministers.
 
An Issue Long Avoided
 Agriculture has been such a sensitive area because until this round of talks, GATT had not addressed protectionism in farm trade. Set up in 1948, at a time when many European countries were still focused on securing food self-sufficiency after the devastation of World War II, the Geneva-based trade organization has never previously acted to remove anomalies that grew out out of the exclusion of farm products from its rules.
A statement by the foreign ministers after their meeting expressed full confidence in Sir Leon's ability to "obtain, over the next few days, the indispensable improvements necessary to safeguard the essential interests of the community and to overcome the problems that remain."
Among those problems is a gathering dispute over anti-dumping duties, which Europeans think the United States uses excessively to protect hard-pressed industries like steel and automobiles. The community wants stringent rules in any accord setting out the criteria for the application and duration of such duties, while the Americans argue that national sovereignty could be infringed by the proposed measures.
There are also differences over textile trade, in which other nations want quotas removed more quickly than the United States does, and over world sales of movies, where France insists that it needs subsidies and quotas to protect its culture from a Hollywood onslaught.
Moreover, any accords between the Europeans and the United States will have to be extended to the other countries taking part in the talks. While a breakthrough between the community and Washington is viewed as the decisive ingredient in an overall accord, gaining the approval of other countries could take time, with the Dec. 15 deadline approaching.
"Difficulties remain," a European diplomat said. "But the political investment in an agreement on both sides of the Atlantic is so enormous right now, it is hard to imagine a failure."

HEADLINE: Delay in Hearing for Rifkin Stirs Plea Bargain Concerns

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 2

 BODY:
A pretrial hearing concerning the seizure of several thousand pieces of evidence from the macabre world of Joel Rifkin, including a blood-soaked wheelbarrow and chain saw, hypodermic needles, women's underwear, used condoms and a box full of personal ads, was postponed this morning when Mr. Rifkin called in sick from the county jail.
Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, has admitted to killing 17 women, most of them prostitutes. 
 The delay increased concern among relatives of Mr. Rifkin's victims that the defense and prosecution wanted to explore further the possibility of a plea agreement.
 
The Only Acceptable Deal
 "The only deal we could agree to is one that puts him in jail for the rest of his life," said Margarita Gonzalez, whose sister, Jenny Soto, 23, was among the victims Mr. Rifkin listed in a confession. Her body was found in the Harlem River in May 1992.
"No one's even talked to us about a deal," said Ms. Gonzalez, who, with her mother, has attended all but a few of Mr. Rifkin's court appearances.
Michael L. Soshnick, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, denied that any deals were in the works and said his client was not brought to Nassau County Court this morning because he was suffering from a stomach virus.
Mr. Soshnick said he had received no formal offer of a deal from the Nassau County District Attorney's office. But law-enforcement officials insisted that a deal had been offered to Mr. Rifkin and that he had balked over some details of the plea bargain.
They said the deal would allow Mr. Rifkin to plead guilty to all the charges against him in exchange for a sentence of 46 years to life.
 
Discussing a Plea Bargain
 Mr. Rifkin has so far been indicted for one murder in Nassau County, two in Suffolk County and and two each in Brooklyn and Queens. If he is convicted of those slayings alone, he could face 175 years to life in prison.
Officials from each of the nine jurisdictions in New York State that have either brought charges or are preparing charges against Mr. Rifkin met at the Nassau District Attorney's Office here on Monday to discuss a plea agreement, law-enforcement officials said. But the talks ended without an accord.
Mr. Rifkin was arrested on June 28 when he was stopped for a traffic violation and the police found the decomposing body of a woman wrapped in a blue plastic tarp in the rear of his pickup truck. Within hours of his arrest, he confessed to killing 17 women and told the police where their bodies could be found.
The current pretrial hearing before Judge Ira H. Wexner is considering the admissibility of Mr. Rifkin's confession and evidence found at his home. Jewelry, clothing and identification documents belonging to many of the victims were recovered in his bedroom, which smelled of oil and gasoline and was littered with old clothing, food wrappers, newspapers, magazines, video cassettes, rolls of undeveloped film and women's jewelry and clothing.
State police investigators testified this week that they had taken 7,000 items from Mr. Rifkin's bedroom, bathroom, closet and garage as they searched for items that might have blood, semen or other body fluids and hair on them.
Blood was detected on many of the items with the help of a what the investigators described as an "enhanced light source." Among them were a wheelbarrow, a chain saw, paint cans, rags, clothing, boots and shoes. The light causes a bright reflection when it strikes a bloodstain.
As Mr. Rifkin nervously shifted in his seat at the defense table on Wednesday, Inspector Alan Brock, told the court that the litter in the bedroom, except for a path to the bed, was a foot and a half deep.
Judge Wexner barred questions by the defense about the content of the video cassettes and the undeveloped film found in the bedroom. Inspector Brock said the film had been developed by the police, but he did not comment on its contents.
By questioning the methods used by the investigators, Mr. Soshnick hopes to raise questions about the admissibility of the evidence.
In his questions to Inspector Brock, Fred Klein, an assistant Nassau County District Attorney and chief prosecutor in the case, concentrated on items found in Mr. Rifkin's room, including wallets, identification cards and jewelry belonging to victims.

HEADLINE: With New U.S. Concessions, Canada Plans to Back Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada announced today that his Government had secured concessions from the United States on the North American Free Trade Agreement and was prepared to drop his opposition to the pact coming into force on Jan. 1.
The announcement removed a last uncertainty about the institution of the three-country accord, which would eliminate most duties and investment barriers within the United States, Canada and Mexico over the next 15 years. 
 Canada, the last of the three countries to sign on, had sought side agreements with the United States to address its concerns, chiefly about the enforcement of what it said were the rules for fair trade.
"I am very satisfied with the progress we have made," Mr. Chretien told reporters in Ottawa today.
But political opponents said Mr. Chretien had obtained little but cosmetics and political window dressing. In dismissing the claims that the accord had been improved, the Progressive Conservative Member of Parliament Jean Charest, the former Deputy Prime Minister, said Mr. Chretien got "zero, zilch, nothing."
Both houses of Congress and the Mexican Parliament approved the North American Free Trade Agreement last month. Canada's Parliament approved the pact last spring under the former Tory Government, but because of the approaching Federal elections and a possible change in Government, the legislation was never formally proclaimed.
During the election campaign, Mr. Chretien had threatened to withhold Canadian participation unless certain conditions were met. His Liberal Party had been sharply divided over the trade accord. In elections five years earlier the party had come out against a free trade agreement with the United States, which went into effect on Jan. 1, 1989, and will now be supplanted by the new accord.
Yet once elected in October, Mr. Chretien's tough rhetoric softened. Though the agreement is not popular here, Canadian businesses have strongly favored participation and have exercised a powerful influence on the new Government through the new trade minister, Roy MacLaren, a former international business executive and foreign service officer.
 
Troublesome Reservations
 Business noted dramatic export growth to the United States under the existing five-year-old free trade pact. That export growth, in turn, has been the main prop for Canada's recent economic expansion.
Though the Canadians said they wanted only side agreements and not to reopen the pact, their reservations proved troublesome for the Clinton Administration in fighting the battle for approval in the House of Representatives. Some opponents argued that the Canadian objections had proved the accord was flawed.
But while the struggle in the House was under way, a number of influential Canadians let it be known that if the United States rejected the pact, Canada might go ahead with an exclusive arrangement with Mexico, noting advantages for export industries and jobs. This was seen as a further indication of the strong desire here to see the deal through.
Mr. Chretien raised the trade issues in his first meeting with President Clinton in Seattle two weeks ago. Mr. Clinton said he was sympathetic to Canadian concerns. Before making today's announcement, Mr. Chretien spoke again with the President by telephone at 7 P.M. on Wednesday.
The main agreement between Mr. Chretien's Government and the United States was to begin two years of talks on establishing codes covering unfair trade. The two countries will try to define what are unfairly subsidized exports and what constitutes the dumping of goods at below fair value in their bilateral commerce.
The Canadians said they felt the United States trade agencies were capricious in the actions they sometimes took against low-priced Canadian goods. The issue looms large here because the United States buys $4 of every $5 Canada exports to the world.
James J. Blanchard, a former Governor of Michigan and the United States Ambassador, said that standards should help both countries. "It's much easier to promote the free flow of trade if ground rules are more streamlined," he said.
Robert R. Amsterdam, an international trade lawyer in Toronto, said the United States was willing to discuss the rules now because its companies were starting to "feel the heat" of dumping actions by Canada. The Canadian Government has taken action recently against American steel, carpets and copper accessories.
Officials of the two Governments are to conclude a report on the unfair trade codes by the end of 1995, but the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said in a telephone interview from Brussels that neither the United States nor Canada "would be bound to comply with the report."
The Administration would have to work closely with Congress on any changes in the dumping or subsidy procedures, and Mr. Kantor's comment was seen as an indication of the sensitivity of the issue in Congress. The agreement announced today also included a statement by all three countries that the pact did not cover Canada's water resources and that Canada could not be forced to divert water resources to meet fresh-water needs of the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mickey Kantor, left, the United States trade representative, and his European Community counterpart, Sir Leon Brittan, at a news conference in Brussels. They said progress had been made on a range of issues. (Reuters) (pg. D17)

HEADLINE: Russia's Workers Pay Price As Military Industries Fade

SERIES: An Army Adrift -- Last of six articles

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OBNINSK, Russia

 BODY:
In the 1940's, the secret ministry charged with developing the Soviet atomic bomb took over the tiny village of Obninsk. About 65 miles southwest of Moscow, it was close enough to be central, but far enough away not to endanger the capital and the Soviet leadership in the event of a nuclear accident.
Today, what is now called the Russian Atomic Energy Ministry remains in effect the owner of Obninsk. The main city square of what has become a well-kept city of 120,000 features an electronic sign that shows the time, the temperature and the radiation level. 
 The city contains 12 military research institutes and a single factory, Signal, which makes instruments for nuclear reactors and some circuit boards for Polaroid cameras.
 
Almost the Only Employer
 Other than a few service jobs, there is almost no other source of employment in Obninsk, one of at least 74 cities in Russia where more than 80 percent of the workers are employed by military industry.
"There's nothing else here," said Anatoly V. Zrodnikov of the Institute of Physics and Power Engineering here, adding with a chagrined smile, "They told us we were an elite and set for life."
But the abrupt collapse of the Soviet Union, with its centralized economy and bloated military budget, has hit cities like Obninsk very hard, prompting layoffs, lower salaries and sharply reduced standards of living. Economic chaos and the drastic decrease in state financing have forced big enterprises and research complexes like the Institute of Physics and Power Engineering here to look for new, civilian products and markets -- a process known as conversion.
Since 1989, Government spending on arms and military equipment has fallen 78 percent in real terms, said Albert F. Trifonov of Russia's Committee for Defense Industries. Spending on military research and development has dropped almost as much. The Government talks of financing conversion through arms sales. But that appears wholly unrealistic while making the West very nervous.
For all the talk about conversion since 1989, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was then the Soviet President, embraced it as an easy answer to demands for consumer goods, there has been precious little of it, Russian and Western officials say. Even here, the Polaroid Corporation's subassembly shop, which began in 1989 and makes a million circuit boards a year, employs only 120 people within the Signal factory, which employs 5,000.
Polaroid's managing director for the Commonwealth of Independent States, George Marquart, says the Cambridge, Mass., company is happy with the quality of the boards, which compare favorably with those Polaroid makes in Mexico and China. In a separate plant near Moscow, Polaroid assembles 60,000 instant cameras a year and sells them all in the former Soviet republics.
But Mr. Marquart knows that Polaroid alone cannot save Signal, let alone Obninsk. "With the drop in building nuclear power plants, Signal's business has suffered badly," he said. "Any project that keeps 120 people employed full-time is very helpful to them."
The breakdown of Soviet manufacturing has been magnified in the once-pampered military industry, which accounted for at least 60 percent of Soviet industrial production and was the backbone of the Soviet claim to be a modern superpower. Military factories had more intricate and hierarchical ties among themselves than their purely civilian counterparts, and they retain an even more distorted notion of the market.
 
Cutting Back
Capital Is Needed As Jobs Are Lost
 In Novosibirsk, a city of 1.5 million people in Siberia, 1,900 miles from Moscow, nearly 80 percent of industry has been tied to the military. At the Oxide factory, which makes capacitors, 70 percent of production was military, mostly for anti-tank weapons. Suddenly it is only 5 percent of current production, which is also down, said Oxide's director, Ivan S. Anichkin, who is furious about the cuts.
The 5,000-member work force has been cut in half. "We've tried to minimize our losses, but we have no money for research or big investments into new products," he said. "We try to get credits from this Government, but it's too expensive and short-term."
Yevgeny N. Kondratenko works for the Lenin Instrument Factory in Novosibirsk, designing optics. "The generals make sure they get good salaries for themselves," he said, using the workers' word for the bosses of these military enterprises. "But there's very little work. We do something. We're just polishing instruments now. We need new inventions or modernization, and that takes capital."
Salaries have been delayed up to three months, he said.
Galina Kondratenko, his wife, broke in to say: "Can you imagine? Three months! How hard that is for the families!"
Mikhail B. Podolsky, who worked on conversion as a designer for the huge Chkalov Aircraft Enterprise, which makes Sukhoi fighters, said that at first, "people didn't take conversion seriously."
 
Finally 'It Wasn't a Joke'
 "It all seemed very far from us, just another crazy idea from Moscow," he said. "Then they stopped buying our airplanes, and it wasn't a joke."
Chkalov, which employs about 100,000 people in 50 different shops, always made some consumer goods, from lounge chairs to small boats and toys. "Everything was of low quality," Mr. Podolsky said. "But there was such a deficit of consumer goods, everything sold. Today it's all different, with imported goods and competition. But only when consumers stopped buying did they think about making the products better."
At Chkalov, too, no salaries were paid for several months at a time, and traditional bonuses have disappeared.
Some factories and institutes have made real efforts to find a niche in the consumer market. Chkalov, for instance, is building a new 28-passenger civilian plane, the AN-38, for local airlines and cargo. Still, the work force there is down 30 percent, real salaries are down by the same percentage, the third shift is gone, and the second is almost idle.
 
Some Don't Try to Convert
 But many more factories, like Oxide, have not even tried to convert and have instead lobbied the Government for cheap credits, new state orders and a bigger effort to sell arms in a shrinking international marketplace.
With the huge reductions in military spending, especially in the last two years, most managers now see the writing on the wall, said Gennadi B. Kochetkov, director of the Center for Conversion and Privatization.
Russia's Committee for Defense Industries says that by far the biggest cuts in government arms spending were in 1992, when spending on arms procurement fell 68 percent compared with 1991, while spending on research and development was cut by 50 percent.
"Conversion only became real in 1992, when there were real reductions in state orders and funding," Mr. Kochetkov said. "It was only then that U.S.S.R. Inc. was really destroyed."
 
Mixed Feelings in West
 These developments both comfort Western Governments and concern them. When the Soviet military operation employed up to 7 million people at 5,000 separate sites concentrated in Russia and Ukraine, the West regarded the Soviet military-industrial complex as a nearly permanent threat.
But given the paucity of successful conversion, the West worries that some of Russia's most advanced weapons will be sold to the wrong countries or that Russia's top scientists may become more susceptible to selling their knowledge to countries like Libya, North Korea and China.
The concerns about proliferation, in particular about sales of advanced rocket engines to India, quiet submarines and civil nuclear technology to Iran and surface-to-air missiles and advanced fighters to China, have strained relations between Washington and Moscow.
Still, as the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, testified in July to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Washington has detected "neither the sale or transfer of significant nuclear material nor the sale or transfer of the weapons themselves." And while delays in pay, deteriorating working conditions and uncertain futures are spurring some Russian scientists to emigrate, they far prefer the West.
"Washington worries about proliferation, but a lot of Western firms want to buy our technology cheaply by hiring our personnel," said Viktor M. Murogov, director of the Obninsk Institute of Physics and Power Engineering. "Rather than invest in cooperation with us, they want to buy a person and squeeze out his knowledge."
 
Making Do
Conversion Is Difficult
 Mr. Murogov's Institute, with 8,000 employees, is doing research in fast-breeder reactors, which use weapons-grade plutonium as fuel, leaving less harmful waste products with a shorter radioactive life. It has developed small reactors to power spacecraft, a technology in which America is years behind. As part of its own conversion efforts, it has identified and is exploiting a large Western market for radioactive isotopes, used in cancer diagnosis and treatment. It has also developed a sophisticated ceramic filter for milk, derived from one for nuclear coolant.
Mr. Murogov has high hopes for these products. But what interests him the most is an efficient fast-breeder reactor that will find a safe end for the world's growing stockpile of plutonium.
The institute has received 1 billion rubles in state conversion loans to develop 24 ideas for new products. The percentage of his research budget going to military work has fallen from 40 percent in 1988 to 20 percent today.
Like other directors of huge Russian enterprises, Mr. Murogov finds his business weighted down with the residue of socialism, including responsibility for the housing, recreation and health care of his employees. The institute still builds 100,000 square feet of housing each year for its workers, who get to keep the apartments even if they quit. Twenty percent of a tight budget still goes for social spending that municipalities or individuals would pay for in the West.
Mr. Murogov tries to use these perquisites to keep good people. Of the 6,000 scientists who work for him, about 500 are top scholars, he said, and about 60 or 70 are elite specialists. "Even for them, the scientific backbone of this place, the salary level today is much lower than comfort level," Mr. Murogov said. The average monthly salary is 45,000 rubles, about $40; top specialists make between 80,000 and 100,000 rubles a month, less than $100.
The problems of Mr. Murogov's institute are written larger at factories run by less sophisticated managers.
One of these is the Malyshev tank factory in Kharkiv, in Ukraine, which has had no orders for tanks since March 1992 and which turned to making motorcycles instead. It also makes fire engines for oil fires out of tanks, by putting a water cannon and big hose where the gun turret would normally be and painting it red. Malyshev has not found its market yet, though. It is losing money on its civilian products and is being kept afloat by cheap state credits.
The Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, described the travails of Severodvinsk, due north of Moscow near the Barents Sea. "It's a one-company town," he said. "They have a 30,000 work force. They produce atomic-powered submarines, but they're not needed any longer. What is to be done about the town? What sort of market will save it? Does anyone have a solution? No. You may haul me over the coals about it, but it takes time and immense investments to change anything, to convert the plant to new product lines."
Many other factories are even in a worse situation because they made components for end products they never saw. "There are plants in the middle of nowhere with settlements around them, but the plant produces nothing finished, only a half-fabricated something that it supplies to some other settlement," Mr. Kochetkov said. "Now they're faced with a free market and find they have nothing to sell, and no very good ideas about what to make or how to find new investment with which to make it."
The Soviet Union simply remained an industrial economy on the 19th-century model for too long, Mr. Kochetkov said, even in the vaunted military sector. "Obviously we need to move to a post-industrial society."
Managers must learn to do what centralized ministries did for them -- to make decisions. "That's the real conversion," he said.
 
Gearing Up
How Much Will Be Saved?
 In the face of all these difficulties, Andrei A. Kokoshin, the First Deputy Defense Minister, has been working to identify the factories and institutes that will constitute the core of the military-industrial complex. These would get priority in state financing or simply remain state-owned.
In an interview, he singled out the continued development of strategic nuclear forces, electronic surveillance and world-class and salable technologies. It is important, he said, to identify military manufacturers able to sell their products abroad for hard currency, as a way to help finance conversion programs for less vital enterprises.
"One of the prime objectives of the Defense Ministry," he said, "is to make sure that in the long run Russia will maintain its proper place in the international hierarchy of arms manufacturers."
Mr. Trifonov, of the Committee for Defense Industries, also emphasized the state's role in organizing conversion and financing it through arms sales. Only some 110 factories and 600 research institutes and design bureaus will remain completely state-owned, he said, but they will be integrated better. The rest of more than 2,000 key military-industrial enterprises will be turned into shareholding companies in which the state will probably retain a voting majority of shares, but some will also be privatized. Through June, however, only 111 such enterprises had been privatized.
"We cannot experiment with the economy as an academic exercise, as if we were sticking a frog with an electrode and watching it jerk around without any special feeling for the creature," Mr. Trifonov said. "We don't need any more illusions; we've been fed enough of those all our lives."
 
Arms Sales an Illusion
 But the idea of increased arms sales to pay for conversion is another illusion. In 1992, Russia sold only $1.3 billion in arms, according to the Congressional Research Service, or $2.7 billion according to Mr. Kokoshin. Even doubled, that barely begins to pay the costs of conversion for an estimated 15,000 military-related industries.
While conversion in general has so far been a failure, there have been some successes. In St. Petersburg, Impuls, which makes military communications, is producing microwave ovens; in Podolsk, they stopped making rifles and concentrate on sewing machines.
The Kazan Helicopter Manufacturing Association is stressing overseas civilian sales and international air-certification. The association makes durable MI-8 and MI-17 helicopters and is developing the MI-38, which will lift a payload of six tons. It has added 345 workers to its more than 10,000 employees, and now has its own marketing department.
The Tula Shtamp factory, which made shells for salvo systems like the Grad rocket launcher, is producing samovars, fire extinguishers, radiators, grills and gas stoves.
"In almost every case," Mr. Trifonov said, "there is something for these factories to do. Of course, it's usually simpler than before. But a factory that made space vehicles can still take pride in making surgical tools precisely and well."
But Russia is a long way from having a real market. Most companies still are producing what they can, rather than what consumers -- Russian or otherwise -- might want or buy. Peter Almquist, a military-industry specialist, has said conversion thus remains "technology push" rather than "demand pull."
 
Exodus to Private Industry
 With the difficulty of profitable conversion and the strong probability that the Russian military sector will continue to shrink, more and more young scientists and engineers are leaving for private industry. Ivan P. Matveyenko, the chief of the Obninsk institute's experimental nuclear laboratory, said he had lost 20 percent of his scientists, half of them young, because of low salaries. "Half of them I don't mind losing," he said. "But to lose the other half is a problem. They're some of our brightest."
He himself, one of the top scientists in the country, makes $100 a month. "Ridiculous, isn't it?" he said.
But what may be bad for the military sector is likely to benefit the civilian one, as some of the most enterprising managers, scientists and workers move to the regular economy. Such spontaneous conversion is likely to hasten the collapse of the Russian military industry, shorn of its special status, much of its financing and, perhaps most important, its traditional priority access to resources at state subsidized prices.
The result, Mr. Almquist suggested, is likely to be "a significantly smaller Russian defense industry" of perhaps one-third its former size and devoted almost exclusively to military production, with an important focus on hard-currency exports. The rest of the military sector, stripped of its best parts by market-minded managers, will either go bankrupt or turn to civilian products.
Two years ago, Mr. Kochetkov said, most managers of military enterprises said they could not possibly degrade their talents and start making spoons and knives. "But now they realize they need the market," he said. "Now they say, 'We'll make anything -- just give us some orders.' "
 
The Soviet Breakup Leaves an Army Adrift

HEADLINE: U.N. Agency Finds No Assurance On North Korean Atomic Program

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency declared for the first time today that there was no longer any "meaningful assurance" that North Korea was using its nuclear materials solely for peaceful purposes, adding pressure on the Clinton Administration to reach a diplomatic accord with the North in the next several weeks or move to economic sanctions.
At the opening of a meeting of the agency's board of governors in Vienna, Hans Blix, the agency's director general, stopped just short of saying that the inspection process had totally broken down because of the North's refusal to allow regular inspections. But his aides made it clear that he was ready to make such a declaration by the end of the month, a step that officials in Washington and Seoul have said would mean sanctions. 
 Mr. Blix's comments came as the Communist Government in Pyongyang accused the Clinton Adminstration and the director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, of "intending to push the situation on the Korean peninsula to the brink of war." The statement, monitored in Tokyo, was apparently in response to comments Mr. Woolsey made on Tuesday that the North Korean Government might not be bluffing when it says it would go to war rather than bend to Western pressure on opening its nuclear plants.
 
Declaration Delayed
 Officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency have said in recent days that Mr. Blix, under some pressure from Washington, Tokyo and Seoul, is postponing a formal declaration that the agency can no longer track nuclear material in North Korea. The delay is intended to give the Administration a few more weeks to seek a diplomatic solution.
"We are really walking the precipice," an agency official said today. "We want to give the political process one more chance, though."
As recently as Wednesday, North Korea's first Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Kang Sok Ju, sent a message to Mr. Blix assuring him that North Korea "totally froze the movement of nuclear material" some time ago, and that "the inspection cameras and seals of the I.A.E.A. remain on the nuclear facilities of our new country."
But Mr. Blix said today that "in the absence of verification, such statements offer little assurance."
In the message, Mr. Kang offered to allow inspectors to visit North Korea for the limited purpose of installing new batteries and film in surveillance cameras. But Mr. Blix rejected a similar proposal a month ago, saying that the inspectors must have the freedom to roam and seek evidence of diversions of material to weapons projects.
Virtually all of the cameras and other suveillance equipment installed at the nuclear site at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of the North Korean capital, have now run out of film and battery power, making it possible for North Korea to slip material past the cameras.
 
Trying for More Time
 A senior South Korean official, speaking on condition of anonymity, acknowledged that his country was trying to lower the political heat so that North Korea did not feel trapped. "We are trying to get some more time," he said.
Mr. Blix has repeatedly said that inspection is a "process" that worsens gradually, the longer that inspectors are kept at bay. Today he said that the inspection system could be "fully or partially restored, if cooperation were forthcoming" from the North Koreans.
If the North is pursuing an agreement, however, it is hardly obvious in its public comments. In recent days the Government, in statements monitored in Tokyo, has denounced the United States and warned that it was ready to face sanctions or war rather than back down.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
President Expresses Hope
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Clinton expressed hope today that North Korea would "crawl back off this ledge they are on" in refusing to permit inspection of their nuclear installations. But he said a buildup of American military forces remained an strategy he could still employ to counter moves by the North.
In a series of interiews, Mr. Clinton expressed deep frustration about North Korea's instransigence. He also sought to allay concerns that the United States might be moving toward an imminent military confrontation.
But with the Pentagon weighing options to strengthen United States and South Korean forces if the standoff turns more tense, Mr. Clinton told NBC News in an interview tonight that he would not exclude the possibility of dispatching American reinforcements.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Progress on many world trade issues was reported by negotiators for the United States and the European Community, which could soon lead to a GATT agreement. The biggest gains were in agriculture, where France's objections to lowering subsidies have wounded relations with Washington. [Page A1.] 
 Canada will drop its opposition to Nafta's coming into force on Jan. 1 after receiving American concessions. The Canadians had sought side agreements with the United States chiefly to address the enforcement of rules for fair trade. [D1.]
The disintegration of the Soviet military has hurt many cities throughout Russia that once thrived by providing arms and technical support. Their residents are now suffering layoffs, lower salaries and reduced standards of living. [A1.]
 
The Economy
November retail sales growth was disappointing, hurt by bad weather and a midmonth drop-off in consumer demand. The news set an ominous tone as retailers headed into the holiday shopping season. [D1.]
Personal income rose 0.6 percent in October and consumer spending rose 0.8 percent, the seventh straight gain. But home sales dropped after a huge leap in September. [D2.]
The economic cost of depression in America is $43.7 billion a year, equal to heart disease, a new study says. [A25.]
 
Companies
Volvo abandoned a merger with Renault amid opposition from shareholders and a management revolt that prompted Volvo's chairman to resign. Many in Sweden viewed the deal as a low-price sellout of one of the nation's industrial gems. [D1.]
The Times Mirror Company president, David Laventhol, who is also publisher of The Los Angeles Times, will step down at the beginning of 1994. He has Parkinson's disease. [D1.]
Sony's co-founder and chairman, Akio Morita, suffered a cerebral hemorrhage and will withdraw from company activities and as a calmer of Japanese-American trade tension. [D2.]

Ornda Healthcorp will merge with Summit Health in a $369 million deal creating the third-largest hospital chain. [D3.]
Merry-Go-Round dismissed nine merchandising executives and took a $35.1 million charge for excess inventory. [D3.]
Barneys New York's women's fashion merchandise manager, Connie Darrow, resigned to join Prada in Milan. [D3.]
The big networks were closely bunched in the November sweep ratings, with NBC showing particular improvement. [D5.]
Long Island Lighting will seek to freeze electric rates for 1995 and 1996. Its costs are falling. [B1.]
 
Markets
Stocks closed slightly higher in a lackluster session. The Dow industrial average rose 5.03 points, to 3,702.11. Investors appeared cautious in advance of November employment data today. [D6.]
Buyers welcomed Marriott bonds, apparently forgetting the jolt the company gave bondholders last year. [D14.]
Oil fell below $15 a barrel, a five-year low, on improved prospects for a one-time Iraqi sale. [D13.] The dollar slipped. [D13.]

Wall Street sees biotechnology stocks as among the most enticing though risky investments, with the current round of stock offerings providing a window of opportunity. Market Place. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Russia Election: Some Rah-Rah, No Sis-Boom-Bah

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Russia's precipitate election campaign entered its home stretch today with blocs led by two old-time reform rivals leading the pack, but with a large clump of voters still undecided or altogether uninterested.
Today was the last day that public-opinion polls could be published before the Dec. 12 election for a new Parliament, and they showed that Russia's Choice, led by Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar and tacitly backed by President Boris N. Yeltsin, still holds a commanding lead. 
 But they also showed Mr. Gaidar's strongest rival to be a bloc led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a pioneering economic reformer who shares most of Mr. Gaidar's goals but has been excluded from Mr. Yeltsin's Government since the Soviet Union fell apart. One of Mr. Yavlinsky's running mates is Vladimir P. Lukin, the Russian Ambassador to Washington.
 
The Ins vs. the Outs
 The difference between the two blocs is largely one of personality, plus the fact that Mr. Gaidar, 37, and many other Russia's Choice candidates are government officials, while Mr. Yavlinsky, 41, is the critical outsider.
Mr. Yavlinsky first came to notice as the co-author of the "500-Day Plan" of radical economic reforms that he prepared in 1990 for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was then the Soviet President and who eventually shelved it. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Mr. Yeltsin bypassed Mr. Yavlinsky and tapped Mr. Gaidar as his chief economic adviser.
Whatever their personal differences, the two men's strength in the polls pointed to a Parliament in which deputies supporting fundamental economic change should have a solid block of seats. But there is no telling whether the former rivals will join forces or whether they will be able to mount a working majority.
Mr. Yavlinsky has said he will join with Mr. Gaidar, but only if Mr. Gaidar "acknowledged his mistakes." Mr. Yavlinsky has also publicly declared his candidacy for president, once an election is set.
 
The 5 Percent Hurdle
 Only two other parties or blocs seem poised to clear the 5 percent threshold to gain seats in the State Duma, the lower house of the Federal Assembly. They are the Russian Communist Party and the Democratic Party of Russia, the latter a centrist organization led by a charismatic former construction boss named Nikolai I. Travkin.
A cluster of other groups, including Women of Russia and two reformist blocs, seem to be just below the 5 percent threshold and could clear it.
Under the election rules, half the 450 seats in the lower house will be filled by parties that receive more than 5 percent of the vote; the other half will be deputies elected individually across the Russian Federation. The upper house, the Federation Council, will be composed of two deputies elected in each of the 88 constituent regions.
According to figures compiled by the newspaper Segodnya, if current poll ratings were translated into seats, Mr. Gaidar's bloc would get 102 and Mr. Yavlinsky's 71, followed by 26 each for the Communists and the Democratic Party. But the leanings of the other 225 deputies will not become known until the lower house meets, and experience has showed that deputies elected locally are likely to be conservative.
 
An Improvised Air
 Of 3,333 candidates seeking seats in the lower house, 57 percent come from government structures of one kind or another, 15.5 percent are lawyers or entrepreneurs and 6 percent were deputies in the disbanded Congress.
Even the major blocs are for the most part hastily convened alliances, not political parties in the Western sense. Once elected, deputies are certain to regroup into new alliances.
The most authoritative poll, by the Russian Center for the Study of Public Opinion, found that 26.3 percent of voters are still undecided and 12.3 percent do not intend to vote.
Many commentators and politicians expressed concern about apathy, especially for the new constitution. Under the rules, at least half of the 106 million registered voters must cast ballots for the constitution to ratify it.
In any case, many Russians seemed taken aback by their first exposure to a real bare-knuckle campaign, replete with catchy slogans, image manipulation, grappling for television time, lavish promises and even dirty tricks.
By American standards it is fairly primitive stuff. Many candidates use government-allocated television time simply to read long statements into a bare microphone. Arguing against private land ownership, for example, a candidate from the conservative Agrarian bloc described how fishermen would suddenly find their fishing grounds surrounded by fencing and -- worse -- owned by a foreigner.
Even the more sophisticated efforts to shape an image often seem crude. This evening Konstantin Zatulin, a businessman running in Deputy Prime Minister Sergei M. Shakhrai's Party of Russian Unity and Accord, interspersed his monologue on television with shots of himself praying in church or dancing with Cossacks.
Nonetheless, for the first time in Russia's tortuous political history, candidates were demonstrating an appreciation of the power of television and image.
 
Polishing Images
 Posters of Mr. Gaidar showed him in a pensive pose over the legend: "Others talk about it. He does it." Mr. Yavlinsky, for his part, combined his name and those of his top running mates into the acronym "Yabloko," Russian for apple, and learned to tame his unruly hair and to slow his speech for the cameras.
Though Russians have voted many times now, previous ballots have been either staid ideological affairs or skirmishes in a bigger power struggle, with little real campaigning. This has been the first election in which rival blocs and parties have taken their messages to the nation.
But most candidates agree that this is not yet a full-fledged democratic election.
For one thing, it was called by President Yeltsin in September when he disbanded -- ultimately with tanks -- the Congress of People's Deputies, a cumbersome and conservative mass of 1,000 representatives left over from Soviet days. The new Federal Assembly was designed by decree, and Mr. Yeltsin limited it to a two-year term.
The legislature, moreover, is being elected at the same time that the electorate is being asked to endorse the constitution under which it will work. The constitution itself has become an issue in the campaign, especially after several candidates sharply attacked it on television.
Aides to Mr. Yeltsin bridled at the attacks. Earlier this week the Press Minister, Vladimir F. Shumeiko, actually urged that two parties be banned for campaigning against the draft. The request was quickly rejected by the election commission.
Mr. Yeltsin himself has generally stayed out of the campaign, but he quickly let it be known that he would fight for the constitution.
"It is unpleasant that certain of you have started criticizing the constitution," he warned leaders of major blocs at a meeting in the Kremlin. "I have to warn you that free air time will be turned off if you stray from the theme, and your theme is your campaign program. We will fight for the constitution. I ask that you not touch it."
Beyond that, Mr. Yeltsin has positioned himself above the fray, though his backing for Russia's Choice, which groups many of his top ministers and lieutenants, is obvious.
 
Yeltsin's Low Profile
 Some politicians, including several close to Mr. Yeltsin, have criticized his aloofness and his failure in two and a half years as President to form a party. But "party" is still a word that connotes the Communist tyranny to many Russians, and they still seem to expect their President to be at least nominally "above politics."
The haste with which Mr. Yeltsin called the election has been repeatedly evident. It was only this week, for example, that the President announced where the new Parliament would sit.
The lower house, he said, will be in the former East European Economic Community high-rise adjacent to the White House, which was the headquarters of the Congress; the upper chamber would be in the House of the Russian Press, a contemporary building several miles away.
One of the first tasks of the new Parliament will be to finally retire the venerable hammer and sickle, which the former Congress refused to abandon as the state badge. Mr. Yeltsin has proposed a revival of the Imperial Russian double-headed eagle, replete with three crowns, orb and scepter.

He was greeted by a supporter at a rally in Moscow; Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economic reformer, leads a rival bloc. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: 5 Die in Gunman's Rampage in 2 California Cities

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OXNARD, Calif., Dec. 2

 BODY:
A man with a shotgun and pistol opened fire without warning today in a state unemployment office here, killing three people and wounding four others. He then shot dead a police officer who was pursuing him in traffic, before being killed by the police in a fusillade outside a second unemployment office.
About 50 people, including women and children, were in the unemployment office in this city 60 miles northwest of Los Angeles about 11:40 this morning when the gunman walked in with his weapons concealed in a brown bag, said David Keith, a spokesman for the Oxnard Police Department. 
 Oxnard police identified the gunman as Alan Winterbourne, a 33-year-old computer science graduate who had been unemployed for at least five years and who ran unsuccessfully for Congress in the 1990 Republican primary.
Liz Smith, a woman who was in the office at the time, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that the gunman had rested his gun on a counter and opened fire without warning. "There was no argument; not one word did he say," she said.
 
Singled Out Employees
 She said Mr. Winterbourne appeared to single out employees of the office and to avoid clients. All three of the dead and all but one of the wounded were employees, Mr. Keith said.
The gunman apparently made no statements and left no notes, and the authorities said tonight that they knew of no motive for the shootings.
One of the wounded, who was not identified, remained in grave condition tonight, said Rita Lowery, a spokeswoman for the Ventura County Medical Center in the city of Ventura.
After the shootings, Mr. Winterbourne fled but became trapped in traffic, at which point he left his car and fatally shot a pursuing officer, James O'Brien, with a shotgun, Mr. Keith said. He then drove to the unemployment office in neighboring Ventura, where he again left his car, shotgun in hand, and was shot to death by officers.
A political gadfly, Mr. Winterbourne had received 14.4 percent of the vote in the 1990 Republican Congressional primary. He was defeated by the incumbent, Representative Robert J. Lagamarsino, in the state's 19th Congressional district.
A woman who answered the telephone at the address Mr. Winterbourne gave when he registered as a political candidate said, "We have nothing to say at this time," and hung up.
 
Man of Many Petitions
 An unidentified neighbor told KNBC-TV news that Mr. Winterbourne was "real quiet and very political, and he always has had petitions going.
"There was one going for Earth Day," the neighbor said, "and one for a stop sign, and one for different organizations that he was speaking up for. He had a petition for almost everything."
The gunman's mother, Ila Winterbourne, appeared outside her home with a friend, Tom Olson, who read a statement on behalf the family, which includes a married sister and a nephew.
"They're devastated by the tragedy," Mr. Olson was quoted by The A.P. as saying. "None of them saw this coming. They're grieving for Alan as well as for the families of those who died and were wounded."
Dave Hall, the pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church, described Mr. Winterbourne was "a gentle man" and a pacifist who was active in charities.
The A.P. identified the dead as Richard Bateman, 65, of Ventura, who worked with an agency associated with the unemployment office; Phillip Villegas, 43, of Oxnard, an office supervisor; and a worker, Anna Velasco, 42, of Fillmore.
Among the wounded was Irma Lopez, 47, a supervisor at the unemployment office and the wife of the Mayor of Oxnard, Manuel Lopez.

HEADLINE: Morita, Sony Founder, Hospitalized

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Akio Morita, co-founder and chairman of the Sony Corporation and the leading statesman of Japan's business community, has suffered a cerebral hemorrhage that will force his withdrawal, at least temporarily, from company activities and from his increasingly prominent role as soother of trade tensions between the United States and Japan.
Sony officials said today that Mr. Morita had been taken to a Tokyo hospital Tuesday morning after feeling ill while playing tennis. His condition was diagnosed, and he underwent immediate surgery to remove blood from his brain. 
 The four-hour operation went well, and "his recovery is quite satisfactory," Tsunao Hashimoto, a deputy executive president at Sony, said at a hastily called news conference this afternoon. But he said it was too early to say when, or if, Mr. Morita could resume his business activities.
What was left unsaid is that it seems probable that the 72-year-old executive will be out for several months at least. Rumors were flying in the business world here that Mr. Morita, who built Sony into one of the world's most innovative companies, would have to retire.
 
Unable to Speak
 Mr. Hashimoto said there was no indication yet that Mr. Morita would step down. He said Mr. Morita, who is in intensive care, had not been able to speak, but could respond to his name by squeezing someone's hand.
Sony officials and analysts said that Mr. Morita had not been actively involved in day-to-day operations at Sony since 1989, when he became chairman and passed the presidency to Norio Ohga. For that reason, they said, there would be little immediate impact on the company. Sony's stock rose 70 yen today to 4,930 yen on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. On the New York Stock Exchange, where Sony stock trades in the form of American Depository Receipts, the issue closed up 12.5 cents at $45.125.
Still, Mr. Morita is what Mr. Hashimoto called the "psychological backbone" of Sony. And his absence comes as the giant company, with $34 billion in sales last year, is facing one of its toughest periods since he and a technical genius, Masaru Ibuka, started it in a bombed-out Tokyo department store in 1946.
Like other Japanese electronics companies, Sony is hurt by Japan's recession, the strength of the yen, which makes exporting more difficult, and a lack of hit products. And Mr. Ohga turns 64 next month, so it might not be too many years before the company undergoes another management transition.
Mr. Morita is also likely to be missed in the broader business and political arena, where he has been outspoken in urging Japanese businesses to cease some practices that are viewed as unfair in the West, and where his international outlook has helped calm relations between Japan and its trading partners.
 
A Business Statesman
 "He's been the leading Japanese business statesman on the world stage, and his inability to play that role will be a serious loss to Japan at one of the most critical times in its history," Norman P. Neureiter, director of Texas Instruments Japan Ltd., said.
Mr. Morita is the co-chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council, a group of executives from both sides of the Pacific that works to solve trade problems. He has also been considered a leading candidate to become chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying organization, when the current chairman, Gaishi Hiraiwa, retires next spring.
Mr. Ohga, Sony's president, met with Mr. Hiraiwa, this morning and said that Mr. Morita would be out for at least a month, according to Hideo Takahashi, an official in the secretary's division of Keidanren. Mr. Takahashi said Mr. Hiraiwa might delay naming his successor until more was known of Mr. Morita's condition.
Mr. Morita would be a somewhat unusual choice for Keidanren because he is still viewed by the Japanese business establishment as something of a maverick. Indeed, Mr. Morita, who is no doubt the most famous Japanese businessman outside of Japan, is more highly regarded abroad than in his home country.
 
A Two-Day Delay
 Sony officials waited two days after Mr. Morita's surgery to make the news public and spoke only after reports starting leaking into the press. Early reports said Mr. Morita had been hospitalized with a cold.
Mr. Hashimoto and other executives said the company wanted to wait until 48 hours after the operation in order to get a better sense of Mr. Morita's condition. They also said they wanted to inform Keidanren first. Others cited the wishes of Mr. Morita's family.
Sony officials said Mr. Morita maintained an active schedule and had shown no signs of problems before Tuesday. He had made eight trips abroad this year, including a three-and-a-half-week visit to the United States and Europe in October.
He played tennis about once a week at 7 A.M., and during one of these matches Tuesday morning he felt somewhat ill. He went home, and when he did not feel better was taken by ambulance to the Tokyo Medical and Dental University Hospital.
Under Mr. Morita, Sony achieved a reputation for marketing flair and consistent innovation, bringing out such products as the Trinitron television, the Walkman, the first consumer videocassette recorder and the compact disk. Mr. Morita has recently been urging the company to stick to developing new products to escape from its slump, Nobuyuki Idei, a Sony director, said.

HEADLINE: Japan Aide Ousted; He'd Criticized Arms Role

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
In a setback for the Japanese Government, the Defense Minister was forced to resign tonight after declaring that Japan's constitutional limitations on the use of military force are out of date and urging passage of an amendment to permit full participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations.
The resignation of Keisuke Nakanishi, the 52-year-old director general of Japan's Self-Defense Agency, underscores the intensity of the disagreements within the Government over Japan's expanding international role, especially at a time when the country is seeking a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council. 
 But it also reflects the fragility of the coalition Government headed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. Mr. Hosokawa, while declining to say whether he agreed with his Defense Minister or not, accepted the resignation when it became clear an argument over Mr. Nakanishi's comments could rip apart the coalition and derail his efforts to pass a political reform bill and an economic stimulus package.
Mr. Nakanishi is the first member of Mr. Hosokawa's Cabinet to be forced out of office. His offense lay in explicitly stating an opinion that is widely held, but seldom voiced, among conservative politicians in the Government and in the Liberal Democratic Party, which was forced out of office this year.
Mr. Nakanishi, in making his comments on Wednesday, said he was speakihg because "the environment has changed" and the topic was now open for discussion. That turned out to be a faulty assumption.
By American political standards, Mr. Nakanishi's comments would seem almost innocuous. At a reception on Wednesday night for members of his political party, the Shinseito, who led the rebellion that ousted the Liberal Democrats, Mr. Nakanishi suggested that the Constitution should explicitly permit Japanese participation in peacekeeping operations.
"I cannot help but think that it is inappropriate to cling with tremendous zeal to a Constitution written half a century ago," he told the group. "While we respect the spirit of the peace Constitution," he said, it must be reformed to "respond to reality."
Mr. Nakanishi was referring to Article 9 of the Constitution that was drafted by Gen. Douglas MacArthur when he commanded the American occupation forces in Japan. It declares that "the Japanese people forever renounce war as a sovereign right of a nation and the threat or use of force as a means of settling international disputes."
After more than a year of fierce argument, Japan passed legislation last year permitting the dispatch of peacekeeping troops under strict conditions, including prohibitions on engaging in any activity likely to get them involved in combat. The law was used to send 600 peacekeepers to Cambodia earlier this year, the first deployment of Japanese troops outside the country since World War II.
The Defense Minister was hardly the first Cabinet minister to express such views. In January, when the Liberal Democrats were in power, the Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, gave a series of speeches on the need for Japan's troops to take on a new role to "maintain global peace and order under the leadership of the United Nations." Breaking a four-decade taboo against discussing the topic, Mr. Watanabe called for a constitutional amendment.
After Mr. Nakanishi's remarks onWednesday night, the Socialists, who are members of the coalition but who have fiercely opposed any expansion of Japan's military role, immediately called for Mr. Nakanishi's resignation. Tomiichi Murayama, the head of the party, said the Socialists had extracted an agreement from Mr. Hosokawa not to bring up the divisive subject of constitutional revision.
Members of the Liberal Democratic Party, seizing the opportunity to embarrass Mr. Hosokawa, soon joined in and brought parliamentary debate on other matters to a halt. They charged that Mr. Nakanishi could not uphold the Japanese Constitution while disagreeing with its provisions. By early evening the coalition membership decided to oust Mr. Nakanishi rather than risk further delays that could threaten their legislative agenda.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
