HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror President Is Resigning

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The president of the Times Mirror Company and publisher of The Los Angeles Times, its flagship newspaper, will step down Jan. 1 because he is suffering from Parkinson's disease, the company announced today.
David Laventhol, 60, will be succeeded as publisher of The Times by Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, 49, a Times Mirror senior vice president who was responsible for the media company's Eastern dailies. 
 Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive of Times Mirror, will assume Mr. Laventhol's duties as president of Times Mirror.
 
 
New Position
 Mr. Laventhol was given the new position of Times Mirror editor at large, where he will work with the company's editors and executives on editorial content and news matters, particularly at the newspapers, the company said in a news release.
Telephone calls to Times Mirror officials seeking comment after the announcement here late this afternoon were not returned.
Mr. Laventhol's departure comes at a time when The Los Angeles Times is struggling to recover from a persistent advertising slump that has caused the paper to undertake job reductions and other measures to cut costs.
In the last year, The Los Angeles Times has pursued three employee reduction programs, ceased publishing its San Diego edition, and recently announced that it was seeking to sell its downtown Los Angeles headquarters, known as Times Mirror Square.
Some executives at The Los Angeles Times, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the medication that Mr. Laventhol takes causes him great fatigue and that he could not continue the duties of publisher. But some high-level editors at the paper suggested that the Times Mirror board was dissatisfied with Mr. Laventhol's performance and had replaced him.
Craig Silvers, an analyst who follows Times Mirror for Crowell, Weedon, said that Mr. Laventhol's departure was a surprise, but he praised the outgoing publisher for taking "the necessary steps to keep the paper afloat" during the recession.
Mr. Silvers said that Mr. Schlosberg was known as a "sharp operations man" and that his main challenge would be to keep the paper "treading water " and "to maintain adequate staffing levels."
Mr. Laventhol had been president of Times Mirror since 1987. He was editor of Newsday, the Times Mirror's daily based in Melville, L.I., from 1970 to 1978 and served as publisher of Newsday from 1978 to 1987. He previously worked at The Washington Post.
Mr. Laventhol was named publisher and chief executive of The Times in 1989, replacing W. Thomas Johnson Jr.
"Dave asked for the change for health reasons," Mr. Erburu said in a statement. "In his 23 years with the company, he has been a major contributor to the successful growth of Times Mirror. In his new role, we will continue to benefit from his skill and experience."
In a statement posted on The Times employee bulletin board, Mr. Laventhol said, "We have succeeded in countering the advertising decline with strong efforts on the cost side that have increased productivity and efficiency while protecting our core market and avoiding layoffs of full-time employees."
 
 
Poor Financial Performance
 During Mr. Laventhol's tenure, The Times expanded its reporting locally and internationally, introducing new editions and sections in the suburbs and the inner city and for Hispanic readers. But many of those successes were overshadowed by the paper's poor financial performance lately.
The company reported a 1992 loss of $66.6 million, with huge special charges for costs including staff cuts at The Times and Newsday.
Mr. Schlosberg, who becomes the seventh publisher of The Times, joined Times Mirror in 1983 as publisher and chief executive of The Denver Post. In 1988, he was named president of The Times, and in 1990 he became group vice president, newspapers, responsible for Times Mirror's five Eastern newspaper companies and chairman of Times Mirror newspaper management committee. In March 1993, Mr. Schlosberg was named senior vice president.
Before joining The Times, Mr. Schlosberg held executive positions with Harte-Hanks Newspaper Operations and newspaper companies in Corpus Christi, Tex., and Anderson, S.C. He is a graduate of the Air Force Academy and received an M.B.A. from Harvard University.

HEADLINE: A NEW U.S. STANCE ON ATOMIC WASTES

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Secretary of Energy said today that her department had a "moral obligation" to help electric utilities store spent fuel from nuclear reactors, even though the department could not keep its promise to take the fuel off their hands beginning in 1998.
In a sharp turnaround from the Bush Administration, which denied it had any responsibility for the waste, she said her department might cover the utilities' cost for storage. 
 Under contracts signed in the 1980's, the Energy Department has been collecting a waste disposal fee from utility companies amounting to a tenth of a cent per kilowatt hour generated in reactors. It has used about $3 billion in the search for a permanent waste repository but still has more than $4 billion on hand, and it is still collecting $600 million a month.
But no permanent repository will be ready until 2013 at the earliest, said the Energy Secretary, Hazel R. O'Leary, in an interview today. A temporary repository is possible, she said, but "we're not going to make it by 1998." The contracts call for the Government to begin pick-ups of the waste then.
 
Mostly Under Water Now
 During the Bush Administration, the Energy Department argued that the contracts did not require it to accept the wastes if it had no place to put them.
Most of the spent fuel is now stored in pools of water next to the reactor buildings, but at many plants these will be full by 1998. Water shields radiation and keeps the waste cool.
Some utilities have built "dry cask storage," concrete and steel casks sitting behind barbed wire near the reactors, and other companies have asked permission to build such casks.
But in several states, most notably Florida, Michigan and Minnesota, state public service commissions have complained that raising electric rates to cover the expense of building such structures amounts to a double charge to consumers for storage, since the companies have already paid the Energy Department.
"I don't think anybody is really pleased by that prospect," said Janice E. Owens of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, a Washington association of state officials that has been pressing the issue.
 
Paying Costs of Casks
 Mrs. O'Leary said she had directed her staff to find a mechanism by which the department could pay the cost of casks at reactor sites, beginning at the dates that the fuel would have been picked up. This might take the form of a credit against future waste fund payments, an aide said.
Mrs. Owens said another mechanism might be for the Energy Department to develop, manufacture and deliver to each reactor a container that would be used for storage for an interim period. The container would then be used for shipping the material to a permanent repository, she said, and would be the final package for the wastes.
The Energy Department is studying whether Yucca Mountain, in the desert outside Las Vegas, Nev., would be suitable as a permanent repository, but the study has been plagued with technical problems and political disputes.
Mrs. O'Leary said she was convinced that for reasons of security, safety and economy, a centralized storage site for the casks was preferable to cask storage at many different reactor sites.

HEADLINE: Costs of Depression Are on a Par With Heart Disease, a Study Says

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
The annual cost of depression in America is $43.7 billion, on a par with heart disease, according to a study made public yesterday.
About 11 million people suffer from depression in a given year, and for nearly two-thirds it goes undiagnosed and untreated, said the study, which was published in The Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 
 "What's striking is that the costs of depression are comparable to those for other major diseases," said the leader of the study, Paul Greenberg, a health economist at the Analysis Group, a business consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass. "In allocating resources as a society, we should consider depression as an important health problem, too."
Dr. Frederick Goodwin, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, said that among major diseases, clinical depression ranks second only to advanced coronary heart disease in the total number of days patients spend in the hospital or disabled at home. "Major depression is far more disabling than many medical disorders, including chronic lung disease, arthritis and diabetes," he said.
 
Tipper Gore's Comment
 The study shows that health insurance for mental illness is not a luxury or a frill, said Tipper Gore, the Vice President's wife, who advises President Clinton on the issue.
The greatest source of economic burden, accounting for more than half the total, comes from depression's impact on work performance, especially among those who receive no treatment. The cost of days lost from work is about $11.7 billion, and impairment from the symptoms while people continue on the job costs $12.1 billion more.
The impairments include poor concentration and memory, indecisiveness, fatigue, apathy and a lack of self-confidence -- and, in those with mania, a grandiose, unrealistic overconfidence. All these symptoms reduce people's capacity to work; on average, for those who are well enough to work, the report estimates that depression reduces a worker's output by 20 percent.
"Depression tends to strike people in the most productive phase of life, and the most productive people," Dr. Goodwin said.
When someone is depressed on the job it can also hamper co-workers, although the report did not include the costs of this effect in the estimates.
 
Burden on Employers Cited
 The costs of depression were calculated for 1990, the most recent year for which complete data are available. In that year 290 million working days were lost because employees' depression was so severe that they could not work at all, the report estimates.
"Because depression strikes early in life and is so often ongoing, depression imposes an especially large burden on employers," said Mr. Greenberg, the health economist.
Depression costs businesses an average of $3,000 for each depressed worker, the report said. A lot of money could be saved if there were more aggressive diagnosis and treatment of depression; treating depression shortens an episode by an average of one-third, the report estimates.
Suicides are another source of costs, because of the loss of lifetime earnings. In 1990 about 15,000 men and 3,400 women in the Untied States committed suicide because of depression, at a cost of about $7.5 billion, the report says.
Psychiatric care, including hospitalization, psychotherapy and medications, totaled $12.4 billion.
 
Hidden Costs Not Counted
 Dr. Goodwin said the report did not consider such hidden costs from depression as the cost of treatment for substance abuse or other problems deriving from the depression, or the cost of unnecessary medical tests ordered by doctors who mistake depression for other diseases.
"Most depressed people present their symptoms to a nonpsychiatrist, and only one in four of these physicians accurately diagnose the problem," Dr. Goodwin said. He suggested that workplace programs "focus as much on depression as they do now on substance abuse."
The report was prepared by a team led by Mr. Greenberg and Laura Stiglin of the Analysis Group, Dr. Stan Finkelstein of the Sloan School of Management and Ernst Berndt of the National Bureau of Economic Research.
The study was based on 1990 figures for the prevalence of three kinds of depression: major, minor and manic. Symptoms of major depression are severe enough to be debilitating. In addition to sadness, the symptoms include thoughts of worthlessness or self-blame, feelings of hopelessness, confusion and indecision, loss of appetite and insomnia, agitation or lethargy.
Symptoms of mild depression include a dour mood that lasts for months or years, a loss of interest in pleasures and any of the symptoms of major depression, though not at such an incapacitating level.
Manic depression, or bipolar disorder, is marked by periods of grandiosity and elation and bad judgment and agitation alternating with periods of deep depression; at its extreme, symptoms include brief psychosis.
Of the nearly 11 million Americans who suffered from depression in 1990, more than 5 million had major depression, about 1.8 million had bipolar disorder and about 4.1 million had mild depression, the report said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Panel Has Grim View Of Fiscal Gaps

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Sketching a grim portrait of New York City's fiscal condition, a panel appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins reported yesterday that the city's long-term budget problems were more severe than previously estimated.
The committee also outlined what it called a "menu" of Draconian and politically unpalatable measures -- including layoffs of city workers, fees for residential garbage collection, postponing of planned hiring of police officers, increases in the sales tax and in property taxes for single-family homeowners, and putting tolls on more East River bridges -- from which city officials could choose to achieve long-term budget balance. 
 "There's hardly a political third rail that we haven't touched," said one of the committee's members, Donald D. Kummerfeld, a former first deputy mayor and budget director, who presented the report at a City Hall news conference.
 
Tax Plan Rejected
 But Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani rejected the panel's proposal for tax increases and reiterated his pledge to phase out several business taxes including the hotel tax and the commercial rent tax to spur the local economy. He has proposed to help balance future budgets by cutting the city's work force and privatizing some city services.
He said the report reflected "a great deal of the economic planning of the prior administration and the economic philosophy of the prior administration."
The panel's main finding -- that the city is suffering from a fundamental imbalance, with the growth in expenditures far outstripping the growth in revenues -- was not new, nor were most of its recommendations.
But the bleakness of its analysis, combined with the specificity of its proposed solutions and the independent standing of its members, gave weight to the report, allowing it to serve as a kind of kickoff to the intense budget debate that will undoubtedly begin when Mr. Giuliani takes office next month.
The essential message of the 19-page report was that the city could no longer balance the budget each year with stopgap measures, as it has during the last four years of recession. Fundamental changes will be necessary, Mr. Kummerfeld said, or the city will eventually reach "a fiscal collision," leading to deficits, downgradings by bond-rating agencies and a state takeover of the city's finances.
"The economy isn't going to bail us out, unfortunately," Mr. Kummerfeld said, "and now we have to do these very tough things."
"The city is going to have to change the way it does business," he said at another point. "It's going to take leadership, it's going to take persistence, and it will hurt."
Mr. Dinkins was careful not to endorse any of the committee's specific proposals, saying it would be up to Mr. Giuliani to decide how to close the coming budget gaps. "I'm confident that Mr. Giuliani and his people will find this useful," the Mayor said of the report.
 
Underlying Imbalance
 The panel also included Dall W. Forsythe, a former state budget director, and William H. Gray 3d, a former Congressman who was chairman of the House Budget Committee. The panel was created by Mr. Dinkins in May, when he was under pressure from members of the State Financial Control Board and other fiscal experts, who contended that the Mayor had failed to confront the city's underlying budget imbalance. Mr. Dinkins asked the panel to propose ways to reach structural balance by saving about $2 billion a year through spending cuts and additional revenues. The city's budget this year is $31 billion.
The committee was scheduled to report to Mr. Dinkins on Dec. 1, a month after the mayoral election, which enabled the Mayor to avoid discussions of difficult budget decisions during the election campaign. The panel came to two initial determinations, deciding that the city's own estimates of future budget gaps were too low and concluding that there were very few city services that could simply be eliminated to help close those gaps.
Mr. Dinkins's budget office estimates that there will be a potential shortfall of $1.7 billion in the next fiscal year, which begins next July, and potential gaps of $2.5 billion, $2.7 billion and $3 billion in the following fiscal years.
But Mr. Kummerfeld's panel concluded that city officials were too confident about receiving certain state and Federal aid, and they calculated higher gaps than the Dinkins administration did. The committee estimated a shortfall of $2 billion in the next fiscal year, with gaps of $3.2 billion, $4.2 billion and $5 billion in succeeding years.
 
A Host of Remedies
 To prevent these shortfalls, the panel proposed a host of remedies, nearly all of which would involve sacrifice and virtually all of which would be politically difficult to achieve.
These were among several dozen recommendations on how the city could save money:
*Cutting the city work force, now about 214,000 people, to 185,000 -- a 14 percent reduction.
*Including teachers and police officers, who have been exempted from previous budget cutting, in the labor reductions.
*Eliminating city subsidies for day care and for private bus routes.
*Charging fees for residential garbage collection.
*Reducing city subsidies to municipal hospitals.
*Eliminating rent regulations and ending most city spending on housing construction.
The cuts in the city's labor force proposed by the panel are somewhat similar to those proposed during the mayoral campaign by Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani, who wants to trim the work force to 180,000, contends that it can be done through attrition and that city services do not have to be compromised if the remaining workers are more efficient.
 
Changes in Work Rules
 But the Kummerfeld panel asserted that layoffs would be unavoidable, in part because city managers must decide which jobs are to be eliminated. The group also determined that city managers will need much more flexibility -- changes in work rules, Civil Service regulations and contractual agreements -- to make the remaining workers more productive and to maintain services.
The committee acknowledged that some city services would suffer, but it also decided that there were few that realistically could be eliminated.
Mr. Kummerfeld and his colleagues on the panel said that even if the city took most of the budget-cutting actions that they recommended -- many of which would require approval by the City Council, the State Legislature and labor leaders -- the city would still have to raise some taxes and impose new fees to balance the budget over the next few years.
The committee recommended no changes in most corporate and commercial taxes because it said increases in those taxes could drive more companies from New York. But it proposed an extension of the surcharge on the personal income tax, which averages about five-tenths of 1 percent; an increase of one-quarter of 1 percent in the city sales tax, now 4 percent, and unspecified higher property taxes for one- and two-family homeowners, who, the report said, "do not pay their fair share of the property tax."
In a proposal likely to arouse much criticism, the panel also suggested that the city cancel plans to hire 1,175 new police officers in February, as it obligated to under the state law that created Mr. Dinkins's Safe Streets, Safe City program. The group also suggested having more patrol cars with only one officer, instead of two.

HEADLINE: Lilco Seeking A Rate Freeze In '95 and '96

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it would seek to freeze its rates for 1995 and 1996, a sharp departure from the increases that were anticipated as part of its agreement with the state to close the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.
Since that 10-year settlement was reached in 1989, the base electric rate here has gone up about 4 to 5 percent each year to allow Lilco to repay the $5.6 billion debt incurred in building the plant. Long Islanders have some of the highest electric bills in the nation, and utility costs have become one of the area's most pressing economic concerns. 
 Business leaders hailed Lilco's decision today.
"This is very significant news for the economic well-being of Long Island," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, the area's largest business group. "If the Public Service Commission grants Lilco's request, we will receive critical and well-timed assistance in our effort to keep Long Island competitive with other regions of the country."
 
4 Percent Rise for 1994
 Most people had expected that Lilco's base rate, which applies to both residential and commercial customers, would increase for the rest of the decade. Indeed, on Wednesday, a 4 percent increase, expected to bring Lilco an additional $85 million, went into effect for 1994.
And while Lilco's agreement with the state did not guarantee increases after the first three years, it did anticipate that such increases would be necessary.
Lilco said today that a number of conditions that were the basis for the projected increases had changed markedly. They included lower interest rates and oil costs, more purchases of cheaper power from outside Long Island and other regulatory and business considerations. Suzanne Halpin, a Lilco spokeswoman, said that a formal request for the rate freeze would be filed with the Public Service Commission later this month, and that it would include a request for a 4 percent increase in 1997.
"We want to let Long Islanders know that we can control rates and turn around the economy," Ms. Halpin said, estimating that the freeze would save Long Islanders roughly $250 million from the 5 percent increase that the utility could have requested.
While the Public Service Commission declined to comment on the request, experts said it would be extremely unusual for the panel to force a utility to raise its rates.
In some respects, Lilco's decision reflects a trend in the electric power industry. The market for electricity is becoming increasingly competitive because of the Energy Policy Act of 1992, which started to deregulate the industry by making it easier for independent power producers to sell energy outside their locality.
In response, many utilities have said that that to survive in this new environment, they will have to hold the line or even cut rates. Coincidentally, this point was made by several chief executives of utilities at the "One World of Energy" conference today at Rockefeller Center, sponsored by Chase Securities Inc.
 
Competition in Whole Industry
 This view was shared by Douglas W. Preiser, an electric utilities analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
"This is not a Lilco-specific trend," he said. "The entire industry is facing the same sort of pressures as Lilco is, and they're all trying to do the same sort of thing to avoid entering the rate arena and ask for increases.
"It's no secret that Lilco has one of the highest rates in the country, and if you're facing a competitive environment where someday larger customers may have a choice where they can get their power, it's in your interest to stem the growth in rates to prevent your customers from seeking another alternative. Plus the economy on Long Island is not so hot, so you don't want to be seen as a big part of the problem."
But while Mr. Preiser praised the rate freeze as a smart decision, he remained skeptical that it would substantially close the gap in electric rates between Lilco and the six other electric utilities in New York State.
 
New York State's Highest
 Figures from the state's Department of Public Service showed that on July 1, 1993, Lilco charged a household that used 500 kilowatt-hours a bill of $85.56, the highest of all the state's electric utilities. Next was Consolidated Edison at $82.48, with Orange and Rockland Utilities third at $75.66. All the rest were below $62.
Still, some people were more optimistic about the impact of the freeze, and argued that even deeper cuts were possible.
At a news conference today, Richard M. Kessel, the executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board and an architect of the Shoreham settlement, heralded the rate freeze as "the best energy news that Long Island has had in decades." But he added that Lilco's proposal did not go far enough.
Both the Consumer Protection Board and another agency Mr. Kessel directs, the Long Island Power Authority, which is responsible for decommissioning Shoreham, filed a petition today with the Public Service Commission for a three-year freeze in Lilco's rates, for 1995 through 1997 followed by a rate cut of one-half of 1 percent in each of the next two years.
 
Other Cuts Possible
 Furthermore, if the company wins its two lawsuits against local goverments regarding taxes on Shoreham, saves more than projected in its operations or substantially improves its sales, cuts could be possible sooner, Mr. Kessel added.
Mr. Kessel called the freeze a great opportunity for Lilco rates to catch up with some of the other rates in the state, as several other utilities, like Consolidated Edison, Rochester Gas & Electric Corporation and Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, are scheduled for rate increases over the next few years.
It is uncertain what other electric companies will do in response to Lilco's decision.
Mr. Kessel said that Lilco was not burdened by energy purchasing agreements, which require a company to buy excess energy from independent power producers at what are now high prices, as is the case for some of the other New York utilities.
The freeze was also possible, said Ms. Halpin, because Lilco refinanced its Shoreham debt with lower interest rates, saving about $160 million, as well as saving about $120 million by cutting the amount of energy generated by its oil-burning plants and relying more on natural gas. These two measures might not provide similar savings for other utilities.

HEADLINE: Consumers Spending At Fast Pace

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Americans continued spending liberally in October aided by a healthy rise in personal income, the Commerce Department said today.
The new data seemed to support the belief that the economy, experiencing an unusually slow recovery, has finally been gathering strength in the fourth quarter, partly because consumers are recovering their battered confidence. 
 Even a 6.5 percent decline in new home sales in October from September, when they surged 14.9 percent, did little to discourage the idea that fourth-quarter economic growth would meet or exceed 4 percent, up from 2.7 percent in the third quarter.
"We're calling this an expansion, not a recovery," said Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc.
 
Fewer Jobless Claims
 Further supporting that notion was the Labor Department's report today that the number of workers filing for unemployment benefits in the latest week fell by 17,000, to 321,000, the lowest level in two months.
The Commerce Department said personal income rose sixth-tenths of 1 percent in October, moving ahead for the third month in a row, following a revised one-tenth of 1 percent increase in September, bringing the seasonally adjusted annual rate to $5.47 trillion.
Consumer spending, the report said, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October -- the seventh straight monthly gain -- to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.47 trillion, following a revised four-tenths of 1 percent rise in September.
But because spending outpaced income gains, the savings rate fell in October, the Government said. Americans saved $177 billion in the month, down from $185 billion in September, a very low level that economists find disturbing.
And in a report reflecting more recent trends, major retail chains reported today that sales in November were tepid.
Personal income and spending are considered key indicators of consumers' ability to help fuel the economy. Consumer spending accounts for roughly two-thirds of the economy.
The October data follow other indications this week that Americans' economic confidence is rising.
The Conference Board reported that consumer confidence soared in November, with an 11-point rise in its monthly index to 71.2, the highest level since last January.
The group said consumers were more positive in their assessment of prevailing business conditions and "considerably more optimistic" in their future expectations.
 
Buying Cars and Houses
 At the same time, low interest rates on mortgages have convinced consumers to dig deep, raising sales of existing homes to a 14-year high in October. Analysts said the 6.5 percent decline in new home sales in October had been expected, following September's extremely strong and unsustainable increase.
"Home sales generally are on the upswing, one month it's new homes, the next month it's existing homes," said Mark Obrinsky of the Federal National Mortgage Association.
He said that the combined performance of new and existing home sales in October was the strongest since May 1979.
This generally coincides with the belief that Americans are making major purchases -- homes and cars -- that they put off for years, worried about the outlook for jobs and fearing that houses were not the lucrative investment they once were.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips Against Mark, But Advances on the Lira

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark yesterday despite signs that the German central bank might cut interest rates. But it reached an eight-year high against the Italian lira.
Gold prices, meanwhile, rose overseas but fell in New York. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for December delivery lost $1 an ounce, closing at $373.80. 
 Traders said the dollar fell against the German mark after the German central bank did not lower its most important interest rates at its meeting yesterday. The dollar later recovered some lost ground as the Bundesbank dropped the rate on securities-repurchase agreements to 6 percent from 6.25 percent.
 
 
'Still Accommodating'
 "It basically showed they're still accommodating in terms of monetary policy," said Hubert Pedroli, manager of foreign exchange at Credit Suisse in New York.
The repurchase rate is the central bank's principal tool for influencing money market rates.
A cut in German interest rates would reduce the return on mark-denominated investments, and could thereby reduce demand for the mark, driving its price lower.
In New York, the dollar ended at 1.7225 marks, down from 1.7235 marks on Wednesday.
Traders said the market had little reaction to positive data on United States consumer spending and personal income in October, which were in line with economists' expectations.
The dollar edged up to 108.90 Japanese yen in New York from 108.80 yen.
The dollar also continued to soar against the Italian lira. The dollar reached 1,736 lire by the end of the day. The American currency had ended at 1,719.00 lire a day earlier.
 The Federal Reserve intervened, apparently on behalf of the Italian central bank, to stop the lira's plunge, traders said. The American central bank bought lire and sold marks, the currency that trades most with the lira.
Zlatko Glamuzina, chief trader for the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, said the lira was falling in advance of local runoff elections Sunday that are seen as foreshadowing general elections next year.
The former Communist Party and the neo-Fascists scored strongly in the first round last month.
"If you have marginal parties running the country, how well can they run it?" asked Mr. Glamuzina. "It doesn't inspire confidence."

HEADLINE: A New Temple For Egyptian Art

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
WHEN the Brooklyn Museum first opened its doors in 1897, it was a long and lonely Beaux-Arts shoe box. Judging from vintage photographs, it must have looked extremely odd: it lacked the prominent entrance usual to the Beaux-Arts style, and it stood out starkly against its low-lying, surprisingly rural background. (A chicken farm was next to it.)
But that narrow shoe box was only the first installment in a master plan designed by the New York architects McKim, Mead & White. As the museum expanded east over the next three decades, the West Wing, as the original building came to be called, became just part of a much larger structure in which it played an ever-decreasing role. By the mid-1970's, when the museum completed its last expansion, the original five-story shoe box had become merely the shabby tail of a very large dog. 
 Now, after seven years of planning, fund-raising and construction, the completely redesigned West Wing is leading the Brooklyn Museum into its second century with three floors of exceptional new galleries. Fully opened to the public for the first time today, these galleries complete the first installment of a new master plan that was devised in 1986 by the architects Arata Isozaki & Associates, based in Tokyo, and James Stewart Polshek & Partners of New York.
While the top floor of the wing opened in the fall of 1992 with exhibition space for postwar contemporary art, the two floors below have just been finished. One holds temporary exhibition galleries, the other is a spectacular home for part of the museum's famous collection of Egyptian art. These three floors of splendidly refurbished and modernized galleries provide 30,000 feet of exhibition space with such up-to-the-minute technical support as the museum's first climate-control system.
This first phase of the master plan also includes new offices on the second floor of the West Wing, into which the museum staff will move over the next six months, and the prize-winning Cantor Auditorium, also designed by the Isozaki-Polshek team, which opened in 1991 in the part of the museum added in the mid-70's.
While the merit of the entire master plan, which was devised in the heat of the expansionist 80's and would double the museum's size, remains a matter of debate, the new West Wing galleries are among the most handsome and viewer-friendly of any in the country. Created at a cost of $31 million, from a combination of public money and private donations, the galleries were built from scratch in the shell of the gutted McKim, Mead & White wing. All that remains of the original interior is a cast-iron-and-slate staircase connecting the three floors.
The floor plan is consistent on each level: the dominant feature is a 100-foot-long navelike gallery bracketed at either end by small antechamberlike galleries, and beyond the second is a generous square space that has a small adjoining gallery on its north side. The effect is everywhere one of lightness and brightness: floors are blond, walls are white or pale gray, and details are minimal. Beaux-Arts monumentality is only discreetly acknowledged in granite baseboards, for example, and in the imposing door frames, which, like the museum's exterior, are limestone.
The quality of the new design is most dramatically apparent in the Egyptian galleries on the West Wing's third floor. Installed by Richard A. Fazzini and James F. Romano, respectively the chairman and the curator of the museum's department of Egyptian, classical and ancient Middle Eastern art, they display 500 artworks and artifacts from the museum's world-famous collection of 8,000 Egyptian objects in circumstances best described as dazzling.
The galleries' exceptionally strong but not harsh lighting and the blond-on-blond tones, obviously intended to evoke the sun and sand of Egypt, give everything a crisp, clear look. While much smaller than the Metropolitan Museum of Art's sprawling Egyptian collection, the Brooklyn display is more digestible and far more beautiful: it's not only a great introduction to the subject, but it's also something like an Egyptian Frick Collection.
The installation immediately conveys some of the basic facts of Egyptian art: its profound serenity, its emphasis on stone carved with consummate sophistication, its focus on dignified renderings of the human face and figure, whether the subject is a pharaoh or a peasant feeding a calf. In works alternately magisterial and intimate, the amazing continuity of Egyptian art comes across in these galleries, as does its endless flexibility, especially its ability to both withstand and accommodate outside influences brought by a succession of conquering rulers from Persia, Greece and Rome.
The objects on view range from ornately painted mummy cases and coffins, through dozens of beautifully carved limestone reliefs, to quick ink sketches on fragments of stone or ceramic, known as ostracons. They include exquisite examples of jewelry, makeup cases and the ceramic objects known as faience, as well as a human mummy, two cat mummies and rare papyrus scrolls. Most of these works have not been on view for several years, if ever; many are fresh from the conservation laboratory and an unusual number are displayed in freestanding vitrines so they can be seen all around.
The inaugural display is in two parts that complement each other well. In the first small gallery and the long navelike space, a large chronological section covers Egyptian art's stylistic evolution through nearly 14 centuries, roughly from the 18th to the 31st dynasties. (Some works from earlier dynasties are on view just outside the new wing, in relatively sparse and dilapidated galleries that are about to receive the full attention of Mr. Fazzini and Mr. Romano, at which point the full scope of Brooklyn's Egyptian holdings will be more evident.)
Then, in the remaining three galleries, a smaller exhibition titled "Temples, Tombs and the Egyptian Universe" examines Egyptian art as an expression of Egyptian religion.
The stylistic section begins with the 18th dynasty in the 14th century B.C., one of Egyptian art's golden ages, and concludes with the beginning of its final decline at the end of the Ptolemaic period, around 30 B.C., when Egypt became part of the Roman Empire.
The first small gallery of the stylistic section is devoted to the Amarna period (1354-1337 B.C.), during which the heightened naturalism encouraged by King Akhnaten jolted artistic conventions that had been in place for more than a thousand years. Included here are the museum's famous Wilbour Plaque, which shows the graceful profiles of Akhnaten and his wife, Nefertiti, facing each other as if in a breakfast-table chat. A nearby relief that is especially touching shows Nefertiti kissing one of her six daughters squarely on the lips.
Although the esthetic changes wrought by Akhnaten were reversed after his death in 1337 B.C., the urge toward naturalism weaves in and out of much that follows, especially in the works from the Ptolemaic period, when the objects frequently waver between Egyptian and Greek traits. In fact, overall and without much fuss, this display chips away resolutely at the popular notion of Egyptian art as stylistically static and uniformly idealizing.
The extraordinary viewing conditions speed this understanding: all kinds of individuality seem to literally pop into view here, whether it is the features of a small head that might otherwise have looked generic or the lines and textures of a relief or painted plaque. For a culture thought to be static and hierarchical, these objects have a startling range of individual workmanship, what is called touch in the modern era.
It is not only in the Amarna section that repeated images of everyday life are found. In one vitrine toward the middle of the big gallery, a display of reliefs from the 22d to 26th dynasties is so beautiful it almost constitutes an artwork itself. One can see a calf being born, a woman stacking fruit, a scribe with his tablet, a singer and his accompanying harpist and workmen building a boat. In a vitrine nearer the beginning, an 18th-dynasty relief displays a line of soldiers with less than army-regulation physiques, and nearly every face suggests a different ethnic type. Just below this is an even more striking relief in which delicate lines depict an old man with a creased face, flabby chest and veined arms and hands.
While the first section emphasizes the "what" of Egyptian art and style, the second concentrates on the "why," trying to place objects in the broader social context of the culture's life and thought. For example, the Egyptian emphasis on order and serenity is abundantly evident in purely esthetic terms in the first section; in the second, through a combination of objects and wall texts, this trait is tied to the fear of chaos, or Maat, as it was called, which permeated the Egyptian world view.
Here one can follow the elaborate narrative on the side of a coffin, which shows its occupant making an orderly transition to the hereafter. One can also learn that something as simple as a hand mirror, an elliptical disk with a plantlike handle, was seen as a metaphor for order's triumph because it represented the sun rising out of the papyrus swamp, which was the personification of chaos.
Of course, the two sections aren't all that separate and actually lead into each other. The high point of "Temples, Tombs and the Egyptian Universe" display is the 26th-dynasty relief from the tomb of a vizier named Nespeqashuty. For some reason the relief was never quite finished: some of its elaborate scenes are merely outlined in red paint, others are bluntly cut out and still others are finished with soft contours and fine details. After savoring so many beautiful limestone reliefs, it is perfect to encounter this marvelously precise record of the process that brought them into existence.
If the Egyptian galleries are the jewel in the West Wing crown, the remaining inaugural displays demonstrate that the architects have come up with a scheme that should successfully accommodate different artistic periods and media despite the narrowness of the building. The current installation of postwar art on the fifth floor, however, is overcrowded and in need of pruning.
The fourth-floor temporary exhibition galleries, the first section of which was used briefly last year for the Frederic Bazille exhibition, are being fully inaugurated with a 30-year retrospective of Mr. Isozaki's work, consisting primarily of architectural drawings and meticulous wood models of nearly 20 different projects, including the Brooklyn Museum master plan.
As might be expected when the container and the contents are the products of the same sensibility, this exhibition looks quite good. It gives one a broader understanding of the combination of restraint and sensitivity that is so evident in the West Wing redesign, while also reminding the viewer that Mr. Isozaki can be more daring and idiosyncratic in his designs, as in his Disney office building in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., for example.
It is also useful to see the model for the complete Brooklyn Museum master plan, for it poses the question of whether it will ever be completed and whether, indeed, it should be. From the vantage point of the economically straitened 90's, when bigger is not so immediately seen as better, the new wings and extensions of the Isozaki-Polshek plan look grandiose.
The valuable lesson of the first phase is that its remarkable transformation has been carried out within the existing building. One hopes its brilliant success will encourage the museum and its supporters to concentrate their energies on those parts of the master plan designed to bring the rest of its already large building up to the exhilarating level of the new West Wing.
The new Egyptian galleries and the "Temples, Tombs and the Egyptian Universe" exhibition, on the third floor, and the installation of postwar American art, on the fifth floor, are on permanent view at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. "Arata Isozaki: Works in Architecture" remains through Feb. 27.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
WPIX Is Facing a 3-and-2 Count

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
This is it, the MSG Network says. The final offer. The last chance for WPIX-TV/Channel 11 to air Yankee games on free television and save Phil Rizzuto from idling in pool halls. After eight months of talks during which both sides negotiated from distant galaxies, MSG yesterday offered a deal to swallow all losses and split any profits with WPIX.
If WPIX says no, that will most likely be it, and all 150 televised Yankees games will appear exclusively on MSG. 
 MSG amended an October proposal to split profits or losses with WPIX depending upon whether advertising on WPIX exceeds or falls short of rights and production costs. MSG has given WPIX until Dec. 17 to respond.
"They're saying carry the game for free; I don't know about that," said Michael Eigner, WPIX's general manager, who chuckled while listening to MSG's offer, which was faxed to the news media before it was sent to him. It is a no-risk offer, he admits, better than splitting losses, but he wants a profit guarantee. Eigner measures his Yankees economics against what he could get by selling the same time blocks for movies or other programming.
Based on the previous three years, when MSG bought time on WPIX to air 50 telecasts at $100,000 per game and sold all the advertising, Eigner finds it unlikely that MSG could sell enough advertising to produce profits.
Eigner did not specifically reject MSG's offer, but he sounded gloomy.
 
MSG Suggests Only 30 Games
 The MSG president, Douglas Moss, suggested that WPIX take 30 games only, and use the remaining 20 slots formerly used for Yankees games to show regular programming.
The wrangling between the two has centered on MSG's cost of buying Yankee telecasts, $300,000 per game in 1994, for which MSG would have to be reimbursed. WPIX has contended that MSG paid too much and that MSG's demand that $300,000 be the absolute benchmark is financially untenable.
"We'd be willing to buy games directly from MSG," Eigner said, "but not at $300,000. It has to be financially viable. I didn't buy 'The Simpsons' or 'Home Improvement' because they didn't make sense financially."
WPIX last week suggested placing a value of $250,000 on the block of time it devotes to each Yankee game, which Moss rejected as financially not doable. In Moss's view, in such a scenario MSG would lose from $6.3 million to $9.1 million and WPIX would make from $3.3 million to $6.2 million.
 
ABC in Punt-and-Pray Situation
 ABC looks as if it will be a ratings loser on Jan. 1, unless the prayers of the Sugar Bowl are answered by getting to pick Notre Dame, a pipe dream possible only if Florida trounces Alabama so badly tomorrow that the Gators pass Texas A&M in the bowl coalition poll.
If events don't veer out of control, ABC's Citrus Bowl will start the day with Penn State-Tennessee, followed by the Rose Bowl featuring Wisconsin or Ohio State against U.C.L.A., and a Sugar Bowl matchup of undefeated West Virginia and Florida.
Meanwhile, on NBC, the tentative lineup would most likely match Miami-Arizona in the Fiesta Bowl, Notre Dame-Texas A&M in the Cotton Bowl, and Nebraska-Florida State for the national title in the Orange Bowl.
A look at past bowl ratings shows some of ABC's fears: In 1991, a Tennessee-Virginia Sugar Bowl got a 4.9 rating for ABC against an 18.3 rating for the Notre Dame-Colorado Orange Bowl on NBC. The next year, with Notre Dame-Florida in the Sugar Bowl, ABC rated a a 10.8, much more competitive with the Miami-Nebraska Orange Bowl, which ended with an 11.0 rating.
Naturally, ABC won't say that its likely Rose and Sugar Bowls fall short of its desires or that it would prefer Notre Dame over West Virginia.
Mark Mandel, an ABC Sports spokesman, denied that the network is influencing the Sugar Bowl's decision to wait for a Hail Holtz bid for Notre Dame.
"We have a dialogue with the Sugar Bowl," said Mandel. What could that dialogue be?
ABC: "Wait."
Sugar Bowl: "O.K."
Here's the irony: a Pac-10 rule that bars its teams from competing at the same time in bowl games caused NBC to flip-flop the Fiesta and Cotton Bowl starting times, so Arizona and U.C.L.A. wouldn't play at the same time in the Fiesta and Rose. That will hurt the Rose Bowl more than its own teams vying for ratings because it will pit the Pasadena game against a Cotton Bowl featuring Notre Dame.
The Pac-10 decided against waiving the rule, said Jim Muldoon, a conference spokesman. "It was a question of doing the right thing long-term for the Pac-10," he said.
 
AIRWAVES
 CBS's JOHN MADDEN, riding the bus to Miami for Sunday's Giants-Dolphins game, said the key reason Jacksonville got the newest N.F.L. franchise was money, and little else: "They guaranteed $1 million to the visiting teams, and the voters were the visiting teams. For them, it's 'Give me $1 million and I don't care if you sell out or not.' "
Madden on the Giants' winning despite a sputtering offense: "The Giants are dealing with weak offenses in the N.F.C. The Giants will find it easy to keep doing this, because you'll get that weather where you play ball control. It's December football. They've been playing December football all year."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Window to the Mind of Christmas

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
SHOPPING isn't a chore. It is a gift. That's the delightful delusion to which we eagerly fall prey each time we enter the great emporiums of consumer fantasy. Showered with the free spritz of cologne, the bonus kit of cosmetics, the floral extravaganzas of spring and the thrill of celebrity appearances, we can easily forget that we're the ones who are paying for this copious largess. Indeed, we may begin to wonder whether we are worthy to receive it.
Christmas decorations, on the other hand, remind us that it is more blessed to give than to receive, a message that calls for a more Baroque set of signals. For while it is indeed a great pleasure to give, the pleasure is likely to be diluted when the giver is faced with a long list of people who expect to be remembered with, at least, a tie. 
 It's up to Manhattan's inspired store-display directors to transform seasonal coercion into cheerful volition. They want us to know that we're not being pressured to give. We have the opportunity to give. Festooned with ribbons, twinkling with lights, Christmas windows wrap up the ultimate present: the gift of giving.
THE GAP (West Fourth Street and Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, and other branches). No one has a more masterly command of this seasonal sign language than the Gap. The store knows that what people want the most this year isn't a cappuccino machine or a Beavis and Butt-head video. It's the ability to chill out, to keep your head while people all around you are going crazy.
The Gap windows take the prize for studied relaxation. The store that devoted full-page advertisements to simple T-shirts and plain khaki pants understands the value of overstated understatement. So the Gap has adorned its windows with a simple red stripe (it's a ribbon if you want it to be), hung up a not particularly ostentatious wreath, and mounted a big color blow-up poster of a guy -- rugged, but not a dreamboat -- looking out from a backdrop of fresh green pine. There's no snow on these trees, but that's fine. He's dreaming of a cool Christmas.
On the bottom of the poster, it says: "What to Give. What to Get." At once question and answer, the slogan is a soothing prescription to the season's anxieties. Not only is the Gap full of gift ideas, it also brims with nonchalance. Give it, get it, don't sweat it. Christmas is an outfit. A little red, a bit of green. Wear it with a smile and even a touch of sincerity. If you get a little wrinkled, that's not a bad look.
TIFFANY & COMPANY (727 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street). Tiffany, by contrast, long ago perfected the art of the understated overstatement. Since there are no diamonds as big as the Ritz, it pays to get shoppers thinking small. Tiffany's windows are little theaters where the stars (twinkling gems, burnished silver and gold) work for scale. These miniature tableaux prepare the eye for the enchanted microcosm of the jeweler's art. And when the eye pulls back from the windows and peers through the store's glass doors, that grand ocean-liner saloon of a main floor appears to expand like the magic tree in "The Nutcracker."
This year, Tiffany's theaters come draped with popcorn curtains that part to reveal a Tom Thumb circus. Lions, clowns and acrobats, fashioned from enameled silver, cavort against a background of blue felt. Tiffany's Littlest Show on Earth (designed by Gene Moore, who has created the store's Christmas windows for the last 39 years) is exquisite, and admission is free, as if to set an example for generous holiday giving. The windows display no baubles to buy, no brooches riding horseback. And they're sure not selling popcorn.
 
Send In the Clowns
 F. A. O. SCHWARZ (767 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street). A circus atmosphere also prevails at F. A. O. Schwarz, though here the figures have mutated up to the far extreme of the size scale. If you missed Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade, Schwarz's jumbo camels, elephants and crayons are the next best way to shrink the kids.
Like the Russian Tea Room, Schwarz doesn't have to go to special lengths to look Christmasy. Those big glass windows facing onto Grand Army Plaza offer year-round glimpses of coming North Pole attractions. On the Madison Avenue side of the store, there's a Barbie boutique that is a study in pink and pearl. Visions of Joey Heatherton seem to be dancing in what passes for Barbie's head.
 
Off to the Islands
 BERGDORF'S MEN'S STORE (745 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street). For those who break last year's vow to get out of town this Christmas, Bergdorf's men's store has arranged a South Sea island escape, with palm fronds, coconut matting, star fish, bananas and red wooden monkeys scampering about a simulated colonial planter's hut. But no one's going native here. Anglophile fashions and Edwardian furnishings make this a civilized outpost, while battered appliances -- a phone, a fan, a refrigerator -- complete the period-piece picture. This is a Somerset Maugham Christmas, a stiff upper lip in a tropical heat wave.
 
Devouring Passion
 BARNEYS (Uptown: Madison Avenue at 61st Street. Downtown: 106 Seventh Avenue, at 17th Street). Those who won't accept the gift of giving may profess to be revolted by it. Barneys understands this. It knows that excess is hard to stomach. In the spirit of homeopathic remedy, the store's windows push indulgence beyond parody into the realm of metaphysics. Gone from this year's windows are the follies of the famous, formerly showcased in Barneys' holiday windows like the attributes of the saints. Instead, the store plays havoc with consuming on a more visceral level, with an ambitious, two-store installation on the theme of holiday dining.
"Seasons Eatings," created by Martha King, is a series of fantasy buffets, long tables laden with imaginary party dishes that are grouped according to themes. Relying heavily on visual puns (a shoemaker's tree sprouts from a deep dish of "peach cobbler"), the displays give new meaning to the term groaning board.
Uptown, there's a "Hell Buffet," with infernal delicacies spread out for "Embers Only." Wooden safety matches no longer seem so benign when served up as matchstick potatoes, while a bowl of pasta carbonara comes lightly tossed with charcoal briquets. For dessert, take your choice among the Seven Deadly Sinnamon Rolls. When the selections get too hot, make your way to an adjacent window, where Angel Hair Pasta and a glittering Holy Rolling Pin await you at the "Heaven Buffet."
The surrealistic Fortnum & Mason's continues at the Barneys downtown branch, with buffets on Hawaiian, Las Vegas and marine themes. But the store also offers a special tribute to downtown iconoclasm with a two-window installation by James Vance that depicts the holidays as a scene of domestic violence. To judge from the overturned book cases, Breuer chairs with ripped cane seats and a floor littered with smashed candy canes and tree ornaments, this was not a silent night.
 
Winter Distilled
 STEUBEN (717 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street). The Steuben store's display department needs to take a squeegee to its dusty holiday presentation. Set on the ground floor of a classic glass skyscraper designed by Wallace K. Harrison in 1959, the store occupies one of the most privileged locations on earth. And Steuben's merchandise could not be more seasonal. The shop's beautiful glass wares are perfect urban distillations of winter, sophisticated city versions of icicles and frozen lakes.
In the Fifth Avenue window, glass pine cones dangle forlornly from skimpy satin ribbons over their natural counterparts. Better lighting could make them zing. On the 56th Street side, stars of yellow canvas with tired-looking points hover over spiky miniature evergreen trees in mottled clay pots. Empty reflection pools out front turn the sidewalk into a dry ditch. If the pools won't hold water, why not pink bubble bath?
 
Silver and Gold
 Glass is used beautifully in the display window at HERMES (11 East 57th Street), where glistening cracked crystal shards have been stuck all over the bark of otherwise naked tree boughs. The effect is something between a child's rope of rock candy and Elizabeth Taylor's safety deposit box, a delicate balance between childhood improvisation and adult indulgence that looks utterly right for Christmas.
The trees are flanked by smaller shrubs with leaves of curled, feathery silver ribbon, and the window's glinting, ice palace impact is enhanced by its contrast to Burberry's window next door. The tone at BURBERRY (9 East 57th Street) is also metallic, but steeped in a mellow, orange light that flickers off dark gold fabric and the warm wood of the shop interior beyond. The unexpected harmony between this pair of carriage trade legends may induce waves of hopeless nostalgia for a time when all it took to be seriously multicultural was to tuck a French silk scarf inside a sturdy British mac.
 
Dead Flowers
 This is the season for dead flowers. Where living trees were once the Christmas fashion, now expired flora are dropping their petals all over town. At CHRISTIAN TORTU, in the new Takashimaya Building (693 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street), dried amaryllis petals have been formed into ruby red lampshades for chandeliers that ascend toward the shop's lofty, gold-leaf ceiling. It's a flower's dream of the afterlife, a Tiepolo potpourri.
At BERGDORF GOODMAN'S MAIN STORE (754 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street), the windows resemble enchanted Brothers Grimm compost heaps, with moldering leaves, mosses and mushrooms, gilded bee hives and spectral chandeliers suspended from desiccated branches. Surrounded by proscenium frames, surmounted by crowns, this sleeping beauty of a scene looks to be a fairy-tale version of lingering recessionary gloom. Won't someone enter the palace and kiss the dormant economy back to life?
GUCCI (685 Fifth Avenue, at 54th Street) also gives us an ample dose of nature morte, though the autumnal tones of dried bittersweet and ruddy apples are a supple match for the store's fine leathers. One window at Gucci is piled with cuddly brown teddy bears that have been dressed (or, in Calvin Klein's case, undressed) by such celebrities as Tommy Tune, Annie Leibovitz and Whoopi Goldberg. The bears will be auctioned on Wednesday to benefit Housing Works, a group that supports people with AIDS. And it may be that this season's citywide dried-flower bouquet is a symbolic response to that disease's continuing harvest of young lives.
At FENDI (720 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street), the symbolism is more explicit. Stretching their wings over groups of somberly dressed mannequins, statuesque engravings of 19th-century angels wear neon versions of the red ribbon that signifies solidarity with those struck by AIDS. The garish neon looks out of place in this temple of refined, classical luxury, but the jarring note is precisely pitched. It would be ugly to look for a matching accessory in a specter that has shattered the world of fashion.
 
The Long View
 LORD & TAYLOR (424 Fifth Avenue, near 38th Street). Lord & Taylor's windows are the Jurassic Park of holiday displays, an enduring family favorite that draws crowds from miles around. And the store makes the greatest effort to pitch the season back onto the spiritual plane, with its animated, intricately detailed fairy-tale tableaux dedicated to such virtues as "A Helping Hand," "The Love of Friends" and "A Song of Peace." There is something movingly archaic about these scenes, almost as if they were the exhibits in the remote corner of some future "Star Trek" version of the American Museum of Natural History, where intergalactic travelers come to explore the glories of an ancient civilization that dwindled at the dawn of the Mall Age.
 
Fashion and Fantasy
 MACY'S (34th Street at Avenue of the Americas). Macy's had the wonderful idea of inviting fashion designers to decorate its Broadway windows, but for the most part the designers didn't rise to the occasion. Who cares that when Tommy Hilfiger hears the word "Christmas," he brightly thinks "Currier & Ives!"? But Josie Natori's silver and white "fantasy in the Imperial Gardens" has a dreamy glow. Silver gift boxes spill from within a pearl-encrusted tree that blossoms with perfumes and costume jewels. And Susie Tompkins remembers what it was like to celebrate Christmas on the beach in a temperate climate, with presents spread out on the sand beneath a whole coastline of trees.
The Clintons have survived the budget fight, Nafta and the President's haircut, so they won't be permanently damaged by Macy's 34th Street windows, where they are the unwitting stars in a witless version of "The Night Before Christmas." Macy's sumptuous ground-floor interior, now suffused with great clouds of rose paper-covered boxes, remains the true miracle on 34th Street.
 
Mannequin Mania
 SAKS FIFTH AVENUE (611 Fifth Avenue, at 50th Street). With Barneys forsaking V.I.P.'s for food, the season's most imaginative mannequins are on view in the windows of Saks Fifth Avenue, which offer a whimsical pageant featuring allegorical figures who represent different genres of gifts. There's a Signor del Suedo (leather bags), a Fiorenza Fragranza (perfume), and a jesterish, hat-twirling "Accessoro, entertainer to the court" who "knows as much about style as he does sport."
The mechanized figures spin to taped music within sepia-toned, Bibiena-style stage sets, their false perspectives creating an ideal visual overture to the sumptuous, fir-lined axis of Saks's main-floor aisle inside. Coupled with the promenade at Rockefeller Center, just across the street, this is one of America's grandest sequences of urban space. Give yourself the gift of seeing it in its best season.

HEADLINE: The Classical and the New in a Musical Adventure

BYLINE: By ALEX ROSS

 BODY:
On an out-of-the-way side street in Brooklyn Heights, nothing is quite as it seems. You enter a building that appears to be a church or a chapel. On the ground floor, you hear the bouncy strains of "Meet Me in St. Louis" as a community theater rehearses its winter production. Upstairs, brightly colored scribblings on the wall strongly indicate a nursery school or a kindergarten. But now there are strange, dangerous noises coming from behind a second door. Walking into a white, high-vaulted auditorium, you see 20 musicians dressed in black, pealing forth the mountainous, molten dissonances of "Deserts," by Varese.
This is the Orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble, one of New York City's most adventurous new-music groups. The surroundings are no great mystery; S.E.M. shares space with the preschool at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity. But the story of how the orchestra came to be formed less than two years ago is an intriguing one. No less intriguing is the background for S.E.M.'s program tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall, one of the oddest in recent memory: Varese's "Deserts," Morton Feldman's "Turfan Fragments," John Cage's "Concert for Piano and Orchestra" (with the legendary new-music pianist David Tudor) and excerpts from "L'Orfeo," by Monteverdi. 
 The mastermind of the whole operation is Petr Kotik, a flutist and composer long associated with Cage. Mr. Kotik came to the United States from Czechoslovkia in 1969, having met Cage several years earlier. He formed the S.E.M. Ensemble in 1972, specializing in Cage works like "Songbooks." His own compositions are very much in the Cage tradition, employing indeterminate procedures and a wide range of literary sources.
 
After Cage
 Intense-looking from afar, Mr. Kotik was very genial, even nonchalant, in a recent interview. "I do not have a career," he said wryly. "I might have had a major career as a flutist in Czechoslovakia, but I could not play the same piece over and over again with the same enthusiasm. I am not goal-oriented." More or less on a whim, Mr. Kotik applied two years ago for a grant to record a full orchestral version of Cage's "Atlas Eclipticalis." Nonplussed when the money arrived, he enlarged his ensemble to form the S.E.M. orchestra. A follow-up concert took place in October of 1992 at Carnegie Hall, to considerable acclaim.
Between the first plans for that concert and its fruition, Cage died. Mr. Kotik went to Mr. Tudor in the hope that he would participate as a memorial gesture. This canonic pianist of the American and European postwar avant-garde had been concentrating on electronic composition for several decades and had not played an ordinary acoustic instrument publicly in 20 years. But the Carnegie Hall concert drew him out of retirement; his phenomenal intensity and concentration were undiminished.
S.E.M. was then invited to the U.S. Arts Festival in Berlin in May. Rather than repeat the same program, Mr. Kotik chose a rarely performed piece by Feldman and a Varese masterpiece more talked about than heard. The daring element of the venture was that the conductor had never attempted a fully notated (non-Cagean) score in public. Varese and Feldman are both fearsomely difficult in different ways, music with numberless small gestures and no central pulse.
 
How a Concert Evolved
 Mr. Kotik may be an inexperienced conductor, but he is passionate about his chosen repertory. Last year, "Atlas Eclipticalis" projected a sense of austere control as well as improvisatory richness. At a preview concert in preparation for the Tully Hall performance on Tuesday night, S.E.M. gave a vehement, fairly exact rendition of the Varese, although the Feldman still had a little way to go. "Conducting is utterly exhausting, just like composing" Mr. Kotik said of his new vocation. "There is always something more to be done, to be thought about, and you stop when you just can't think about it anymore."
The conductor insists that his Tully Hall program evolved by chance. Yet it has an underlying logic, a hidden theory about music's tension between repetition and freedom. On the first half, Monteverdi and Cage sit side by side, possibly for the first time anywhere. "In comparison with Monteverdi, Cage is very precise," Mr. Kotik noted with another wry smile. "Both scores leave a lot to the performer. I went back to the manuscript and made my own performing version of the Monteverdi. But music is fundamentally about imitation and repetition. So I also listened a lot to the John Eliot Gardiner recording." The concert tomorrow night will feature period instruments; the soprano soloist, Sarah Pillow, is a veteran of early-music performance.
In "L'Orfeo," the aria "Dal mio Permesso amato" ends with a plea that nature "halt upon its way"; Monteverdi's accompaniment falls into reposeful fragments. The transition is not shockingly abrupt to Cage's "Concert," a 1958 piece in which performers are free to choose among "aggregates" of fragmentary notation, and in which the texture often lapses into silence. Mr. Kotik will present a version with two orchestral groups and two pianists; the soloists are Joseph Kubera, playing an acoustic piano, and Mr. Tudor, playing an electronically prepared piano.
 
An Independent Approach
 In Varese, Mr. Kotik once again proceeds with rigor, and also with independence. "Deserts" is most often performed with an electronic background that the composer assembled from synthesizers and recorded ("concrete") sources. Mr. Kotik rejects the electronic material, calling it chaotic and dated. He prefers the instrumental score, which summons enough monstrous drama on its own.
The concert will close with Feldman, the Cage protege who found his own extraordinary path and whose work has become vastly influential since his death in 1987. "Turfan Fragments," composed in 1980, is very quiet and very tense, not quite so evenly textured as many of the composer's late pieces. Mr. Kotik's program once again reveals a neat sense of juxtaposition: Feldman greatly admired Varese, and "Turfan Fragments" seems to pick up where the ethereal closing bars of "Deserts" leave off.
Despite the intelligence behind it, this concert is a risky, not altogether rational venture. Mr. Kotik admits as much. But he quotes a favorite passage from Feldman's essays: "Art is a crucial, dangerous operation we perform on ourselves. Unless we take a chance, we die in art."
S.E.M. will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $30; $15 for students and the unemployed. Information: (718) 488-7659.

HEADLINE: Songwriters See Copyrights Infringed in Rap Parody Case

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Critic's Notebook article on the "Oh, Pretty Woman" rap parody case pending before the Supreme Court substantially mischaracterizes the views of the United States community of songwriters and music publishers ("Parody, Not Smut, Has Rappers in Court," Nov. 13). 
 While certain forms of parody and satire of musical works may be permissible under the fair use doctrine, the 2 Live Crew rap group appropriated far too much of the underlying work -- and its commercial use of the song usurped far too much of the market for the work -- for the group to sustain a fair use defense in this particular case.
Much more disturbing, however, was the article's irresponsible suggestion that musical compositions that achieve a certain level of success should be thrust into the public domain "as if its fans had ransomed it from the copyright holders." This outrageously regressive attitude, which runs contrary to the principles of free expression and private ownership, has been rejected by nearly every government in the world. Even the Soviet Union refrained for the most part from "nationalizing" creative works in the realization that to do so would utterly destroy the incentives and safeguards that permit creators to survive.
The basis for copyright protection is rooted in the United States Constitution, and the Supreme Court has recognized that copyright protection is the very "engine of free expression." These principles are what has enabled the cultural heritage of the United States to blossom.
Our country is the pre-eminent source of the world's music because American creativity has been nurtured through strong copyright protection. As a result, intellectual property today makes up 5.6 percent of the United States gross national product and is one of the only growing segments of our export market.
I suggest that your critic may wish to re-evaluate his position in light of not only the foregoing thoughts, but also in consideration of protecting the livelihoods of his colleagues. Copyright protection, after all, serves as the cornerstone of The Times's ability to protect its proprietary intellectual property interests throughout the world.
 
EDWARD P. MURPHY
President, National
Music Publishers' Association
New York, Nov. 24, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Where the Money Isn't

BYLINE: By Karen D. Shaw; Karen D. Shaw is president of the Institute for Strategy Development, a financial consulting company.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The plan to streamline Federal bank regulation announced last week by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen makes sense. There is no reason to have four overlapping agencies overseeing the industry. But this fine-tuning may be beside the point. Commercial banks are heading for trouble, and it will take far more dramatic Government action to save them.
Although the industry has made an impressive recovery from the problems of the late 1980's -- banks will post record earnings for the eighth consecutive quarter -- the numbers do not look so good when carefully analyzed. 
 Judged by their return to shareholders, banks remain weak. Ominous signs appear in the otherwise ebullient stock market: even as banks' earnings reach new highs, their market value is falling, indicating long-term trouble.
In all the industry's traditional functions, banks are losing ground to mutual funds, mortgage companies, finance companies and other non-banking institutions. Unhampered by the laws that accompany Federal deposit insurance (commercial banks can't underwrite securities, for example) these competitors lure customers from banks. The competition can also create new financial products, like mutual funds, without the legal impediments that confine banks to high-cost, low-profit ends of the business.
A quick look into the wallet of any consumer reveals the best evidence of banking's problems. Vacations and washing machines used to be financed by installment loans. Now people use credit cards, which are more and more frequently issued by institutions other than banks. Household savings have also left the banking system; money market and mutual fund investments will equal bank deposit balances for the first time ever by the end of the year.
The way companies use banks has also changed. Large companies steered away from traditional banking loans in the mid-80's; they began borrowing directly from pension funds and others in the capital markets. Now, smaller and less stable companies are doing the same. Once finance companies start offering small-business loans (probably next year), the basic franchise of the commercial bank -- commercial lending -- will be under siege.
The corporate landscape is littered with the wreckage of industries that failed to change with the times. But banks can't just disappear. They are backed by a full faith and credit guarantee from the Government. Serious changes must be made quickly to insure that the Government's bet on banks is not called when their profitability begins mirroring their declining market share.
There are two ways to retool the system. The Government could simply take over commercial banking. Private banks would turn over their deposits to Uncle Sam and become unrestricted finance companies. But this would insert the Government into the economy in a dangerous way. Nationalized banks might become inefficient bureaucracies and, as in Europe, slush funds that blindly support foolish Government projects.
A far better alternative is modernization of the financial industry. The Government should continue to insure commercial bank deposits but should allow banks to diversify into more profitable financial services.
One can understand why the Administration might be reluctant to take on another huge reform initiative. But only a major overhaul can stabilize banks, protect the deposit insurance fund and spur economic recovery.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HANSON TO SPIN OFF U.S. AND BRITISH HOME-BUILDING UNITS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, announced plans yesterday to sell its home-building subsidiaries in the United States and Britain through a public stock offering. The offering in the two units, Beazer P.L.C. and Beazer Homes U.S.A. Inc., will be made in the first half of 1994. The home-building businesses had an operating profit of $87 million on sales of $699 million for the latest year. The announcement came as Hanson reported that its earnings fell to $1.1 billion for the year that ended on Sept. 30 from $1.6 billion a year earlier. The company attributed the decline to recession in several markets and a strike at its Peabody Coal subsidiary in the United States. The American depository receipts of Hanson fell $1.375 yesterday, to $19.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
