HEADLINE: What's What In The World Trade Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:

THE OVERVIEW
The United States is negotiating with 115 other nations to broadly rewrite the free trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which have governed most international trade for 45 years. GATT was created in 1948 with the aim of expanding economic activity by eliminating tariffs and other protectionist barriers. Trade ministers have successfully completed seven previous rounds of talks to broaden the original agreement.
The current negotiations began seven years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, leading negotiators and commentators to call it the Uruguay Round. Its main goal is to broaden the rules to cover trade in agriculture and in services like tourism, insurance and telecommunications. Negotiators are also trying to reduce or eliminate many tariffs. 
 After years of obstacles, there is a growing sense that the trade talks may finally be headed for a conclusion. They have dragged on so long mainly because of disputes between the United States and Europeans over agricultural subsidies. This summer, Congress gave President Clinton special negotiating authority to clinch a deal by Dec. 15. If agreement cannot be reached by then, the Administration will have to seek Congressional permission for another extension, which could prove politically ticklish because of the recent fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
In July, Peter Sutherland of Ireland took over as GATT's Director General. In a few months, he has succeeded in getting the world's governments to regard Dec. 15 as a true, pressing deadline. And Mr. Sutherland has warned that if the talks failed again, national leaders must face the blame for harming the global economy.
 
What Is At Stake
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based consortium of 24 of the more prosperous nations, estimates that a successful completion of the trade talks would mean about $270 billion more in annual trade by the year 2002. The extra economic output would come from the more efficient use of labor, capital and other resources.
Some American economists, industry groups and labor unions say that the draft version of an accord now being negotiated will channel most of the benefits to other countries, at least in the short run, and some economists question whether the overall gains have been overstated.
But most economists believe that over the course of years, free trade allows each country to specialize in products that it can make most efficiently, trading them for products made more efficiently elsewhere.
 
The Basics
 
TARIFFS
These are taxes that Governments collect on imports from other countries. The overall goal of the Uruguay Round is to reduce average tariffs by at least one-third. Previous GATT negotiations have cut average tariffs on manufactured goods to 5 percent from 40 percent in the late 1940's. While other nations' tariffs can be quite high, the average American tariff on manufactured imports is 4 percent. Japan, Canada, the United States and the European Community agreed in Tokyo in July to eliminate tariffs entirely on pharmaceuticals, construction equipment, medical equipment, some furniture, and whisky and beer. In addition, it is proposed that agricultural tariffs be reduced by 36 percent in industrial nations and 24 percent in developing nations. Agricultural tariffs vary widely because they are often charged by the penny per kilogram or liter, rather than as a percentage of the product's value.
 
QUOTAS
These are limits on the quantity of imports, like American limits on the number of tons of imported peanuts. Previous talks have eliminated most manufacturing quotas except for textiles and finished apparel. The Uruguay Round would eliminate this exception and also require countries to replace their extensive quotas or bans on farm imports with tariffs that provide comparable protection. Quotas are pervasive in international farm trade, and the United States imposes them on dairy products, peanuts and sugar. Some of the new tariffs could start as high as several hundred percent, and would be gradually reduced.
 
INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
The agreement, as it now stands, requires that all countries protect patents, copyrights, trade secrets and trademarks, including developing countries, where pirated computer programs, record albums, videocassettes and prescription drugs have been commonly available for years. But Western pharmaceutical manufacturers are angry that the proposed protections will come too slowly to benefit many companies doing business now. Indeed, some drugs will not receive full patent protection in developing countries for 20 years.
 
A NEW TRADE ORGANIZATION
The current text would create an institution in Geneva to enforce GATT's free trade rules. The new institution would be much more powerful than the GATT Secretariat is now, having the power to assess trade penalties against countries by a vote of two-thirds or three-quarters of the nations, whereas the Secretariat can act only when the members unanimously vote to do so -- something that is rare. The Clinton Administration and many Rust Belt industries like steel oppose this new organization because it could prevent American companies from seeking Commerce Department penalties on foreign industries that sell their goods in the United States with subsidies, or at unfairly low prices.
 
 INVESTMENT
The proposed text would ban the widespread practice of requiring high local content in some products like cars and of requiring factories to export as much as they import. The aim of that practice is to preserve local jobs and discourage imports. The proposed agreement would limit the ability of countries to favor domestically owned factories at the expense of foreign-owned ones.
 
TAXATION
The agreement would bar countries from imposing higher tax rates on foreign companies than on domestic ones. The United States is objecting to this rule, which would break a long American practice of individual tax agreements with more than 50 nations. These two-country deals also bar tax discrimination against foreign companies and individuals. But other countries are worried that American efforts to crack down on tax evasion by foreign companies may prove discriminatory, and they are pushing for GATT protection.
 
MAJOR INDUSTRIES AFFECTED BY THE TALKS:
Agriculture. The big dispute holding up the talks for the last three years has been a quarrel between the United States and the European Community over farm subsidies. Last year, the United States and the Europeans agreed to reduce the tonnage of subsidized grain exports by 21 percent, and to limit other farm subsidies. But France, Europe's biggest agricultural exporter, wants the subsidy deal renegotiated. Yesterday, in negotiations in Brussels, the United States tentatively agreed to allow the Europeans to subsidize more grain exports over the next six years than previously planned. In exchange, the Europeans tentatively agreed to convert some of their quotas on farm imports into low tariffs, as Washington demands.
Automobiles. Over the years, the United States and the European Community have each forced Japan to accept limits on its auto exports. The current agreement text would virtually ban these restrictions. Each country would only be allowed one such export limit on any industry, and Detroit car makers worry that they might not get the exemption. The Big Three also worry about clauses in the text that would make it harder to prove that foreign cars were being sold at unfairly low prices in the United States.
Financial services companies. In theory, commercial and investment banks, insurance companies and issuers of travelers checks would all be allowed to do business around the world, subject only to restrictions aimed at protecting depositors and insurance-policy holders. But few developing countries have actually committed themselves to opening their markets, angering American financial-services companies. The Clinton Administration has antagonized some countries by saying that it will not guarantee the continued openness of the American market except in the cases of countries that considerably open their own markets.
Movies, TV programs and music recordings. The European Community now allows its 12 members to restrict the distribution of foreign films, television programs and recordings in an effort to protect the national culture of each country. Several European countries, notably France, have imposed quotas on these imports. Hollywood wants the quotas eliminated. European Community officials are pushing a compromise that would maintain existing quotas at current levels and not allow new ones.
Steel. Some European government subsidies to uncompetitive steelmakers would be banned. But no agreement has been reached yet on whether to ban many other subsidies, and whether to allow penalties like steeper tariffs on countries that continue banned subsidies.
Textiles and apparel. The current text would phase out textile and apparel quotas over 10 years, but the Clinton Administration is trying to extend this to 15 years. The quotas would then be replaced by less-restrictive tariffs. KEITH BRADSHER
 
(Sources: GATT Secretariat, Clinton Administration officials, industry groups)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Helpful Hints for an Era of Practical Feminism

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Fire With Fire
 The New Female Power and How It Will Change the 21st Century
 By Naomi Wolf
 373 pages. Random House. $21.
Naomi Wolf's messy new treatise, "Fire With Fire," is really two books. The first aspires to be a kind of sequel to Susan Faludi's best seller, "Backlash," arguing that a new era of gender politics is at hand. The second purports to be a manifesto for a new, inclusive brand of feminism eschewing extremism and rigid ideology.
As Ms. Wolf, the author of "The Beauty Myth" (1991), sees it, the backlash against feminism culminated during the years of the Ronald Reagan Administration and ended with the Anita F. Hill-Clarence A. Thomas hearings of October 1991. Those hearings, she argues, focused women's anger and galvanized the development of what she calls the "genderquake": that is, a major shift in the balance of power between American men and women, accompanied by "unprecedented female political activism." 
 To begin with, Ms. Wolf suggests, the election of President Clinton represented the defeat of the patriarchal politics championed by the Republicans at their 1992 convention. More victories for women followed in the wake of last year's elections, including the passage of the Family Leave Act, the reversal of the gag rule in pregnancy counseling and the appointments of women to prominent positions within the Clinton Administration.
Ms. Wolf also notes that the organization Emily's List helped 25 new women win political office by raising $6.2 million in campaign money for 1992, and that women still have "enormous unclaimed" political power. Women spend 85 percent of the consumer dollar, she writes, and in last year's Presidential election, they represented 54 percent of the voting public.
In an effort both to celebrate the positive effects of the "genderquake" and to rally support for the continuing fight against sexism, Ms. Wolf frequently contradicts herself. For instance, speaking of women's growing political power, she declares that "without the women in the media, all these parties could not have linked up in the unstoppable chain reaction that ushered in the new era." Pages later, she asserts that "the mainstream media leave out women in general, and the women's movement in particular, with a comprehensiveness that has disturbing implications for a democracy."
On one hand, Ms. Wolf cites this year's vapid Academy Awards tribute to "Women in Film" and the success of television series like "Designing Women" as evidence of changing cultural politics. On the other hand, she complains about the male domination of Hollywood, noting that 95 percent of Premiere magazine's list of heavyweights in the entertainment industry is male.
It is on the subject of the women's movement -- and its internal divisions -- that Ms. Wolf is most impassioned. In her view, contemporary feminism has alienated many American women, who share its goals of women's rights but shy away from the movement's strident image. She argues that this problem stems, in part, from distortion by the media and the religious right, but she adds that the movement, too, bears responsibility.
In recent years, Ms. Wolf charges, feminism has developed some "intellectually destructive habits," namely an either-or, us-versus-them attitude that emphasizes ideological purity and consensus thinking. Its insistence on a checklist of attitudes (toward everything from abortion to cosmetics), she says, has "closed the word 'feminism' off to enormous numbers of people: women who are not sure about, or who actively oppose, abortion; women who are terrified of being tarred with the brush of homophobia; women who strongly resist identifying themselves as victims; women who are uneasy with what they see as man bashing and blaming; conservative women; and men themselves."
The old "victim feminism," Ms. Wolf contends, depicts women as virginal, peace-loving creatures pitted against violent, aggressive males. It denigrates the importance of leadership, money and sexuality, and it self-righteously identifies with powerlessness. As examples of "victim feminism," Ms. Wolf cites Take Back the Night rallies forbidding the participation of men, and criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton for submitting to a campaign makeover.
In contrast to this "victim feminism," Ms. Wolf posits a "power feminism" that emphasizes individualism over collectivity, that "hates sexism without hating men," that is willing to use the traditional tools of male society, including the mass media and the political system -- to achieve its ends. Examples of power feminism, she says, include support from Emily's List for female candidates, business counseling provided by the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation, and Attorney General Janet Reno's use of her office "to prosecute deadbeat dads and domestic violence."
In her efforts to articulate an accessible, pragmatic feminism, Ms. Wolf scores some valid points, helping to replace strident dogma with common sense. Unfortunately, her arguments are undermined by sloppy thinking and even sloppier prose.
To begin with, "Fire With Fire" is peppered with dubious oversimplifications and highly debatable assertions. Ms. Wolf writes, for instance, that "the Bush White House went down because it paid too little attention to its female constituents." She maintains that many young women "truly believe that the main thing that determines feminism is body hair." And she asserts that "America, and all its women, won big" by witnessing the ugly face-off between Elizabeth Holtzman and Geraldine Ferraro in the 1992 New York Democratic primary race for a United States Senate seat.
To make matters worse, Ms. Wolf displays a disconcerting penchant for inflationary prose. In "The Beauty Myth," she went so far as to draw parallels between the Holocaust and anorexia; in this volume, she describes what she perceives as discrimination against women in the mass media as "gender apartheid."
Elsewhere in the volume, she resorts to the peppy language of self-help books in an effort to win new converts. She repeatedly insists that feminism should be "easy," "lucrative" and "fun": that is, fun in the sense of "the rape crisis center starved for lack of fun."
In the end, it is such egregious passages, not Ms. Wolf's more persuasive arguments about feminism, that ultimately stick in the reader's mind.

HEADLINE: A NEW U.S. STANCE ON ATOMIC WASTES

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Secretary of Energy said today that her department had a "moral obligation" to help electric utilities store spent fuel from nuclear reactors, even though the department could not keep its promise to take the fuel off their hands beginning in 1998.
In a sharp turnaround from the Bush Administration, which denied it had any responsibility for the waste, she said her department might cover the utilities' cost for storage. 
 Under contracts signed in the 1980's, the Energy Department has been collecting a waste disposal fee from utility companies amounting to a tenth of a cent per kilowatt hour generated in reactors. It has used about $3 billion in the search for a permanent waste repository but still has more than $4 billion on hand, and it is still collecting $600 million a month.
But no permanent repository will be ready until 2013 at the earliest, said the Energy Secretary, Hazel R. O'Leary, in an interview today. A temporary repository is possible, she said, but "we're not going to make it by 1998." The contracts call for the Government to begin pick-ups of the waste then.
 
Mostly Under Water Now
 During the Bush Administration, the Energy Department argued that the contracts did not require it to accept the wastes if it had no place to put them.
Most of the spent fuel is now stored in pools of water next to the reactor buildings, but at many plants these will be full by 1998. Water shields radiation and keeps the waste cool.
Some utilities have built "dry cask storage," concrete and steel casks sitting behind barbed wire near the reactors, and other companies have asked permission to build such casks.
But in several states, most notably Florida, Michigan and Minnesota, state public service commissions have complained that raising electric rates to cover the expense of building such structures amounts to a double charge to consumers for storage, since the companies have already paid the Energy Department.
"I don't think anybody is really pleased by that prospect," said Janice E. Owens of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, a Washington association of state officials that has been pressing the issue.
 
Paying Costs of Casks
 Mrs. O'Leary said she had directed her staff to find a mechanism by which the department could pay the cost of casks at reactor sites, beginning at the dates that the fuel would have been picked up. This might take the form of a credit against future waste fund payments, an aide said.
Mrs. Owens said another mechanism might be for the Energy Department to develop, manufacture and deliver to each reactor a container that would be used for storage for an interim period. The container would then be used for shipping the material to a permanent repository, she said, and would be the final package for the wastes.
The Energy Department is studying whether Yucca Mountain, in the desert outside Las Vegas, Nev., would be suitable as a permanent repository, but the study has been plagued with technical problems and political disputes.
Mrs. O'Leary said she was convinced that for reasons of security, safety and economy, a centralized storage site for the casks was preferable to cask storage at many different reactor sites.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 11, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 3 about disposal of spent fuel from civilian nuclear reactors misstated the amount paid by the utilities to the Federal Government for that purpose. It is about $600 million a year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 The Economy
The nation's unemployment rate fell four-tenths of a point in November, to 6.4 percent, the biggest monthly improvement in 10 years. The decline resulted mainly from strong job creation and the hiring back of many people who had been laid off. [Page 1.] The employment picture improved in New York and New Jersey, but New York City's rate continued to run high. [48.]
Stores, restaurants and hospitals in New York City will no longer be allowed to bar the elderly, teen-agers and children under new age-discrimination rules that will take effect on Dec. 13. [1.] 
 A fund financed by the coal industry to pay for repairs of environmental damage from mining has dried up. [9.]
 
International
Russia's industrial production seems to have stopped falling, the ruble has stabilized and important parts of state industry have been privatized. These are considerable achievements as President Boris N. Yeltsin approaches a crucial election. [1.]
U.S. world trade negotiators made striking changes in strategy to take advantage of the political momentum generated by Nafta's passage. [37.] France may have to convince a country stirred up by years of anti-GATT rhetoric that GATT might be good. [49.]
Many questions remain about how the successor to Mexico's President Salinas will guide the economy. [37.]
OPEC has warned that lower oil prices can wound all the producers in the world, and eventually its consumers. [37.]
 
Companies
Sales of domestically made vehicles surged in November, leading auto executives and analysts to predict that the industry's recovery, which began in the spring, would prove steady. [37.]
U-Haul offered $309.5 million in cash to investors in 17 real-estate partnerships that Shurgard wants to consolidate. [39.]
National Medical Enterprises will sell 28 hospitals and 45 clinics to Healthsouth for about $300 million in cash. [39.]
BCE, Canada's biggest telecommunications company, plans to buy almost one-third of Jones Intercable for $400 million. [39.]
Texas Instruments is forming a three-member office of the chief executive in a move that obscures the line of succession. [39.]
 
Markets
Shares of Pacific Telesis's wireless telephone spinoff were eagerly snatched up by investors. [37.] Stocks inched higher led by technology issues, firm bonds and good economic reports. [38.]
Treasury prices rose sharply despite the good unemployment report. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.23 percent. [47.]
Silver prices soared to three-month highs amid signs of greater industrial demand. Gold also rose. [47.] The dollar was lower. [47.]
 
 Your Money
Taxpayers who use the holidays to review financial records might ferret out savings and avoid surprises in April. [34.]
Tax software for personal computers can provide advice and prepare returns for less cost than hiring tax preparers. [34.]
Investors should be cautious in letting tax consequences drive their investment decisions, financial advisers say. [34.]
The I.R.S. is promoting programs in which companies augment their employee benefits packages with free tax filing. [35.]

HEADLINE: Pitching GATT's Pluses To a Reluctant France

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
A spearhead of free trade for most of the world, GATT has become a four-letter word in France, a frightening symbol of a perfidious American plot to drive French farmers off the land, crush French culture in Hollywood's vice and rob France of its very identity.
Indeed, for more than a year now, first a socialist Government and then its conservative successor have been preparing the French to stand alone in the world, even face ostracism, if France decides it must torpedo a liberalized General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade pact to save the republic. 
 But with hopes rising for an accord acceptable to France perhaps as early as next week, the rightist Government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur may soon face a different challenge: how to convince a country stirred up by anti-GATT rhetoric that GATT might be good for France after all?
Last weekend, former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing warned that France may already have gone too far in its posturing. "Let's beware of isolating France," he said. "It's a dangerous road, full of disappointment and frustration." And if an agreement is not reached, it will take some explaining.
 
An Irritable Mood
 The simplest approach may be for the Government to declare victory, to claim that France's demands have been satisfied, even to boast that France's show of determination has forced the United States to back off. Yet, since any GATT deal will be a compromise, charges of surrender may be unavoidable.
The Government has good reason to be worried. With a painful recession spawning record unemployment, France is in an irritable mood. Further, French farmers have a fearsome record of blocking highways, dumping produce in front of town halls and crying treason whenever their interests are threatened.
Today, in a peaceful warning of what may lie ahead, farmers built a pyramid of wheat in the courtyard of the Louvre Museum here today, imitating the glass pyramid of I. M. Pei. "It's a symbol of European prosperity that is now under attack," one farmer said.
Yet even Mr. Balladur's political future might be in the balance. Since taking office in March, he has enjoyed such popularity that he is now widely considered the front-runner for the Presidential elections in May 1995. A wave of social unrest, though, would badly bruise his image.
 
Seeking Concessions
 Eager to be seen fighting to the end, the Government is still seeking more concessions from the United States, noting that a breakthrough reported by American and European negotiators on Thursday was insufficient. But even in Paris, the expectation is that it will eventually sign onto GATT.
In reality, most French economists and industrialists have long argued that France was set to benefit enormously if seven years of negotiations under the auspices of GATT climaxed in a new global trade accord this month. But so far, their voices have hardly been heard.
Instead, France has focused its indignation on a parallel farm trade pact signed last November by the United States and the European Community requiring a reduction of subsidies for many agricultural exports. As Europe's largest food producers and exporters, French farmers would be hit the hardest.
Then, this fall, after GATT set a deadline of Dec. 15 for the completion of this round of negotiations, dubbed the Uruguay Round because it began in Punta del Este seven years ago, France raised another objection, arguing that the moves to liberalize movies, television and musical recordings would allow Hollywood to crush a French movie industry that had survived because of subsidies.
 
Ignoring a Threat
 On both these issues, because the European Community negotiates as a single trading bloc and can only act unanimously, France's repeated threat to use its veto could not be ignored. And without the participation of the 12-country community, a global trade package would clearly be meaningless.
As part of its strategy, France also has raised the stakes for its European partners, who have been all too aware that a French veto would provoke a big crisis inside a community already weakened by disagreements over the war in former Yugoslavia, exchange rate policies, interest rates, immigration and unemployment.
As a result, while most community countries were campaigning for a GATT agreement, Germany -- France's strongest European ally -- took the lead in preventing France from becoming isolated. "The Americans would be wrong to gamble on a split inside Europe," a senior French official said this week.
The French stance has borne some fruit, forcing Washington to renegotiate with the European Community the farm trade pact signed in Washington last year. And this week, the United States agreed to loosen the timetable for cutting European export subsidies in exchange for greater access to European markets.
 
An Exception for Movies
 On the perceived threat to its movie industry, France first demanded that culture as a whole remain outside GATT. Now it is willing for movie production to be treated as a "specific" exception, a concession the United States has said it would grant if trade in the fast-expanding audio-visual industry was liberalized.
The package under negotiation affects far more than just farm and audio-visual products, involving services for the first time as well as textiles, steel, civil aircraft, telecommunications, computers and government procurement. World Bank economists said they believed that the reduction of the protectionist barriers would bring an extra $200 billion worth of world trade.
If an accord emerges, the challenge for the French Government will be not only to "sell" whatever concessions it has won on farm issues and movies, but also to focus the public's attention on how the country's aircraft, computer, service and luxury industries will profit -- and bring new jobs.
Yet the Government has complicated its task by allowing the emotional farming issue to dominate the debate here. For example, when Patrick Devedjian, a conservative deputy, drew up a report arguing that France should sign a GATT accord "despite agriculture," his own Rally for the Republic party refused to publish it.
Now, with the trade talks approaching their make-or-break point, French farmers said they were already mobilizing in case they felt betrayed. Unlike most French, for whom the GATT debate represents a patriotic stand against ever-encroaching American influence, the farmers are likely to look at the small print of any deal. And some, if not all grain producers are certain to be adversely affected.
"As long as the game is not over, we're not reacting," a spokeswoman for the Federation of French Farmers said today. Her message was clear: Even if the negotiations in Brussels and Geneva end in an agreement this month, the game may be far from over for the Government.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With hopes rising for a trade accord acceptable to France, the Government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, above, may have to convince a country stirred up by anti-General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rhetoric that GATT might be good for France after all. (Chesnot/Witt/Facelly SIPA Press)

HEADLINE: Jobless Picture Brightens In New York and New Jersey

 BODY:
The employment picture improved in New York and New Jersey last month, according to figures released yesterday, but a persistently high rate in New York City continued to drag down the region's recovery.
In New Jersey, where the unemployment rate had dropped sharply in October, to 6.5 percent from 7.7 percent, the improvement continued in November, falling to 6.2 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 Unemployment in New York State, which had risen in October to 7.9 percent from 7.1 percent, reversed course in November, falling back to 7.5 percent.
 
 
New York City Nearly Unchanged
 But the rate in New York City, which for more than a year has been far higher than elsewhere in the region, remained almost unchanged in November. The Federal agency said it stood at 10.2 percent, down from 10.3 percent in October.
In both of the states, the November rates were lower than a year earlier, when they stood at 8.7 in New Jersey and 8.2 percent in New York. In the city, however, the rate was down only slightly from a year ago, when it was 10.5 percent.
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who narrowly lost a bid for re-election last month in a campaign in which the economy was the major issue, said yesterday that the November unemployment report reflected a slow but strengthening recovery for his state.
"We have worked very hard for the past four years to try to make the investments that would result in economic improvements that obviously are coming," he said. "It would have been nicer a couple of months ago, but they're coming nonetheless.
As is the case each month, the Federal report released yesterday covered only 11 major industrial states, with rates for the other states to be reported later in December. The rate for Connecticut was not reported yesterday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offering to Mediate Russian-Ukrainian Disputes on Security

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The United States offered today to mediate a range of thorny security disputes between Russia and Ukraine, including military protection for Ukraine, the dismantling of its nuclear arsenal and Russian compensation for Ukraine's highly enriched uranium, senior State Department officials said today.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher made the offer during a meeting with Ukraine's Foreign Minister, Anatoly Zlenko, as part of the Clinton Administration's strategy to nudge Ukraine into giving up its nuclear weapons by offering it political and economic incentives, the officials said. 
 Officials stressed that the idea was still in a preliminary stage and that Mr. Christopher did not raise the issue directly when he presented Ukraine's security concerns in a later meeting with Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev. But both countries have sought the direct intervention of the United States for some time, and Mr. Zlenko's appeal today led Mr. Christopher to accept.
The goal is to set up talks led by Strobe Talbott, the American Ambassador at Large for the former Soviet Union, and his Russian and Ukrainian counterparts.
 
Third- Largest Nuclear Power
 Ukraine's missiles and bombers make it the world's third-largest nuclear power, after the United States and Russia, and in the last several months, Ukraine has stiffened its conditions for dismantling and destroying them, in part because of a growing pro-nuclear lobby in its Parliament.
Reflecting the ambivalence involved in becoming a non-nuclear state, Ukraine's leaders told Mr. Christopher in Kiev in October that they were committed to ridding the country of nuclear weapons, but want billions of dollars and pledges of Western military protection to do it.
Today Mr. Zlenko denied that his country was using nuclear blackmail to extract security promises and money from the West, telling reporters after the meeting, "I would like to tell you that our economic situation obliges us to find the solution to very acute problems in my country."
But aides to Mr. Christopher said he was very frustrated with his conversation with Mr. Zlenko today, which took place against the backdrop of a meeting of foreign ministers of the 16 NATO members and 22 members of the former Soviet bloc to prepare for next month's NATO summit conference.
Mr. Christopher reportedly pressed Mr. Zlenko on why his country had not yet signed final agreements that spell out how Ukraine intends to spend $175 million in American funds to begin the dismantling of its nuclear weapons. Once the agreement is signed, the United States will send the money.
"Christopher told him there were bureaucratic logjams that he didn't understand," an official said. "He expressed irritation that things were not moving forward at the rate they should be."
The United States has also recently pledged to give Ukraine $155 million in economic aid and loan guarantees in 1994, but only if it makes strides in decentralizing its economy.
"It would be very difficult for us to provide aid in a situation where there remains a command economy," Mr. Christopher said, adding that the United States and Ukraine could not have a "full, satisfactory relationship" until Ukraine became nuclear-free and reformed its economy.
Ukraine's leaders have complained that foreign aid has been inadequate. Mr. Zlenko told reporters that Ukraine needs $2.8 billion to dismantle and destroy its nuclear weapons.
Shortly before coming to Brussels, Mr. Zlenko submitted a letter to NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, requesting legally binding security guarantees for Ukraine, senior State Department officials said. These include a promise to come to Ukraine's defense if it is attacked or threatened with attack by nuclear or conventional weapons and pledges to respect Ukraine's territorial integrity and not to use economic pressure on Ukraine for political goals.
 
Arms Treaty Ratified
 Last month, Ukraine's Parliament ratified the first Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, and in a telephone conversation with President Clinton last week, President Leonid Kravchuk promised to put it into effect.
But Mr. Zlenko said during Mr. Christopher's visit to Ukraine in October that there was no way to guarantee that Ukraine's Parliament will approve the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, as demanded by Washington.
On Thursday, NATO foreign ministers threatened to exclude Ukraine from an American plan that would expand NATO cooperation eastward if it did not fulfill its promises to become a non-nuclear state.
In presenting the plan to the countries of the former Soviet bloc today, Mr. Christopher was met with one basic question by a number of Central European nations: When can we join?
Their reaction was decidedly less enthusiastic than that of America's NATO allies, which embraced the proposal on Thursday as a way to offer a hand to the former Soviet countries but avoid letting them into NATO soon.
Although no one nation opposed the American proposal, a number of ministers clearly told Mr. Christopher that they expected more.
 
Goal Is Membership
 "We, the Poles, expect a more positive response to the aspirations that we regard as justified," the Polish Foreign Minister, Andrzej Oleschowski, said today. The plan, he added, "will meet our expectations only if it opens the prospects of membership to partners, who, like Poland, share the purpose and values of the alliance."
The Czech Foreign Minister, Josef Zieleniec, also urged "the accentuation of the prospects of membership."
Mr. Kozyrev, whose country has opposed any expansion of NATO membership to the east, praised the American plan in remarks to reporters. But in the private ministerial meeting, he proposed a "more pan-European approach" to security, rather than a plan under the control of the NATO powers.

HEADLINE: CLINTON REASSURES CENTRIST COUNCIL

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Gently admonishing centrist Democrats, President Clinton today called for them to be a little more understanding of his need to compromise with the right and the left to build coalitions that will advance the centrist's own cause.
The President delivered his plea in a keynote address to the Democratic Leadership Council, an organization of centrist and conservative Democrats that he helped found and that later helped him in his march to the White House. 
 But lately, members of the council have been concerned that Mr. Clinton has abandoned their views on many issues since taking office.
 
Give and Take of Politics
 The homecoming for Mr. Clinton, a former chairman of the group, could have been the scene of an open brawl over their differing approaches to health care. But the President and the council's leadership alike took pains to mute their differences and underscore their common ground.
First, however, the President rebuked his fellow "new Democrats" for not being more understanding of his need to engage in the give and take of politics to achieve many of the programs they had called for during their years together in the political wilderness -- from national service to budget reform to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"I come here to say more than anything else," Mr. Clinton said, "that when you produce policies that embody these values of opportunity and responsibility and community in a democratic society that elects people to Congress and that requires the President to work with the Congress, that requires the accommodation of various interests all across the country in the private sector and requires a partnership with people at the state and local level; having the best ideas in the world does not free you of the obligation to make difficult decisions."
The President told the audience, made up of hundreds of the council's followers from around the country and from Capitol Hill, "I further come here to say that we don't want to be in the position that some of our predecessors were in the other party, where they were willing from time to time to exalt political rhetoric over reality and where they were willing from time to time to let the perfect become the enemy of the good."
On health care, where Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, prefer an approach that contrasts with one being advocated by the council, the President took a nonconfrontational line, focusing more on his objectives rather than how to get there.
Two leaders of the council, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee, have offered an alternative to the Clinton health plan. Instead of Mr. Clinton's proposals for global budget ceilings set by government, heavy regulation, employer mandates and oversight boards, the Cooper plan seeks to control health care costs primarily by stimulating market competition.
 
Avoiding Public Spat
 "Do not give up on universal coverage and do not give up on the proposition that there has to be a competitive capacity for all, all employers, including small businesses and the self-employed," Mr. Clinton said. "If you will stay with that, then we can reach an agreement next year."
Mr. Clinton's olive branch was reciprocated by Representative Cooper and Senator Breaux after 24 hours of behind the scenes contacts between the council and the White House to prevent any public spat.
In an afternoon speech to the council's annual conference, Mr. Cooper said: "The Cooper-Breaux bill is closer to the Administration bill than any other bill in Congress. We have a lot more in common than we do in difference."
With regard to health care, Mr. Breaux said, "Let me say clearly that we already agree on much that needs to be done, and we, in the D.L.C., share this President's goal of universal health care coverage for all Americans."
Mr. Cooper told reporters, though, that he still had "grave doubts" about the President's reliance on government controls to limit private-sector health spending.
The President also used much of his speech to convince the audience -- and he appeared to succeed -- that his first year in office was guided for the most part by the council's playbook and should be seen by the organization as a major victory.
That was clear, he said, in the $500 billion deficit reduction package, in the trade agreement, in national service, in tax incentives for small businesses and in the expansion of the earned-income tax credit for low-income families. The object of all these initiatives, Mr. Clinton said, is to convince middle-class Americans that the Democratic Party embodies their interests, articulates their aspirations and can protect their future.
 
Meaning of 'New Democrat'
 "We must fight their fight," Mr. Clinton said. "We must give voice to their concerns. We must give them the chance to build security while embracing change.
"And above all, we must honor those basic values of opportunity, responsibility and community, of work and family and faith. This is what it means, in my view, to be a new Democrat. I was proud to campaign as one; I'm proud to govern as one."
The council's president, Al From, after listening to Mr. Clinton's speech, said he had "no doubt that Mr. Clinton is trying to govern as a 'New Democrat.' " He said that while the Democratic Leadership Council was happy with Mr. Clinton's performance, it would keep its pressure on him because, he said, Mr. Clinton "needs the pressure from our side to counter the pressures from the other side."
The council gave Mr. Clinton a paperweight designed as a golf club to help him hold down all the memorandums it is sending to the White House each day.
"I will tell you this," Mr. Clinton said, accepting the gift, "I did not know this until recently, but Al From had recruited the famous American golfer, Tom Watson, into the D.L.C. Watson was the captain of our Ryder Cup team, and when they came to the White House to get a good send-off for their international competition, Watson says to me, 'Hold this golf club, Mr. President.'
"So, I'm holding the club. I swear, Al From wrote this speech for him. He said, 'Now look at your grip. If you move your grip too far to the left, it gets you in trouble on the right. But if you move your grip too far to the right, it gets you in big trouble on the left. The trick is to keep your grip balanced in the center,' said Tom Watson and Al From."
Later, President Clinton began a two-day Western trip by traveling to a health care clinic in Bernalillo, N.M., where he told doctors and patients that his plan for overhauling the health care system would help to expand the services available in rural communities.
The President was to travel on to Los Angeles, where he is scheduled to take part in a panel discussion on Saturday about California's ailing economy.

HEADLINE: Man's 7-Year Search to Find Job Ended With 5 Dead in California

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: OXNARD, Calif., Dec. 3

 BODY:
Alan Winterbourne wanted a job and even ran for Congress partly because the pay looked good.
But his job search evolved into a long battle with bureaucracy, and it ended Thursday in a shooting rampage at a state unemployment office that left him, three state employees and a police officer dead. 
 The police said today that they were uncertain what set off Mr. Winterbourne, who was 33. They were reviewing documents he had left at a newspaper just 30 minutes before the attack in which he went into detail about his seven-year search for work.
"We've got thousands of things to look at," said David Keith, an Oxnard police spokesman. "Our first review of those documents reveals nothing that gives us insight as to motive."
 
Workers Singled Out
 Mr. Winterbourne, armed with a pistol and a shotgun, walked into a local office of the California Employment Development Department just before noon on Thursday and opened fire. He singled out workers, witnesses said.
Mr. Winterbourne fled in a car after a brief shootout with the police. In the pursuit, he killed an Oxnard police officer and was later killed by the police outside another unemployment office in nearby Ventura, when he emerged from his car carrying a gun. Five other people were wounded, one by police bullets.
The police seized two rifles besides the shotgun and pistol. Mr. Winterbourne had no record of arrests, Mr. Keith said.
Avelina Villalobos, the employment department's office manager in Oxnard, said she did not remember seeing Mr. Winterbourne in the office before the shooting. Asked if any of the victims had worked with him, she said, "To my knowledge, nobody had anything to do with him."
 
'Tell Us the Reason Why'
 Flowers and cards piled up today outside the bullet-marked entrance to the office, which was closed for the day. One handwritten note on a red poinsettia read: "We have comfort in God. We know He took four people home. Please tell us the reason why."
A half-hour before the rampage, Mr. Winterbourne left documents with The Ventura Star-Free Press detailing his search for work. He said he would call later to discuss them with an editor.
Among the documents were job applications and 288 letters to every major employer in the county.
Mr. Winterbourne had been unemployed since 1986 after resigning as a computer engineer for the Northrop Corporation, citing an inability to adapt to a change in assignment. Six months after quitting, he filed for unemployment benefits at the Oxnard office, but his application was denied after Northrop said he had left voluntarily.
The envelope left at the newspaper included a transcript of his appeal to an administrative law judge on Dec. 3, 1986. Mr. Winterbourne told the judge he quit Northrop, where he worked on a missile contract, out of fear for his personal safety, but could not elaborate because of Government secrecy.
In 1990 he lost a Republican primary contest to Robert J. Lagamarsino, then an incumbent Congressman representing California's 19th Congressional District. Mr. Winterbourne said before the primary that he was attracted by a Congressman's salary of more than $100,000. "I think it would be a good job," he said.

HEADLINE: North Korea Softens Nuclear Stance

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
In a move that keeps alive the possibility of a diplomatic solution to the escalating crisis over North Korea's nuclear program, Clinton Administration officials said today that North Korea had offered to allow international inspectors wider access to nuclear sites.
North Korea's latest diplomatic initiative falls short of American demands that it broaden its dialogue with South Korea. But Administration officials said tonight that North Korea hadpresented a proposal that offered hope that international economic sanctions might not be needed. North Korea has said it would view such sanctions as an act of war.
 
Presented at U.N. Meeting
 The new North Korean proposal was presented in a meeting today at the United Nations between North Korean diplomats and mid-level State Department officials. 
 It came against the backdrop of escalating tensions over North Korea's refusal to allow international inspectors to visit nuclear sites to make sure Pyongyang is not developing nuclear weapons. Angry oratory from Pyongyang about Western pressure on nuclear inspections has fueled fears of renewed conflict on the Korean Peninsula.
The proposal was made in response to a Clinton Administration effort to forge a diplomatic solution, which was publicly touted by President Clinton last week.
Administration officials familiar with the North Korean offer said it was complex and appeared to establish links between the nuclear and political issues.
 
'Caution Is Prudent Course'
 Traveling with President Clinton in Bernalillo, N.M., the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, would say only of the New York meeting: "We're not characterizing it. We're going to evaluate and talk to our allies about it."
Another White House official said: "When it comes to the North Koreans, we just think caution is the prudent course."
Behind the official veneer of caution, Administration officials said the North Korean proposal signaled movement on the thorny issue of inspections of nuclear facilities.
"They are willing to allow greater access than their previous proposal," an Administration official said. "It is a significant step."
Specifically, the officials said, the North Koreans said that inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency could have have unlimited access to most of the nuclear sites they have officially disclosed. The degree of access to a small number of other sites would have to be negotiated.
North Korea's nuclear program has become one of the most explosive issues on the Clinton Administration's foreign policy agenda. The Central Intelligence Agency believes that North Korea has already diverted enough plutonium for one or two crude bombs. For months, North Korea has added to Western fears by refusing to allow inspectors to visit all of its officially disclosed nuclear sites, raising concerns that it may try to acquire more bomb-grade material.
Washington has sought to persuade North Korea to agree to inspections through diplomacy, holding out the lure of improved economic and diplomatic relations. But at the same time, Washington has said it is prepared to ask the United Nations Security Council to impose international economic sanctions if the North Koreans refuse.
Time has been running out for a diplomatic solution because Hans Blix, the director general of the atomic energy agency, is approaching the point where he must make a formal declaration that the agency can no longer assure the "continuity of safeguards," meaning it can no longer track nuclear material in North Korea.
Already, film has run out of most of cameras installed by the agency at the nuclear site at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of the North Korean capital, and batteries in some cameras have gone dead.
While a formal deadline has not been set, Administration officials say that as a practical matter, North Korea must agree in the next several weeks to the visits at its officially disclosed sites.
What makes the North Koreans' new offer promising, Administration officials said, is that it appears to be signaling that, as part of a broader agreement, it will give inspectors much, if not all, of the access they require to make sure that North Korea is not using its nuclear plants to make plutonium for nuclear bombs.
In their previous offer, the North Koreans offered only to allow the international agency to replace the film and batteries in the cameras. Mr. Blix rejected that as insufficient.
What makes the North Korean offer something less than a major breakthrough, officials say, is that Pyongyang has still not agreed to give the agency the access it needs to determine how much plutonium it might have diverted in the past. To determine how much plutonium might be hidden, the agency wants to inspect two nuclear waste sites that are not on the list of official installations provided to the agency.
 
No Breakthrough on South
 Nor does the proposal put forward by North Korea today signal a major breakthrough its relations with South Korea. The United States wants North Korea to agree to an exchange of envoys with South Korea.
Washington has said that access by inspectors to North Korea's declared nuclear sites and the exchange of envoys are conditions that must be met before the United State will agree to a high-level meeting with the North to discuss the broader agenda of expanded economic and diplomatic relations.
As an added incentive for North Korea to meet the conditions for high-level talks, Washington has offered to cancel next year's annual military exercises with South Korea.
The complexity of the North Korea new proposal, however, means that Washington must consult with South Korea and Japan before responding and seek clarifications on key points, officials said.

HEADLINE: Scars of Mining Endure as Repair Fund Dries Up

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BULAN, Ky.

 BODY:
Like almost everybody who lives in Ajax Hollow, Charles Miller set his house high on the mountain, far above the winding road and out of the path of the unpredictable stream that floods its banks after heavy rain.
Then the hill that was his front yard melted away in a landslide last year. The slide, caused by the steady seepage of water from a coal mine abandoned decades ago, carried away so much dirt that Mr. Miller's front door is now only a few feet from the edge of a 100-foot cliff. 
 Sixteen years ago, as part of legislation to control strip mining, Congress established a fund financed by the coal industry to insure that money would be available to repair the damage caused by mining, like the landslide in front of Mr. Miller's home.
 
Money Used for Benefits
 But in the last several years, money from the fund, part of which is directed for emergency repairs, has declined as Congress and successive Administrations have diverted it to help offset the Federal budget deficit and to provide pension benefits for widows and orphans of union coal miners.
Last June, the part of the fund used for emergency repairs dried up, and the Office of Surface Mining, Reclamation and Enforcement -- the Interior Department agency overseeing the $22 billion coal mining industry -- has made no new money available, even in Kentucky, where the problems are worst.
The office's field engineers here say they have repeatedly asked the Interior Department for help, even appealing directly to Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt in meetings with him last summer in Lexington, Ky. But the engineers say there has been no response.
Mr. Miller, a 30-year-old heavy-equipment operator who is out of work, is now coping with the consequences.
More than a year after the landslide on his property in Ajax Hollow, a construction crew was dispatched by the Office of Surface Mining. The crew recently laid heavy rocks across the hillside to stop the slide temporarily. But there is no money for permanent repairs.
The mud, sticky as chewed gum, is still moving down the steep slope, undermining Mr. Miller's driveway and threatening the house where he lives with his wife, Anna, and their daughter, Jessica Ann. The slide has made the steep path up to the house so unstable that the Millers may soon be cut off from their home.
His mother's house next door is falling into a widening crevice created by the slide. And his sister's house just down the road straddles the crevice and has been condemned.
"It's hard to tell whether it's going to help at all," Mr. Miller said of the emergency work. "They told me there wasn't any money to finish. But I wish they could have put a little more rock in to make it safer for us."
Federal engineers, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity because they said they feared reprisals from Washington, said the difficulties in solving Mr. Miller's emergency reflect longstanding problems in the Office of Surface Mining.
In Washington, the press spokesman for the agency, Alan A. Cole, said the field engineers were "committed in protecting the environment and people in the coal fields." But he added: "Congress's appropriations statutes tightly limit the Interior emergency-reclamation spending in any one state. There will always be more of these emergencies than dollars to fix them."
This year, in more than 70 hollows like this one scattered across the coal fields of eastern Kentucky, landslides caused by negligent practices at mines abandoned decades ago have destroyed homes and caused enormous environmental harm.
During the Reagan and Bush Administrations, Congress and the Interior Department's Inspector General investigated accusations of mismanagement in the Office of Surface Mining and produced a series of critical reports. The Justice Department is conducting a criminal investigation into whether the agency's director during the Bush Administration, Harry M. Snyder, interfered in the enforcement of the strip mining law.
When Mr. Babbitt became Interior Secretary 10 months ago, both the agency's staff and environmental groups hoped he would appoint a strong leader for the agency and provide a clearer mandate for protecting the environment. But engineers and residents here say that under Mr. Babbitt's tenure, conditions in the agency and in the coal fields have got no better and in some cases have grown worse.
"To this point Babbitt has backed off everything he told us he was going to do," said Sidney Cornett, a member of Kentuckians for the Commonwealth, an environmental group based in Prestonsburg, Ky. "Things are going on just as they have, which isn't any good."
Mr. Babbitt's top deputies acknowledge that they had not paid enough attention to problems in the Office of Surface Mining. But they countered assertions that conditions in the agency and the coal fields had deteriorated under the Clinton Administration.
"We have tried to hold the line and keep things together, and that has been met with mixed reviews," said Bob Armstrong, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for land and minerals management. But he said that after just 10 months in office, "you're not going to clean up a genuine mess that took 12 years to develop."
The Office of Surface Mining "is a can of fishhooks," Mr. Armstrong said. He added, "Our efforts have been slower than we would like, but I would really take issue with the fact that it is worse."
Mr. Armstrong and the Federal engineers in Kentucky agree that perhaps the most visible problem at the Office of Surface Mining is that it has been leaderless for nearly a year. Robert Uram, a San Francisco lawyer who was a top Interior Department lawyer from 1975 to 1983, has been nominated by Mr. Babbitt to fill the post.
Coal industry executives praised the nomination, which will be considered by the Senate early next year. But environmentalists denounced it, saying that in his private practice Mr. Uram has represented mining companies seeking to avoid regulation.
The Interior Department's critics say they are also concerned that the Administration is considering a proposal by coal states to limit the ability of citizens to bring formal complaints against coal companies for polluting and causing safety hazards.
 
Concern for National Forests
 Conservationists are critical, too, of a Clinton Administration decision in September not to appeal a court ruling that lifted a ban on strip mining in the Wayne National Forest in Ohio. Robert More, an Interior Department lawyer, said the ruling would not set a precedent. But environmental lawyers said the court decision could pave the way for strip mining in national forests in eight states east of the Mississippi.
"If you had told me after the election that conditions were going to deteriorate under Clinton, I'd have said you were crazy," said L. Thomas Galloway, a Washington lawyer who helped write the 1977 Surface Mining Reclamation and Control Act, the Federal strip mining law. "But that's what's happened to some extent."
Of the industrial technologies the Interior Department oversees, perhaps none is more destructive than strip mining, in which thousands of tons of rock and dirt are heaved aside to lay bare seams of coal. Streams are polluted with sediment and acidic material, and wastes are dumped down mountainsides, causing slides.
Over time, water seeping under the wastes causes entire hillsides to move. Such dumping has been illegal since 1977, but landslides at abandoned strip mines are increasing. Federal inspectors said new slides were also likely at some existing mines because coal operators there were still dumping haphazardly, knowing that penalties are weak. A violation typically brings a fine of a few hundred dollars, they said.
The strip mining law was intended not only to end destructive practices but also to repair millions of acres damaged by mining and to respond to emergencies. The law required the coal industry to pay an environmental tax -- 35 cents a ton for coal from strip mines and 15 cents a ton for coal from underground mines.
 
Millions in Yearly Interest
 The Abandoned Mine Lands Fund now has $678 million collected from the coal tax and is accumulating interest of $35 million to $40 million a year. The growing total is being used to help offset the Federal deficit, said Kristi Heisel, a senior budget official in the Interior Department office. In addition, each year the tax raises $240 million, although Congress allows only $190 million to be spent for restoring land damaged by strip mining. Since 1992, Congress has directed that the interest and the remaining $50 million raised in coal tax revenues be used for pension benefits that are due the widows and orphans of workers from bankrupt coal companies.
These shifts upset construction laborers as well as environmentalists. In 1985, more than 1,000 people were working in eastern Kentucky to repair lands damaged by slides resulting from strip mines, according to Federal estimates. This fiscal year, only two projects, employing a handful of workers, were under way, one of them on Mr. Miller's property.
Construction workers said they were dismayed by the trend, especially in light of President Clinton's promise to link environmental restoration with economic rejuvenation.
"Congress took care 16 years ago to see that there would plenty of money to do the work," said John Basso, a construction contractor and former mine inspector from Hazard, Ky. "But now it's being spent for almost everything else than what it was originally intended. Now you tell me, is that right?"

HEADLINE: As Oil Prices Slide, OPEC Reaches Out for Cooperation

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Steep drops in oil prices, like those that followed OPEC's failure to agree on production cuts last week, are usually greeted with relief from consumers.
But the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, in an apparent retreat from a seven-year policy of defending oil prices, has issued a tacit warning that lower oil prices are a double-edged sword that can wound all the world's producers, and eventually its consumers. 
 OPEC and oil industry officials said the organization was calling for an international effort to shore up oil prices, which fell to a three-year low of $15.31 a barrel in the United States on Monday, the first trading day after the OPEC meeting. Falling oil prices, they say, are a problem for all countries, not just the 12 members of the oil group.
 
 
Help From Industrial Nations
 The new strategy is to push industrial countries to cooperate in maintaining production levels and prices.
OPEC ministers argue that a steep fall in oil prices will depress the vast and powerful oil industries of the United States and Britain, as well as the many service industries dependent on them.
The organization also argues, and oil experts agree, that if earnings of large oil companies fall drastically,investment in exploration for oil will slow, creating the potential for an eventual shortage many years from now.
Among the less-developed nations that are oil producers, many count on oil revenues to pay for ambitious economic and social plans. A shortfall in financing for such programs could have a profound impact on Mexico, Oman, Yemen, Malaysia, Brunei, Colombia and especially Russia.
 
 
Impact on Russia
 "Oil exports represent the bulk of export revenues for the Russians," said Matthew Sagers, an oil affairs expert at Planecon, a Washington consulting firm. A steep drop in prices, he said, would affect "the pace of economic reforms, their ability to borrow money against oil sales and the stability of the currency, even if it eases the burden on the Russian consumer."
 Declining oil revenues have certainly hurt OPEC members. With inflation taken into account, oil prices today are nearly at 1986 levels. But the member nations, particularly Saudi Arabia, the group's largest producer, have undertaken costly civil projects they can now barely afford. Saudi Arabia has even resorted to borrowing to finance its projects.
The squeeze has led to political upheavals in many OPEC nations.
Algeria's economic situation, for example, has deteriorated sharply as oil revenues have dropped. The country faced a major uprising by unemployed youth in 1988 and is now locked in a virtual civil war intensified by the inability of the Government to improve economic conditions.
Nigeria, too, has been in political and economic turmoil for years, undergoing one military coup after another as its economy fails to keep up with the demands of a growing population.
And Venezuela's development program, sustained for decades with oil revenue, has collapsed.
The first indication of the new strategy became evident at the OPEC meeting of oil ministers in Vienna last week.
 
 
A One-Day Meeting
 During the one-day gathering, the organization's shortest in years, the 12 members served notice that they would not reduce their collective output below the present level of 24.5 million barrels a day. None of the individual nations, continuing to crave oil revenues, appeared willing to sacrifice.
Instead, the organization pointedly called in its official communique for "international cooperation to support prices."
OPEC officials confirmed that the notion of universal production restraint was spreading within the organization. "I think it is time for everyone to face their responsibility," a senior official said.
In a telephone interview today, Alirio Parra, Venezuela's energy minister, said OPEC was determined to "sweat it out."
"Most of us are not willing to sacrifice output any longer," he said. "There will be no OPEC production cuts before March, when we are scheduled to meet and evaluate the situation. Until then, we just have to wait and see."
A number of oil industry analysts warned, however, that unless OPEC returned immediately to its role of balancing supply and demand by reducing its collective output, it would risk seeing oil prices head toward $10 a barrel or lower.
 
 
'They Will Lose'
 "This is a deadly game; they will lose," Gary N. Ross, the chief executive of Petroleum Industry Research Associates of New York, said in an interview.
Mehdi Verzi, an oil analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London, agreed in a telephone interview that oil prices would probably head lower.
"Oil prices have entered a new trading range that can only get lower in the absence of an OPEC production cut," Mr. Verzi said.
The recent failure to raise prices is only the latest example of the oil organization's dwindling power. Even though the OPEC share of oil sales has increased -- to nearly 25 million barrels of the world's estimated daily oil consumption of 68 million barrels -- prices have remained low.
In 1986, OPEC tried a similar strategy of maintaining production, but it eventually failed and prices fell to $10 a barrel, provoking a change of strategy in an emergency meeting.
 Analysts say the organization's latest quest to preserve its share of the oil market is misguided. OPEC, they say, would be better off seeking higher oil prices and cutting as much production as necessary,
"Cartels work if they sell oil," said John H. Lichtblau, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "They don't work when they just try to preserve market shares."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Hits a 3-Month High On Signs of Economic Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Silver prices soared to a three-month high yesterday amid signs that the American economy is growing fast enough to bolster demand from industrial users. Gold prices also rose.
Increased economic activity can lead to increased use of silver, which is used for a variety of industrial applications. 
 "Silver rallied on the favorable economic data," said Bette Raptopolous, analyst with Prudential Securities in New York.
Silver for March delivery, the most active futures contract, leaped 20 cents higher, to $4.85 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Meanwhile, the active February gold contract jumped $3, to $378.60 an ounce.
The Government reported that the nation's unemployment rate fell to 6.4 percent in November from 6.8 percent the month before. In addition, its index of leading indicators jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in October, signaling continued improvement in the months ahead. And factory orders surged by 1.2 percent in October to their highest level ever.
Better economic news prompted new demand from commodity funds, traders said. "The funds are looking to economic reports as justification for buying or selling," said Daniel Weissman, head of precious metals trading at MTB Bank in New York.
Rising demand from the Middle East and India are also helping silver prices rise, traders said. Demand for silver in India could reach 100 million ounces this year, according to the New York consultants CPM Group, a 73 percent gain from the 57.8 million ounces used last year.
A growing economy and reduced import restrictions are pushing up demand for silver in India.
The collapse in oil prices is not having much of an effect on gold because of perceptions that the price drop is not likely to last long, Ms. Raptopolous said.
Crude oil has plunged about 29 percent this year, hitting a five-year low of $14.95 a barrel on Thursday amid concerns Iraqi crude exports will return to already glutted markets by the second quarter of 1994. Yesterday, crude oil for January delivery picked up 2 cents to settle at $14.97 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The price of oil, a leading industrial commodity, is a key ingredient in future inflation. Investors often buy gold when inflation threatens the value of other assets.
