 THE DESTINY MAKERS. By George Turner. (Avonova/Morrow, $20.) The Australian novelist dispassionately homes in on a tough issue: In a world of runaway population growth, who decides which babies don't get born?
DREAM OF GLASS. By Jean Mark Gawron. (Harcourt Brace, $21.95.) A complex and engrossing philosophical novel that explores, with great energy and flashes of poetry, the future of freedom in a world dominated by computers.
THE HAMMER OF GOD. By Arthur C. Clarke. (Spectra/Bantam, $19.95.) Who but Mr. Clarke could write such a bracing, cheerful story about scientists cooperating to ward off an asteroid heading for Earth?
THE INNKEEPER'S SONG. By Peter S. Beagle. (Roc/Penguin, $20.) A beautifully written tale of love and loss, set in a world of hard-edged magic where quests don't necessarily end in triumph and moral lessons are teasingly complex.
NIGHTSIDE THE LONG SUN. By Gene Wolfe. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $21.95.) Mr. Wolfe, master of the tightly focused epic, begins a new multivolume series about a young priest whose faith leads him to disturbing discoveries about his world and his gods.
VIRTUAL LIGHT. By William Gibson. (Bantam, $21.95.) The man who initiated cyberpunk with his novel "Neuromancer" offers a mellower but no less gripping view of the future, with likable characters and an upbeat ending.
WHITE QUEEN. By Gwyneth Jones. (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $19.95.) A stylistically challenging novel about the profound bewilderment generated when humanoid aliens in the 21st century land on an Earth transformed by political revolution and a new pathogen.
 
Spies & Thrillers
 
 BRIDES OF BLOOD. By Joseph Koenig. (Grove, $19.95.) What makes this crackling, shocking police procedural about a murdered prostitute wildly different is its setting -- the hate-filled streets and prisons of present-day Iran.
HARD DRIVE. By David Pogue. (Diamond/ Berkley, paper, $4.99.) A company in Silicon Valley, on the verge of unveiling a computer that takes dictation, is foiled by a virus, and Armageddon begins.
THE JOURNEYMAN TAILOR. By Gerald Seymour. (Edward Burlingame/HarperCollins, $20.) An Irish terrorist and a woman who is a British secret service agent tangle in this morally complex, captivating novel.
MAESTRO. By John Gardner. (Otto Penzler, $23.) The Herbie Kruger trilogy has become a tetralogy, because the old ace of British intelligence has come out of retirement to interrogate one of his favorite conductors, a 90-year-old German-born American suspected of being a Nazi and a K.G.B. informant.
THE NIGHT MANAGER. By John le Carre. (Knopf, $24.) Mr. le Carre's solution to the disappearance of the Soviet Union is to create an arms dealer-cum-drug lord as smart as the Devil.
POINT OF IMPACT. By Stephen Hunter. (Bantam, $21.95.) This superbly written page turner, about a sniper-turned-hunter who has been framed, teaches us, among other things, the details of shooting at a target half a mile away.
THE SILENCER. By Simon Louvish. (Interlink, cloth, $24.95; paper, $10.95.) This stingingly written novel about an Israeli journalist whose career is stymied by a mysterious figure called the Silencer partakes of satire, surrealism, politics and espionage.
 
Sports
 
 THE ERA. 1947-1957: When the Yankees, the Giants, and the Dodgers Ruled the World. By Roger Kahn. (Ticknor & Fields, $22.95.) Eleven seasons of meaningful lunacy as seen by a New York baseball bard.
JIM MURRAY: An Autobiography. By Jim Murray. (Macmillan, $20.) The Pulitzer Prize-winning sportswriter covers his own eventful life with stinging wit.
THE LIP: A Biography of Leo Durocher. By Gerald Eskenazi. (Morrow, $23.) A biography of the colorful player (Yankees, Reds, Dodgers and Cardinals) and manager (Dodgers, Giants, Cubs and Astros), who mouthed off until his death in 1991 at the age of 86.
THE MAN IN THE DUGOUT: Baseball's Top Managers and How They Got That Way. By Leonard Koppett. (Crown, $22.50.) A veteran sportswriter gives a breakneck, boiled-down history of the game from the manager's perspective.
O HOLY COW! The Selected Verse of Phil Rizzuto. Edited by Tom Peyer and Hart Seely. (Ecco, paper, $8.95.) Not just an elegy to the many moments of baseball boredom but poetry that captures the confusion of the human mind, by the longtime Yankee play-by-play announcer.
 
Travel, Nature & Adventure
 
 AT THE HAND OF MAN: Peril and Hope for Africa's Wildlife. By Raymond Bonner. (Knopf, $24.) Mr. Bonner inspects nearly every relevant argument about conservation in Africa and he finds that there will be none, without support by intelligent exploitation.
THE AYE-AYE AND I: A Rescue Mission in Madagascar. By Gerald Durrell. (Arcade, $22.95.) Mr. Durrell's 24th book, written in support of grave efforts to save a rare mammal and its environment, is a sharply detailed romp in an enchanted landscape of unique flora and fauna.
THE CRYSTAL DESERT: Summers in Antarctica. By David G. Campbell. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Mr. Campbell, a biologist, spent three seasons in the Antarctic and returned with eerily clear perceptions of that sere and uninhabitable place.
DRUMS ALONG THE CONGO: On the Trail of Mokele-Mbembe, the Last Living Dinosaur. By Rory Nugent. (Houghton Mifflin, cloth, $21.95; paper, $10.95.) And was it found? Well, something was, and the trip was loads of fun.
EXTREME CONDITIONS: Big Oil and the Transformation of Alaska. By John Strohmeyer. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A journalist's account, full of old-fashioned outrage, of the self-destruction of a nouveau riche state.
GOING BACK TO BISBEE. By Richard Shelton. (University of Arizona, cloth, $35; paper, $15.95.) A memorable ride through time and experience from booming Tucson to struggling Bisbee, Ariz., with fascinating sidetracks into botany, history and biology.
THE HIDDEN LIFE OF DOGS. By Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) What do dogs want, feel, even think? A close, sympathetic observer's data make this a profoundly unsilly question.
KAYAKING THE FULL MOON: A Journey Down the Yellowstone River to the Soul of Montana. By Steve Chapple. (HarperCollins, $23.) Self-discovery by an arduous journey into the wilderness is a literary device that works just fine in this instance for the author and his family.
KING LEOPOLD'S DREAM: Travels in the Shadow of the African Elephant. By Jeremy Gavron. (Pantheon, $23.) An Englishman's boundlessly energetic quest finds elephants distinctly less endangered, in some places, than they used to be.
NATURAL OPIUM: Some Travelers' Tales. By Diane Johnson. (Knopf, $21.) The distinguished essayist meditates frugally and perceptively on the psychological strangeness of travel, from Tanzania to Mormon Utah.
NOAH'S GARDEN: Restoring the Ecology of Our Own Back Yards. By Sara Stein. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Ms. Stein's argument is persuasive and succinct: You have no ground to bemoan the fate of the rain forests unless you've cultivated diversity in your own patch of suburbia.
PICTURING NATURE: American Nineteenth-Century Zoological Illustration. By Ann Shelby Blum. (Princeton University, $59.50.) This clear, critical narrative by a former archivist at Harvard University's Museum of Comparative Zoology shows that 19th-century American illustrations of animals form a record of how science looked, in both the passive and active sense.
ROAD SCHOLAR: Coast to Coast Late in the Century. By Andrei Codrescu. (Hyperion, $19.95.) A poet and author mounts a red '68 Caddy for a journey in essay writing, a countertravelogue that visits lots of spots important in the less orthodox history of America.
SONGBIRDS, TRUFFLES, AND WOLVES: An American Naturalist in Italy. By Gary Paul Nabhan. (Pantheon, $22.) A personal, informative and entertaining tour of Tuscany and Umbria, by an ethnobotanist who has set out to see whether the example of St. Francis has served the land well.
VISIONS OF CALIBAN: On Chimpanzees and People. By Dale Peterson and Jane Goodall. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) This odd and moving dialogue between an English professor and a chimp expert centers on the master-slave relationship between humans, who often act like brutes, and chimps, who are remarkably human.
WHOREDOM IN KIMMAGE: Irish Women Coming of Age. By Rosemary Mahoney. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Having traveled through Dublin and Corofin talking to women -- nudists, nuns, poets and preteens -- Ms. Mahoney captures some stunning shards of Irish life.
 
True Crime
 
 DEATH BENEFIT: A Lawyer Uncovers a Twenty-Year Pattern of Seduction, Arson, and Murder. By David Heilbroner. (Harmony/Crown, $20.) How a straight-arrow lawyer ran to earth the appalling psychopath who killed a client's daughter.
EVERYTHING SHE EVER WANTED: A True Story of Obsessive Love, Murder, and Betrayal. By Ann Rule. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A harrowing look at a murderous modern-day Southern psychopath.
THE MISBEGOTTEN SON. A Serial Killer and His Victims: The True Story of Arthur J. Shawcross. By Jack Olsen. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A fascinating and forceful account of a life of torture, mutilation and homicide.
ONCE UPON A TIME: A True Story of Memory, Murder, and the Law. By Harry N. MacLean. (HarperCollins, $22.50.) A true-crime tale that transcends its genre in its examination of the sudden return of a witness's buried memory.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 5, 1993

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2220 words

HEADLINE: Travel

BYLINE: By Francine Prose; Francine Prose's most recent book is a collection of stories, "The Peaceable Kingdom."

 BODY:
READING travel narratives, we may find ourselves pausing to wonder precisely how great travel writing (say, Rebecca West's "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon") differs from the neighbors' slide show of the family's five days in Rome. In neither case do we take the journey, but only hear about it secondhand; in both cases, selected moments and views have been chosen for us, so unlike the total immersion we seek when we travel ourselves.
Having felt our eyes glaze over when dear ones describe their sojourns abroad, we can only marvel at the skill of those rare writers we'll allow to travel for us. Often, they are people to whom odd or exciting things happen, authors who can observe and describe, deep thinkers or snappy prose stylists. Agreeable or crabby, their dispositions hardly matter so long as they are smart, aware, fired with curiosity and untroubled by the more banal tourist prejudices and anxieties. A survey of recent travel books inspires us to consider the chasm between Rebecca West's accounts of Dubrovnik or Mostar and the slides of the kids next door, posed in front of the Colosseum. 
 Rebecca West is only one of many eloquent women travelers represented in Mary Morris's anthology MAIDEN VOYAGES: Writings of Women Travelers (Vintage, paper, $14), edited in collaboration with her husband, Larry O'Connor. One can breeze through Ms. Morris's introduction ("Women, I have come to feel, move through the world differently than men. . . . The fear of rape . . . most dramatically affects the ways women move through the world") and hop on board with Boxcar Bertha, riding the rails in 1930's Illinois with hobos of both sexes. In 1717, Lady Mary Wortley Montagu notes how Turkish women hide under their veils when sneaking off to meet their lovers. A century and a half later, Mabel Sharman Crawford's "Through Algeria" pleads for a woman's right to tourism, a right taken for granted by the boy-crazy Margaret Foun taine, encouraging and coyly eluding a baron from Palermo, and by the intrepid Mary Kingsley, playfully writing about using salt to dislodge thirsty African leeches. ("It was most comic to see us salting each other; but in spite of the salt's efficacious action I was quite faint from loss of blood.")
There are lots of wild adventures here: Alexandra David-Neel uses a Tibetan Buddhist breathing technique to raise her body heat and keep from freezing to death. In China, Emily Hahn becomes the opium addict she "always wanted to be." Dressed as a man, Sarah Hobson rides a moped through Iran. There is also plenty of attitude: Mary McCarthy complaining about the noise in Florence, Mrs. F. D. Bridges slandering polygamists in Salt Lake City in 1880: "Two rather depressed-looking wives, ugly middle-aged women in poke bonnets, holding unlovely babies, sat in the back, while the new young wife, with her baby in smart hat and feathers, occupied the front seat with their lord and master; not a pleasant or poetical domestic picture; and they were all so ugly!"
Reading the pieces in chronological order provides a mini-history of travel writing. We're reminded that it once was enough for a writer simply to go somewhere and describe the landscape and the exotic local costumes. But in the age of packaged safari tours, the stakes are dangerously higher. Now the travel writer must do something life-threatening or original, or at least stick around long enough to know more than the average tourist.
Cathy N. Davidson is the latter sort of writer. She made four lengthy trips to Japan in the 1980's, and 36 VIEWS OF MOUNT FUJI: On Finding Myself in Japan (Dutton, $20) documents her passion to understand what she found there. This appealing book is always sincere -- and often better than that. Ms. Davidson taught at Kansai Women's University in the suburbs halfway between Kobe and Osaka, and no one could have tried harder to fathom Japanese culture. The result is a series of illuminations not unlike the sudden break in the clouds that finally lets her glimpse Mount Fuji from the window of a bullet train.
In her English class, Ms. Davidson's students must struggle so hard to speak that they have no energy left for decorum or concealment; asked to tell the class about their summer, they detail the gastrointestinal woes endured over the school vacation. A chance encounter in a restaurant reveals the Japanese obsession with foreign table manners. Ms. Davidson's friends take her to places ordinary visitors rarely see: to the sacred grove of a priestess on Okinawa, and to a retreat at which the writer bathes with the Japanese Women's Studies Society, where she notes the women's lack of shame and their "ritual attention to the body." When her husband's brother and sister-in-law are killed in a car accident in Canada, her neighbors and colleagues shower her family with such generosity, warmth and kindness that we may want to rethink what we have heard about a society based on propriety, distance and reserve.
In theory, the society that Thomas Matthews attempts to join in A VILLAGE IN THE VINEYARDS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23) is closer to our own; yet he and his girlfriend, Sara, are embraced by the Bordeaux wine country with less warmth than Ms. Davidson is accorded in urban Japan. A fervent oenophile, Mr. Matthews rents a house in a wine-making village in order to deepen his knowledge of "French wine and country life." He works in the vineyards alongside his neighbors and learns about wine production; he and Sara hear gossip, attend church services and bingo games, and grieve with the villagers when a local woman is electrocuted in a freak accident.
Here, too, we find glimpses of the hidden: a priest takes the American couple on a tour of his private museum of prehistoric artifacts. Yet this book may be less compelling to travelers than to the sort of wine lovers who have ample patience for a certain sort of lyrical paean to the nuances of the grape: "Wine is the most articulate of beverages. To an attentive and practiced palate, a glass of wine speaks of the grapes that comprise it, the soil that nourished the grapes, and the weather that shaped the year of its making." I was more fascinated by the loving descriptions of what Mr. Matthews and his companion cooked or were served to eat.
Ernst Aebi, a Swiss-born artist who made his fortune "as a renovator of lofts in New York City's SoHo," takes a far more interactive approach to his subject in SEASONS OF SAND (Simon & Schuster, $22). On a quixotic camel safari from Timbuktu to the infamous salt mines in Taoudenni, Mali, Mr. Aebi wanders into the desolate, impoverished settlement of Araouane and decides to take on the challenge of being its sole salvation. After a trip to Switzerland, he returns to Araouane with a "Land-Rover 110 Turbo Diesel, equipped with sand tires, extra fuel tanks, solar panels, a heavy-duty roof rack, reinforced springs and an electric winch," hooked up to a double horse trailer loaded with "saplings, soil, buckets, shovels, tarpaulins, sprinkling cans, seeds, rakes, spare tires, spare parts, medicine, food and lots of jerricans full of water."
A believer in the efficiency of a "benevolent (I hoped) dictatorship," buoyed by natural confidence and the fact that he seems not to have heard of the word "imperialism," Mr. Aebi takes Araouane by storm. Amazingly, he succeeds in revitalizing it -- at least for a while. Soon the villagers have a productive garden, young trees, a school, a hotel and a market economy; then another invasion, this time by Tuareg rebels, undoes Mr. Aebi's work.
"Seasons of Sand" is an interesting book partly because it goes no deeper than it does. Mr. Aebi expresses regret for having introduced greed to Araouane, where previously there was nothing to covet. And he manipulates new desires in order to wipe out entrenched social institutions like the virtual enslavement of blacks by their lighter-skinned Arab neighbors. What are we to make of all this? The reader feels a creeping suspicion of Mr. Aebi's white-hunter, can-do spirit, and yet because of it starving people were now eating vegetables from their own gardens, not sacks of foreign-aid staples. And when the desert and its marauders reclaimed the town, was it worse off than before? Mr. Aebi doesn't think too hard about the political and moral implications of his story, but the reader may -- and may find that these questions enrich the experience of reading his book.
Miles Morland's MILES AWAY: A Walk Across France (Random House, $21) offers less food for thought, though some readers (presumably not those who have made the book a best seller in England) may wonder crossly how Mr. Morland and his wife could possibly find so many grubby hotels and inedible meals in southwestern France. ("How boring Gascon cooking was. How many different things can you do to a duck?") As the tale begins, Mr. Morland forsakes his upscale wage-slave career in the London stock-brokerage office of the American firm CS First Boston, and with his wife (whom he had divorced and then remarried five years earlier) takes off on a compulsive, often tedious and uncomfortable monthlong walk from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic through the foothills of the Pyrenees.
It would take a stronger writer, I'm afraid, to keep me transfixed by frequent updates on the couple's blisters and sneakers and by their costly wrong turns, or to render me suitably charmed when Mr. Morland has a bit of fun with two waitresses' "lack of polish." (" 'More at home milking a goat than serving wine,' I had said.") Readers who cannot hold out until Peter Mayle writes another book may be amused by this journey, inspired by Mr. Morland's trading of security for "adventure," and aware that their own such adventure might resemble the Morlands': equipped with pages from a wide selection of guidebooks, worried about the next night's hotel, plagued by growling farm dogs and their own frayed nerves and sore feet.
Hanns Ebensten's VOLLEYBALL WITH THE CUNA INDIANS: And Other Gay Travel Adventures (Viking, $22) left me with a similar sense of not getting the joke, exactly. Mr. Ebensten, the head of a travel company and "a pioneer in the field of gay group travel," has journeyed from Easter Island to Mount Olympus; he's led intrepid tourists on rafting expeditions through the Grand Canyon, to remote Greek monasteries and the idyllic San Blas Islands off the coast of Panama. Along the way, he's crossed paths with practically everyone: Princess Margaret at the Cotton House on Mustique, Marlene Dietrich cozying up to the bar in a Paris club. And isn't that cute Panamanian guy . . . Manuel Noriega? ("Despite his ugly, puffy face and short, stout body . . . this ithyphallic colonel exuded sexuality like a randy beast.")
Mr. Ebensten aims for the frisson rather than the revelation, a choice that may explain how a writer whose father fled Nazi Germany can rhapsodize over motorcycle police sent to Florence to suppress a student demonstration: "The arrival of these Cocteau-like angels of death turned the dormitory into a homosexual's dream come true. . . . They wore black leather jackets, black turtleneck sweaters, jodhpurs, and boots up to their knees; they had holsters strapped around their waists and menacing billy clubs and handcuffs hanging from their heavy belts."
Given his affection for "picturesquely ragged" Central Asians, it seems unfair of him to fault gay tourists for their fashion mistakes: "Tour members often cannot resist a mania for going forth dressed ludicrously in T-shirts or tank tops and tiny shorts that last suited them 30, 40 or 50 years before in kindergarten."
One would rather watch the neighbors' slide show than hear Mr. Ebensten boast about his good taste and sexual charisma. Happily, other travel books remind us of the difference it makes when a writer really knows a particular place. MAGIC PRAGUE (University of California, $30), by Angelo Maria Ripellino (who was a professor of Russian and a lecturer in Czech language and literature at the University of Rome before his death in 1978), is such a book -- though, to be sure, a strange one, less travelogue than evocation, and the result of a long obsession with the literary, mythological and historical currents that run through the Old Town of Prague.
Not surprisingly, Franz Kafka haunts this volume, as do the mythical golem and the artist Giuseppe Arcimboldo, who lived in Prague when he painted his fanciful human faces assembled from fruits and vegetables. Artfully translated from the Italian by David Newton Marinelli and edited by Michael Henry Heim, much of the text is dense, difficult, lyrical, almost incantatory: "I see a double key to Prague: it is not only a repository of splendors and treasures, dainties nibbled at often enough by foreign boars over the centuries; it is also a heap of singed and stained rubbish, showcases exuding resignation like a large family of chipped utensils, broken-down gadgets and spoiled trinkets." Yet, having read "Magic Prague," we feel that, arriving in the Czech capital, we'd recognize it instantly from what we've learned in these pages, that we could get along more easily than if we'd studied a conventional guide or a book that told us where its writer stayed, what he ate and who he met.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephane Asseo, owner of the Domaine de Courteillac, a winery in Ruch, near Bordeaux, France. (SARA MATTHEWS/FROM "A VILLAGE IN THE VINEYARDS")(pg. 84)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 44; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Slouching Toward Utopia in the South Bronx

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
From the classical colonnades of the Greek Revival to the heavy metal wrappers of Frank Gehry, American architects have found many ways to tell the story of modern democracy. But if architecture's version of that story is to be more than a fairy tale, architects must learn to do more than tell it. They must also try to live it. Louis Sullivan once said that for him architecture was not an art but a religion -- "part of the greater religion of democracy." He had a good sense of priorities. It is fine for architects to focus on symbolic forms and images. But if their symbols are disconnected from social reality, their buildings may end up mocking the values they represent.
For the past year, residents of the South Bronx have been working to create a solidly democratic content for architectural form. Rather than sit back and wait for architects and planners to tell them how to improve the prospects for their legendarily troubled borough, they have joined with architects and planners to renegotiate the social contract between citizens and builders. Bronx Center, as the heartening project for this area is called, is becoming a national model for community-based planning, though that dull term scarcely conveys the excitement of an undertaking that promises to change the way people think about urban design. 
 The project began a year and a half ago with the recognition that the South Bronx has suffered not only from neglect but from the wrong kind of attention, and not just from those in the media who routinely depict the place as a hell on earth. In fact, many people like living there. And in recent years, about $2 billion worth of public and private projects have been planned for the area, including the new Police Academy, a court center and a housing complex. But the borough's president, Fernando Ferrer, had the presence of mind to look this gift horse in the mouth.
Obviously, Mr. Ferrer welcomed investment in his borough. But he was painfully familiar with the kind of project that, while physically located in a community, contributes little of value to it. Streets and parks planned by professionals who may have good abstract ideas about places but little knowledge of what it's like to live in this one. Housing projects that displace people from existing buildings and shred the urban fabric. Office buildings that generate jobs for which local residents lack adequate skills. Architecturally impressive buildings that provide temporary construction jobs but offer residents no long-range economic stability.
In 1992, Mr. Ferrer asked Richard A.
Kahan, a former president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, to help him develop a strategy to revitalize a 300-block area east of Yankee Stadium in the heart of the South Bronx. Mr. Kahan, who volunteered his services, enlisted other volunteers to form a steering committee and hired organizers who corralled several hundred Bronx residents into a series of public forums. Working groups were set up to focus on specific issues like health care, job training, housing and transportation. Volunteer architects, meeting in a private home, set up design studios where residents learned how to translate their ideas into urban forms.
Those ideas range widely from traditional urban design concepts (renovated subway stations, community gardens in vacant lots) to more ambitious proposals (alternative high schools at Yankee Stadium and the Police Academy; "greenway" streets leading to small, "defensible" parks). Mr. Kahan has kept the groups coordinated, while Harold DeRienzo, a political activist, steered the meetings along a firmly democratic course.
The group scored a major success last year when it halted the city's plan for Melrose Commons, a 2,600-unit housing complex near 161st Street and Third Avenue that would have displaced about 800 people from their homes. With the support of the Dinkins administration, residents worked with the architects Petr Stand and Lee Weintraub to overhaul the plan, formulating their own recommendations for housing, stores, routes for pedestrians and cars, and the design of a new park. Their revised plan was approved by the City Planning Commission last month.
At the edge of the planned Melrose Commons complex stands a fine architectural landmark, the old Bronx Borough Courthouse, a granite Beaux-Arts monument built in 1915. Empty since 1978, it looms as a symbol of lapsed civic pride. Mr. Kahan, Mr. DeRienzo and their colleagues want to restore the building and its spirit by turning part of it into a planning center. Renovating the building will cost $800,000. The spirit, which is priceless, was already in vibrant evidence at a meeting I attended a few weeks ago at Lincoln Hospital. The cooperative approach was at the opposite end of the spectrum from the imperial planning practiced by Robert Moses. And it contrasted sharply with the typical community board hearing, where politicians, developers and architects line up against neighborhood activists and watch their energy disperse in rancor.
The image that surfaced in my mind was Ellis Island: this meeting was a port of entry into a city that is made not just of steel and concrete but of information. These people are heirs to the construction workers Lewis Hines photographed in the 1920's, bolting girders into the skyline. Instead of using riveting guns, they are wielding their experience. It turns out to be powerful stuff. They tell each other stories, and a language of urbanism begins to take shape as their stories intersect.
At one working-group session, someone announces that there is $400,000 available in city and state Percent for Art programs. A man talks about his vision of how local artists should be trained. A woman tells the group about a new "electronic atelier" at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, where students will be able to master the tools of multimedia. Click. Art and media -- realms frequently perceived as privileged -- have collided and come down to earth, demystified and accessible. In another group, someone is arguing that the Bronx Center should exclude planners, because they make everything sterile. Someone else says that won't happen in Melrose Commons; the will of residents to remain in their buildings will insure a visually varied streetscape. Click. A connection has been made between political action and esthetic effect.
PEOPLE ARGUED WITH passion, but this was not a contest. It was an entrance into their own city. Many people at this meeting had been trapped within the armor of their grievances. Their Golden Door opened with the recognition that they stood to gain by setting grievance aside. They passed through that door by joining others who have felt similarly displaced.
Experts and politicians have had useful experiences, too. Bronx Center has benefited from their analytic skills, technical information and knowledge of the historical forces behind the borough's decline. But perhaps the most useful asset displayed by Bronx Center's volunteer professionals is their grasp of hierarchy. Though their expertise places them at the apex of the organizational pyramid, they've turned the pyramid upside down. They stand at the bottom, supporting those above.
Morale at the Bronx Center meeting was so intense I was tempted to resist it. Another inner voice wanted to be heard -- a voice of caution. Mustn't get carried away, mustn't get sentimental about poor people, maybe nothing will come of this, it is cruel to raise false hopes. And didn't architecture already go through this in the 1960's, with advocacy planning? Aren't we well rid of the utopian baggage the modern movement came freighted with? Didn't we learn that making forms is the most valuable social service architects can perform?
But it is missing the point of Bronx Center to think that architects must choose between community service and design. Bronx Center is design. It extends the field in which designers operate. It shows that design is not only a matter of form but a matter of content, and that the designer's area of responsibility embraces both.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The old Bronx Borough Courthouse, at Third Avenue and 161st Street -- The South Bronx has suffered not only from neglect but from the wrong kind of attention. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LOOK WHO'S WIRING THE HOME NOW

 BODY:
Steven R. Rivkin's vision of electric utilities entering the telecommunications business provides an important new means to reduce air pollution and slow global warming, while also providing a less expensive on-ramp to the information superhighway ("Look Who's Wiring the Home Now," Sept. 26). Cutting peak power demand by communicating and cooperating with consumers via new digital technologies will reduce the use of coal-fired power plants, and create a growth market for electric utilities that build the new telecommunications facilities. President Clinton would be wise to encourage their efforts, which can provide enormous economic and environmental benefits for the nation.
 
CHRISTOPHER FLAVIN

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3044 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Hill: The Past Serving the Present

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
THE Clinton Hill neighborhood in west central Brooklyn is a late-19th-century treasure trove of mansions and brownstones, wide, tree-lined boulevards with broad vistas and a few smaller, charming side streets. A pedestrian roaming its avenues can marvel at fluted and banded Doric and Tuscan columns, bay windows and flower-bedecked balconies, bearded titans in the facades and pretend Loire Valley chateaus capped by conical towers.
On Nov. 10, 1981, a section of the neighborhood, part of the borough's brownstone belt, was declared a historic district, one of 61 such districts created by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. 
 Since the idea of landmarks became law 38 years ago, a debate has raged over the appropriateness of designating areas or buildings that, because of their architectural quality or history, may not be razed or even altered without going through a strict approval process.
But to the people of Clinton Hill there appears to be little doubt: Residents and developers agree that the neighborhood is an outstanding example of the capacity of a historic district to generate housing value by opening the door to new investment and taking advantage of a potential market.
Clinton Hill, they say, fortuitously possessed the unusual combination necessary for success: much space and many vacant (some of them burned-out) buildings; their availability in a time of real-estate expansion; a Federal historic-district tax credit and the eagerness of moderate- and middle-income people to move into renovated housing or to renovate it themselves.
But the pluses also carry with them minuses: complaints about the relatively high cost of housing in a historic district and the difficulty an understaffed landmarks panel has had in recent years in enforcing the regulations.
SOME residents also complain that enforcement, when it occurs, can be excessively bureaucratic and nit-picking and can require changes too costly for low- and moderate-income homeowners. And others point out that while the designation has been beneficial to Clinton Hill, it has not been as helpful for other, less economically fortunate, areas of the city.
In the historic districts of Harlem or the South Bronx, for example, while there are many empty buildings, there have not been enough people of sufficient income seeking housing to make unsubsidized rehabilitations economically viable on a broad scale. And the added cost of conforming to landmark standards adds to the problem.
In Clinton Hill, however, the emphasis is on the positive.
"Historic districts are crucial to the well-being of an area," said Stephen B. Jacobs, an architect and developer who has renovated 30 brownstones and three major apartment houses in Clinton Hill and neighboring Fort Greene. "They are a useful tool that can be used in preserving urban neighborhoods.
There has been an impact on the storefronts, on the buildings, on the quality of life, because somebody was seeing the total picture and trying to institute standards instead of letting each landowner do his own thing."
Naida McSherry, a resident and a real-estate agent, said the designation had enhanced property values. "Had it not been a landmark area people would not have put this kind of money, time and effort into their houses," Ms. McSherry said. "I moved here because the architecture was beautiful, and landmarking meant it would stay that way, that my neighbor across the street could not paint his house chartreuse."
Brent Porter, a neighborhood resident, architect and professor of architecture at Pratt Institute who is also on the board of the Society for Clinton Hill, said that "the historic district has renewed our identity."
"In the 1880's and 1890's," Mr. Porter said, "leading families came to Clinton Hill, one of the highest points in Brooklyn, to establish their mansions. Now we have a totally different identity. We have an across-the-board mix of ethnic and racial groups and income levels, and because of the district we have renewed our pride of place.
"People have a concern for their neighborhood. They find many ways to make it better, from their garden to the stoop in front of their house to a major renovation."
In the late 19th century, when Brooklyn was a suburb of Manhattan, the area that is now Clinton Hill became known as the gold coast. It was the dwelling place of the rich and famous: the Pfizers of Pfizer pharmaceuticals, the Bristols of Bristol-Myers, the Sperrys of Sperry-Rand, the Otises of Otis elevators, the Reynoldses of Reynolds Aluminum, the Liebmans of Rheingold Beer, the Underwoods of Underwood typewriters, the Arbuckles of Yuban coffee and, most especially, the Pratts. Charles Pratt, partner of John D. Rockefeller of the Standard Oil Company, built four mansions near his own glorious house on Clinton Avenue as wedding presents for his four oldest sons.
AS the century turned and it became clear that Manhattan was becoming the prime city address, the neighborhood began to decline. Some mansions were torn down; others were turned into apartment buildings or rooming houses. The area lost much of its distinction and was often lumped with neighborhoring Bedford-Stuyvesant.
But the stabilizing presence of Pratt Institute and St. Joseph's College helped keep it from sinking too far, and by the late 1960's and early 1970's an upturn had already begun. Clinton Hill became part of the Brooklyn brownstone revival that also included the historic districts of Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Park Slope, Fort Greene, Boerum Hill and parts of Bedford-Stuyvesant. Pioneers eager for affordable homes and willing to put in the work to fix them up fled the high prices of Manhattan for the racially and economically mixed areas of Brooklyn, of which Clinton Hill was one, and transformed them.
Clinton Hill itself is bounded by Myrtle Avenue on the north, Vanderbilt Avenue and Fort Greene on the west, Classon Avenue and Bedford-Stuyvesant on the east and Fulton Street on the south. The part of it designated a historic district centers on the Clinton Avenue mansions in the western half of the neighborhood, taking in 17 whole blocks and parts of 12 others.
By the time Clinton Hill became a historic district, gentrification -- the gradual arrival of people with a higher level of income than those already living in the neighborhood -- had already begun. Then, fueled by the real estate boom of the 1980's and the Federal historic-investment tax credit -- 25 percent for housing in historic areas -- gentrification, renovation and development blossomed. (The gentrification process itself received mixed reviews: positive for growth, negative for the displacement of lower-income people it sometimes brought about.)
Now, although the end of the boom has slowed growth considerably, and a change in the law has reduced the tax break, its results in new investment remain. Restored buildings are scattered throughout the blocks of the district, among them Washington Avenue, St. James Place and Gates Avenue, where the historic-district tax credit spurred entrepreneurs and individual owners to buy and renovate buildings.
"IN terms of the renovation of market-rate, moderate-income housing, none of it would have been built if there had not been a historic district," said Mr. Jacobs, whose work includes the Washington Court complex at Washington and Gates Avenues, four buildings and 115 apartments on a block that had been 60 percent burned out and vacant before the huge restoration was completed in March 1987.
There are certain types of buildings, Ms. McSherry said, that probably never would have been restored if they had not been landmarks, because they normally were not the kinds of buildings homeowners would buy and restore: big apartment buildings that had deteriorated, beautiful exteriors with burned-out shells inside.
"Because of the investment tax credit for landmark areas, developers were willing to come in and renovate and make lovely apartments," she said.
Derelict buildings were renovated and put into service at reasonable rents. "There are lights in the windows," said Abigail Golde, a real-estate agent and a member of the Society for Clinton Hill. "There are children on the streets. And it's marvelous."
The change after 1987 reduced the credit to 20 percent, Mr. Jacobs said, limited it to sheltering passive-income losses and eliminated private investors who earn more than $250,000 a year. But restoration and renovation in Clinton Hill has continued despite the change in the tax laws, sometimes taking the form of subsidized housing for low- and moderate-income buyers.
The role of the historic district has remained crucial, residents say. It certainly played a key part in saving the Vendome, a five-and-a-half-story landmark 1887 building at the corner of Grand and Gates Avenues. The city had seized it for back taxes in 1982 and wanted to tear it down because it was in ruins.
But in late 1987 and early 1988 a consortium of private and public groups battled to save it, and it was redeveloped with the assistance of city and state funds.
Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, which played a major role in the development, said that after some financial difficulties the now fully occupied 24-unit building has helped revitalize the surrounding neighborhood. Tenants, all lower income, rent for 15 years and then will be able to buy their apartments as condominiums, Ms. Wylde said.
The Housing Partnership is a nonprofit organization that works with the city and the private sector to create "affordable" ownership housing -- housing that can be bought and carried by people with annual household income of about $25,000 to $50,000. Among its other projects is the Clinton Hill Houses, 48 duplex apartments in 24 attached houses completed three years ago on two previously vacant parcels next to the Vendome. Those 1,100-square-foot units sold for about $100,000 each.
The end of the real-estate boom has created some of the same problems in Clinton Hill as it has in the rest of the city, and residents who bought when the market was at its highest and whose houses or co-op apartments have decreased in value often find it difficult to sell. But Ms. Golde said there were still opportunities for first-time buyers and young families.
Housing prices vary greatly in the neighborhood, she said, changing block by block and building by building. A "modest" house or a larger house requiring much renovation might cost about $250,000, she said; one of mansion quality "could go for under $700,000, though you could certainly spend a lot more."
Co-op prices also vary, she said, but a "nice three-bedroom" might be available for under $200,000. The same is true for rentals, which, she said, "are very strong now, in Clinton Hill and all over the city; a two-bedroom apartment could easily go for $1,000." Less expensive two-bedrooms are available, but those probably have not been renovated.
WITH the benefits of the district come problems, and one of them is a concern over cost for those with smaller incomes. The Rev. Anthony Trufant, pastor of the Emmanuel Baptist Church on Lafayette Avenue in Clinton Hill, said that while the landmarks status had helped maintain a sense of continuity, it was also in a way a curse because it made the price of housing "rather exorbitant" for both buyers and renters.
Price is also a problem in another way: Because all new buildings or changes to old ones must be reviewed by the landmarks panel, which decides if they are historically and architecturally in keeping with their surroundings, the historic district can increase the cost of a project significantly. "We calculate the add-on cost at about $10,000 per unit for exterior facade work and as much as $30,000 a unit, with an average of about $20,000, for interior requirements," said Ms. Wylde of the Housing Partnership.
SHE said that while the historic district had generally been good for Clinton Hill, the cost factor was responsible for difficulties in other, less fortunate districts.
"Clinton Hill came on line as a historic district and a reinvestment area at the height of the 1980's real-estate boom and took advantage of that," she said. "But many other designated historic districts, in Harlem, in the South Bronx and in other parts of Brooklyn, are in the 1990's real-estate cycle and are having a problem."
Very often, she said, the economics of those neighborhoods are not strong enough to support the "extraordinary cost" of compliance with landmark standards. A result, she said, is a gap in financing that inhibits or prevents development and "threatens many of the lower-income historic districts."
But Frances A. Eberhart, the executive director of the Historic Districts Council, said that "people who say that should ask themselves why residents of such districts as the Clay Avenue Historic District in the South Bronx are so keen on historic designation. The residents look on designation as one of the only things that can salvage the quality of their neighborhoods."
The landmarks commission is considering increasing the size of the Bedford-Stuyvesant district, Ms. Eberhart said, and many residents want it to be even larger than the panel's recommendation. To assist in such areas, she said, the landmarks panel runs a facade improvement program that provides grants of up to $15,000, and the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a private supporter of preservationist efforts, manages a program that provides low-interest loans and grants. "In the short run, the costs can be greater," she said, "but in the long run evidence shows that the cost and the investments are worth it."
The rules of the historic district strictly limit what an owner can do.
"Someone who buys a brownstone that is not in a historic district can do anything he or she wants, can take off the stoop, can install any kind of windows he wants," Mr. Jacobs said. "In the historic district, work on the building's exterior has to maintain the character of the neighborhood."
The process of renovation, he said, also becomes more tedious: a review procedure is mandatory, "and to some people such a procedure is an onerous thing."
Ironically, another major concern is enforcement: some residents are unaware of or openly flout the strict standards, and it can be extremely difficult to get them to adhere to the rules.
"MANY people in the neighborhood either assume they can do anything they want to a building or assume a change they want to make is not significant," said Ernie Bitzer, an architect who has lived in the neighborhood since 1970. "People change wood windows to aluminum windows, which is taboo as far as Landmarks is concerned."
The landmarks commission itself is understaffed; it has only one inspector to check on violations throughout the city.
"If the people across the street knock off a banister, I can call landmarks and they can issue a summons, but nothing will happen," said Bill Sikes, a Clinton Hill resident since 1956.
Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the landmarks commission, agreed that enforcement was difficult. "The law is flouted with impunity and violations are going unpunished," she said. "We give them a violation but we can't enforce it. We can take them to Civil Court, but you know what the courts are like, and do you really think the city's Corporation Counsel is going to make putting in the wrong window a prime concern? I don't think so."
On the other hand, those who willingly seek to obey the law sometimes complain that the commission, given the opportunity, is needlessly rigid about such things as windows and colors and that the rigidity can often add unnecessary costs.
Vivian Becker, executive director of the Pratt Area Community Council, a nonprofit housing organization that focuses on the interests of low- and moderate-income residents, said that when the regulations were enforced "people are sometimes held to a standard that can be arbitrary and more expensive than they might be able to afford."
Ms. McSherry said that when she told the commission she wanted to change the color of her cornice, an aide told her the panel wanted to send someone up to her roof and do a scraping to try to determine what the color was initially. "I think that attitude is rather silly," she said.
Ms. Beckelman replied that "part of the general preservation philosophy is to try to maintain what was there originally; the first rule is if it can be fixed, don't replace it."
"'We would never say that we would only approve the original color," she said. "But the reason a district is designated is for its architectural fabric, and color is a part of that fabric."
Ms. McSherry, despite her concerns, said that when the historic district was created it was not big enough. "They would not cross Fulton Street," she said. "There were beautiful buildings on the other side of Fulton that should have been part of the district. There were also very nice buildings on Fulton itself that since then have been destroyed."
RESIDENTS also say that the designation by itself is not enough, that more work is required to continue to improve the area. The Rev. Glory Thomas, pastor of the Apostolic Faith Church on Lafayette Avenue, said that more government involvement, including increased police protection, was necessary.
Tom Schutte, the new president of Pratt (who lives in the Caroline Ladd Pratt House on Clinton Avenue, next door to the Charles Millard Pratt House, the residence of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn), said he and Pratt were committed to doing "everything possible to preserve the neighborhood."
The school recently planted 35 trees around the border of its 25-acre campus.
Lawrence Golde, president of the Society for Clinton Hill, said that his group maintained the same commitment.
"The advantages of the historic district are sometimes difficult to quantify," Mr. Golde said. "But when real estate agents speak to a buyer it has to be a plus that there are criteria and standards keeping the neighborhood looking and feeling like a good place to live. That has to be a positive thing for an inner-city neighborhood."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Principled Approach to Lower-Cost Housing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN his 30 years as an architect, Zane Yost of Bridgeport has put principle over profit. The principle is to create quality housing for people with modest incomes. In the best of times, his profits are meager. In a recession, they drop to negligible.
This limited architectural niche has brought him some celebrity. Anticipating by two decades society's current perception that packing thousands of people into enormous masonry projects would not solve the problem, he began designing individual clusters of private homes in 60 developments with a total of more than 7,000 units throughout New England. He is involved now in half a dozen projects around Connecticut. 
 Financing provided by nonprofit housing corporations and the Connecticut Department of Housing have made the units affordable for families earning $20,000 to $60,000. Land taken over from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by the state and given back to the towns is sometimes crucial to keeping prices in the $60,000 to $135,000 range.
Committed to a set of philosophical, social and political tenets, Mr. Yost is sometimes at odds with those to whom he must sell his ideas.
"With the best intentions a great deal of low-cost housing fails because of cheap construction, overwhelming density and sheer ugliness," he said. "Good construction is not what makes housing expensive -- it's the cost of land. Zoning, created with the purpose of making better communities, succeeded instead in creating artificial scarcity, totally destablizing the value of land."
The idea that higher density will bring about lower cost is anathema to him.
"The most expensive building is the high-rise-elevator-fireproof structure that requires expensive maintenance and security after it's built," he said. "The village is the most cost-effective way to build, and the way to a more orderly society.
"We forget that all human beings are affected by where they live, motivated by the need to associate in small groups and have deep relationships with others. They need a community that's under control, supported by a local power structure dedicated to preserving their quality of life."
In his village concept, each family has a private house, private fenced yard and secure parking. Houses are clustered around a common green and there is enough shopping to meet immediate needs. Streets are keyholed into dead ends, and through traffic is diverted to move around the complex rather than slice through it on speedways.
"VITRUVIUS, the early Roman architect," Mr. Yost said, "identified three essential architectural elements -- firmness, a sound structure; commodity, accommodating the form to its use; and delight, the esthetic appeal of the building. Most low-cost housing lacks all three."
His firm, Zane Yost & Associates, has its headquarters in a sprawling Victorian house in Bridgeport, where his design for Marionville, a low-cost town-house project built 25 years ago, won an American Institute of Architects Award.
Forty percent of the original owners still live there, experiencing the pleasures of privacy and paid-up mortgages.
A block away is the 40-acre Father Panik Village, which once had 1,036 units and held out a promise of decent housing for low-income people. Instead it became a dangerous web of blind alleys, corridors and stairways where drug dealing and violence were commonplace. The last buildings were torn down last month to make way for the first 50 duplexes in 25 new buildings that Mr. Yost is designing. Eventually there will be 500 units clustered with private yards, communal green space and shops.
"What sets Yost apart is his innate knowledge of what works," said Jeffrey Sager, principal in Metro Realty of Farmington. Mr. Yost is the architect for Metro's 68-unit complex on 9 acres, in which 40 percent of the units will be rented below market rates, up to $810 for three bedrooms.
"WE interviewed many architects in the affordable-housing field and found that Zane was a leader in the industry," Mr. Sager said.
The Waterbury chapter of the nonprofit Neighborhood Housing Services of America is using a Yost design for Old Farm Ridge, with 144 town houses in clusters of 4 to 12 units on 21 acres. Work on the first 30 units has started and prices for two- , three- and four-bedroom homes range from $72,000 to $95,000.
By simply putting the structures down without laying out lot lines and leaving all unbuilt spaces green, greater use of the land for gardens and play areas is possible. Driveways and roads are kept at the periphery of the cluster. Mr. Yost calls it the "not lot" plan.
"We try not to work with architects," said Adele Strelchun, executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services' Waterbury office,"in order to keep the costs down, but his housing philosophy was very important to me. The houses are lovely, nicer than some of the homes of neighbors who objected to having the development built." So far 176 applications have been received from potential buyers.
AT Waterside Green, Mr. Yost's sold-out 75-unit complex in an industrial area of Stamford, a three-bedroom town house costs $109,000, including major appliances, carpeting, two and a half bathrooms, separate dining room and fenced yard. It was built by Fairfield 2000, a nonprofit agency based in Stamford.
Mr. Yost will work with Fairfield 2000 again to build Clock Hill Homes in Darien. The town has approved a plan for 28 units on a 22-acre site formerly known as the Prindle-Hopkins property. A one-bedroom unit with den will sell for $99,950 and a two-bedroom unit with a den will cost $133,925.
Mr. Yost said the recession had doubtless led some architects to go into subsidized housing to supplement sparse market-rate commissions, but Robert Hurd, who devotes 60 percent of his time to low-cost housing in the Hartford area, has been doing it for 15 years.
"If its done right, it helps people," he said. "It empowers them, gives them a stake in the community."
Kermit Thompson, principal at TPA Design Group in New Haven, is designing 35 rental town-house units and remodeling a housing project in Norwalk. "Affordable housing is one of our largest market areas," he said.
To help some of Bridgeport's troubled neighborhoods, Mr. Yost drew up a plan for putting highway barriers back to back, filling them with decorative plants and positioning them across intersections, forming dead ends.
"The cost is minimal and there has been a dramatic drop in the number of shootings," said Thomas J. Sweeney, the chief of police. "There is less racing up and down and fewer drive-by drug deals."
A total of 40 intersections will eventually be involved. "We are giving the neighborhoods back to the people who live there," said Chief Sweeney.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Change in Belle Harbor;
Failed Condo Project Reborn in New Form

 BODY:
The Belle Harbor section of Queens is providing yet another example of the turn back to traditional housing forms in low-rise residential neighborhoods of New York City.
What began as the "Sea Breeze Condominium" in the hands of one developer a few years ago is now on the market as "Ocean View Homes" in the hands of another. The condominiums -- in seven attached and semi-attached two-story houses on Beach 129th Street -- were partially sold but never occupied after they were completed three years ago. 
 Now they are on sale for $375,000 to $420,000 as two-family houses. The buyers are expected to bring in a renter for the space where in the earlier incarnation there would likely have been a resident owner.
The renter should provide the owner-occupant with enough rental income to substantially offset his monthly carrying costs.
Why the change?
The one suggested by the developer, Lawrence Rosano of Bayside, Queens, is that "People would rather own their own home and have total control." Mr. Rosano, with Thomas Naples and John Norton, bought the project in September.
But it may also be the case that both buyers and banks will be more comfortable with the housing form that is more traditional in the homeownership neighborhoods of New York City. And carrying costs for buyers should be lower.
The previous developer had a few signed contracts when he was forced to abandon the project, including one for a $250,000 duplex. That buyer would have faced monthly housing costs of $1,451, based on a $37,500 down payment and a 7.5 percent interest rate on a loan for the balance of the purchase price. With a 10 percent, or $37,500, down payment on a two-family house, however, a buyer's monthly cost would be only $1,152, the developer says, assuming the same mortgage rate and monthly rent of $1,250 from a tenant.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Informal Cuisine in a Lush Hotel Atrium

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
SEVERAL months ago the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Old Greenwich closed its upscale restaurant Conde's (except for private parties) and is now "making do" with its second-tier eating place, Winfield's Cafe, in keeping with current lighter, more informal dining habits. Conde's was part of a 1980's national trend toward small, gourmet-style restaurants that many hotel chains embraced. Economic times and changing eating patterns have been hard on such efforts.
Winfield's Cafe is situated in the vast 56-foot-high glass-roof atrium that is the hotel's centerpiece. Towering columns covered by climbing greenery, ficus trees, hibiscus, philodendron and other plants, a small pond, streams and waterfall all add to the appeal. In the evening, the sound of live piano music drifts over from a small bar across the way. 
 The menu, as befits the new American cafe-style concept, is brief. It accommodates the current penchant for pasta and other Italian dishes and a few other popular foreign items.
Count among the better entrees a Mexican dish, sizzling fajitas. Winfield's offers a choice of beef, shrimp, vegetable or chicken. We opted for the chicken, which was served in strips, along with green and jalapeno peppers, grilled on a red-hot iron skillet -- delicious. Along with the skillet came a straw basket with flour tortillas (for wrapping around the chicken and peppers) and a container of respectably tangy guacamole, red salsa, shredded Cheddar cheese and sour cream.
Not all ethnic renderings fared as well. Seafood-chicken gumbo, one night's special, was more a bland vegetable soup broth than the swamp-thick Cajun gumbo that is traditionally packed with okra and file (sassafras powder) and deeply garlicked andouille sausage. Another starter, fried dim sum with kim chee, provided adequate dim sum (chicken, pork and shrimp dumplings) and a mound of mildly spiced Korean kim chee (only distant kin to the hot pickled cabbage dish of the same name).
Ethnicity was better served in a garlicky Gorgonzola bruschetta, a thick slice of toasted Italian bread rubbed with garlic and blue cheese, nesting on wilted greens with a sautee of wild mushrooms (oyster mushrooms and shiitake among them) -- good hearty winter fare.
Another old Italian standby was a victim of inventiveness that misfired. The dish was described as mozzarella and olive pesto in carrozza, and the egg batter-dipped mozzarella sandwich was enveloped in a lemon caper sauce that turned the expected crunchy-edged mozzarella in carrozza into a soggy, bready morass that even a plethora of capers couldn't save. Not a good idea.
Better appetizers were the Buffalo-style fried chicken wings (lathered in reddish-pink Tabasco spiciness), served with carrot and celery sticks and a dense blue cheese dip; and Maryland crab cake (a fat, well-browned cake with a cascade of lightly dressed mixed baby salad greens).
Two pasta dishes were also worth attention: prosciutto provolone tortelloni with two small grilled chicken breasts, calamata olives, mushrooms and Parmesan; and penne pasta with spicy marinara, tossed with ricotta cheese and grilled vegetables -- well-seasoned and generous. Another entree, sauteed veal medallions in Marsala jus, was satisfying, though hardly memorable.
Disappointments included dried-out grilled salmon (though the sauteed greens in an orange balsamic vinaigrette had sparkle) and a bizarre grilled barbecued chicken pizza with vegetables and Cheddar cheese that was inedible, with a crust so thin it confounded the pizza fans in our party.
Among several commercial-tasting desserts, a strawberry shortcake was almost rock hard, but the tiramisu, served with two biscotti cookies (a redundancy of sweets), was actually appealing. Raspberry sherbet was also a refreshing choice.
A recent dinner for two came to $50 for three courses apiece, before tax, tip and beverages. A minimal wine list features American, Italian and French selections, priced from $18 to $36, with two wines by the glass.
By choosing selectively you can enjoy a meal at Winfield's Cafe in a perfectly delightful indoor-outdoor ambiance that is at its best at lunch on a sunny day (with natural light pouring into the atrium) during the long winter months.
 
WINFIELD'S CAFE
Satisfactory
Hyatt Regency Hotel, 1800 East Putnam Avenue (between Laddins Rock Road and Rockmere Avenue, Exit 5 from I-95), Old Greenwich. 637-1234, extention 58.
 
Atmosphere: Dining room is set in the open space of a vast, airy atrium with pools, a waterfall, towering ficus trees and pillars covered with greenery.
 
Service: Willing and prompt, but sometimes overeager to clear dishes before all diners are finished.
 
Recommended dishes: Garlicky Gorgonzola bruschetta, Maryland crab cake, penne pasta with spicy marinara, prosciutto provolone tortelloni, sizzling chicken fajitas, sauteed veal medallions Marsala, raspberry sherbet, tiramisu.
 
Price range: Lunch, entrees $7.50 to $14.50; dinner, entrees $7.50 to $19.

Reservations: Accepted.

HEADLINE: Bora-Bora Prices

 BODY:
To the Editor: Bravo on your first color section (Oct. 31), and the Bora-Bora cover photo. As a long-time sales agent for Tahiti, however, I want to clarify Lenore Magida's classification of Tahiti as "expensive."
Over the last year, French Polynesia has experienced a surge in tourism from North America. The addition of two new airlines serving Tahiti has helped bring arrivals up while lowering air costs. Packages now start as low as $1,132 for a seven-day vacation (per person for accommodations in double occupancy, air fare from Los Angeles and inter-island air). While Ms. Magida comments that "dinner for two can easily run close to $100," this is true in many locations from Bora-Bora to the Caribbean. Our Sofitel resorts in Tahiti, like many other large hotels in Tahiti and the outer islands, offer a meal plan at $45 a day for American breakfast and dinner with a choice of entrees. Many packages include day excursions -- such as the shark feeding mentioned in the story -- in the overall rate. 
 Finally, Ms. Magida's hotels ranged from the ultimate in expensive to the ultimate in economy, offering no representation of the wide middle range.
 
JEAN CLAIR ARNAUD
Sales Manager, Sofitel Tahiti Resorts
New York, N.Y.
