HEADLINE: Old Age Catches Up With the Oil Patch

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: GUADULUPE COUNTY, Tex.

 BODY:
ROBERT SPILLER started calling around a few months ago to sell the 38 old, nearly dried-out oil wells his mother inherited when his father died. His younger brother, Jay, an oilman, was on his list. "Jay, the price of oil is low, and I don't know if I'm doing you right by calling," he told his brother. In the last year, Robert had finished selling off all of his own oil wells.
Jay, always stoic, said he would think about it. The oil from those wells, a relatively low grade, was selling then for about $14 a barrel. Jay figured he could produce for $13 a barrel, and counted on prices going back up. And he wanted to keep his father's wells in the family. 
 So Jay came back with a bid of about $100,000. Not the best offer, but competitive enough to win his mother's favor.
Since then, however, the price has dropped to $10.25 a barrel. Which is why, at noon last Thursday, he was standing among the mesquite thorns and the sulfurous fumes -- looking into the sky for rain, into the horizon for a repair truck that was supposed to have come that morning and into the future for higher prices.
 
A Patch by Another Name
 As a stripper producer, J. A. Spiller is playing the Texas oil endgame. Stripper wells are those whose flows have fallen to 10 barrels a day or less, from perhaps 30 to 100 barrels initially. Operated primarily by independent and smaller producers and not by the major international companies, stripper wells already account for more than a fifth of the state's and nation's oil output, a portion that is growing as this country's reserves are depleted.
Because of their high production costs, they will be the first casualties if oil prices stay where they are, which is possible, given the outcome late last month of meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Weakened by squabbling, OPEC failed to agree on production cuts, and the possible end of international sanctions against Iraq could add to the supplies, pushing prices downward.
Nearly all the stripper production could shut down in the next year or two if prices stay where they are, said Julian G. Martin, speaking for the Texas Independent Production and Royalty Association in Austin. "It would be disastrous -- the wipeout of several hundreds of thousands of barrels a day -- which could only be replaced by imports from the Middle East."
Some economists, however, view the association as alarmist.
Wherever prices head, Jay Spiller is also fighting history in a region whose designation as the nation's Oil Patch is becoming an anachronism. Natural Gas Patch, maybe, as 1993 promises to be the first year that Texas earns more from natural gas than oil, with Robert Spiller among the converts to natural gas.
But as oil prices have dropped and the majors have shifted more of their production abroad, Texas might be better known as the Government Patch, the Medical Patch, the Electronics Patch, the Shopping Mall and Warehouse Patch -- all larger sources of jobs now than oil.
The Halliburton oilfield equipment company is still the state's second-largest corporate employer, but General Motors and its EDS computer services unit form the largest, with Texas Instruments the third-largest, followed by American Airlines and then Wal-Mart. Exxon, the state's biggest oil company, comes in at No. 15. And no company matches the size of the Texas Medical Center in Houston, which employs 53,000 people.
As a result, last week's plunge in oil prices, to the lowest level in five years, caused worry in Texas, but not trauma. "Almost every industry except the oil industry likes low oil prices," said Ray Perryman, whose economic consulting firm is based in Waco, Tex. "As you diversify, you get the benefit. We can pretty well sustain the recovery we've had if oil prices stay at this level."
Not that energy has become unimportant. For each dollar decline in the price of oil -- and prices have dropped $4 in two months -- , Texas loses 17,000 jobs, about two-tenths of 1 percent of the work force. The nation, meanwhile, gains more than 78,000 jobs as transportation and manufacturing costs decline and the economy expands, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
But oil and gas now account for only about 12 percent of the combined gross state product of Texas -- about half what it was a decade ago.
 
The View Beyond Oil
 Robert Spiller -- 44 years old and as fervid and talkative as his brother is reserved -- is not shy about repeating his warnings to Jay. "I let him make his own decisions, but I've told him how I feel," he said from behind a wide, leather-topped desk in San Antonio, where his natural gas operations are based. "He should get rid of his oil wells."
But Jay Spiller has no gas wells or drilling prospects, leaving him only his oil properties and his brother's wary admiration. "He has no overhead," Robert said. "If he can't make a profit, no one can."
Almost every day since he bought the oil wells a month ago, Jay has driven about an hour south of his office in Austin to inspect, repair and plan. He knows the brown, rolling hills of the Austin chalk formation well. He worked them with his father, and he had dozens of wells there even before his latest purchase.
Jay, who is 43, dresses in jeans, mud-stained boots and a broad-brimmed canvas hat. From his Ford Bronco, he talks by a crackling two-way radio with his production foreman, his sole employee.
Jay's oil is not the sweet, West Texas Intermediate -- the benchmark crude whose price is quoted in the newspapers -- but a sour (higher-sulfur) oil harder to refine and therefore several dollars a barrel less valuable. But as the major companies move out, smaller operators see opportunities in lower-grade and stripper wells, which sell for only a few thousand dollars each.
If his oil stays at around $10 a barrel, he said, "You'd have to turn all your operations down." His mild stutter betrays him on the word "turn.' "Wherever you could cut back, you'd cut back."
He argues that with OPEC nations losing billions of dollars of revenue from their oil, they are bound to get prices back up. But he is already watching every dollar.
 
The Rusting of the Patch
 From a compartment between the front seats of his truck, he unfolds a sheet of yellow paper listing the 15 or so of his wells that need repairs, averaging $1,500 each. Holes in the outer tubing, weak pumps, split rods, all hundreds or thousands of feet below ground.
His land is leased from ranchers, with ramshackle barns and lowing cattle still there. Some of his pumps are slowly bobbing and whirring, while others stand rusted and silent.
Last Thursday morning, he expected a truck to arrive with a workover derrick, to pull busted equipment from the ground. He planned to fix all 15 wells, but with oil prices where they are, he will only do two or three.
He was also planning to drill several more wells in December, with the help of about five investors. But at a cost of about $75,000 each, that's now out of the question, for him and many others. In April, the national rig count reached the lowest point in 50 years of record-keeping. It has rebounded somewhat since then, as a few major oil companies, unable to sell their domestic properties, have resumed drilling, though they will probably cut back again if oil prices remain low.
Jay Spiller's foreman used to drill for him. This morning, he drove up in a spattered white pickup, jumped out and doffed his cap to reveal a scalp shaved bald after a lost bet on a Houston Oilers game.
His truck carries a four-wheel Kawasaki motorbike. When it rains, he plows through the mud on the bike instead of in the truck, saving the $500 repair bill that results when mud clogs the truck's joints. "That's a cost-saving technique, and it works," Jay said.
With their marginal production, stripper wells require every such technique Jay can muster. Sometimes the wells keep producing for decades. But falling prices and flows require him to plug some holes. He plugged 15 last year, and would rather not fill any more. "Plugging costs money, too," he said.
His father, Horace, a wildcatter and the son of a wildcatter, began drilling here in the 1930's, and continued, with Jay's and, for a while, Robert's help, into the 1980's.
Guadulupe County still has a Spiller Field, and Robert and Jay still maintain shrines to Horace, lining their offices with his pictures. Robert and Jay both studied petroleum engineering at Texas A&M, then joined their father's company. Even when Jay left the company in 1982, five years after Robert did, Jay continued working out of the same offices.
Jay has three sons, the oldest a freshman at A& who gained his first oilfield experience last summer. He heard about the tough times. "I told my sons, 'If you want to be employed in this business, you'll probably be employed outside the United States,' " Jay Spiller said. "That's how Exxon operates. They're getting out the country and going overseas."
Of Exxon's 1.7 million barrels of daily liquid production, mostly oil, only 286,000 come from the continental United States, half of that from Texas.
 
A Fuel for the Sons
 Or the Spiller sons could drill for gas. The Clinton Administration, with a former oil and gas executive, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, as chief of staff, has been encouraging natural gas production. "It's environmentally clean, abundant, and a cheap resource that's domestically available," explained Tom Sullivan, speaking for the Maxus Energy Corporation, a major independent producer in Dallas.
With a pickup in demand, natural gas prices have been rising, to about $2 a thousand cubic feet, from the $1.60 range last year. Lower oil prices can bring natural gas back down, but not much, since it's difficult and expensive for many users to switch fuel sources.
With all the easily recoverable domestic oil long since found, Maxus, for one, has been looking for gas in the Texas Panhandle and the Gulf of Mexico, and for oil in Latin America and Indonesia. Gas at home, oil abroad is the trend, Mr. Sullivan said, "from an Exxon on down to a Ma-and-Pa operator."
The Robert Spiller Company, with five full-time employees concentrating on natural gas, isn't quite Ma and Pa, but it is down from 15 or 20 employees in the 1980's. Last week, a geological consultant was busy comparing maps pinned to the walls with charts spread across a table to help choose five sites for drilling gas wells by the end of January.
 
Dying or Just Hurting?
 Jay Spiller called for a word with his brother to make sure that the impression left by a speech that Secretary of Energy Hazel O'Leary, delivered in Texas several weeks ago does not go unchallenged.
"The Energy Secretary referred to the independent producer as a dying breed," Jay said. "We're not a dying breed, but we're a hurting breed. The way the Government can help is to have some sort of floor on the price of oil, or tariff on imported oil, to keep oil at a constant level."
Few see much chance of that, since most of the country likes lower prices. "When it comes to oil, people down here in Texas feel pretty persecuted," said Stephen Brown, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. "But they're outnumbered."
Robert Spiller, in suit, tie and an Aggie ring from Texas A&, can sound and look almost evangelical as he preaches about his industry.
"We're more and more dependent on foreign oil," he said, his voice rising. "Are we willing to pull the trigger to prevent them from pulling another oil embargo?"
He paces his office, shoves his hands into his pockets, then resumes. "I got into the business young and fired up, ready to make the American dream come true. Now we're being inundated with inconsistent prices. On top of it we're being crushed, totally crushed, with the environmental movement. You're talking to someone who has seen the writing on the wall and walked out of it. There are going to be a lot more like me. A lot of those people are just holding on by their fingernails."
Robert Spiller doesn't rule out a return to the oil business. But he was hurt even more than his brother by the 1986 oil crash.
His luck changed when he drilled for gas. On Feb. 21, 1990, on a ranch owned by former Gov. Dolph Briscoe, he discovered the Janey Field, prudently named after the Governor's wife. That first strike turned into a huge plume of flame, but there was plenty left once the fire was out. He has kept drilling nearby.
His brother, meanwhile, continues to try to suck the last drops of oil from the Spiller Field. "I don't think you'll find him drilling a lot of wells," Robert said. "I look at him and shake my head."
Jay Spiller, out in the field, saw that it was past 1 P.M., with no truck or workover rig in sight. Time for a lunch break at the Luling City Market about 10 minutes away.
He nodded to one of the men behind the counter in back, who was spearing brisket from a barbecue pit and carving slabs of it onto brown butcher paper. "Did you see that fellow there?" Jay said as he carried his beef back to a table. "The last well he drilled for me was two or three years ago. Now he's slicing meat."
 
 
 
IN TEXAS, MEDICINE TAKES THE LEAD
 AS Texas's earnings from exporting oil to other regions decline, its earnings from importing patients are rising. Even as new office contruction virtually ceased in the recession, the state's major medical centers continued to expand.
Only about 1 out of 50 Texans still works to discover or produce oil and gas. One of 13 Texans works in private-sector medicine; adding those employed by government, the count rises to 1 in 10, or more than 740,000 people.
Houston, Dallas and San Antonio all have sprawling medical centers and military hospitals, with the Texas Medical Center in Houston the largest. Roughly the size of New York's Central Park, it includes a dozen hospitals and 53,000 employees, with a budget of more than $4 billion. An expansion of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center there is adding as much new space as a 50-story office building.
The center, with headline surgeons including the heart specialists Denton Cooley and Michael E. DeBakey, has attracted thousands of patients from foreign countries, among them the Sultan of Brunei.
William E. Kuykendall, a senior vice president at the center's headquarters and an engineer by training, said that the demands for new roads, lighting, sewers, parks and parking spaces would tax most local governments. "We're kind of like a city hall here," he said.
And while the research, training and treatment are top-drawer, Texas has fallen behind in finding ways to manage costs. The business of medicine here is still, by and large, traditional. Health management organizations are few, with Methodist Hospital at the Texas Medical Center just considering one now.
As a result, the state's medical centers might be pinched more than many others by President Clinton's campaign to control costs. "It's gotten our attention," said Mr. Kuykendall, with pointed understatement.

HEADLINE: Profile: Bernie Feiwus;
A Successful Match: Quirky Catalogue, Offbeat Executive

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: IRVING, Tex.

 BODY:
A NEW black-and-gold flag snaps in the wind that blows more or less constantly across the Trinity River basin outside Dallas, home base for NM Direct, Neiman Marcus's mail-order division.
The flag is a fitting symbol of NM Direct and its chief executive, B. D. (Bernie) Feiwus. "It's kind of like the flag of a pirate ship," he said. 
 If NM Direct is a pirate ship, then Mr. Feiwus, 45, is its swashbuckling captain, flouting convention within the conservative Neiman Marcus empire and leaving his mark on the huge mail-order business. He is as different from the well-groomed merchants who mind the shop for Harcourt General, the conglomerate that controls Neiman Marcus, as the mail-order business is different from traditional retailing.
It is not only his attire -- usually khakis, an open sport shirt and crepe-soled shoes -- that sets Mr. Feiwus apart. This fall, he climbed onto a platform to boogie with a Michael Jackson impersonator at a party for the 1993 Christmas catalogue, and he often hands out odd hats to make a point -- once giving Mickey Mouse ears to an executive whose judgment he considered less than sound.
And the day after Thanksgiving, when treacherous sleet on the Dallas highways prevented some operators from getting to the office, Mr. Feiwus and some of his merchants filled in on the telephones. Even on this hectic shopping day, they did a good enough job to match last year's sales.
Also setting him apart is his microscopic knowledge of NM Direct's business and his ability to use that knowledge to fine-tune mailing lists, catalogue designs, even the timing of conveyor belts.
NM Direct, of course, is no stranger to idiosyncrasy. Long a stepchild of the glamorous Neiman Marcus Group, operator of the exclusive Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman stores, as well as Contempo Casuals on the West Coast, it is best known for its lively Christmas Books, featuring gifts like a miniature golden train carrying emeralds, rubies and diamonds, mummy cases and even an Angus steer, complete with carving tools and silver serving trolley.
Always a great publicity machine, the mail-order division was never regarded as a big moneymaker. But since Mr. Feiwus took over in 1991, NM Direct has become the company's ballast in a fickle economy, in no small part because of his leadership.
Though NM Direct's vital statistics are not made public, one estimate puts its annual sales at $250 million to $300 million. "It's been their savior in at least a couple of quarters," said Thomas H. Tashjian, a retail analyst at First Manhattan.
A close look at Mr. Feiwus offers some insight into his magic. He has reduced a dependence on the fourth quarter, once the only profitable time of year, by mailing out more catalogues the rest of the year.
He has pushed merchants and creative teams to build brand identities for each catalogue NM direct operates -- Pastille, Horchow, Trifles and Neiman Marcus by Mail -- by forcing them to adhere to standard type sizes and prices.
And he has used his training as a statistician to milk Neiman Marcus's coveted mailing list for all it's worth, striving to send catalogues only to those households likely to make big purchases.
While he has on occasion shocked colleagues with his antics, they are apparently willing to go along because NM Direct has prospered under his leadership. At one meeting, he made them wear sombreros and played a mariachi tape while he announced the foray into Mexico, set for this spring. And he has given quizzes on merchandising, awarding prizes to high scorers.
"We try to be personality-blind around here as long as an executive is an effective leader," said Robert J. Tarr, president and chief executive of Neiman Marcus and of Harcourt General, which owns 63 percent of Neiman Marcus. Mr. Tarr balked at the suggestion that Mr. Feiwus has revived the division single-handed. "There's a team that runs the business," he said firmly.
Still, Mr. Feiwus's tenure has coincided with a distinct shift in NM Direct's fortunes, a turnaround based in large part on strategies he put in place after analyzing the division's costs. That analysis showed that NM Direct could make money with few additional costs if it put out about 30 more catalogues and increased business from January through August. Traditionally, the division mailed most catalogues in the fall, leaving its high-tech distribution center and crack telemarketing and merchandising teams idle much of the year. "Even if customers didn't respond at the same level they did in peak season, our variable costs, mostly part-time labor at Christmas, were much lower, so we could be profitable then, too," he said.
OTHER fine-tuning followed. Neiman Marcus by Mail, which had primarily sold apparel and accessories, scored big with a new catalogue selling home furnishings and decorative items. The division increased the number of packages it mails out each hour by 50 percent, to 1,200 from 800, by varying the speed of four conveyor belts that snake through the distribution center.
Mr. Feiwus also imposed standards for paper weights and type sizes on his creative teams, who were used to cooking up each catalogue differently. Now, the only changes from spring to summer to fall are the merchandise and copy. "We needed to send out the message to the creative teams that whatever you do, you're going to have to live with it for awhile," he said.
Mr. Feiwus does have critics. Some say that for all the efficiency, the catalogues have become less distinctive. "Horchow, in particular, had a unique franchise, but it no longer stands out," said Dick Hodgson, the principal in Sargeant House, a mail-order consulting firm.
When Mr. Feiwus joined NM Direct nearly three years ago, the mail-order business was a tub adrift. The division had always been small and heavily reliant on Christmas, and it had had difficulty swallowing Horchow Mail Order Inc., which Neiman Marcus acquired for $100 million in 1988 only to find it was loaded with inventory no one wanted.
NM Direct was struggling to adjust to a rise in postal rates and United Parcel Service charges and the Persian Gulf War, which sent consumer spending into a tailspin.
Those factors led to heavy markdowns in Mr. Feiwus's first year, and, to protect themselves, merchants placed conservative orders for the spring 1992 catalogues.
But after studying various economic indicators, and his rivals, Mr. Feiwus believed the prospects were good for 1992 and worried about missing out for lack of inventory.
"So I broke the fundamental rule of retailing," he said. Buyers are typically held accountable for markdowns on orders they place, but Mr. Feiwus promised he would assume responsibility for markdowns they might incur by placing bigger orders.
Business began to boom, and has been booming ever since. Mr. Feiwus said sales have climbed 30 percent since 1991, and operating profits have climbed even more.
And Neiman Marcus apparently believes its mail-order division has even greater prospects: it is investing $15 million to add 250,000 square feet to the warehouse and distribution center.
NM Direct is also venturing into Mexico with test catalogues. Mr. Feiwus recently returned from Europe, another potential growth area, as is the Pacific Rim.
This is all heady stuff for Mr. Feiwus. One colleague recently found him in his office staring at the Neiman Marcus prospectus. "I couldn't believe what I was making," he said of his $293,000 salary. "Seeing it there in black and white was a shock. I just never in my life expected to be where I am now."
He was born in East New York to Orthodox Jewish parents who immigrated from Czechoslovakia in 1923. As far as he knows, the name Feiwus (pronounced FY-wus) is unique to his family, having been created by a harried immigration official at Ellis Island.
Mr. Feiwus attended Thomas Jefferson High School, then went to the City University of New York, earning a degree in statistics.
After graduating, he joined Citicorp, where he worked on the national rollout of Visa and Mastercard, a task that led Neiman Marcus to him in 1979 when it was looking for a new vice president for credit. He recalled that the first thing his wife, Leslee, said was, "Dallas? Don't you know that's in Texas?"
"Our concern wasn't so much with religion as it was with the heritage," Mr. Feiwus said. He wanted his children to "understand what it means to be Jewish, and I wasn't sure we could do that without the strong family ties we had in New York." Setting their doubts aside, they moved to Dallas. Two years later, Mr. Feiwus was named controller.
One of his early ideas was to establish a frequent-buyer program. Nothing came of this at first, but when American Airlines started its frequent-flyer program, Neiman Marcus started In-Circle, which rewards its best customers with special gifts and events. One valuable aspect of In-Circle -- regarded as one of the most innovative of such programs -- is the access it provides to information about big spenders.
Mr. Feiwus then moved into sales promotion, where he cooked up other plans to cement Neiman Marcus's ties to customers. His talents soon made him a strong candidate to head the mail-order division, although the company did first do an outside search.
The key to the mail-order business, Mr. Tarr said, is "to make sure your catalogues are going into those homes where there is the highest probability a purchase will be made." And tweaking such probabilities out of mailing lists and sales figures was right up Mr. Feiwus's alley.
Oddly, though, the man who heads one of the more creative merchandising companies insists he has little feel for the goods NM Direct sells. He tried his hand at merchandising for the first time in the current Christmas Book, coaxing the merchants into including two large dinosaurs.
His instincts may be better than he thought. While NM Direct has yet to sell a high-tech airplane ($150,000) or elaborate applique tent ($3,300), a $63,000 mechanical dinosaur is on its way to a Middle Eastern embassy in Washington. The beast's final destination is rumored to be Aspen, Colo., to be the star of a New Year's Eve bash.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: November 26 - December 3

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
If the Numbers Don't Lie, America's Going Back to Work
Is it as good news as it seems that the nation's unemployment rate plunged from 6.8 percent to 6.4 percent in November? Skeptics were quick to say that for complicated statistical reasons, the progress reported by the Labor Department last week was almost surely overstated, and financial markets shrugged it off. But with any kind of faith, what you see is a stunning number -- the biggest improvement in a decade, and a compelling sign that this on-again, off-again economy is at last performing its most basic function: creating jobs. Employers added jobs from California to Florida to New York, and most places in between -- and they were more likely to be full-time jobs, too. As those of you with jobs well know, companies have been putting off hiring and leaning on existing workers, uncertain about things like medical costs, but this news may show that they just couldn't hold out any longer.
 
An Economy on a Spree
It's more than jobs. The economic engine keeps gaining speed as it barrels toward that year-end blowout -- which long ago, rumor has it, was some sort of religious celebration. But once Christmas is past, will the vigor survive? Economists are cautious. Last week, though, the numbers were strong: income, construction spending, and factory orders all up, the purchasing managers' index showing the fastest growth since last winter. There were some blips: new-home sales were off, but that followed a surge the month before, so housing still looks good. And retail sales rose just slightly -- but of course any shoppers worth their credit cards would not dream of going wild till it's almost Christmas.
 
Tired of Waiting for S.& L. Job
It's clearly liberating to be nominated for a Government job and then decide it isn't worth jumping through all the hoops. Stanley Tate, named in July to head the Resolution Trust Corporation, but still awaiting a confirmation hearing, didn't mince words last week when he called it quits. "Washington," he said, "is a vicious city, with all kinds of hidden agendas. It is a city full of rumors, allegations and accusations." And why did his nomination die? Because he's a Republican? Because Bill Clinton didn't back him fully? Or because there was something to the "serious questions" that Donald Riegle, Senate Banking chairman, had about Mr. Tate? Mr. Tate's version: bureaucrats were afraid he'd root out mismanagement. Whatever the reason, Mr. Tate, a Florida developer, said he felt "disposable and dispensable." And the bailout agency just keeps on drifting.
 
Mending Hubble, Mending NASA
If NASA were a corporation, it would long since have become an obscure Wal-Mart subsidiary. It's made one cosmic gaffe after another: the Challenger disaster, the flawed Hubble Space Telescope, the apparent kidnapping of the Mars Observer by little green spacepersons. It's no understatement to say, as one space expert did last week, "NASA can't afford another highly visible failure." So the pressure's on the astronauts on the shuttle Endeavour, which lifted off on Thursday. The astronauts' mission: to fix Hubble in mid-space, essentially by putting a pair of eyeglasses on it. If they succeed, secrets of the universe could snap into focus; if they fail, the focus will be on NASA's jugular. But as one Hubble scientist put it, "This is not like going to Grandma's to fix a leaky faucet."
 
OPEC, Where Is Thy Sting?
Twenty years ago, OPEC seemed sure to strangle America with ever-higher oil prices. But last week it was clear just how times had changed. After slipping all year, oil prices plunged to a five-year low after OPEC failed to agree to cut output. So gasoline, steadily cheaper in 1973 dollars, seems likely to get cheaper still, which would help the economy. But everything has a cost, and cheaper gas means auto makers are less likely to put their efforts into making more efficient cars.
 
Victor Posner Is Out of Play
It was an unusual penalty, but the judge said the scope of the violations justified it. Saying they "have had a long and notorious history of engaging in self-dealing and corporate waste," a Federal judge last week banned Victor Posner and his son, Steven, from serving as officers or directors of any public company. The order came in a civil suit brought by the S.E.C. as part of a broader case against Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky, and it involved charges that the Posners made secret stock deals with Mr. Boesky. In light of past abuses, the judge said, another warning "would serve little purpose."
 
COMPANIES
 
Paying a Price for Family Values
Family values. So simple a term, yet so laden with subtext. On the surface, it means apple pie, caring, a cozy hearth; but it can also be a code phrase for excluding, condemning, even denying the existence of anything but cookie-cutter Americans. Normally, to cry "family values" is just free speech, but in Texas last week, the price was high. Apple Computer planned to build an $80 million office complex north of Austin, creating 1,500 jobs. But county officials rejected a $750,000 tax abatement, citing Apple's policy of granting health benefits to employees' unmarried partners, and Apple took its blueprints and hit the road.
 
Sony's Pain, And the World's
In 1946, in a bombed-out Tokyo department store, a young man named Akio Morita helped found the Sony Corporation. Since then, as both Sony and Japan grew mighty, Mr. Morita became, in one American's words, the world's "leading Japanese business statesman." So it is symbolic that as Japan's phenomenal half-century shows distinct wear and tear, Sony's chairman falters. Last week Mr. Morita, 72, underwent brain surgery, and he may have to retire. That would be bad news for Sony, where, even removed from day-to-day operations, he remained the "psychological backbone." And it would be bad news abroad, for Mr. Morita has played a leading role in smoothing trade tensions with America.
 
Volvo Vants to Be Alone
The planned Volvo-Renault merger created serious friction at Volvo. Many executives wanted to back out, loath to let Sweden lose one of its corporate stars. But the chairman, Pehr Gyllenhammar, stuck to the plan, seeing strength in having a European partner. Last week Mr. Gyllenhammar lost his fight: The merger was called off, and he quickly resigned, saying that Volvo's managers had "turned their backs on Europe."
 
Job Cuts: A Weekly Ritual
It almost stops being news, squarely in a class with "Dog Bites Man." Another week, and more corporate giants cut thousands of jobs. Last week was no exception. A. T.& T. may cut as many as 4,500 jobs as the long-distance wars take their toll. And airline woes continue to seep through to Boeing, which will cut production, meaning a loss of up to 3,000 jobs. Even the beer industry is pulling in its belly, as Miller said it would close a plant in upstate New York, eliminating 900 jobs.
 
G.M. Downsizes Its Data
Saturated with economic numbers? Good news: Detroit is going to spare you some. Much as eager-beaver pundits crave the latest word, General Motors decided last week that 10-day sales reports were overkill and would scrap them in January; Ford will probably follow suit. Chrysler went to monthly figures a couple of years ago, but then some helpful souls started estimating 10-day sales. While some analysts found the figures useful, most were relieved. "About time," said one.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Again, Hope for World Trade
Your eyes glaze over at the words "Uruguay Round"? You're forgiven: these trade talks have long since taken on a Dickensian dimension. Begun seven years ago to lower tariffs worldwide, the talks have hit more snags than "Bleak House" has characters. But yet again last week the tireless negotiators, including Mickey Kantor of the United States, cried, "Breakthrough!" One snag has been French objections to cutting farm subsidies, but a resolution may be at hand. If there is an accord, it could do much for the world economy. But that's still a big "if."
 
Trade progress is possible, though: last week Canada's new Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, dropped his opposition to Nafta. The pact now goes into effect on Jan. 1, and the vigil will begin to see which side was right about jobs.
Tokyo Sweet-Talks the Market
All the Japanese stock market was waiting for, it seems, were some rosy words from the Government; last week it got them. Stock prices had been sliding for weeks. But after the Government finally promised to do what it could, the Nikkei index surged more than 4 percent in a day, then 2 percent the next. Prices are still depressed, though, and they are likely to stay that way until Government actions follow words. "Jawboning," one analyst said, "won't work for too long."

HEADLINE: Corruption Overseas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "U.S. Must Halt Corruption -- Abroad" (Viewpoints, Nov. 21), Frank Vogl highlights the consequences of corruption, from political instability to wasting and rerouting aid money and foreign investment. However, his suggestion that the United States persuade or pressure developed and developing countries to adopt its moral, ethical and legal anticorruption standards misses the point. 
 First, it is not in the best interests of competing countries to adopt laws like the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Adopting such laws would result in a loss of lucrative contracts to "deep pocketed" American companies and the United States would be perceived as imposing its values on other countries and as meddling in their domestic affairs.
Second, international lending agencies may have the "leverage to promote anticorruption initiatives," but establishing a standard and enforcing and monitoring it are another story. For example, applying a Western human rights standard in non-Western countries has caused more problems than it has resolved. Externally defined and generated anticorruption laws, imposed upon developing countries via the international lending agencies, will not work.
Where there is little respect for the law, a situation common in developing countries, statutory solutions are secondary. The laws are perceived as entrenching the incumbent politicians and further enriching the wealthy at the expense of the masses. The people are fed up, and they want a solution that they understand and in which they have some involvement.
That solution is a news media free of the influences of the entrenched and enriched. The lending agencies should pressure the countries that receive aid to remove their hands from the media.
People who are "fed up with corruption" are willing to take the matter into their own hands because they know the consequences of continued corruption: economic stagnation and regression. I suggest laws similar to the United States' "whistle blower" law, offering monetary reward to those who expose, with enough evidence for indictment, entities and individuals dedicated to siphoning money from the government. The responsible, free news media could pursue such stories and expose the wrongdoers.
Further, applying a local standard, with local enforcement and monitoring procedures, would be more successful than imposing a law like the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act from Washington. Finally, applying a local standard would remove the unfair comparative advantage that Germany, France, Britain and others have obtained, vis-a-vis the United States, in winning lucrative overseas contracts.
Corruption will never be eradicated. However, it may be contained if the process in countries that receive aid becomes more transparent, and if all parties adhere to the same principles and rules.
 
A. RUSHDI SIDDIQUI
Woodmere, L.I., Nov. 23
 
The writer is a lawyer and consultant in privatization and international business.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
For Contrarians, Commodities Are Looking Up

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE American bond market is shaking because it sees signs of economic strength. European stock markets are zooming as evidence mounts that the continental slowdown is ending.
And yet there is consensus that commodity prices will stay low. The assumption is that demand, no matter how strong, will not overtake supply. It is a supreme insult these days to dismiss something as a "commodity business." 
 Nowhere is that clearer than in oil, which last week fell to its lowest level in five years. And that is measured in weak dollars. If you look at oil prices in Japanese yen, they're at a 20-year low.
Another way of looking at oil prices, which might be of interest to investors, is to measure the relative costs of oil and American stocks. In other words, how many barrels of oil could you buy with the same money needed to buy the basket of stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500? Measured that way, oil is the cheapest it has been since 1972, even before the first OPEC oil shock.
Of course, just because something is cheap doesn't mean it won't get cheaper. There is pervasive bearishness on oil now because of worries that Iraq will settle with the United Nations, enabling it to begin shipping large quantities of crude, and because inventories in this country are surprisingly high. And anyway, betting against inflation and commodities has been the winning strategy for more than a decade.
Industries around the world have concluded that it is folly to have inventories on hand, either of excess commodities or of workers that are not absolutely needed. Jim Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Review, has a point when he asks if that may not produce a scramble -- and perhaps even shortages -- when a lot of companies suddenly realize they are having trouble getting what they need.
That could happen sooner rather than later. The American economy is finally picking up steam, as was shown by the surprisingly strong job figures released Friday. Low oil prices themselves are bullish for economic activity, especially in Europe and Japan. A year from now, the chances are good that the major world economies will be doing substantially better than they are now. And if that is the case, oil may not be the only commodity whose price has moved up faster than expected.
There is no guarantee that oil prices will rally soon, of course. But for a long-term investment, one could do a lot worse than oil or the stocks of the companies that produce it. Wertheim Schroder's Mike Mayer notes that the dividend yield on big oil stocks is now about 75 percent of the yield on Treasury bonds, the highest ratio ever save for a brief period in 1986 when oil hit $10 a barrel. He is one of the few analysts pushing oil shares.
In 1981, when oil was peaking, the stocks were loved and crude was expected to hit $100 a barrel in a few years. Now oil is low and the shares are ignored. It may be that the crowd will prove to be just as wrong this time.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Gutenberg Goes Digital

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE computer, which in the last decade has created a whole new industry -- desktop publishing -- is now fixing its digital gaze on the venerable printing press.
Ever since Gutenberg, printing large volumes of documents has meant creating a metal plate for each page. Even in today's high-speed, four-color offset printing presses, each page requires its own metal plate. And because making and adjusting these plates is expensive and time-consuming, it is cost-effective to use sophisticated presses for full-color jobs only when making thousands of copies of each page. 
 The digital revolution may change all that. A new generation of presses is emerging that eliminates the metal plates, creating flexibility that should allow shorter press runs and even let the publisher make on-the-fly changes. A full-color advertising circular, for example, could carry a message tailored to each individual customer.
It's the ability to customize that has led Mark D. Kvamme, president of CKS Partners, an advertising agency in Campbell, Calif., to consider buying such a device. "With mass printing," he said, "people end up throwing away a lot of stuff."
Relatively low-cost color photocopiers have been available for years, of course. But with typical speeds of less than eight pages a minute, they are too slow for anything resembling volume production. The faster plateless color presses might crank out 100 to 10,000 copies of a booklet, brochure or annual report, industry experts say, while above 10,000, metal-plate techniques would probably still be more economical.
The reason color printing has typically been complex is that the images must be separated into their primary colors, each with its own plate. And once the plates are mounted, the press must be fine-tuned so the colors align precisely. This involves considerable time and money, so most short-run publications are printed in black and white -- or maybe with one additional color dropped in.
The printing of one- and two-color documents is a $25 billion-a-year business in the United States, said William R. Thompson, a printing consultant and ajunct professor of graphic arts at the University of Wisconsin. He estimates that two-thirds of that market would convert to full color if the high initial costs of setting up the presses could be reduced.
Two of the first entrants in the plateless-press market are the E-Print 1000 by Indigo Inc. of Rehovot, Israel, and the Chromapress by Agfa Gevaert of Belgium. Others expected in the market are photocopier companies like Canon and Xerox as well as makers of conventional presses.
Both E-Print and Chromapress are offset presses that borrow some of the technology at the heart of xerographic photocopiers -- forming images on paper by using electrostatic charges to distribute fine particles of pigment. But each has its own distinctive wrinkles.
Indigo's E-Print, for example, uses liquid inks rather than the dry powders found in most xerographic copiers. Benny Landa, president of Indigo, said the liquid ink can produce finer, more precise images than the relatively large grains of solid toner.
THE press accepts pages -- text, art and photographs -- that exist only as digital computer files. (With conventional presses, the files must be converted to photographic film, then to the metal plates.) The E-Print sends the computer file directly to a laser scanner that forms an electrostatic image on a metal roller. Electrically charged ink particles are attracted to the electrostatic image and then transferred to another roller, known as the blanket, for final transfer to the paper. (The blanket roller, also found on standard presses, acts as the intermediary between plate and paper; it's go-between function is what "offset" refers to in printing parlance.)
Only one color is printed at a time on the E-Print, so the paper is held on the impression roller for four passes if full color is being used. If it is to be printed on both sides, the paper goes into a buffer, to be turned over and remounted for more impressions.
Unlike conventional "web" printing, which uses continuous rolls of paper, the E-Print uses paper already cut into sheets, which it ultimately collates, folds and staples into booklets. Since each impression is new with each turn of the image roller, the press can produce finished booklets one at a time -- each customized for an individual reader.
Robert Conrads, president of Indigo America Inc., said E-Prints have been shipped for sale in Japan and are expected in North America early next year. A fully equipped machine costs about $400,000, although stripped-down models can be had for as little as $200,000.
The Agfa Chromapress is based on xerographic printing technology developed by Xeikon, a Belgian company in which Agfa holds a minority stake. Unlike Indigo's machine, the Chromapress prints on a continuous web of paper. And, with eight separate printing heads, four on each side of the web, it can print on both sides of the paper simultaneously.
As a result, it is a lot faster than the Indigo machine, capable of churning out 1,050 full-color, two-sided pages an hour -- compared with about 500 for Indigo. And because the paper runs continuously, Agfa officials contend, it is less likely to jam. A cutter at the end of the line slices the web into sheets.
The Chromapress uses specially developed dry toners that Agfa executives say are neater than liquids because they are instantly fused to the page by heat. And the image is comparable to Indigo's, Agfa officials insist. (For people who like to compare specs: the Indigo machine produces an image resolution of 800 dots per inch, and the Agfa, 600.)
Like the Indigo printer, Agfa's Chromapress uses no printing plates, meaning each page can be customized. But its much higher speed is so far limiting the amount of variability from page to page.
"We have a software limit and we are still working on the data rate," said Paul Willems, product manager for Chromapress. He said that only textual changes will be possible for customized publications when the machines begin selling next year in Europe, but later versions will be capable of changing graphics as well.
Agfa expects to begin shipments to North America toward the end of next year, well behind the Indigo E-Print. Pricing has not yet been set, but the Seybold Report on Publishing Systems, a trade journal, estimates Chromapress's price will be $250,000 to $300,000.
The digital printing press portends all sorts of changes in the way business is conducted. Eric O. Edelman, a consultant in New York with the Finnish paper-products consulting firm Jaakko Poyry, said he expects digital operations to spring up near airports, so that salesmen and marketing specialists will not have to drag heavy bags of brochures and other sales material from city to city.
"They will carry a three-and-a-half inch disk," Mr. Edelman said, "and print what they need for each presentation."

LENGTH: 1585 words

HEADLINE: Soul Central

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Moving as silently as dawn's approach, Art Manley walked over dew-dampened grass one morning recently to an old, concrete fountain at the center of an acre of municipal park land. The 31-year-old jazz musician took a long look out over the slumbering neighborhood that stretched before him in blocks of neat, pastel-colored houses, European-village-style shops and towering cypress, cedar and palm trees.
Only then, as he had for months of mornings, did Mr. Manley plant his snakeskin loafers in the sod, square his shoulders, close his eyes and lift his trumpet to his expertly pursed lips. 
 For more than an hour, Mr. Manley -- smartly dressed in a gray Italian-cut suit, starched white shirt, floral-print tie and pocket handkerchief -- blew a jazz-steeped reveille for this square-mile chunk of predominantly black southwest Los Angeles that is known as Leimert Park.
"I feel a lot of love around here," he said in a whispery voice as he returned approving nods to passersby for his just-finished rendition of "Stella by Starlight." "That's why I come here every morning.
"People really appreciate things over here," said Mr. Manley, who lives a 35-minute bus ride away and who never asks for contributions for his outdoor concerts. "Nobody has ever told me to shut up." Nor is anyone likely to in Leimert Park, which many see as a homespun cultural center in the making.
The neighborhood was created in 1927 by the developer Walter H. Leimert and designed by Olmstead & Olmstead, the successor firm to that of the designer of Central Park.
Leimert (pronounced luh-MERT) Park is situated just south of the Santa Monica Freeway, northeast of the Los Angeles International Airport and north of the city of Inglewood. More than 8,000 people live in this mostly middle-class enclave, which is about 82 percent black. Asians and Hispanics make up most of the remainder. More people own their homes than rent. Property values are relatively high; crime is relatively low.
Despite an ailing local economy and the riots of April 1992, which also struck this close-knit community, Leimert Park has become a haven for black musicians, artists, artisans and entrepreneurs of African-American culture and tastes. Still a long way from tourists' must-see lists, it has developed over the last five years into an Afrocentric enclave, much like Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
Leimert Park has "excellent potential" to become a nationally recognized center of Pan-African culture, arts and entertainment, said Charles E. Loggins, professor of urban and regional planning at California State Polytechnic University in Pomona. His students completed a study of the area last year.
But there are also stress lines beneath the successful surface. Some merchants and artists believe the area is growing too fast for its own fragile good.
From dimly lit shops hardly larger than walk-in closets to the blond-planked floors of sun-gorged galleries, anything from ceramic Aunt Jemimas to masks and headpieces from the Yoruba of Nigeria is for sale.
At Brian Breye's Museum in Black, visitors can gaze at slave manacles under glass and shop for that certain African or African-American symbol of self-affirmation.
You can order halal short ribs and fish sausage from the menu at the Shabazz Restaurant, which is owned by James Abdullah Butler, 49, an aerospace software designer, and managed by his son, Darrell Butler, 28, a former math teacher in the public schools.
"We know it's the black hub," said the younger Mr. Butler who, like his father, is a Muslim. "This area seems to have had a renaissance," he said. "There is a cultural consciousness here where people are 'brothers and sisters.' "
Jackie Kimbrough-Ryan, who owns Kongo Square, an African-American culture shop, with her sister and brother, said there is a "diversity of opinions" in Leimert Park about its future. Clashes occur. "We have a lot of other-mindedness here," she said with a weary smile.
A tectonic rift has been widening since August, when Leimert Park was the site of many of the activities in the citywide L.A. Festival. Some of the more recently arrived owners of arts and cultural shops find themselves on one side, with many longtime operators of the area's many service businesses like beauty salons on the other.
Some merchants like Ms. Kimbrough-Ryan, 56, say they want to bring more Saturday festivals to the area in hopes of attracting still more new faces with dollars to spend.
But Stewart, 39, a longtime Leimert Park resident and hairdresser who uses only his first name, is opposed to the idea. "If they have festivals on Saturday they want to close the street, and that's disruptive to my business," he said from his small loft on Degnan Boulevard, where he lives and runs the Venusian salon. "I have a Saturday crowd, and they want be able to get to me. Let them have their festivals on Sunday when I'm closed."
More pressing, many say, is the concern that Leimert Park has also been rediscovered by large developers and real-estate speculators. Residents fear that outside interests could strip the neighborhood of its kente cloth and cowrie shell ambiance and replace it virtually overnight with the tinsel and neon of so many other Southern Californian commercial districts.
Marla Gibbs, an actress best known for her role as Florence the maid on "The Jeffersons" and more recently as the star of the series "227," bought buildings for an arts and theater complex in Leimert Park in 1990. She said blacks must take the initiative in the neighborhood's further development. "When someone else comes in, it's going to be redeveloped for their purposes, not for yours, because it's their money," she said. Ms. Gibbs said she had invested more than $2 million in her Vision Complex Theater and Crossroads Arts Academy.
Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas, who moved to Leimert Park a year ago and whose Eighth District newly includes the neighborhood, said some changes to the area's core business district, known as Leimert Park Village, were inevitable.
"This area has the possibility of being a nice little cultural niche of small businesses that can thrive with a kind of African motif," he said, adding that there must always be a place for noncultural businesses, too.
One of first changes his office has successfully sought will be welcomed by all: the planting of trees along the southern edge of Leimert Park Plaza, a triangular city park that faces the neighborhood's business district and the residential area beyond.
But others clamor for more drastic changes. James Dodson, the owner of Banjo's Yogurt and Deli, offers what he calls his "radical plan," which calls for cooperative economics among village merchants, who would simultaneously raise money and raze the aging village buildings.
"We should rebuild from the ground up," said Mr. Dodson, 46, who also works as an electrician and who is studying marketing. He said he had to invest $15,000 to upgrade the wiring in his rented building. Few merchants share Mr. Dodson's view.
In the meantime, however, life in the area goes on, and so does its beat -- literally. Along the village's one-block strip on Degnan Boulevard between 43d Place and 43d Street, live and recorded music seem to be everywhere, spilling into the street even in daytime and mixing with the low growl of the occasional passing car. For a cover charge of $3 to $10, anyone can pull up a seat in the long-running neighborhood nightclub scene.
Less than six hours before Art Manley gave his sunrise serenade, he had added his trumpet's piercing voice to the beat of an Afro-Latin jazz band at Fifth Street Dick's Coffee Company on 43d Place, which is across the street from the park.
Last month, Whitman Mayo, an actor best known for playing with Redd Foxx in the television series "Sanford and Son," prepared to guide a crew from Black Entertainment Television on a tour of the latest "in" neighborhood. "There are so many major cities that don't have anything like this, a place for people to proudly develop their culture," he said.
Leimert Park is also catching the eye of black film makers. Allen and Albert Hughes came to Leimert Park to shoot scenes for their film "Menace II Society." And earlier in the fall, Andre Young, better known as the "gangsta" rapper Dr. Dre, brought a film crew and extras here to shoot his music video "Let It Ride."
On week nights, however, band members outnumber the audiences in local clubs like the World Stage. But Richard Fulton, the owner and founder of Fifth Street Dick's Coffee Company, a two-story coffeehouse and jazz spot, said he is not too concerned about the sometimes light turnouts.
"Fifth Street Dick's is not going to make money," he said of his business, which he opened a year and a half ago. "I just want to bring the people together."
A 50-year-old Vietnam veteran, he said he once wandered the streets homeless and in an alcoholic stupor. He is also a force behind the nearby Alcoholics Anonymous center, one of the largest in the city. Mr. Fulton said some 3,000 people visit the center daily.
Commodore Williams, who described himself as a recovering alcoholic, is a weathered fixture around Leimert Park. Supporting himself on odd jobs and his good humor, he said the neighborhood was blooming again because of people like Mr. Fulton.
"It's simple," he said as he swept the pavement in front of the coffeehouse. "He's a man that's been to hell. Now he's trying to bring us a little heaven."

HEADLINE: Free-Market Misery for Latin America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Latin America Finds Harmony in Convergence" (The Week in Review, Nov. 21) suggests that opening markets and pursuing economic austerity offers reformers in Latin America the best hope for raising living standards among the masses and in turn creating a politically stable future.
Recent trends in Latin America confirm just the opposite, showing that living standards for the vast majority of the region's peasants and workers have plunged precipitously at the very time that free-market reformers have been opening markets to foreign producers, privatizing state companies and reducing public spending. 
 Juan de Dias Parra, leader of the Latin American Association for Human Rights, summarized the recent trends at a meeting in Quito, Ecuador, noting that "in Latin America today, there are 70 million more hungry, 30 million more illiterate, 10 million more families without homes and 40 million more unemployed persons than there were 20 years ago. . . . There are 240 million human beings who lack the necessities of life and this when the region is richer and more stable than ever, according to the way the world sees it."
The mass dislocation and suffering that have accompanied the move toward free markets and open trade result directly from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank's neo-liberal development model, which is tailored to the needs of foreign investors irrespective of local conditions and needs.
A better policy for the United States and its lending agencies would be to encourage development that incorporates domestic content laws (to help local producers), compensatory financing (to develop backward areas), and continued social spending (to alleviate the jarring effects of privatization).
Without such provisions and careful planning, opening markets and pursuing austerity will continue to generate mass dislocation, social misery and political unrest throughout Latin America.
 
EYAL PRESS
New York, Nov. 29, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Baltics Can Afford to Live a Little

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: TALLINN, Estonia

 BODY:
THE first snow squalls are already slanting off the Baltic Sea, and darkness settles over the city each afternoon by four o'clock. But these days, beneath the ancient pitched roofs and gabled churches of Tallinn's old town, the cobbled alleyways are suffused, here and there, with the warmth of the Baltics' new glow.
Behind the steamy storefronts where socialism once showed its shabby wares, there are now sleek coffee shops and boutiques, brightly lit art galleries and snug taverns, including a replica of an Irish pub that could just as easily be in Dublin. 
 In these brittle northern latitudes, there is no surer boost to confidence than knowing you can stare winter straight in the eye and not blink. And this December, for the first time since 1989, the people of Estonia and its neighbors, Lithuania and Latvia, are settling in for the Baltic winter with the expectation they will have the heat and hot water to last them through next spring.
After several difficult years enduring a different kind of cold war with Moscow, which at times choked off supplies of gas and oil, the Baltic nations say they have the cash and the fuel to stay warm.
By any measure, these tiny nations -- together they cover an area about the size of the state of Washington -- have come a long way since they bravely wrested themselves loose of Moscow in 1991, the first tug in the rebellion that ultimately unraveled the whole of the threadbare Soviet empire.
Culturally and historically, the three Baltic states had always been the least Soviet of the Soviet republics, seized by the Red Army and annexed in 1940 under Stalin's secret pact with Hitler and its codicils. Not only was their orientation more European than Slavic, but their incomes and living standards were higher, and their economies more productive.
As a result, recovery appears to have come about less painfully here. Inflation, which topped 600 percent a year in 1991, is now below 10 percent in all three countries. Their new currencies, freed from the ruble, are stable and freely convertible on Western exchange markets. Shortages are mostly a thing of the past.
The wrenching shift toward market economies has claimed many victims. Reforms closed factories and state enterprises, leaving thousands without work; the homeless are now a common sight in the rail station in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, and pensioners complain they cannot live on payments of less than $25 a month.
Still, economists say the future looks reasonably bright. World Bank studies predict sustained economic recovery in all three countries by next year, with growth rising steadily through the turn of the century.
At the same time, progress has been made in defusing tensions over the remnants of the Red Army left behind when the republics split away. With steady pressure from the West, the number of former Red Army troops inside the Baltics has declined from 150,000 in 1991 to a ragtag force of fewer than 18,000, all but 2,500 of whom are in Latvia, where Moscow is clinging to key radar installations facing West. Russian troops have been withdrawn entirely from Lithuania.
 
Russians Who Aren't Going
 A more difficult question is the large minorities of Russian-speaking natives in Estonia and Latvia, mostly the families of blue-collar workers resettled during the Communist era. Although many people have been here all their lives, they argue that they are now being relegated to a second-class status, barred from citizenship until they pass rigorous language exams.
But while nationalist hard-liners and political extremists still argue on behalf of a kind of Baltic ethnic purity, the tensions have never resulted in bloodshed, and in Estonia this fall, the Government let Russian non-citizens vote in local elections. Seizing their chance, they stacked city councils in several cities.
For the most part, the largest obstacles to the Baltics' future are no longer economic, but the legacy of corruption, inefficiency and cynicism resulting from a half-century of Communist control. Organized crime has become a major force. In Estonia alone in 1993, gangs competing to control rackets are suspected of setting off some 50 bombs.
In government and the armed forces, corruption is endemic. In an interview, Gen. Aleksander Einseln, the 61-year-old retired U.S. Army officer and native Estonian who is now commander of Estonia's nascent army, waved a sheaf of papers that he predicted would send shock waves through his ranks. "It's the U.S. military policy on conflict of interest, translated into Estonian," he said.
The Baltic nations, small and vulnerable on the edge of Western Europe, also have a traditional reluctance to cooperate closely with one another. While Westerners often think of the three nations as of a single kind, they are distinctly separate places, each with its own language, history, culture, even architecture. Last year, according to World Bank figures, less than 10 percent of the countries' combined foreign trade volume consisted of intraBaltic trade.
Some attempts are being made at Baltic unity. The three countries say they intend to offer a joint contingent of soldiers to the United Nations to serve as a Baltic peacekeeping battalion, and their Parliaments are now studying a pan-Baltic trade agreement.
But an even larger question is how the Baltics will come to terms with Russia, which looms as not only their greatest worry but also potentially their most profitable trading partner. Last month, Lithuania became the first of the new Baltic nations to reach a trade agreement with its eastern neighbor, but not without protests from nationalists who still harbor grudges. Here in Estonia and in Latvia, feelings are even sharper, tinged by suspicion that Russia might use human rights concerns over Russian minorities as a pretext to meddle or even intervene. "For all the progress we have made, we must be careful not to become too confident," said Hannes Walter, an official of the Estonian Defense Ministry. "For now, the Baltics are still a power vacuum."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Washington's Biggest Special Interest Is Still Itself

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MARVIN DAVIS, the billionaire oil and real estate mogul who once owned 20th Century Fox, likes to hobnob with people of influence. In 1984, when Gary Hart was winning raves in Hollywood as a possible Democratic Presidential nominee, Mr. Davis gave a lavish backlot banquet in his honor. Four years later, he donated $100,000 apiece to the Republican and Democratic parties.
So it was hardly a surprise that Mr. Davis invited President Clinton to his Beverly Hills mansion last night as the star attraction of an intimate dinner party, at a cost of $25,000 to $100,000 per couple (proceeds go to the Democratic National Committee). 
 The surprise was that Mr. Clinton accepted.
Mr. Clinton was elected last year on a promise of sweeping reform; his would be the Presidency in which the flow of millions of dollars of special interest donations would be halted. As he introduced his campaign finance package last May, which would virtually eliminate events like Mr. Davis's, Mr. Clinton boldly vowed to "change the way Washington works." His chairman at the Democratic National Committee, David Wilhelm, declared that the party would rely "less on black-tie dinners and more on brown-bag lunches."
The oratory from candidates for Congress was just as enthusiastic. As recently as last month, there was heady talk of a "reform week" on Capitol Hill, when members would approve tight regulations on how campaigns are financed and new restrictions on lobbyists.
For all the promises, the basic culture does not seem to have changed. Members of Congress are still taking expense-paid getaways from lobbying groups. And like many of his predecessors, the President is choosing dinner companions by how much they give.
The campaign finance bill that Mr. Clinton said would be a top priority was rendered toothless by jittery members of the House: it contains no mechanism to finance vouchers for advertising that would go to candidates who limit their spending. The optimism of many new members elected last year on the promise of reform suddenly seemed like naievite when efforts were dropped to impose a $20 limit on gifts from lobbyists (especially contentious was whether the greens fees that lobbyists often pay when they golf with lawmakers would be subject to new restrictions).
"Clinton can say whatever he wants, but the patterns of behavior are the same old stuff," said former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr., of California, who for years cajoled wealthy supporters for donations then ran against Mr. Clinton in the Democratic primaries last year by attacking the system that he himself had thrived on. "This exclusive dinner goes against every concept of a populist Democratic Party."
Michael Waldman, a reformer himself as director of Public Citizen's Congress Watch and now Mr. Clinton's chief aide on campaign finance, defends the President's attendance at the dinner. "The President has proposed reforms that cut off much of the money that has been raised for Presidential campaigns and that will cost Democrats literally tens of millions of dollars," he said. "We are fighting to pass that legislation. We are not going to unilaterally disarm before that happens."
Indeed, if Mr. Clinton can prod the House and Senate to reach an accommodation on the sometimes contradictory bills they have passed, and resolve Constitutional questions, it would be the first major victory since right after Watergate. But the result would likely fall far short of Mr. Clinton's initial package, which offered advertising subsidies for candidates who limited their spending, and sharply restricted political action committees.
To be fair, Mr. Clinton appears to be well intentioned. He put in place the toughest restrictions ever on Administration officials' lobbying after they leave Government. But he underestimated the resistance from Congress, both from the leadership and the rank-and-file members who fear they will be defeated if special interests are restricted.
 
Setting High Standards
 Faced with competing demands, the President also made a decision not to sacrifice political capital by thrusting himself into the negotiations over campaign finance. "A lot of the liberal, progressive Democrats who helped carry the budget hate campaign finance reform," Mr. Clinton said in an interview in Rolling Stone.
If he is being held to a high standard, it is largely one of his own making. "Once you say you're going to be the most ethical and reform-minded Administration in history, you raise the bar," said Norman Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. "It is inevitable that he will be accused of hypocrisy."
It could be that the only way Mr. Clinton can achieve the changes he promised is by convincing lawmakers that their constituents want solid evidence that they are willing to upset the status quo. Ross Perot, who pressed reform during last year's campaign, will certainly try to keep these issues alive, though his own credibility was tarnished in the debate last month when Vice President Al Gore recalled the Texan's history of lobbying Congress in support of his business ventures.
But there is still a real question of how much disillusioned voters would be impressed by enactment of new ethics and campaign laws. "Everyone has concerns about health care, and issues like the economy," said Ruth Jones, a political scientist at Arizona State University. "But only 12 to 15 percent even give to campaigns."
Representative J. Alex McMillan, a Republican from North Carolina who is the latest of nearly 20 incumbent House members who announced plans to retire next year, does not seem convinced that his colleagues will be moved to change their ways anytime soon. In a parting letter to his constituents last week, a clearly soured Mr. McMillan wrote: "I have been frustrated and greatly disappointed by the failure of Congress and our Presidents to exercise strong, independent leadership, as opposed to yielding to the influence of various special interest groups and the cynical political environment that dominates present-day Washington."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Foreign Aid Of Words, Not Cash

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON stood at the White House with the leaders of all five Central American countries last week and noted that it was the first time in the 20th century that a United States President was meeting a group of democratically elected Presidents from the region. "My message to these distinguished leaders and to the millions whom they represent is simple: The United States will be there as your partner to help," Mr. Clinton said. "We will not make the mistake of abandoning this region when its dramatic recovery is not yet complete."
Fine words, but like much of what comes out of the deficit-plagued Federal Government these days, the reach exceeded the grasp. 
 The hard reality is that in the last few years, American financial aid to the fledgling democracies of Central America -- and to much of the rest of the world -- has fallen, as if off a cliff. El Salvador, for example, has seen direct cash payments shrink to $45 million from $126 million in 1991. Three years ago, cash assistance to Nicaragua was $226 million. It is now $10 million. Hondouras received $50 million in 1991 in direct payments. It is due to get $7.5 million in the current fiscal year.
And the pattern has been repeated in other regions. Public support for foreign aid -- never strong -- is eroding with the end of the cold war. As a result, total foreign aid has dropped by roughly $4 billion since 1985, when the total was about $18.5 billion. "The security interests have diminished, the political interests are small and we don't have much money," said Peter Hakim, president of the Inter-American Dialogue.
Experts have begun to worry that the drop in American financial assistance may actually increase political instability in areas like Central America and that this will inhibit economic growth by scaring away new investment. Some of the experts point out that this seems to belie the stated American goal of encouraging the rise of consumer societies abroad that would be better markets for United States exports -- although it is also an obvious, if harsh, truth that large countries like Mexico are far more likely to be taken seriously in this regard than tiny ones.
Indeed, even as President Clinton was trumpeting American concern for Central America, State Department planners were preparing confidential memos warning that aid cutbacks were imperiling the region's nascent democracies. "Without timely material and moral support from other democratic countries, fragile transitions to democratic rule could be lost," said a memo prepared by State Department analysts.
To much of the public, foreign aid is an amorphous, little understood and not well liked program. The $14.4 billion in aid appropriated this year represents only about 1 percent of total Federal spending and encompasses everything from military aid to population stabilization, anti-narcotics programs, disaster assistance, the Peace Corps, non-emergency food aid, help for refugees and contributions to the United Nations and the World Bank.
About 40 percent of this aid is designated for the Middle East and the former Soviet Union (Israel and Egypt remain by far the largest individual recipients under arrangements that date to the Camp David accords). And with a new American commitment of $75 million a year to support the effort to find peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians, money for other countries is drying up.
Aid to the Philippines has been cut by 85 percent in the last three years. The United States is $1.2 billion behind on its payments to the United Nations and to international lending institutions. It has failed to meet its promised share of international assistance to nations such as Peru and Guyana. Non-emergency aid to sub-Sahara Africa has diminished only slightly, but Africa hands at the State Department fear major cutbacks.
And the Office of Management and Budget has told the State Department to reduce foreign aid by another 6.5 percent in the next budget. State Department planners say there will be no cuts for the Middle East and the former Soviet Union, meaning that other programs -- mainly in Asia and Latin America -- will probably see reductions of 40 percent to 60 percent.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Part Two of The Free Trade Triathlon

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration is trying to complete a free trade triathlon: the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada last month, a global trade pact this month and greater economic integration with Asia, including a deal with Japan on cars, insurance and several other industries early next year.
After seven years of tedious negotiations and missed deadlines, a global free-trade pact may be just 10 days away, trade officials said last week. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's top trade official, are expected to announce in Brussels tomorrow a settlement of many trans-Atlantic trade squabbles that have blocked completion of an overall trade pact among 116 nations. 
 The deal is designed to address French objections to an agreement last year that would have cut European Government payments to farm exporters very sharply in 1995 and very gradually from 1996 through 2001. The new deal would spread all of the cuts evenly over the years from 1995 to 2001.
The European Government's payments to exporters have depressed world prices, angering American farmers. In exchange for the slower cuts, the community agreed to open its markets a little wider to American farm exports.
The global trade pact now taking shape is as important as it is arcane. It would cut world tariffs on manufactured goods by a third. It would also broaden the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to cover agriculture and service industries like tourism and insurance for the first time. Until now, the 45-year-old GATT has covered trade in manufactured goods, gradually lowering worldwide tariffs to 5 percent from 40 percent.
Estimates vary widely on the effects of a broader trade agreement on the American consumer and the world economy. The price of a grocery basket of food is unlikely to change much at first, because the agricultural provisions take effect so slowly. But eventually a pound of sugar or a bag of peanuts would probably be a few pennies cheaper. The cost to taxpayers of Federal payments to American farmers would eventually fall by $2 billion to $3 billion or more a year.
The Administration forecasts that the agreement could also create 1.4 million American jobs over the next decade by eliminating foreign trade barriers that keep foreign consumers from buying such American products as records, insurance and corn. But labor unions and some American business executives warn that many jobs could be lost because the Federal Government would be less able to impose special taxes on cheap imports that hurt American companies. KEITH BRADSHER
