HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why Mexico Has Only One Big Hat In the Ring

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
THERE was no white smoke. No cannons boomed. But when the man handpicked by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to be his successor was brought to the headquarters of Mexico's governing party last week, the event represented as secretive and undemocratic a process as any selection of a pope or coronation of a king. That night, thousands of people surrounded party headquarters. And the streets rang not with rage but elation.
The scene might have dispelled President Clinton's vision of a rising democracy in Mexico, and it probably disappointed those who believed that Mr. Salinas would make the process of picking the next president more open than it has been during the 64 years that his party or its predecessor have been in power. 
 But it might also have provided some grim satisfaction for those United States legislators who, during the long debate in Congress over the North American Free Trade Agreement last month, had argued that Mexico was more dictatorship than democracy.
Democracy might seem an odd issue to have been included in a free trade debate, but President Clinton sold the agreement partly on the premise that by opening its economy further with the accord, Mexico would quicken the pace of its political opening as well.
The White House now seems uncertain about how to deal with Mexican reality. Vice President Al Gore traveled to Mexico City last week pledging that free trade "promotes democracy," but he said nothing about the secretive anointment last Sunday of Luis Donaldo Colosio Murietta as the candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party in an election on Aug. 21 that most people view as no contest. Perhaps worse, Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, was taken to task by the scraggly Mexican opposition for seeming to refer to Mr. Colosio prematurely as "the new president."
Mexico's economy has indeed opened up, with more than 1,000 state-owned companies privatized and many protectionist tariffs reduced or removed already, before the free-trade agreement takes effect on Jan. 1.
But even President Salinas admits that Mexico's political opening has been far more modest. He has said political reform should come after economic restructuring, not before; otherwise the country would risk the sort of instability that undid Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet Union. Since Mr. Salinas's popularity soared after the Nafta vote, it appears that most Mexicans are willing to accept his argument.
Thus it often seems, as it did during the Nafta debate, that the pressure for democratizing Mexico is stronger outside the country than within. Why?
"It may not be politically correct to say so, but there is a very strong element of authoritarianism in many aspects of Mexican life," said Roderic A. Camp, a Mexico expert at Tulane University. Mexico, after all, is still a society where even middle-class families have maids and people routinely identify themselves as "su servidor," literally "your servant."
Mexico has loved a strong leader since before Moctezuma. Indigenous tribes were ruled by caciques, or chieftans, and in some rural communities caciques are still unchallenged. After independence in 1821 ended 300 years of Spanish rule, Mexicans time and again turned to emperors, dictators or caudillos -- strong rulers.
"What we have experienced just recently is still part of this heavy cultural burden," said Raymundo Riva Palacio, an editor of the independent El Financiero. "Last Sunday a king died and a new king was born."
Maybe it was the burden of culture that compelled thousands of Mexicans to stand in the night. Maybe it was the governing party's free sandwiches.
Whichever, not one of the people carried a sign objecting to the near-inevitable succession of Mr. Colosio -- near-inevitable because of the Institutional Revolutionary Party's virtual lock on Mexican political life.
The original party was formed by the post-revolutionary leaders of 1929 so they could maintain power, and it became an incarnation of the Government, dispensing favors, repressing opposition and becoming so entwined with Mexican life that joining many unions still brings automatic membership in the party.
The PRI, as the party is known by its Spanish initials, was also based on allegiance, always leading back to the president. But unlike the typical authoritarian Latin American regime, Mexico is run by civilians, not generals. The PRI has deliberately absorbed weak opposition parties and tolerated a small critical press. And the prohibition against re-election meant the absolute ruler was absolutely discarded after six years.
The system produced an enviable record of stability for a third world country. Unrest surfaced in student riots of 1968, and a near loss for Mr. Salinas in the election of 1988, but mostly Mexico has been at peace.
 
Geographic Release Valve
 Terry L. Karl, director of the Center for Latin American Studies at Stanford University, says the party avoided unrest in part by repressing or buying off potential opponents. Moreover, Mexico has an extraordinary advantage of geography, and the release valve of the Rio Grande. The angriest and most entrepreneurial simply went north when the problems of Mexico got to be too much. As in Communist Cuba, those departures weakened the voice of opposition.
The middle class has generally been quiet, though not necessarily supportive of the government; rather, it acquiesces to it. For many middle-class Mexicans, the government is a path to privilege, not a way to change society. In one 1990 survey, two-thirds of Mexicans said their government was working only for its own interests.
Still, a lot is riding on the August election. After hearing so many promises about the impact of a trade agreement, expectations among ordinary Mexicans for more trade, more pay and more political openness have undoubtedly risen. The United States has great expectations too, especially since Nafta can be abrogated if it seems that promises are not being kept.
Mr. Colosio's contradictory brief in the election will be to give the appearance of real change while also insuring that his party retains power. He not only has to win, but to do so cleanly and convincingly.
He may have gotten the message. The night he was selected, he took the surprising step of proposing to debate the opposition candidates, Diego Fernandez de Cevallos of the National Action Party and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the Democratic Revolutionary Party.
But such concessions don't always sit well with old-line party members emboldened by Mr. Salinas's victories into thinking the party may rule for another 64 years. More than anything, Mr. Colosio will have to avoid the kind of black cloud now hovering over the state of Yucatan. While Mr. Gore was extolling a hemispheric "community of democracies" in Mexico City last Wednesday, Mexicans in the Yucatan were out in the street, not praising Mr. Colosio, but protesting that the PRI had stolen last Sunday's gubernatorial election, and that they had been cheated again.

HEADLINE: The Difficult Math of Welfare Reform

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
There are approximately 60,000 words in the Administration's plan to overhaul the welfare system, but three of them have the potential to mock the rest and expose President Clinton's bold promises as empty slogans. Those words are: "Deficit neutral funding."
That means Mr. Clinton plans to finance an ambitious set of child care, education and work programs for people on welfare by cutting other programs for the poor. 
 If past practices hold, advocacy groups will rebel, political bloodletting will follow and Mr. Clinton will wind up with a program not nearly as bold as his campaign promise to "end welfare as we know it."
That's what veterans of past welfare wars foresee, as a draft of his plan came to light this week.
"It can't work," said Joseph Califano, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare when President Jimmy Carter failed to win a similar self-financed plan. "Deja vu, isn't it?"
Mr. Clinton's pledge to make welfare recipients work is an enormously popular one, and he turned to it often on the campaign trail last year.
 
What the Public Hears
 The public hears the talk of time limits as a way to get tough and save money. But the plan described in the draft, subject to the President's review, talks of first expanding training programs and day care. That is so welfare mothers can acquire job skills and find people to watch their children while they work. The plan also talks of financing some of the jobs.
That is much more expensive than simply sending welfare checks, which now average about $370 a month for a mother and two children.
How expensive? The Clinton plan does not say, and no one will know the extent until the President puts forward some numbers. The plan itself describes a phase-in to ease the burden.
"We have not fully thought through the financing because we are not sure how much the President wants to do," Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview on Friday.
 
Cynicism Is Perceived
 But Ms. Shalala insists that even a large program can be financed by savings from the current human services budget. She accused old Washington hands of undue cynicism about efforts to make bureaucracies more efficient.
"Is it possible?" she asked. "Yes," she said, arguing that local and state governments are doing it. "Will it be difficult? Yes. Has Washington ever done it? No."
Five million adults and nine million children receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal cash program, and that is a record.
Poor and disproportionately black, seen to be idle, they are not a popular bunch. Welfare and food stamp benefits have already shrunk by about 25 percent over two decades, when adjusted for inflation, and state and local governments remain under stress.
While the cost of welfare is not small, it is not as large as the passions that surround the issue, which are inflamed by notions of race and class and sexual behavior.
The A.F.D.C. program costs about $23 billion a year. Medicaid and food stamps for welfare recipients add about $40 billion to the bill.
That's less than half the cost of Medicare, the $140 billion health insurance program for the elderly. And it's about a quarter of the cost of Social Security, which will reach $320 billion this year.
Mr. Califano has called welfare reform the Middle East of domestic politics, a world composed of warring tribes and irreconcilable differences.
An overly pessimistic judgment? Perhaps. But the plan is still only a draft and the tribes are already on the move.
One is composed of centrist Democrats. In October, 77 of them in the House, loosely affiliated with the Democratic Leadership Council, urged Mr. Clinton by letter to stick to the time limits. But they ducked the question of money, asserting vaguely that the costs of various welfare programs could be cut. "You can squeeze other programs that are not as high a priority to pay for this," said Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, a leader of the group. "That's what making choices is about."
The liberal tribe responded in November. A letter signed by 89 Representatives called a time-limit plan arbitrary and said it would "increase poverty and hurt needy families."
And then there is a Republican view, expressed in a House bill that would impose tougher time limits than those being contemplated by the Administration. It does spend money -- up to $6 billion a year for child care and training. But it plans to raise the money by cutting food programs and welfare benefits for immigrants.
Otherwise, the plan would be "taking money from people who work, to give more to people who don't," said Representative Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania. "That's not what anybody beyond the Beltway means by welfare reform."
But existing programs do not yield lightly, even those for the poor. The Administration recently tried to raise $330 million for unemployment benefits, by cutting a disability program for immigrants. Hispanic members of the House were enraged, and defying the Democratic leadership, they defeated the plan.
During his campaign, Mr. Clinton suggested spending an additional $4 billion on training. An aide said this week that it would look silly to propose a more limited program than the one the $6 billion Republican bill.
And even that might not be enough to cover all the families on welfare, even if the Administration finds the money, through real cuts or overly optimistic projections of savings.
A rough estimate prepared for the Administration last year suggested that as many as 1.5 million families would exhaust a two-year limit without finding a job. Past experience suggests that it could cost about $5 billion just to run the work portion of the program. The training portion could possibly double that sum.
That is why the plan now talks about phasing in a program slowly, creating a structure but deferring its costs.
Time limits have the appeal of sounding cheap: two years and then people will have to work. But work where? Some will find private jobs, but many will not, especially in an economy with 8.3 million out of work.

HEADLINE: Gambling, Pariah No More, Is Booming Across America

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 1

 BODY:
The newest venture in the booming national industry of legalized gambling is now open for business: futuristic virtual-reality rides to soothe the losers' souls, just up the theme-park escalator from acres of the latest video slot machines.
Here in the desert where Bugsy Siegel started it all six decades ago as a limited-audience, amoral escapade for high rollers, legalized gambling is displaying its growing mass-entertainment role in grand fashion. Three huge new casinos costing a total of $2 billion are opening with a new kind of Hollywood star power, a tie-in emphasis on special-effects theme-park entertainment. 
 "Did you see that?" asked one distracted loser, Jim Czarniecki, emerging in great delight from one of the new participatory trompe l'oeil theater entertainments at the mammoth new Luxor casino hotel.
With its replica of Tut's tomb, the glass pyramid-cum-Sphinx extravaganza is enough to make the old American connotation of the sinfulness of gambling seem as quaintly distant as the Conestoga wagon.
The sin is indeed gone from the nation's gaming industry, obliterated by the notion of mass entertainment. Fifteen years of astounding growth has seen legalized gambling mushroom from just two main casino cities and a handful of state lotteries and race tracks to take root in some form in all the states but Utah and Hawaii, creating an estimated 500,000 jobs.
 
Lotteries in 37 States
 Americans, unrestrained in their entertainment appetite by the recession, spent $29.9 billion on legal gambling last year. That was six times what they spent on movie tickets, as the gambling industry enlarged its share of the nation's entertainment dollar through a dizzying, competitive combination of state lotteries, Indian reservation casinos, and riverboat gambling that saw the industry buck the recession with an 11 percent annual growth rate across the last decade.
Of all the factors that rolled back the bias against gambling, the steady growth of mass-market state lotteries may be most influential if least flamboyant in making gambling accepted more as middle-class recreation. From New Hampshire's first lottery in 1964, elaborate lotteries are now under way in 37 states, raking in 38 cents of every legally wagered dollar. With new, more inviting video technology helping increase play, the total tax revenue from the lotteries alone climbed to $11.45 billion last year, an increase of 12 percent over 1991.
Popular lottery acceptance, recession pressures on state and local budgets, and a sudden cascade of casino investments on land and water are the main factors in gambling's growth.
"People are now looking at gambling as another entertainment option," said Paul Dworin, publisher and editor of Gambling & Wagering Business magazine.
"Americans spend more on leisure and entertainment, and gambling has become a significant part of that economy," said Mr. Dworin, whose own publication has paralleled gambling in moving from editorial pariah to industry resource in a decade of changing attitudes.
In that metamorphosis, no factor has been more noticeable than the shift in morality issues in American politics, which, while coming to focus on abortion more, has spared gambling the fulmination and denunciation of the past.
"Helping this change in attitude is the fact that two of society's moral arbiters and most outspoken critics of gaming -- church and state -- have been quelled in recent years due to their dependence on revenues derived from gaming," concluded a detailed analysis of the industry boom by Wertheim Schroder & Company, investment consultants.
In the least expected part of the explosion, at least 65 Indian reservation casinos have opened since 1989 in 17 states in the hands of tribes resurrected from poverty by gambling that created more than $900 million in annual profits. Eighty more court-protected sovereign tribes have gambling plans in a dozen other states.
They were inspired by the industry's phenomenon, the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, Conn. Since being opened 21 months ago by the Mashantucket Pequot tribe, which was once nearly extinct amid urban poverty, it has become the most profitable casino in the world, according to industry estimates. It has greatly increased nervousness in the Atlantic City casino industry as well as pressure in neighboring states to guarantee their own flow of gambling revenue.
Even with the tribes' total profits doubling annually, they control only about 5 percent of the market. In another boom factor as the recession-wounded states scrambled for revenue, Iowa started riverboat gambling only two years ago with two modest operations. Now there are more than two dozen casino boats working the waters and betting handles, and 40 more authorized in six states along the Gulf Coast and Mississippi River. High-stakes gambling goes on round-the-clock in cut-throat regional competition, lately aboard land-locked "riverboats."
 
Boating to the Elevators
 Fun more than fortune is the promised payoff in gambling's modern market approach through theme-park casinos designed by specialists like Douglas Trumbull, the special-effects master who fantasized time travel for such movies as "Bladerunner" and "Back to the Future."
Here within the recently opened Luxor pyramid, there is an indoor Nile for boating from the registration desk to the elevators and a huge atrium that easily includes a mall of food, entertainment and merchandizing. The resort contains 2,526 large, low-priced rooms and traditionally steep house-odds that rise against the cinnamon hue of the desert mountains in 30 stories of black-matte glass and fake Egyptian mystery.
There are three theaters for past, present and future virtual-reality rides that Aldous Huxley only dreamt of, plus an arcade of prototype Sega games for third-dimension pinball buffs, all designed to be profit-making, not come-ons for the casino games.
"I mean, it's like being inside, not just at, the movies," said Mr. Czarniecki, pleased with his bit of loser's bonus in getting to jounce and duck and zoom through a big-screen, Indiana Jones-type of a tumble in a wired seat set before an electronic Egyptian fantasy.
He is a fairly typical modern American gambler, according to industry statistics: one of the 50 percent of adults who have been inside a casino to spend their entertainment dollars, a percentage that has been rapidly rising, and a middle-income worker who regularly plays the weekly lottery in his home state.
Clyde Turner, president of Circus Circus Enterprises, which built the Luxor mega-casino, thinks Mark Twain would savor the current boom, with his insights into such Americana as riverboats, pragmatically shifting mores and bourgeois delights.
 
'Changes in Ideas'
 "The showboat icon of progress and fun that Twain understood is a serious factor in all this," said Mr. Turner, a 56-year-old accountant who was born in this city yet sternly shielded from gambling as a boy by his father, who worked at a small casino.
"Years ago people wouldn't tell their friends they had been here," he said of Las Vegas, one of the fastest growing cities in the nation as the generation of theme-park casinos is built and staffed. "The key to what is happening with legalized gambling is the change in peoples' ideas and thoughts."
The pervasiveness of the change is not always for the better, concede some industry specialists like Eugene Martin Christiansen, a consultant who tracks gaming growth for Gambling & Wagering Business magazine. "Jaded, shopped-out consumers who take a little measured stimulation in Las Vegas now and then are one side of the coin," he noted in his latest industry study. "Housewives who play street-corner video lottery poker machines compulsively are the other."
His larger point, however, is legal gambling's undeniable growth and new status as a national institution. "Gambling is now squarely in the American mainstream," Mr. Christiansen said. "It is an enormous business: about the size in 1992 of the Hollywood filmed entertainment industry." .
He estimates that the nearly $30 billion in annual revenue in the growing gambling industry is equal to all of the revenue in films and related cable and video enterprises in Hollywood, which saw theater patronage dip slightly last year.
Gambling executives contend that the industry, through tighter regulatory controls, has succeeded in driving out most organized criminal influences from casinos, which serve a third of the market. Still, not all states are cooperating in the high-stakes urge.
Idaho recently approved a constitutional ban on casinos, though the state does allow bingo, betting on greyhound and horse races. Colorado, a pioneer in small-town mountain casinos, has set new limits after some towns went from boom to bust because of saturation, a problem in some regions but one that specialists do not expect nationally, at least for the rest of this decade.
 
Rivaling Health Clubs
 The percentage of Americans' personal income spent on gambling has been growing, reaching 0.59 percent last year. According to Mr. Christiansen, this is comparable to what Americans spent on dentistry or on health clubs and beauty parlors. In the eyes of the new generation of entertainment-gambling executives here, wagering is a consumer attraction as morally defensible as the nation's passive mania for movies and videos.
Looming here across from the Luxor's sphinx is a giant lion symbolizing the MGM Grand casino about to open with 5,009 bedrooms -- the world's largest hotel -- and a theme park that will take days to visit. The third in the new generation of casinos, Treasure Island, is already open on the Vegas Strip, complete with an hourly sea battle of actor-buccaneers aboard two full-size sailing ships set in a desert canal just outside the gaming rooms.
"Say, I thought we were here for the gambling," one woman in the crowd said to her companion in confusion the other night as the battle raged. The spectacle was soon over, and her man urgently said, "C'mon." They hurried inside to a vast new gambling mart, in pursuit of their own fantasies.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
'Alliance' to Buy Health Care: Bureaucrat or Public Servant?

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
If the Clinton health plan becomes law, it will put a new institution into the lives of most Americans: the health alliance. Almost no other aspect of the plan is so little understood or so radically different from the status quo.
Administration planners envision the alliances as benign and helpful organizations that would perform many functions now handled by employee benefit departments. 
 In essence, the Clinton alliances would act as middlemen between consumers and health plans. They would collect premiums from individuals and employers, enforce Federal rules on the amount of premiums health plans could charge, rate the performance of the plans the way Consumer Reports might and conduct annual open enrollments when people could decide which plan to join for the year to come.
In short, Clinton advisers say, the alliances would give people more power, more information and more choices in the kind of health care they receive than they have today.
 
Comparing Bureaucracies
 "What we are doing is replacing the inept, wasteful and ineffective bureaucracy, if you will, of the unfettered marketplace," said Judith Feder, a deputy assistant secretary of Health and Human Services.
This, however, is just one vision of the alliance. There is also a nightmare concept from critics on both the left and the right. They see a new layer of bureaucracy imposed on people already dissatisfied with the amount of government in their lives. They see an enormous amount of power invested in the appointed boards that would run the alliances, a situation ripe for corruption and conflicts of interest.
There would be one alliance in every region, whose boundaries and administrative structure would be determined by the states. Everyone would belong to it, rich and poor alike, except those who work for the biggest corporations. Critics predict brutal political battles in state legislatures over how the borders of the alliances are drawn, as localities struggle to avoid sharing their alliances with inner city, poor and high-risk populations.
The critics also fear that making the alliances monopolies will make them as sensitive to consumer needs as the average Department of Motor Vehicles. And, perhaps most of all, they say the Administration's planners are putting an astonishing amount of faith in an idea largely untested in the United States. What happens, many critics ask, if the Federal Government puts 70 percent of Americans, including many of those in the Medicaid program for the poor, into a system of health alliances that fails to work?
"They're too large and they're too regulatory," said Representative Jim Cooper, a conservative Democrat from Tennessee with a rival plan.
Representative Pete Stark, a liberal Democrat from California who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said, "It's a cockamamie program."
The predominant attitude on Capitol Hill, however, may be simply wariness about how an alliance would work. "Who appoints them?" asked Senator Barbara Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland. "How would they be accountable? What can you do with them if they're not working? Who watches the franchise in this new approach?"
 
Idea Whose Time Has Arrived
 The idea of health care alliances has been percolating for years. The original rationale is simple: small businesses have serious problems in buying affordable insurance. They are often too small to spread the risk of medical catastrophes. For example, one terribly ill child covered by a small company's plan can send its premiums skyrocketing. And they are too small to attain the economies of scale in administrative costs available to the biggest companies.
Enter the alliances, originally called the health insurance purchasing cooperatives, a name changed on the advice of Clinton political advisers. Like any other cooperative, from those for farmers to those for aging hippie food purchasers, they would presumably combine and strengthen the bargaining clout of members -- in this case, small businesses.
They would spread the risk over a larger pool, share administrative costs and end up, theoretically, as a big and powerful market that health plans would compete to serve. In other words, a little tinkering with the marketplace would solve a social problem, very much in keeping with the political fashion of the day.
The idea caught hold. According to the Institute for Health Policy Solutions, a Washington research group, eight states have passed legislation in the last few years providing for some kind of alliance. Most are focused on the needs of small businesses; membership in all is voluntary, according to the institute, and most are just getting off the ground.
Several alternative proposals to overhaul the nation's health care system now pending in Congress would create alliances. And the Jackson Hole group, an influential gathering of planners from the health industry, government and academia, put alliances at the center of their theory of managed competition, the concept that was eventually embraced by the Clinton forces.
The alliances have an obvious appeal for Mr. Clinton and his advisers, many of whom pride themselves on rejecting stereotypical big-government Democratic solutions to social needs, like straightforward government-financed, Canadian-style health insurance.
They have a new-Democrat, reinventing-government flavor, with a reliance on a magic blend of market and regulatory forces and a populist twist to boot. "Today, only big business has the clout to negotiate lower prices," the official White House account of the health plan says. "After reform, every American will have bargaining strength to get low prices and high quality care."
But by the time the Clinton forces finished drafting their health plan this fall, the alliances had been transformed into something that the original architects of managed competition disdained. They had become far more elaborate, far more regulatory and far bigger than a simple little co-op for small businesses.
Under the Clinton plan, the bulk of the Medicaid program for the poor, on which the Federal Government and the states spend more than $130 billion a year, would be folded into the alliances. The jurisdiction of the alliances was extended to all businesses with fewer than 5,000 employees. (Mr. Cooper's plan, for example, would require participation by companies with only about 100 employees or less.) Alliances would also be responsible for managing a system of subsidies for low-wage companies and low-income people that is an important part of the Clinton plan.
Beyond that, the alliances would collect premiums from employers and employees and pass the money onto health plans, they would negotiate a rate schedule with health care providers that would keep practicing traditional fee-for-service medicine (rather than forming H.M.O's.), and they would insure that participating health plans stayed within the boundaries of a premium price structure set by a National Health Board.
To its critics, the Clinton plan has transformed a market-oriented solution into another Government bureaucracy, and a largely untested one at that.
 
How the Public Sees Government
 Administration officials are keenly aware that this is not an auspicious moment to propose the creation of a network of government agencies; confidence in government remains quite low in public opinion polls. In interviews and in Congressional testimony, Clinton health planners are adamant that the alliances are not a vast new expansion of government.
"There isn't quite as much here as may meet the eye at first," argues Paul Starr, the Princeton sociologist who helped develop the Clinton plan. Walter Zelman, another architect, asserts, "I'm not denying that the alliance is a linchpin, but it's not an enormously powerful structure in the sense that it has all kinds of political flexibility to change rules and to treat people differently."
Administration officials insist that alliance staffs would be modest; Ira C. Magaziner, the domestic policy adviser who led the health plan effort, asserted that even in New York, "I don't think it's a huge bureaucracy."
Officials, however, have been reluctant to discuss just how big alliance staffs would be. One rough estimate -- Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, described it as a very rough estimate -- figured each alliance would cover about a million people and have a staff of about 200.
Clinton aides assert that the alliances would lead to a net reduction in bureaucracy, replacing much of the health benefits bureaucracy of the private sector. Mr. Zelman argued, "Its main functions are in doing, hopefully efficiently, what millions of employers and hundreds of providers and insurers are doing inefficiently now -- collecting money, redistributing money, facilitating the purchasing of and paying for insurance."
Administration officials contend that making the alliances as large as they did, as well as making membership in them mandatory for all but the biggest companies, was essential to spread the risk and prevent the practice of "cherry picking" by insurance companies, or going after the healthiest clients and leaving the sickest and those with the highest risks to fend for themselves. The system would not work, they argue, if alliances ended up serving only small, high-risk populations like former Medicaid clients, inner city populations and a smattering of small businesses.
In the end, the Clinton defense comes down to this: Other, more modest proposals to reform the health care system, like Mr. Cooper's, simply fall short of the goals of guaranteeing health coverage to every American and controlling the rapidly rising health care costs.
Still, the third way that Mr. Clinton so often seeks between left and right has, on the question of alliances, left him open to withering fire from both sides.
The purists of managed competition argue that the Clinton alliance idea is more of a vehicle to control prices than to spur competition. Mr. Cooper said the Clinton version "could be a stepping-stone to a single payer system." A spokesman for the Jackson Hole group, testifying before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, called it "a good health care idea gone bad." Meanwhile, the supporters of a single-payer system counter that their system is much less complicated and far more appealing.
 
Political Reality Raises Questions
 Another set of concerns is practical, not ideological. For all the good intentions of the Clinton planners, just how well would the alliance work in the real, messy world of politics?
There is substantial worry on Capitol Hill about this. For example, the Clinton plan would turn considerable discretion over to state legislatures and governors in setting up the alliances. States would decide how many alliances to have, the details of how to structure the entities and whether to make them nonprofit organizations, independent agencies or agencies of the state. The Clinton proposal does specify, however, that they be run by an appointed board of consumers and employers.
In a Congressional hearing this fall, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, told Ms. Feder: "As sure as I am sitting here, some of these alliances will become monolithic; some of them will take unto themselves powers that are not pro-consumer. They will be thinking more about preserving their own position, about whom they are doing business with and what is in it for them."
Then there is the question of setting boundaries for the alliances; the Clinton plan prohibits redlining high-risk areas and it stipulates that all of a metropolitan statistical area must be included in the same alliance. But some predict a battle in state legislatures that would make Congressional redistricting look tame. "I can assure you that politics will play an important role, because basically there is no redistribution across alliances," said Robert Reischauer, head of the Congressional Budget Office. "So, there will be a temptation to isolate low-income, high-risk people in an alliance if that's feasible."
Clinton supporters argue that much of the criticism of the alliances is being stoked by insurance industry groups and others with a vested interest in holding off true restructuring of the health care system. Still, the debate is clearly joined. While many believe the plan that finally emerges from Congress will include some kind of alliance or purchasing cooperative, it is widely expected to be considerably more modest than the one that Mr. Clinton is proposing. For example, lowering the 5,000-employee threshold necessary to opt out of a regional alliance is a likely area of compromise.
Alain Enthoven, a Stanford University professor of management, an architect of managed competition and principle theoretician of the Jackson Hole Group, seems somewhat taken aback at what has become of his alliance. "I think there are large implementation risks," Mr. Enthoven said of the Clinton plan. "It just seems to me to be this huge leap into the unknown to say right away that everyone's got to be in this thing."

The Buyers
Chart: "How Alliances Would Work"
 Employers and employees each pay a share of the cost of purchasing health insurance, and the Government contributes for low-income people.
 
The Alliances
 The middlemen that collect the premiums and pass them on to health plans. The alliances also have many broad responsibilities: They manage the system of subsidies for poor people and low-wage businesses. They make sure that health plans stay within the limits of a federally-set premium cap. They take complaints from consumers and issue report cards each year grading the various participating plans. They conduct an annual enrollment period to let people decide which plan they want for the coming year. They also negotiate rates with doctors who choose to stay outside of health maintenance organizations and practice traditional fee-for-service medicine.
 
The Plans
 Health plans would compete for business. A variety of plans would be available: health maintenance organizations, fee-for-service plans or some mixture of the two. These plans could be organized by doctors, by insurance companies, by hospitals or a variety of other institutions. (pg. 38)

HEADLINE: Venezuela Votes Today, Cautioned by Clinton

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Buffeted by two military coup attempts, a presidential resignation and plummeting economic performance in the last two years, Venezuela's voters are to choose a new President on Sunday.
For the United States, political volatility in South America's oldest democracy is a matter of concern. Venezuela controls the largest oil reserves outside the Persian Gulf and is the United States' largest source of imported oil after Saudi Arabia. 
 President Clinton this week sent his top two advisers on Latin American affairs to Caracas, bearing clear messages of support for democracy.
"Any disruption in the democratic process would inevitably have an immediate and chilling impact on the full range of our bilateral relations," Mr. Clinton said in a letter to Venezuela's President, Ramon J. Velasquez, an elder statesman who is not running. "There would be no possibility of a normal relationship between the United States and a nondemocratic Venezuela."
On Thursday, as newspapers here carried reports of the latest coup conspiracy, a blunter warning came from one of the envoys, Alexander F. Watson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.
"Military regimes are an anachronism in this hemisphere, vestiges of a dark and discredited past," Mr. Watson told Venezuelan businessmen. He added that an expanded version of the North American Free Trade Agreement "does not include, and will not include, countries that don't have democratically elected governments."
On Friday, security officials said they had detained six officers who they suspect were plotting to sabotage the election.
Venezuela is dependent on oil for 80 percent of its exports. With oil prices at a three-year low, the country is experiencing its worst economic performance since 1989. This year, inflation rose to 47 percent, and the economy shrank by about 4 percent.
The presidential race is too close to call, but the two front-runners are Rafael Caldera, an aging populist who first ran for President when Harry Truman was in the White House, and Andres Velasquez, a state governor from the leftist Radical Cause party.
Polls give a slight edge to Mr. Caldera, who served as Venezuala's President in the early 1970's. He is running as an independent with the support of 16 small parties.
If elected, Mr. Caldera would start a five-year term in February at age 78. Although he has refused to debate his opponents, his program appears to call for reversing some of the moves toward a free market in recent years.
"The country's going through a very serious political and economic crisis, and it needs a very experienced man in the presidency," said Alvaro Celis, a business manager who was handing out Caldera leaflets at a subway station here. "Caldera enjoys excellent physical and intellectual health."
A different view came from Carlos Andres Perez, who steered Venezuela down a free-market course until he was forced to step down as President last May in a corruption scandal.
"Caldera has more or less created the expectation of a return to the past," Mr. Perez told El Diario, a Caracas newspaper, this week. "In reality, this is impossible. As much as he would like to try, he won't be able to do it without causing a catastrophe in Venezuela."
Mr. Velasquez, 40, is running a close second to Mr. Caldera in public opinion polls. A former steel worker and reform unionist, Mr. Velasquez is running on an anti-corruption platform.
"The man comes from the bottom, and he understands the problems of the poor," said Ritxi de Munarrain, a Radical Cause volunteer.
Whoever wins Sunday is expected to take office backed by the votes of fewer than 10 percent of Venezuela's 20 million people.
Not only will the vote be split among four major candidates, but the abstention rate is expected to be twice the level of the 18 percent of the 1988 election, when Mr. Perez was elected. Analysts said discontent with politicians and the complex paper ballot were likely to keep turnout down.

HEADLINE: TRIAL IN SINGAPORE TESTS PRESS CURBS

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 3

 BODY:
There was unexpected bad news for Singapore investors in the summer of 1992, when Government figures showed that economic growth was sluggish, at least by the standards of this booming Southeast Asian city-state.
A year later, the news may be far worse for the newspaper editors who dared to run an exclusive article citing the Government's numbers. Their exclusive may send them, and their sources, to prison. 
 In a trial that is testing the limits of press freedom in Southeast Asia's most prosperous nation, two editors from Singapore's leading financial newspaper, Business Times, are accused of violating the Official Secrets Act, a law so broadly worded that it bars the release of any information the Government deems confidential.
 
Quarterly Growth Estimate
 In this case, the published information strikes many Singaporeans as reasonably innocuous -- an early, inexact estimate of economic growth for the second quarter of 1992. But the leak was considered so damaging by the Government that it raided the newsroom of Business Times and spent hours rummaging through the computer files of reporters and editors.
If convicted, the two editors, Patrick Daniel and Kenneth James, and their co-defendants -- two securities analysts and a Government economist who are charged with taking part in the leak -- face up to two years in prison.
The case centers on an article that appeared in the English-language newspaper in late June 1992. It disclosed that early, unpublished Government figures showed that economic growth for the second quarter of last year was slower than the 5.1 percent growth of the first quarter, declining to 4.6 to 4.8 percent.
While that sort of growth would be cause for celebration in the United States and most of the rest of the world, it was a disappointment in Singapore, one of Asia's economic tigers and a place accustomed to nearly double-digit annual economic growth.
Although a number of reporters and editors expressed anger over the prosecutions, none would allow their names to be used, saying they feared retaliation from the Government.
 
'Nip It in the Bud'
 Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has said that if the Government allows the leak to Business Times to go unpunished, it could encourage more damaging leaks in the future.
"We thought, better nip it in the bud, get to the bottom of it if we can," he said. "You can't run a Government which is leaking all over the place. You can't sail a ship on the high seas if it is leaking all over the place."
While the Government has provided Singapore's 2.8 million people with a prosperity equaling that of several Western nations -- Singapore looks like nothing so much as an affluent, leafy California suburb -- it has chosen not to offer them Western-style freedom of speech or information.
What would be considered resourceful investigative reporting in the West is considered here to be a threat to the stability of the Government and the financial markets, and to the relative harmony of the city-state's multiracial society.
The Government has banned or restricted the distribution of several foreign publications for their coverage of Singapore, most recently, The Economist magazine, which was placed under a circulation cap earlier this year. Local news organizations are not known for their aggressive reporting on the Government.
The defendants -- Tharman Shanmugaratnam, the Government economist, and the two securities analysts, Manu Bhaskaran and Raymond Foo Jong Chen of the firm Crosby Securities, and the two editors -- have all pleaded not guilty.
 
Editors Deny Violating Law
 The editors have insisted that they did not know they were violating the Official Secrets Act by publishing the growth estimate.
Mr. Daniel, the editor of Business Times, has said that while he knew that the estimate was official, he did not know that it was a violation of the law to publish the information, since it had come to the paper indirectly, through private sources. Mr. James, the technology editor, has said through his lawyer that he was never told the estimate was an official figure.
At the trial, prosecutors have attempted to prove that Business Times obtained the quarterly economic results from the securities analysts, and that they in turn received the information from the Government economist.

HEADLINE: Once Again, President Finds Time to Visit a Troubled State

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANOGA PARK, Calif., Dec. 4

 BODY:
If Bill Clinton hadn't paid a sick call on California this month, it would have been an exception.
The workaholic President has found time for only three weekends at Camp David and five visits back home to Arkansas. But the trip this weekend to California, a continent away, is his eighth since taking office. 
 With television cameras whirring, Mr. Clinton spent well over three hours this morning with California's United States Senators, the Mayor of Los Angeles and other leaders discussing the state's enfeebled economy and what might be done to nurse it to health. From the floor of an aerospace factory here, he later offered soothing words to an audience composed largely of workers made vulnerable by cuts in military and space spending.
 
Pledging Prosperity
 The setting was a Rockwell International plant that will receive new Federal grants intended to ease the pain from cuts in Pentagon spending, making it an example of Mr. Clinton's pledge to do everything he can to bring back prosperity in California.
Aides made little mystery of Mr. Clinton's motivation: if California does not recover from its recession, they say, the results could prove debilitating to his re-election chances.
With 54 electoral votes, California holds one-fifth of what is necessary to reach the White House. Mr. Clinton claimed that prize last year in a three-man race, but he did so with only 44 percent of the state's votes. And with rising bitterness over 300,000 jobs lost in the state because of Pentagon cuts, the prospect of recapturing that prize is ever more unlikely.
Mr. Clinton's visit was preceded by some good news for the state: its unemployment rate plunged last month from 9.8 percent to 8.6 percent. But that is still more than two percentage points above the national average, and the President was hardly gloating.
Nonetheless, the President was warmly received by the politicians, scholars and business executives who took part in the discussion here at Rockwell's Rocketdyne plant in the San Fernando Valley, which builds engines for the space shuttles.
But the President also heard pleas from Senators Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer, who urged him to give special consideration to California by limiting future Pentagon cuts, rethinking plans to close military bases, and providing at least $100 million in small-business loans that Senator Feinstein said could help create 400,000 jobs.
Today, Mr. Clinton announced that Los Angeles would receive a $46.2 million Federal grant to improve its public housing, and the White House noted that the city would become the largest recipient of such beneficence.
The President responded sympathetically to virtually every proposal, including an appeal to end a prohibition on the sale of communications satellites to China. A Hughes Corporation executive said that step would mean thousands of jobs for his company and the state.
The President suggested that the State Department's opposition to such sales was based on its preference "in all close questions" against relaxing restrictions on sensitive exports and suggested that he was considering a Commerce Department recommendation to make way for such sales.
If the state's economy was one motivation for Mr. Clinton's trip, another had to do with prosperity in a much more direct way. The President was expected to raise more than $2 million for the Democratic Party at two fund-raising events today, much of it from the movie stars and executives who were to be the main guests.
Mr. Clinton has asked Congress to tighten campaign finance laws in a way that would prohibit unlimited donations to political parties, and he has put some distance between himself and Hollywood since last spring, when critics began to suggest that he had become rather star-struck.
But the lure of the entertainment industry wealth and its loyalty to the Democratic Party apparently proved irresistible to Mr. Clinton, who agreed to attend an evening reception at the Creative Artists Agency and then to have dinner at the Beverly Hills house of Marvin Davis, the oil and real estate billionaire. Guests like Steven Spielberg, Barbra Streisand and David Geffen paid anywhere from $25,000 to $100,000 a couple for the privilege of dining with the President.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Clinton Chides Hollywood
 LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Clinton gently admonished Hollywood tonight about the dangers of violence in entertainment and called on the industry to be more conscious of its influence in American society.
Mr. Clinton said repeatedly that he was not asking Hollywood to do away with violence. But he urged actors, filmmakers and executives to do more to provide positive role models for young people.
"There are few things more powerful in any time or place than culture," the President said at the first of two star-studded receptions at which he was to raise $2 million from the entertainment industry for the Democratic Party. "The ability of culture to elevate or debase is really profound."
Mr. Clinton's comments were not as blunt as those made six weeks ago by Attorney General Janet Reno, who warned that the Government would intervene unless the television industry curbed violent programming. But they served notice that the President intended to include the entertainment industry in his call for Americans to take greater responsibility for behavior that may contribute to crime and violence.

HEADLINE: U.S. SEES PROBLEMS IN NUCLEAR OFFER

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
North Korea's new offer to allow greater access to its nuclear sites restricts international inspectors at the two most critical installations, leaving the Clinton Administration divided over how to respond, Administration officials said today.
The Administration has scheduled a Cabinet-level "principals" meeting for Monday to try to fashion a response, officials said. 
 After careful examination of the North Korean offer, American specialists today disclosed details of the plan, saying it contained serious deficiencies.
In particular, they said, the North Koreans have not agreed that international monitors could inspect the two most sensitive installations at Yongbyon: their nuclear reactor and their nuclear reprocessing plant, which can be used to separate plutonium for a nuclear bomb.
 
South Korea Criticizes Plan
 In another sign that the issue is far from solved, South Korea today publicly criticized the plan as inadequate.
"The North Korean reply looks insufficient but is something we need to examine," said Han Sung Joo, South Korea's Minister of Foreign Affairs.
As Clinton Administration officials debated the proposal, President Clinton stuck to broad themes about his effort to persuade Pyongyang to abandon its nuclear program.
"We tried to be very firm but also hold out the hand of possible cooperation," Clinton said in interviews with radio stations in Denver and Albuquerque. "They need to come join the rest of us. They need to reconcile with the South, and I want to help them."
But his Administration now faces a critical decision: whether to reject the proposal as inadequate, make a counterproposal or accept much of it as the best Washington can do in a crisis that has raised fears of a renewed conflict on the Korean peninsula.
The North Korean offer was presented on Friday in a meeting in New York with Tom Hubbard, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State.
 
Proposal Is Outlined
 Administration spokesmen declined to discuss the confidential plan, but officials familiar with it say it would work as follows:
*The International Atomic Energy Agency would have unlimited access to five of seven officially disclosed nuclear installations. But these are relatively minor sites.
*The agency would not be allowed to inspect the nuclear reactor or reprocessing plant, but it would be allowed to replace the film and batteries in cameras there. The agency in the past has rejected that as insufficient.
*North Korea said it was willing to negotiate with the agency over greater access to the reactor and reprocessing sites but did not offer anything specific.
In putting forth their offer, the North Koreans not only set limits on the access of inspectors but also specified a series of diplomatic steps to be taken by the United States, South Korea, North Korea and the atomic energy agency. The details of this formula also concern Administration officials.
 
Two Announcements
 The diplomatic process outlined by North Korea is choreographed precisely.
The arrival of international inspectors at installations is linked with two announcements. The United States and South Korea are to announce jointly the cancellation of the Team Spirit military exercise, which is a rehearsal of American efforts to reinforce the defense of South Korea.
Meanwhile, the United States and North Korea are to set a day jointly for a new round of high-level discussions of broader economic and diplomatic relations, including the possibility of diplomatic recognition of Pyongyang.
After these announcements, North Korea will take steps to exchange envoys with South Korea. But it is not clear when and if that would take place since the countries already have been discussing the issue for months.
Additionally, the North Korean plan says that productive "working level" talks with South Korea can occur only as long as Seoul shows its "sincere" attitude by canceling what North Korea calls nuclear war exercises. This appears to be a reference to several military exercises that are carried out in addition to Team Spirit to maintain the readiness of American and South Korean forces.
 
Stop 'International Pressure'
 Another condition is that Seoul stop "international pressure efforts." The proposal does not say exactly what this means. One interpretation is that it is a demand that other countries drop threats to impose economic sanctions on North Korea if does not abandon its nuclear program.
American experts say that on the positive side, the proposal covers all seven of North Korea's officially disclosed nuclear sites and holds out the possibility that North Korea will negotiate access for inspectors to its most critical ones.
But the drawback is that it is highly unlikely that the atomic energy agency can accept restricted access to North Korea's most critical nuclear sites. The North Korean discussion of the exchange of envoys with South Korea is also extremely vague, American officials said. The United States has insisted that North Korea agree to the exchange of envoys with South Korea as a condition for holding higher-level talks.

HEADLINE: Angola and Rebels Agree to Terms for Cease-Fire

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Angolan Government and the rebel Unita movement formally adopted terms today for a cease-fire in fighting that was renewed after the forces of Jonas Savimbi rejected his group's defeat in last year's elections, diplomats here said.
The diplomats said the terms had been adopted at talks attended by all negotiators from the Government and the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. But no date for the cease-fire was announced. 
 "At a plenary session this morning, the two delegations and Alioune Blondin Beye formally adopted the cease-fire," one diplomat said, referring to the United Nations special envoy. "There is no going back on this now."
Another said: "They agreed all points on the cease-fire and then went on to discuss modalities on formation of a new army. When they reconvene next Monday they will discuss a few military aspects but mostly political issues."
Only one issue, how and when to disarm the Unita guerrillas, had previously stood in the way of a cease-fire to halt the 18-year Angolan conflict, in which Unita forces had recently seized control of about two-thirds of the country. All the other details of the cease-fire had already been agreed upon by Thursday at the talks, which opened in Zambia's capital on Nov. 15.
 
Disarmament Issue Resolved
 The diplomats said the negotiators had resolved the issue of Unita's disarmament by agreeing that rebel forces be allowed to hand over their weapons to an armory controlled by the United Nations shortly after arriving in designated barracks.
Rebel forces would also stay a "very short time" in the barracks to allow for a quick selection of those who would join government troops in forming a new national army, which is to be composed of equal numbers of soldiers from both sides, the diplomats said.
After today's talks, Angolan Government negotiators flew home for high-level consultations centering on political demands by Unita, which are to be debated next week.
"They will seek guidance on various political matters and then be back here by Monday morning in time for a session planned for the afternoon that day," said a person close to the negotiators
Mr. Beye, who has imposed a news blackout on the talks, was also flying to Angola's capital, Luanda, apparently to talk to visiting United States congressmen. "It's obvious Beye will use this occasion to also talk to the Angolan Government," one source said.
A Unita official said that among his movement's political demands were that it be given important posts in such areas as the Ministry of Defense or Interior, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or Information and the Ministry of Finance or Economic Planning.
 
Decentralized Power Sought
 Unita also wants the Government to decentralize power, giving elected regional leaders power to control budgets and the formation of national and regional police, the official said. The group also wants a revamping of the state-run news media, guarantees of protection for its leaders and a government house for Mr. Savimbi.
Another demand, the Unita official said, is that President Eduardo dos Santos of Angola, who defeated Mr. Savimbi in the presidential election last year but did not achieve a clear majority, would have to be Acting President pending new elections.
The elections in September 1992, which were won by the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, were described as free and fair by international observers.
 
1991 Peace Agreement
 The elections were made possible by a May 1991 peace agreement between the Government and Unita that ended 16 years of civil war, which began after independence from Portugal in 1975.
"We have given in to many military demands of the government at this peace conference," the official said. "It's now up to the government to make significant concessions and show that it wants and means peace."

HEADLINE: Compromises Edge GATT Nearer New Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Efforts to strike a free trade pact among 116 countries have dragged on for seven years for a simple reason: A deal would hurt many politically powerful industries in many countries.
American steelmakers worry that the Commerce Department would not be able to slap steep taxes on low-priced foreign steel. Insurance companies in Southeast Asia worry that they will go broke if American insurers are allowed into their markets. French grain farmers worry that crop prices will fall there if their Government pays them less to export their harvests than if they sell them in France. 
 Most of the trade conflicts between industries are settled by deals that give both sides some of what they want. But the current talks are so broad and complicated that many recent compromises have satisfied no one.
Pharmaceutical manufacturers in India, for instance, are concerned that they will be bankrupted by the requirements that they pay to use Western patents. American pharmaceutical makers have been pushing the Clinton Administration to reopen the compromise because the requirements will not take full effect for 20 years.
 
A New Momentum
 Yet a compromise on many issues seems probable on Monday between the United States and the European Community. The likelihood of a global deal by Dec. 15 is also growing. The new momentum partly reflects the exasperation of many countries over the length of the talks. It also reflects the willingness of the Clinton Administration to accept a slightly less ambitious deal than the Bush Administration had demanded.
No Republican President since Dwight D. Eisenhower has concluded a global trade agreement. Less encumbered by free-trade ideology, Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Jimmy Carter clinched the last two global pacts by excluding difficult agricultural issues and striking modest compromises on other issues.
The Clinton Administration is following the same course. American trade and agricultural officials agreed with European officials on Thursday to pursue less sweeping changes in farm trade policies than previously planned. The United States is also seeking to take taxation issues out of the talks and reduce the number of new limits on countries' trade laws. If all these and the other changes sought by the Clinton Administration are made, the trade pact will still rewrite the rules of international commerce, but not quite as extensively as the Bush Administration had planned.
 
A Broader Pact
 The talks are intended to broaden a 45-year-old pact, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. The GATT sets trade rules for international commerce in manufactured goods like cars and television sets. Seven rounds of GATT negotiations since 1948 have reduced the average tariffs on manufactured goods to 5 percent from 40 percent. Tariffs are taxes on goods bought from other countries.
Seven years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, most of the world's trading countries began the Uruguay Round of talks. The current draft text for the Uruguay Round would reduce the world's remaining manufacturing tariffs by a third, and eliminate many countries' limits on the number of sweaters, coats and other clothing they import each year.
The draft would also apply GATT rules for the first time to agriculture and services like banking and consulting. Governments would have to eliminate the tonnage limits on food imports and reduce their special payments to farmers, which cost $300 billion a year for industrialized countries. They would also have to remove many bans on foreign service companies and protect foreign copyrights, patents and trademarks.
 
Promoting Global Growth
 Most academic economists said they liked the idea of a 116-country free-trade deal as a way to promote global economic growth. Trade allows each country to specialize in the goods and services that it makes most efficiently, and exchange them for other goods and services made more efficiently elsewhere. The result, in theory, is a more efficient world economy.
No one knows what the Uruguay Round's effects will be on the average consumer or the world economy. Most of the effects would be gradual. The limits on clothing imports, for example, would be phased out over 10 years. The Clinton Administration is trying to extend this to 15 years as part of a deal it made last month to win support in Congress for the North American Free Trade Agreement. Even then, the limits would be replaced by tariffs, which would be gradually reduced.
Yet many economists said they believed the economic effects of a free-trade pact would be large. The GATT secretariat in Geneva estimated on Friday that the elimination of tariffs and tonnage limits on food imports would result in a $230 billion increase in world economic output by 2005.
 
Ambitious Numbers
 A study released in January by the Bush White House had much more ambitious figures. The study estimated that the international adoption of the Uruguay Round draft text would increase the size of the American economy alone by $219 billion by 2000.
The numbers are much larger because the study tried to estimate the indirect effects of a global trade deal. For instance, greater protection abroad of American copyrights on computer programs would mean a larger market for American companies. This would prompt these companies to invest more money and develop more programs, increasing the size of the economy, the Bush Administration officials said.
But many American industries and labor unions are worried that the United States is giving up too much in the trade talks.
The text calls for many restrictions on laws that the United States has used to impose steep tariffs on imports that foreign companies sell here below cost or with financial help from foreign governments. Many economists said they disliked the tariffs because they meant American consumers paid more for these products. More countries are adopting the laws and imposing tariffs on American products.
But many American companies, including those in the steel, automobile and computer-chip industries, want to keep the laws. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, is seeking changes to the text to preserve these laws.
 
Controversial Farm Payments
 An even bigger dispute appears to have been resolved this week. It involves Government payments intended to increase farm exports. These payments have been especially controversial because they depress prices in foreign markets.
The European Community and the United States agreed a year ago to reduce all farm subsidies. The agreement required the community and the United States to cut the tonnage of their subsidized farm exports immediately to the average level from 1986 to 1991, and then reduce this by another 21 percent over six years. The agreement is known as the Blair House accord, after the White House guest quarters in which it was negotiated.
But France rejected the Blair House accord. French farmers are especially influential because two-thirds of French city-dwellers have a parent or grandparent who grew up in the countryside. American and community officials agreed on Thursday that the tonnage reduction to the average level in the late 1980's could also be spread over six years.
For example, subsidized European wheat exports last year were 3.4 million metric tons higher than the average level. Instead of cutting shipments by 3.4 million tons in 1995, this reduction will be divided into six annual cuts totaling 3.4 million tons.
Trade negotiators are racing to finish a deal now because of a deadline set by Congress early last summer. The House and Senate passed a so-called fast-track law then. The law says that any deal struck by Dec. 15 can be put to an up-or-down vote in each chamber with no amendments allowed.

HEADLINE: For Christopher, New View of Mideast Peace Role

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Dec. 4

 BODY:
After nearly a year as Secretary of State, Warren Christopher has begun to see himself as a Middle East peacemaker.
Ask him in public about his expectations for a comprehensive peace in the region, and he is certain to give an intensely guarded answer. His remarks to reporters in Brussels on Thursday about his current eight-day trip were typical: "I would urge that expectations be lowered about what can be accomplished over just a few days' period." 
 But in private, seated with his aides in the back of his limousine, he is apt to rattle off a checklist of things that need to be done, measuring his success in tiny bits of progress he has made. In recent weeks he has even allowed himself to construct a tentative timetable and muse about an endgame for an overall peace settlement, his aides say.
 
'Time and Patience'
 It is not that Mr. Christopher has suddenly transformed himself from the cautious lawyer who once painstakingly negotiated an international cotton textile agreement for the Kennedy Administration into a larger-than-life visionary. Mr. Christopher has often said that he is not a man of grand gestures or dramatic flourishes, and a senior aide said that even his message to his senior Middle East advisers today in a planning meeting was modest and simple. "This is going to take a lot of time and patience," he said.
But with the breakthrough of September's Israeli-P.L.O. accord, Mr. Christopher has moved away from the listening mode he said he was in last February, when he came to the Middle East for the first time as Secretary of State, and has begun to focus on specific areas where the United States can seize opportunities.
Part of his investment of diplomatic capital in the Middle East stems from a belief that Washington "is the only honest broker with clout," as one of his aides said.
On another level, the frustrations of the Clinton Administration policy in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti have prompted Mr. Christopher to redefine and repackage America's foreign policy priorities by training the spotlight on places like the Middle East where Mr. Christopher may have more of a chance for success.
 
Four Goals for Trip
 As part of his strategy for the Middle East, Mr. Christopher has set himself four precise goals for a trip that is taking him to Israel, Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Tunisia and Morocco, senior Administration officials said.
First, he will try to find specific ways to help carry out the Israeli-Palestinian agreement.
In recent days the Palestinians have declared their negotiations deadlocked and appealed for Washington's "urgent intervention" in resolving the critical remaining issues in their self-rule agreement. Certainly, the fact that Dennis Ross, the Administration's special coordinator on the Middle East, now talks two to three times a week on the telephone with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and that Mr. Christopher himself will hold meetings with Mr. Arafat in Tunis and Amman this week highlights the dramatic changes that have transformed the political landscape in less than three months.
But Mr. Christopher is likely to limit his involvement to suggestions about issues like what the Palestinians should do to meet World Bank requirements rather than intrude into thorny internal security issues, like what the boundaries of Jericho should be, that are supposed to be resolved in the next nine days.
 
A Reluctance to Intervene
 "I don't know that there is an appropriate role for me," Mr. Christopher told reporters before leaving for dinner with Israel's Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. "If I was asked by both parties to do something, I certainly would. But I certainly don't want to interpose myself in any way."
The second goal Mr. Christopher will pursue will be to help make the Middle East a more friendly neighborhood for Israel by urging the Arabs to support repeal of anti-Israeli resolutions at the United Nations, to reconsider their recent decision to maintain the economic boycott of Israel and to meet with Israeli officials. The main reason Mr. Christopher will visit Morocco, his aides say, is to show appreciation for King Hassan's efforts to reward Israel for its accord with the Palestinians.
Mr. Christopher's third goal is to build on progress in the talks between Jordan and Israel. Last Wednesday Jordan and Israel initialed an agreement in Washington that allows Jordan to reopen banks in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, and Mr. Christopher will explore ways to move forward on trade, development and water issues.
Despite wide-ranging predictions among officials in Jerusalem about Jordan's willingness to make a separate peace with Israel, the United States has no illusions that King Hussein is on the verge of signing an accord without a comprehensive peace that includes Damascus.
 
Visit to Syrian Capital
 The fourth and most important goal -- and the most difficult -- will come in Damascus, where Mr. Christopher will meet with President Hafez al-Assad on Sunday and again on Thursday.
While the Israeli-P.L.O. accord is a crucial step toward peace, American strategic interests are locked into acheiving an Israeli-Syrian peace, which would help isolate Iran, a Syrian ally.
Mr. Christopher has a double task on his agenda: to convince Mr. Assad that the United States has no intention of abandoning him, or of leaving him alone to scuttle the Palestinian peace with Israel.
