HEADLINE: Israel Restoring Drained Wetland, Reversing Pioneers' Feat

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HULATA, Israel, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Rumbling across a desolate landscape of dark brown earth, a fleet of bulldozers has been working to reverse part of what was long considered one of the major feats of Zionist pioneering: the draining of the Hula swamplands in the Galilee region of northern Israel.
Churning up clouds of peat dust, the bulldozers have been scooping out earth for a lake that will be the core of a planned area of 1,500 acres of restored wetlands at the heart of the Hula Valley. 
 The $25 million enterprise, one of the biggest environmental projects ever undertaken in Israel, reflects a basic shift of priorities. Ambitious projects that altered nature to expand agricultural settlement -- the stuff of Zionist lore -- have given way to a new awareness of the environment and a realization that farming alone cannot form the backbone of the Israeli economy.
The drying of the Hula lake and marsh in the 1950's freed some 15,000 acres of land for cultivation. But it also left behind a tangle of ecological problems so serious that planners are now preparing to reflood this area at the center of the drained basin.
 
Now Unfit for Farming
 Dried peat soil from the bottom of the marsh has decomposed, burned and released pollutants that once were filtered by the swamp, leaving a wasteland unfit for farming.
Draining the Hula, north of the Sea of Galilee, was a powerfully symbolic national enterprise, celebrated with patriotic fervor much as the space program was in the United States. It was expected to reclaim expanses of peat soil under the marsh that were considered to be both highly fertile and a source of fuel.
Millions of gallons of swamp water previously lost through evaporation were to be channeled in canals to the Sea of Galilee, the national reservoir. And eliminating the marsh, officials said, would destroy a breeding ground of malaria-carrying mosquitoes.
Between 1951 and 1958, a network of canals was dug to drain the lake and swamp. According to press reports at the time, Agriculture Minister Kadish Luz declared, "Land had been redeemed from hostile nature, and water that had been a menace to health turned into a blessing."
 
Peat Was a Problem
 Although thousands of acres were brought under cultivation by neighboring settlements, problems emerged in large tracts of land with high concentrations of peat soil.
The dry peat disintegrated, sank and burned in underground fires caused by spontaneous combustion. The fertility of the soil declined sharply, and it released nitrate pollutants that were washed by rains into the Sea of Galilee. As farmers stopped cultivating large areas, the land was overrun by mice and weeds, and peat dust whipped up by winds covered the region.
The desolation contrasted sharply with the teeming animal and plant life that had filled the Hula marsh, situated at a meeting point of tropical and temperate climate zones. Several species unique to the swamp became extinct when it was drained, and even though a 750-acre nature reserve was set aside to recreate the lost wetlands, their rich diversity largely vanished.
When the draining project began, destruction of this everglade environment was not deemed too high a price. There was little ecological awareness in the 1950's, and those experts who warned of problems were overruled by the planners.
 
Need for Land and Jobs
 Also, with waves of new immigrants arriving in Israel's early years, the Hula project filled a pressing need for jobs and for agricultural land that could support farming settlements.
"It was clear that agriculture and settlement were top priority, and it was considered obvious that swamps should be drained," said Amotz Zahavi, an Israeli conservationist who had lobbied for preservation of some of the marsh. "No one imagined that you could say no to drying the Hula."
Azaria Alon, another conservationist, recalled: "The draining was deeply troubling to nature advocates, but it was difficult to talk about it, because anyone who spoke out was considered anti-Zionist. This was seen as a tremendous achievement, celebrated in writing and song."
"But it wasn't thought through, and the result was ecological destruction," Mr. Alon said. "I'm against such policies that enthusiastically promote all kinds of big projects that change the face of the land without a comprehensive assessment of their environmental impact."
Officials of the Jewish National Fund, a land reclamation and development agency that first drained the Hula and is now reflooding part of it, insist that the original project was not a failure, arguing that it provided a livelihood for farming settlements.
 
No 'Mistake' or 'Regret'
 "We're not saying that it was a mistake and that we regret it," said Moshe Rivlin, the fund's chairman. "The new project is a response to the problems that emerged."
Shimon Amar, a 63-year-old worker who had helped drain the Hula swamp and is now taking part in the reflooding project, said he saw no contradiction between his labors today and 40 years ago. "Potatoes, melons and cucumbers were grown on this land, but there are also neglected areas that produce nothing, and they should be saved," he said. "Now they'll be turned into something completely different, a tourist attraction. It will be beautiful."
The reflooding plan calls for the creation of a wetland wildlife park that will include a lake and islands surrounded by marshes and boating canals for visitors. The water used to reflood the area is expected to raise the depleted water table under adjacent farmland, helping improve yields in about 5,000 acres of peat soil.
The 1.3 billion gallons of water needed for the project will be drawn from the Jordan River, which used to flow through the Hula marsh but was diverted when the swamp was drained. The river's meandering course will be restored as part of the reflooding plan.
The project is scheduled to take three to five years, and is being managed jointly by the National Fund, the Ministry of Agriculture and the Israel Lands Administration. If it succeeds, planners say, another area of similar size may be flooded.
Giora Shaham, the project director, said a balance must be struck among the competing interests of environmentalists, farmers and tourism promoters from neighboring settlements who want to make money for their hard-pressed communities.
 
What Kind of Animals?
 The tourism developers want activities that draw visitors, like boating, hiking and jeep tours. They would build guest accommodations and stock the area with a wide variety of animals, including some not native to the Hula region.
Environmentalists say the area should be managed as a wildlife refuge where only animals that once lived in the wetlands, like water buffalo deer and wild boar, will be reintroduced to restore the original marsh habitat. Visitors would be limited. As for farmers, they want to reduce the areas to be flooded, and to devote more resources to improving agricultural yields.
The lessons learned from the Hula draining, Mr. Shaham said, were part of a process of trial and error that would continue as the reflooding project is monitored in the coming years.
"This is a corrective plan which will have to be tested as it is carried out," Mr. Shaham said. "More corrections may be needed in the future. We are not perfect. We are not God."

HEADLINE: Gunman Robs Riders in Van, Killing Driver

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
A man driving an illegal livery van on a Brooklyn street was shot to death on Friday night in front of four other passengers in what the police said was the first shooting involving the unlicensed vans, which have proliferated on city streets in recent years.
The shooting of the driver, Frank James, 45, comes as the police struggle to stop a seemingly unending series of killings of cabdrivers. But unlike the 41 cabby killings this year, the shooting Friday night happened in front of several passengers who were also held up by the gunman. 
 A police spokesman, Sgt. Anthony Barlanti, said the gunman got into Mr. James's Ford Econoline van at Avenue P off Flatbush Avenue, pulled a gun and told the passengers to put their heads down. As the van drove south on Flatbush Avenue, the gunman ordered the driver to turn off the main road to East 26th Street, where he robbed the passengers. He hit one with the butt of the gun and then shot the driver in the head, Sergeant Barlanti said.
The sergeant said there was no apparent motive for the shooting and no indication that the driver had put up a struggle. Two passengers fled on foot as the others ran to a nearby home and called the police. The gunman was still at large.
 
Immigrant's Part-Time Job
 Mr. James's vehicle was one of the hundreds of illegal vans that offer commuters low-cost rides, often from subway stops to residential areas.
Like many of the slain cabbies, Mr. James was an immigrant, having come from Guyana 14 years ago. He worked as a pest-control worker at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, and drove the van part time to earn extra money, Sergeant Barlanti said.
A father of two children, Mr. James had recently moved with his family from Flatbush to the second floor of a two-story brick building along a residential street in Cypress Hills.
"They were just a normal family with two kids and now they don't have a father," said Lystra Gaddy, 35, a next-door neighbor of the family. "It's very sad."
Michelle Casimir, a neighbor, said she was watching television when Mr. James's wife, Kathleen, 26, came running down to her apartment after hearing that her husband had been shot. "She was crying and sobbing," Ms. Casimir said.
At the house where the robbery victims fled after the shooting, a resident said that the passengers came to her door knocking and screaming for her to call the police.
"At first I thought it was a prank," she said. "As soon as I saw the blood I told my husband to go open the door."
Although the police said Mr. James was apparently the first unlicensed van driver to be killed, it was not the first time passengers have been held up. One morning last July, three young men, two of them armed with guns, held up a city bus, terrorizing and robbing 22 passengers. Although the bandits fired some shots into the roof of the bus, there were no serious injuries and the thieves escaped with $300 in cash and jewelry.
 
A Popular Service
 The illegal vans first appeared in the Bronx in the early 1970's and quickly spread to Brooklyn and Queens, providing something the official transit system largely did not: fast service into Manhattan or between outlying areas and subway stops.
The vans, many with frosted glass and comfortable seats, have become so popular along some city bus routes that the Transit Authority estimates that it loses about $30 million a year, or 7 percent of revenues because of the vans.
The loss of riders has caused the Transit Authority to drastically reduce service along six heavily affected routes in Brooklyn and Queens. And the service cuts, in turn, have prompted still more people to turn to the vans.
Despite the popularity of the unlicensed vans, Friday's incident underscores the risk that passengers face when they ride the unregulated vehicles.
Haji Shasique, a shopkeeper at K & A Grocery on Flatbush Avenue, near where the shooting occurred, said that about three months ago, a woman was robbed nearby at gunpoint by a group of teenagers on one of the vans. Mr. Shasique said the youths jumped off the van as it pulled to a corner.
"Nobody is safe on the bus or in the van," he said. "But at least the bus has insurance and the van has no insurance."
 
'Anything Can Happen'
 Josephine Saunders, a resident of Crown Heights, said she does not ride the unlicensed vans.
"You don't know the driver and anything can happen," Ms. Saunders said. "Even if you take the bus and get robbed on the bus it's better."
Yesterday, at the corner of Flatbush and Foster Avenues, more than a dozen vans full of passengers drove by in less than 10 minutes.
" I know it's very dangerous, but the bus has many problems," Sandra Desir, a native of Haiti, said as she got off a van. "The van is faster."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Giuliani Suggests Style Will Be Close to the Vest

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
When Rudolph W. Giuliani assumes office next month, he will be an anomaly, the first New York mayor in modern politics who has not held a previous elective post. And so whatever his governing style will be, it will have to be worked out in the crucible of one of the nation's most visible, high-pressure offices.
The first few weeks of Mr. Giuliani's transition offered few clues about how he will govern, beyond his awareness that he had to begin healing the city after a racially polarized vote. 
 But in the last week, as he made his first two high-level appointments, he began showing a few signs that as mayor he may govern with the deliberative close-to-the-vest approach of the prosecutor he once was, and less of the instinctive politician's flair for using the bully pulpit.
One telling moment came Thursday. Mr. Giuliani stood side by side at a news conference with his newly named Police Commissioner, vowing to take back the streets, when the specter of the city's financial problems made an unwelcome intrusion into the occasion.
 
Politically Unpalatable Menu
 The Mayor-elect was asked what he thought of a long-awaited report that echoed at least one theme of his campaign: that the city faced long-term fiscal problems more severe than Mr. Dinkins's advisers had advertised. It outlined a "menu" of politically unpalatable solutions including millions of dollars in taxes, fees, layoffs and efficiencies.
But in the same disdainful tone with which he criticized the Dinkins administration during the campaign, Mr. Giuliani dismissed the report as "old thinking" reminiscent of "the prior administration." Then he turned his attention back to his virtuoso campaign issue: crime.
The moment could have been an example of the political maxim that a leader sends one message at a time. But when Mr. Giuliani condemned the report again on Friday, saying "it has no application of a philosophy of stimulating the economy of New York City," even some of the people close to his transition effort viewed his response as a missed political opportunity to begin preparing New Yorkers for the difficult choices ahead.
 
No Debate Until Ready
 But privately, Mr. Giuliani's advisers said he dismissed the report because he had no intention of engaging in the budget debate before he was ready. One of them said Mr. Giuliani and his senior staff members were concerned that if he embraced some of the report's suggestions of layoffs and more efficient government, he would have to answer why he was rejecting its companion recommendations for fee increases, tolls and property and sales tax increases. And others said he was loath to speak until he had found a budget director and had a budget plan.
"Wait until we get our people, our personnel in place," said Richard Bryers, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani. "Then you'll see a different approach laid out."
Each mayor or governor brings a new style to office. Some figures, like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, muse aloud about their decision-making. Some, like former Mayor Edward I. Koch, shoot off ideas, opinions, insults and mischief like Fourth of July sparklers. At two news conferences last week, Mr. Giuliani made clear that so far at least, he plays close to the vest.
 
Corruption? 'Against It'
 He repeatedly used humor to sidestep questions about the governing initiatives ahead. When his choice for police commissioner, William J. Bratton, was asked how he would combat the lingering problem of police corruption that has dogged the force, Mr. Giuliani interrupted and quipped, "he's against it," deflecting the question.
When Mr. Giuliani named Ninfa Segarra, a Board of Education member, as a deputy mayor, he made several jokes again before finally answering the question about which salary she would take while holding down two posts. She would, he eventually made clear, take the $112,000 deputy mayor's salary and drop the $15,000 Board of Education stipend. And even as he said he would "substantially" reduce the number of deputy mayors -- currently six -- he gave no further hints of which posts would be eliminated.
His style is reinforced by those around him. Despite the creation of a highly visible transition council, Mr. Giuliani's true inner circle is shaping up to be largely lawyers and former assistant Federal attorneys, who can act as if they are empaneling a grand jury, not a municipal government.
While Mr. Giuliani has not yet formally named any deputy mayors or personal advisers beyond Ms. Segarra, it is becoming clear who will be around him. When Mr. Giuliani had the final meeting with Mr. Bratton before offering him the job, the small group in the session with him were Peter J. Powers, a tax lawyer who is the transition chairman; three former assistant United States attorneys, Howard Wilson, Randy M. Mastro and Dennison Young Jr., and Richard Schwartz, a former Parks Department official under Mr. Koch and then Mr. Dinkins.
 
Checking Out the Furniture
 Minus Mr. Wilson, who was chairman of the search committee for police chief, much the same group of advisers was recently in City Hall looking over the offices, space and floor plans, said aides to Mr. Dinkins. This time the group also included Fran Reiter, the chairwoman of the State Liberal Party, and Richard M. Berman, a lawyer who once worked for Senator Jacob K. Javits.
Still, the secrecy surrounding the transition is such that while publicizing the existence of an ethics code, Mr. Giuliani's aides have declined to identify the people serving in what are potentially the most sensitive transition positions, reviewing the inner workings of city agencies for the Mayor-elect. Cristyne Lategano, a spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani, said that the volunteers would have to be alerted that their names would be released because some had not expected their names to be made public.
How quickly Mr. Giuliani will be in a better position to start detailing his plans -- particularly in the area of fiscal policy -- is not certain. Despite his early heady prediction that he would have a police commissioner, budget director, and finance chief by Thanksgiving, some of his advisers admit privately that it has been harder than expected to lure high-caliber executives from private business. Several of their first choices to be interviewed have turned them down.
But with his earliest selection of Mr. Bratton and Ms. Segarra, Mr. Giuliani signaled a few things about his administration: that he is not afraid of strong personalities or controversy, that he is taking pains to avoid taking his constituencies for granted, and that he repays political loyalty.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Son of Joe Hill: Quiet, Patient, Alive as Ever

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
THERE was a distant time when this was more of a union city and the working class had a legion of labor organizers, many of whom knew the lyrics to "Joe Hill," the leftist ballad of the ghostly union idealist who finally did expire, it seems, sometime after the 1960's. Nowadays the city seems to have a greater number of illiberal polemicists on union-dead newspapers than it does labor organizers. Which only makes more encouraging the arrival of Francisco Chang upon Gotham's fabric heart in the mid-Manhattan garment district.
He is a 28-year-old, Korean-born, Spanish-speaking sweatshop organizer in behalf of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and its new experimental strategy of shop-by-shop confidence building instead of confrontational, hit-the-bricks tactics of the past generations of Eastern European sweatshop workers. This means Mr. Chang, speaking in Korean to the newer owners and Spanish to the newer workers, tends to respond in quiet ombudsman fashion to the specific shop complaints about lost wages, denied overtime pay and missing fringe benefits that have long been the bane of each immigrant wave of sweatshop workers as they tend toward meekness in their new land. 
 Mr. Chang's job may sound like a desperate tactic in a desperate industry, half of whose 50,000 city workers are in nonunion sweatshops, according to the I.L.G.W.U. But on Dec. 18, Mr. Chang expects to celebrate with 350 loyalist workers the six-month anniversary of the union's new Garment Workers' Justice Center. The workers will not only attend, but also run the show and script a new union strategy for slowly enlisting workers shop by shop and complaint by complaint in 60 targeted factory buildings between Seventh and Ninth Avenues and 35th and 40th Streets.
This tight bull's-eye contains most of the 3,000 small, ever marginal, ever portable sweatshops of Francisco Chang's target group. This is the perpetual vineyard in the endless task of the I.L.G.W.U., which is grateful, even so, for the industry that remains in such a job-depressed city as this. "It's 1910 all over again," says Marty Berger, a career organizer for 35 years in the garment district, speaking with a certain envy of his young colleague's patience and optimism.
Mr. Chang discovered his knack for unionism when he held a tough job in a hat factory as a teen-age immigrant. He never heard of "The Pajama Game," the musical about organizing, but he looks as if he could sing the lead role with grand ebullience. "Look, 40 workers showed up last March after I distributed 10,000 pamphlets in the district, so I can say there is progress now with 350 coming for the celebration," he says. "Unions can't come on with a preset agenda and a lot of staff organizers these days," he says, speaking as the only staff member in the center, one who relies on 15 sweatshop workers for their after-hours union work.
"The key eventually is that we don't go to the workers, the workers come to us" as word of initial small successes in back-pay problems at a given shop is spread through word of mouth, explains Mr. Chang, who enlists aid from government labor law agencies at critical moments. When contacts and confidence grow from a track record at most of the shops, his committee will signal that, finally, it is time for him formally to organize a swath of shops.
Thus, his organizing art is not so simple as the lyrics of "Joe Hill." Some immigrant workers mistrust unionism because of experiences back home. Then, too, the industry is turning more to immigrant sweatshops in Miami and elsewhere, putting jobs here at greater risk.
Part of Francisco Chang's art is explaining the tricorner economics of the industry to its own workers, not immediately risking their livelihood on union cards. He teaches where the money goes as the big retailers put in orders with the 500 jobbers, or manufacturers, who then farm out the work to the 3,000 contractors whose workers he is trying to groom. When this is grasped by workers in a shop with a problem over minimum wages or overtime, they sense injustice and want to do something about it, he says, and increasingly turn to his center's worker volunteers and himself. Several successful job shutdowns, sit-ins, and even takeovers of freight elevators and sewing machines have occurred, he notes, some lasting weeks, and virtually all unnoticed in a city where private-sector unionism seems so moribund.
But there have always been I.L.G.W.U. successes, Mr. Chang says in his optimism, citing the union's organizing of sweatshops in Chinatown. This, of course, was followed by fresh sweatshops opening in Sunset Park in Brooklyn, site of a newer Chinatown. There, the I.L.G.W.U. has patiently opened a second justice center like Mr. Chang's. And a third is in Williamsburg, among Hispanic workers.
"This is just the beginning," says Francisco Chang, rather lyrically.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Ban on Wall Street Gifts Hurts McCall Campaign

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The October decision by Wall Street's leading bond underwriters to ban political contributions was widely hailed as a significant move toward cleaner government. But the timing could not have been worse for the new State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who is trying to bankroll what will clearly be an expensive campaign in 1994.
Mr. McCall, who wants to become the first black person to win statewide elective office in New York, estimates that the decision will cost him $2 million in campaign contributions. He based that on the amount that his predecessor, Edward V. Regan, typically received from the bond houses. 
 Mr. Regan resigned earlier this year in the middle of his term, and the State Legislature elected Mr. McCall, a New York City Democrat, to succeed him.
"Those are the people who normally provided the majority of the money for this office because they're the ones that have an interest," Mr. McCall said of the underwriters. "That's the money that's drying up."
The Wall Street firms typically gave tens of thousands of dollars to incumbents and other leading candidates for state and city comptroller because those officials are responsible for awarding the state's and city's highly lucrative bond business.
Mr. McCall said he will need a minimum of $3 million to run next year. The ban on contributions from underwriters has forced him to search elsewhere, and he has done most of his prospecting out of the state.
He has held fund-raisers in recent weeks in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington and Boston, and has scheduled other events for Atlanta and Chicago. His first New York event will be this week at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan.
Mr. McCall said he does not think the ban on contributions will significantly diminish the influence of money on politics.
"All these efforts will really miss the mark," he said. "What you need is public funding. The abuses were serious and something had to be done. But what was done doesn't make any sense because it doesn't solve the problem. We've still got to go out and raise large sums of money, and however we do it there will be questions."
 
Father Defers to Daughter
 Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island was undoubtedly being chivalrous last week when he said he would set aside his own decision whether to run for governor next year until his daughter, Representative Susan Molinari, decides whether she wants the job. It is even likelier that he was being smart.
As a young Republican woman, and an Italian-American Roman Catholic who supports the death penalty and abortion rights, Ms. Molinari could be a formidable contender, as she is telegenic and well-spoken, and, in a simpler age, might have been called "peppy." She would be the kind of statewide candidate who could strike fear -- or at least fright -- into the hearts of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Democrats.
Ms. Molinari, who was elected to her father's old seat in Congress after he gave it up to be Borough President in 1989, said she would spend the next few weeks exploring a possible candidacy by talking with Republican and Conservative Party leaders, friends and family. Among the considerations, she said, was whether she could win party support, raise enough money and be willing to give up her Congressional seat to run.
Ms. Molinari, who has become a bigger presence on the political talk show circuit and in Washington than most junior House members -- in part because she is a Republican, and a woman, and a supporter of abortion rights -- said she thought Mr. Cuomo would be politically vulnerable next year, because of New York's lackluster economy and fear of crime, among other things.
"It has been over 20 years of Democratic control of the Statehouse," Ms. Molinari said. "Has anybody's lives gotten better? Has there been any more fairness and safety for anybody in New York State?"
Mr. Molinari predicted, "You're going to see a tremendous amount of support coming her way."
 
Council Race Finally Decided
 One month after Election Day, the outcome of a City Council race on Manhattan's Upper East Side was finally decided last week. Andrew S. Eristoff, the Republican incumbent, was declared the winner over his Democratic challenger, Jane R. Crotty, by a margin of 135 votes out of 47,000 cast.
The candidates had also squared off last spring in a special election won by Mr. Eristoff by 57 votes. They were fighting to fill a Council seat vacated by Carolyn B. Maloney, who was elected to the United States House of Representatives in November 1992.
In both contests, Mrs. Crotty was slightly ahead when the results on voting machines were counted, but Mr. Eristoff prevailed after prolonged, labored counts of absentee ballots -- which his campaign made a big point of sending to the doorman apartment buildings of the district, where house-to-house canvassing of voters is impossible and telephoning sometimes reaches only domestic servants.
The special election in February was among the most expensive Council races in the city's history, with Mr. Eristoff, an heir to a White Russian emigre fortune, lending his campaign $110,000 of his own money, and he is estimated to have spent much more this time.
Mr. Eristoff said he had to spend a lot of money on the campaign, primarily because, in his view, Mrs. Crotty had several inherent advantages: the district has more than twice as many registered Democrats as registered Republicans, and she was supported strongly by many labor unions and by the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Queens Democrat.
 
No Senate Race for Roukema
 Representative Marge Roukema has become the most recent big-name New Jersey Republican to decide against testing the incumbency and the wealth of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat, next year.
Mrs. Roukema announced last week that after several months of serious consideration, she will not run for the Senate in 1994 because she prefers her current job in the House of Representatives, where she has spent the last 13 years. She said she will spend next year concentrating on health care reform and the proposed sweeping changes in the welfare system.
Mrs. Roukema is the second Republican within a month to shy away from the Senate race. Representative Dick Zimmer announced on Nov. 8 that he could not raise enough money for what is expected to be a tough primary and an even tougher general election campaign against Mr. Lautenberg, who in previous races has spent millions of dollars of his own money to win.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced about two months ago that he would not be a candidate, despite the urgings of state and national Republican leaders.
Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian has emerged as the front-runner for the G.O.P. nomination. He has already established a fund-raising committee, started pulling together a campaign staff and met with national party leaders like Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader.
Mr. Haytaian said last week that he needed to raise at least $1 million to be a viable candidate for the nomination and that it would take at least $10 million to run against Mr. Lautenberg.

HEADLINE: Even the Most Dedicated Need More Help to Help the Neediest;
In 'Double Recovery' and Sharing His Story

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
By his own reckoning, Raymond Lopez should not be alive today, looking trim at the age of 52 and sporting a persistent smile beneath the tweed cap that rarely leaves his head.
From the time he was a teen-ager growing up in the South Bronx, Mr. Lopez had already begun a slide into alcoholism. Most of his days were consumed with playing cards or betting on the horses or organizing neighborhood gangs. When he did not have a gun, his weapons of choice were an ice pick or a hatchet, which he concealed beneath his coat. 
 He also suffered from bouts of manic depression, during which he would burn off boundless energy by walking the highways for days with no sleep. He did not know he was mentally ill until he was well into his 30's, he said, because he always was too stubborn to seek help.
 
Like 'Death Wish'
 "I wanted to be a wise guy all the time, not listening to anybody," Mr. Lopez said recently. "I thought I was Charles Bronson there for a while, walking around like I was in 'Death Wish.' I thank God I'm alive."
Now the tales that he once spun for fellow jail inmates and for patients at the mental hospital where he spent six years are used to encourage others who, like Mr. Lopez, suffer both from mental illness and drug or alcohol abuse.
Mr. Lopez is one of 50 such people enrolled in Project Moving On, a program in downtown Brooklyn that helps them learn to live on their own and develop vocational skills. The program is operated by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Since the program began eight years ago, Project Moving On has guided hundreds of people through the slow, often fragile process called "double recovery" and has helped them get jobs and apartments. For many, it is their first time living on their own after decades of institutionalization or subsisting on the streets.
 
Donations Are Crucial
 The Neediest Cases Fund, now conducting its 82d appeal, raised $4.5 million last year for programs like those of the Brooklyn Bureau, to aid New York City's poor, disabled and unfortunate. The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar can be used for direct services.
At Project Moving On, which has an annual budget of $600,000, the contributions help fill a $140,000 gap not covered by government money. Because increases in the program's public funds have not kept up with inflation, money from private donations such as those given to the Neediest Cases Fund are crucial, said James Hood, the Brooklyn Bureau's assistant executive director.
For Mr. Lopez, the money not only helps finance his recovery but also pays for his transportation when he takes the stage to address hundreds of people in other programs for MICA's, mentally ill chemical abusers.
 
Hilarious and Heartbreaking
 Debra Rubowitz, a program supervisor and Mr. Lopez's primary counselor, said the sometime hilarious, sometimes heartbreaking story of his life never fails to keep listeners rapt. "They're very taken with Raymond, because when he goes through where he's been and how far he's come, they have some hope," Ms. Rubowitz said. "He's come a long way."
For seven years, Mr. Lopez worked as a diesel mechanic at a Postal Service garage in Manhattan. Although he was often drunk, he said, he was usually able to function. But his drinking finally got the better of him and he was dismissed, starting a decadelong downward spiral.
For a time he lived in a hotel for transients, then agreed to join a group of drug abusers and other alcoholics traveling to Virginia to work on a farm. Instead, they were taken to North Carolina and the little money they earned picking tomatoes was held back for room and board, Mr. Lopez said. Eventually he ran away from the farm, owing $67 to his employers.
 
Life Turned Around
 He hitchhiked around the Northeast, finally landing in Washington, where he lived for several months in a shelter for the homeless. But he was soon arrested for breaking windows with an iron pipe and was committed to a mental hospital, St. Elizabeths. There, Mr. Lopez said, his life was finally turned around.
"St. Elizabeths was a horrible place," he said. "And I promised myself that if I ever got out of there, I'd never do anything to get back in."
All signs seem to indicate that his days in hospitals are over, Ms. Rubowitz said. Mr. Lopez now lives in an apartment with a roommate who has gone through many of the same problems. He sees a psychiatrist regularly and takes lithium to control his manic depression. He spends most of his time at the Brooklyn Bureau, where he helps members of Project Moving On learn to work with tools. By early next year, he said, he plans to look for part-time work.
"My main goal right now is to keep feeling the way I feel about myself," Mr. Lopez said. "Sometimes, that's all the work I can handle."

HEADLINE: Even the Most Dedicated Need More Help to Help the Neediest;
An Opportunity to Start Over in a New Land

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
It is almost two years since Yakov Borisevich Alesker declared himself a political refugee at the United States Embassy in Moscow and immigrated to New York with his wife and daughters. At the age of 54, when he could have been basking in the accumulated glory of a long career at a prestigious Soviet engineering institute, he now finds himself near the bottom of the ladder at a Brooklyn vinyl-manufacturing plant.
As an expert in polymers, Mr. Alesker received 40 patents in construction techniques and published dozens of books and scientific papers in the former Soviet Union. He won praise from the Communist Party, and even a shiny red automobile in recognition of his accomplishments. But as a Jew, he said, his life was haunted by a growing anti-Semitism that finally became unbearable. 
 The family gave up a seven-room apartment in a tony part of Moscow for four small rooms in a building of faded gentility in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. These days, Mr. Alesker rides the subway to work, where he taps out computer formulas to tint sheets of vinyl that will become shower curtains and upholstery. Late in life, he is starting over.
 
Accounting and Computer Training
 Mr. Alesker's transition has been helped by the U.J.A.-Federation of New York, one of seven charities that provide a variety of social services through donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Through the U.J.A.-Federation's Employment and Guidance Service, which trains needy people regardless of race, religion or ethnic origin, Mr. Alesker received training in accounting and computer skills that he is using on the job today.
"I knew he was frightened because of his age," said Joan Berger, a senior case manager with the employment service . "But his attitude, his eagerness, his efforts in getting himself a job were just unbelievable." Mr. Alesker threw himself into his classes and sent out 200 resumes, finding a job in the plastics industry just a week before he graduated from the courses.
It has been nine months since he was hired by Nuhart Inc. in Green Point. "He's a highly intelligent man," said Sol Graf, the company's general manager, who emigrated from Hungary in 1966 and has hired many Soviet Jews over the years. "He's working out just fine. He is among the best we've ever had, education-wise."
Mr. Alesker, a diminutive man with a regal bearing, tells of his exodus in true Russian fashion, full of historical sweep and personal drama, interspersed with gentle jokes and folksy aphorisms. "You can feed a wolf much, but he will still look in the forest," he said, explaining his search for a job in his field even though he was offered other work.
 
At Risk Because of Religion
 Mr. Alesker was born and raised in Moscow, one of three children of an engineer. The family lived comfortably by Russian standards, but when it came to their religion, they were always at risk. "Every day of my life in Russia, I had to remember that I am a Jew," Mr. Alesker said. "When I had to choose an institute for my education, I couldn't choose the one I wanted because they didn't want Jews. I had a gold medal for getting the highest score in all my subjects, and still they rejected me."
Learning about Judaism was next to impossible, he added. "I didn't learn Yiddish or Hebrew," he said. "I didn't attend synagogue, only on Yom Kippur. We went to the Moscow synagogue, but it was dangerous even to go. Special agents from the K.G.B. would take pictures and give them to the university officials, who could expel you." As a child, Mr. Alesker said, if he read books on Judaism, it was always "under the pillow."
Once he became an engineer, Mr. Alesker said, anti-Semitism continued to haunt him. At one point during the early 1980's, a delegation from his institute was assembled to visit West Germany and instruct the Germans on an infrared heating device that Mr. Alesker had patented. At the last minute, Communist Party officials intervened and told his supervisor that there were "too many Jews" in the delegation, Mr. Alesker said. He was left behind.
 
A Monument Toppled
 But the last straw came even as many restrictions on Soviet life were easing. In 1991, thugs in Belarus toppled a monument marking the grave of Mr. Alesker's father, a veteran of World War II, and spray-painted it with swastikas. "My father was not only a kind man, he was a man who was for me, maybe the second God in my life," he said. "He was awarded many honors in the military. He worked very hard for Russia, and it was very tragic for me to find pieces of his monument on the ground with these fascist symbols painted on them."
An official investigation produced no suspects, Mr. Alesker said, which further disheartened him. "I couldn't live in my country anymore," he said. "It was not only one episode. There is anti-Semitism that grows deeper and deeper in Russian life. With perestroika and new troubles, many politicians try to explain that it is Jewish people who are at fault. By culture, I am Russian, but when you see this anti-Semitism every day, it is terrible."
He and his wife, Raisa, an economist, and their daughters, Julia, now 31, and Victoria, now 14, decided to leave.
Victoria is now a freshman at Brooklyn Tech, one of the city's selective public high schools. A promising violinist, she has won a scholarship to continue studying and performs with a community-college orchestra that otherwise consists of adults. Raisa has completed a computer training course and is looking for a job.
At the same time, the family is trying to pick up the threads of its religious life, observing all the Jewish holidays now. Last spring, the Aleskers were invited to celebrate Passover at the home of an Orthodox family in New Jersey, where they shared meals and the Haggadah and reveled in the freedom to do so.
Yet Mr. Alesker still seems to be looking over his shoulder, back at his former colleagues and at the change-shaken country that is an indelible part of who he is. "Let me just say that I am a Muscovite," he said. "My whole life I lived in this city. Now I live in New York, but to tell the truth, my heart is in Russia."

HEADLINE: The Public Interest vs. Solo Motorists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The article by Barbara Presley Noble on proving commuting options for workers ("Getting Them There Is Half the Job," At Work, Nov. 21) did not address the social, economic and environmental impact of not dealing with pollution and congestion caused by excessive use of automobiles. 
 Irresponsible commuters force the rest of us to breathe filthy air, leading to illnesses and an overall reduction in the quality of life. The trip-reduction rules of the Clean Air Act of 1990 are intended to address the larger social costs of solo driving for the benefit of an entire region -- not just the individual motorist.
By law, the New York area and nine other regions are required to find ways to reduce automobile use and change the daily commuting patterns of workers. To help employers, the New York City Transportation, Environmental Protection and Economic Policy and Marketing departments have held briefings on the new Federal mandates. These sessions have reached about 200 corporations, and more than a quarter of the affected employers have received information about the program. In addition, the city Transportation Department has already organized two demonstration projects, helping 80 businesses prepare for the November 1994 start-up date.
As the article says, "changing the mindset of employees" will be difficult. New York City is providing its business community with advance notification and assistance and working to insure that the program will be as palatable as possible. What is at stake is not individual rights, but the collective rights associated with the air all of us must breathe and the roads we all share.
 
JANETTE SADIK-KHAN
New York, Nov. 24
 
The writer is director of the New York Mayor's Office of Transportation.

HEADLINE: The Trade Deadline Approaches

 BODY:
Top negotiators say they have made important progress toward agreement on new international trade rules. Yet the world's 116 trade partners remain divided on critical details with only 10 days left to strike a deal.
Over the last 50 years, trade has been the foremost engine of growth: In seven previous rounds of negotiations, tariffs have been brought down from an average of 40 percent to under 5 percent. That, in turn, has allowed trade to grow at a 5 percent clip -- fast enough to add trillions of dollars to the world economy. 
 By Dec. 15 -- a deadline set by Congress -- negotiators must settle their differences. They appear close on big issues, but apart on scores of knotty disputes. Everybody will have to blink if small squabbles aren't to sabotage world growth.
The current trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, envision a grand bargain. Industrialized countries would agree to import more food and clothing from the less-developed countries. They, in return, would open their markets to exports of services, like telecommunications, and intellectual property, like movies.
For the first time, international rules would govern trade in agriculture, services, intellectual property and foreign investment. The likely impact would be substantial. In the U.S. alone, open borders could cut consumer prices by a few percentage points according to government estimates -- a handsome tax cut that would primarily benefit low-income families. Overall, a trade accord could add hundreds of billions to the world economy.
The draft text and tentative agreements from which officials will work this week offer significant gains. Manufacturing tariffs would be cut by about one third. Textile tariffs and quotas would be phased out. Foreign investors would be guaranteed the same treatment as domestic companies. And every country would honor patents and copyrights. The principle of imposing identical tariffs and conditions on imports from every trading partner -- an important protection for weak countries -- would be extended beyond manufacturing.
So who's holding up the deal? For starters, the European Union and the U.S. -- ironic because they would be the big winners from an accord. The U.S. would win from both sides of the grand bargain because, almost uniquely, it exports food, services and intellectual property.
But what's good for a country isn't good for each industry. In France, a tiny number of farmers are fighting cutbacks in agriculture subsidies; France also wants to shut out U.S. movies and television programs. The U.S. is fighting to protect its textile manufacturers and shipbuilders. And as long as the developed countries hold back, the third world won't agree to new intellectual property rights. The entire Uruguay Round could unravel.
These aggravating disputes can probably be solved. But a fracas created by the U.S. over anti-dumping laws is more difficult. Countries are currently permitted to retaliate against imports that are sold at prices below their cost of manufacture -- a practice known as dumping. But the rules are so loose that many countries -- including the U.S. -- manipulate them to find dumping where none occurs. The draft text would stymie such use of anti-dumping laws for protectionist purpose.
But, giving in to domestic manufacturers, the Clinton Administration wants to change the draft in ways that would give governments leeway to misapply anti-dumping statutes. The U.S. might come out ahead in the jungle warfare that would ensue. But that would tarnish the principled position the U.S. has backed for 50 years -- that trade should be dictated by rules fair to all, to benefit the world economy and consumers everywhere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: In America;
A Philadelphia Story

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Phyllis Lawrence knew something was up when the kids started clamoring for Time magazine.
These were high school youngsters in Philadelphia who had been used to hanging on street corners and being cool, gossiping night and day about who was having whose baby and the latest casualties of neighborhood combat. They were not much interested in school, were even less interested in reading, and generally ignored the proposition that there was a future for which they should be prepared. 
 Four years ago, in an experimental program financed by the Ford Foundation, an effort was made to reach these kids. Twenty-five were selected. They were 14 years old and in the ninth grade. They were not the cream of America's high school crop. They were poor kids, primarily from single-parent families that were on welfare. All were black.
The idea was to have a local organization, in this case the cumbersomely titled Opportunities Industrialization Center, step into the lives of the youngsters and stay with them for the four years of high school. If the plan worked, some lives would be salvaged and society would avoid the heavy expenditures associated with adult job training, welfare or prison.
The effort was dubbed the Quantum Opportunities Program and it was quite an adventure.
The kids were paid about a dollar for every hour they participated. For each dollar they earned during the four years, a matching dollar was placed in a special account to help finance college or some other form of post-high school training.
Nonsense was not tolerated. Phyllis Lawrence and her co-coordinator, Reuben Mills, started with the basics. The youngsters would be well groomed. The message to the boys, said Ms. Lawrence, was: "No pants hanging off your heinie. Let's put on a pair of pants with a belt, and let's wear a tie."
"Young ladies were expected to wear stockings," she said, and no one wore sneakers.
The youngsters received counseling at the center and intensive remedial work in English, math, social studies and the sciences. They received training in citizenship skills. They were required to perform community services, such as working with the homeless.
There was a cultural component. The youngsters were taken to plays and to the opera. There were outings in which they wore tuxedos and gowns. They were taught the proper way to behave in restaurants and were not spared the perennial, "Keep your elbows off the table."
Throughout the program the youngsters were encouraged to read and then to discuss what they had read. That got off to a slow start. Magazine subscriptions were ordered, including subscriptions to Time. The coordinators kept pushing. Read, read.
On one occasion, well into the program, the Time magazines were late. To Ms. Lawrence's surprise, several youngsters came to her, "And they wanted to know, 'Well, where's our Time magazines?' "
Ms. Lawrence said she tried to conceal how happy she felt. "They wanted them. Of course, we rushed as fast as we could to get their Time magazines."
Perhaps most importantly, the youngsters were assured that the program would be there for them the entire four years. "They saw us as their family," said Ms. Lawrence. "And it was so important to have a male as part of the program. There was such a need for that."
The four years ended in June. Of the 25 participants, 18 are in college, three are in post-high school apprenticeship programs, two are in high school equivalency programs, one is still in high school, and one is in jail.
Those results are very impressive. When the program was launched, proponents thought that 70 percent of the youngsters would never last the entire four years. A control group of 25 similar youngsters who were not in the program had a high school graduation rate of only 42 percent.
Sixty-two percent of the control group is currently out of school and unemployed.
The Quantum Opportunities Program was tried in five cities in five different states. The Philadelphia program, which spent approximately $15,000 per youngster, had the best results. It's worth a very close look.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In Haiti, a Growing Disillusionment With Clinton

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEOGANE, Haiti, Dec. 2

 BODY:
People in this sleepy seaside town celebrated the election of Bill Clinton last year. Like Haitians throughout this country, they saw the election as presaging the quick restoration of democracy here and the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Braving beatings by soldiers who pursued those who dared speak to outsiders visiting this town, people continued to praise Mr. Clinton even after he broke a campaign vow not to return Haitian refugees fleeing their country. The most common explanation for Mr. Clinton's continued popularity was that if Washington would bring democracy back to Haiti, as it had pledged, little else mattered. 
 But with efforts to restore Father Aristide stalled in the face of defiance by Haiti's military, which overthrew him 26 months ago, faith in Mr. Clinton has turned to scorn and despair.
 
Doubts About Washington
 On a shadeless beach here , few people said they still believed that Washington cared enough or that other countries had the will to force the Haitian military to surrender power.
"We had a beautiful faith in Bill Clinton that was not borne out," said Paul Jean, a fisherman who was repairing his wooden boat.
"There was an accord signed between President Aristide and General Cedras in front of the whole world to settle this crisis. The army has violated its word, and the United States, by doing nothing, has lost its honor."
In fact, the United States has acted since the army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, broke his commitment to resign on Oct. 15 and allow Father Aristide to return by Oct. 30. Washington has sent Navy ships that still patrol the waters here, often visible from the shore, to enforce a global embargo on oil and arms supplies meant to punish the military.
 
Withdrawal of Ship
 But for most Haitians, the withdrawal of an American troopship in early October in the face of a rowdy dockside protest by army sympathizers set the stage for the many other setbacks the diplomacy here has suffered since. The ship carried about 200 American and Canadian soldiers who were to have begun the process of retraining Haiti's unruly security forces.
Throughout Haiti now, across class lines and irrespective of the sentiment for or against Father Aristide, a populist leader feared by the wealthy but adored by the country's poor masses, resentment of the outside world, primarily the United States, is growing.
"Let Bill Clinton speak one last time on our country," said Sauveur Mimi, a fisherman. "After that, we won't care to listen any more."
"It's not like there a million Haitians who are against Aristide and five million who are for him. We are talking about a handful of people who are running this country, killing more and more of us every day while they violate the popular will."
 
Effect of Sanctions
 Feelings about the current economic sanctions, the third effort to impose an embargo on Haiti since Father Aristide's overthrow, are similarly sour.
In Leogane, the effects of the sanctions are seen most clearly in the lack of transportation. Push carts and bicycles have replaced automobiles on the highway that leads to the town, and jobs are few. But as a coastal town, Leogane manages to survive well enough on fishing income, supplemented by the distillation of cheap white rum that is sold in poor quarters of the capital, Port-au-Prince, about 20 miles away.
Foreign relief workers say that elsewhere, however, hunger and disease are spreading at an alarming rate.
"The people asked for the embargo, a total embargo, because we were willing to sacrifice anything if the result was going to be real freedom," said Edner Pierre, a 26-year-old who spoke angrily. "Why hasn't Washington ever wanted a full embargo here? They keep doing just enough to crush the people while the army just keeps getting richer."
In Port-au-Prince, a wealthy businessman who opposes Father Aristide expressed a similar view.
"You get the feeling the United States is mocking us," he said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Their will has been the law in this region for as long as anyone can remember, and yet they pretend to be powerless here. You have got to ask yourself, 'Do they really want Aristide to come back?' "

CORRECTION-DATE: December 6, 1993, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A map yesterday with an article about disappointment with Washington's efforts to restore democracy in Haiti mislocated the town of Leogane in some editions. It is about 20 miles west of Port-au-Prince, not east of it.

HEADLINE: Did Time. Fought Flood. Willing to Work.

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
"What are you looking for?" the woman behind the desk at the job placement agency in downtown Chicago said to the broad-shouldered young man standing before her.
"Anything," he said, clutching his cap nervously. "Anything." 
 The woman asked what his last job had been.
"Burger King."
And when was that?
His voice was low: "1991."
The woman asked what he had been doing since.
He swallowed. "I've been in boot camp." And then, in the silence, he added quickly: "For young men going down the wrong road."
His name is Greg Yance. He is 23 years old, a convicted drug dealer four months out of the Illinois Department of Corrections Marine-style boot camp. What he did not tell the woman -- indeed, what he did not get the chance to tell anyone at the downtown hotels, department stores, restaurants and drugstores where he has been looking for work -- was that as part of boot camp he had fought the Mississippi River last summer, and in that war he was a hero.
To the people doling out job applications, boot camp might just as well be prison. But to Greg Yance, those four months transformed him. "We say: 'We graduate from boot camp; we can do anything,' " he said.
Hurling sandbags along the levees was the best job he has ever had. "We had a purpose," he said. "People thanked us."
The people of what used to be the tiny town of Niota, Ill., have given testimonials about how for eight days last July Mr. Yance and his fellow inmates gave their all to hold back the river and to try to save their town. The other inmates nicknamed Mr. Yance Nature Boy because he was always pointing out the rabbits and birds. He was also the one who wrote the songs they sang as they worked. One refrain: "I'll be your sandbagger, baby; I'm gonna sandbag all night long."
When the levee finally broke, Mr. Yance wept. He and the other inmates had to be ordered away from the river. The people of Niota are white, the inmates mostly black. "It didn't matter what color you was," he said. "The only thing mattered was how loud can you sing, and how fast can you throw the bags."
After they had moved onto the next town -- people up and down the river were pleading for their help -- the inmates received a thank-you card, covered with signatures, "with love from your Niota family."
Mr. Vance's three-minute conversation with the woman at the employment agency was the only interview he had in a day spent going from the Marshall Field department store to six downtown hotels to a restaurant with a "help wanted" sign in the window. In a month of looking, he said to a visitor to Chicago, he had only one other interview, equally brief, at a new Walgreen's downtown.
He said he had a good feeling about Walgreen's. "I was sure they were going to call me," he said. Mr. Yance says he spends three days a week looking for work and two days at home waiting for phone calls -- calls that don't come.
What Greg Yance would like to tell all the personnel people downtown who seem not to have noticed him is this: "I've worked 18-hour days for $3 a week -- throwing sandbags dawn to dusk, stepping in water with snakes, and insects I never seen before. It was 110 degrees. Our uniform be soaked with sweat when we finished. After all that, we still got to do our P.T. -- physical training, push-ups, jumping jacks, stomach crunches. Then we jog our three miles. I'm a hard worker. I'll start at the bottom. Making $3 an hour would be a big accomplishment for me."
 
The Ability to Lead
 One of Mr. Yance's references is John W. McCorkle, the superintendent of the boot camp, in Roodhouse, Ill. Mr. McCorkle, a 6-foot, 5-inch Vietnam veteran who specializes in intimidating inmates, said he would give Mr. Yance a glowing recommendation.
"You could see Yance's leadership qualities," he said in a telephone interview. "He was the one who came out singing. He noticed all the little things, like the wildlife. He showed me he had a good heart, a strong heart. He's extremely bright. I wish I could put him in a uniform and have him be an officer here. Wouldn't he be great?"
For now, though, Mr. Yance is back where he started, in one of Chicago's poorest and most violent neighborhoods, on the West Side, where when he was 8 years old his father was shot to death. Mr. Yance himself carries a bullet in the back of his neck, though he was shot in Rockford, Ill., where his mother had sent him to live with relatives several years ago in the hope he would be safer there, but where he ended up selling drugs.
Twenty years ago a young man like Greg Yance might have found work in the neighborhood tool and die factories; today they are mostly shut down. The wire factory that is open has a sign out front: "No Help Wanted." The one growth industry, it seems, is drug dealing. Mr. Yance said that when he got home last August the local kingpin himself extended a job offer. Asked if he had considered it, he said: "I'm not going to lie to you. I've thought about it. I be thinking I could make $100, then $200. I want to give it to my mama, but she'll ask me where I got it."
 
Trying to Be Positive
 And so the other morning, like many mornings since he got off his three-month, at-home detention at the end of October, Mr. Yance went looking for legal work. He put on the clothes his stepfather, William Wade, a disabled blast-furnace worker, had bought him a month ago: black slacks he had hemmed himself, a white shirt he had ironed the night before, a gray and black sweater and matching tie, black loafers with the heels already worn down from job-hunting.
His mother, Yvonne Yance, 39, who for 13 years has worked as a secretary in the state welfare office, had some advice for the oldest of her three children as he left the house: "Be positive."
Squaring his shoulders, Mr. Yance raised his voice in the trademark boot camp chant: "Hoorah!"
Talking at home two evenings earlier, he listed all the people he knew who had been shot and killed in the last year or so : "My homey Alex dead. Carl got shot. He was in boot camp, came back and got into the same thing, selling drugs. Pookie got killed. He my best friend since sixth grade. Derrick got shot. And Baby Ty. Frank shot dead in the head. He died two days before his 23d birthday."
Asked to name the young men he knew who had jobs, he could think of only one: Demetrius Simpson, 26, a $6.40-an-hour grill server in the employee cafeteria at the Hyatt Regency downtown. (Pointing out that he has no arrest record, Mr. Simpson said it took three months of looking to land that job three years ago.)
 
Tough New Battles
 Battling a wild river seems easy, compared to what Greg Yance faces now. Last summer was war: It did not matter that he had been expelled from school in the 10th grade for packing a gun, nor that he had belonged to the Vice Lords, nor that he sold drugs.
Now, he is looking for a job in a town where even law-abiding citizens cannot find work. His resume: a piece of lined paper on which he has painstakingly printed his former jobs: Burger King, setting up rooms for conventions at the Holiday Inn O'Hare, selling hot dogs at the Lincoln Park Zoo, cooking at a fast-food restaurant.
Walking briskly toward the subway on a cold morning last week, Mr. Yance passed two young men, in black parkas and skullcaps, on a stoop a block from his house. One called out: "When you gonna come back and get some duckets?"
"P-O," Mr. Yance said, and kept walking. To the visitor, he explained: "That mean posse out, you're out, bye-bye." The young men, he said, were drug dealers.
A few steps farther, he pointed to an alley. "That's where I got arrested," he said. One more block was an abandoned building. "My brother got arrested there for selling drugs the day after me." Felix Yance, 20, got out of jail last summer. He is living with a girlfriend; he does not have a job.
Paying the $3.60 round-trip fare with money borrowed from his sister, Crystal, 22, who was working in telemarketing until she had her baby last month, Mr. Yance rode the subway downtown. First stop: Marshall Field; they might need stock boys for the Christmas rush. On the street outside, he smoked a cigarette while men and women hurried by with their briefcases. "I'm nervous," he said.
 
'They Might Call Me'
 He took the small black-pearl stud from his left ear and removed his cap. "Respect," he said. Walking past the Christmas displays -- which reminded him that he had spent last Christmas in jail -- he arrived at the ninth-floor personnel office.
One question on his job application: Have you ever been convicted of a felony? Mr. Yance wrote "yes," with a note that he would explain in an interview. When he handed the form to the receptionist, she informed him that all the Christmas jobs were taken.
"That's O.K.," he said, heading back to the street. "Someone might quit. They might call me."
For the next four hours, with a biting wind blowing up from Lake Michigan, he walked from one hotel to the next, filling out applications for security guards, cashiers and restaurant workers. Entering the Hyatt, he looked uncomfortable. "I feel bad," he said. "I lied to my mama. I told her I had an interview at the Hyatt. I felt it was necessary. When things aren't going right for me, seems like she gets depressed. She thinks it's still the 70's. She thinks I can just walk out the door and get a job."
One of his last stops was the new Sheraton, where a year ago 9,000 people, many of them unemployed professionals, had waited in a brutal snowstorm for a chance to be busboys and housekeepers. Five hundred were hired. There was nothing for Greg Yance.
It was inside the Marriott on Michigan Avenue that he spotted the ADIA employment agency. The woman there said she would keep him in mind for temporary office and "light industrial" work. Afterward, Mr. Yance confided that he had considered lying: "I wanted to tell her I was in college."
He earned his high school equivalency diploma in boot camp. He would like to go to college. He has a lot of big dreams. He talks of becoming a psychologist. Or moving to Niota. "I dream of Niota," he said. "Me with a farm, and corn."
 
Jobs Are Few
 But right now Niota is just that, a dream. The 250 townspeople who once lived there, many of them factory workers, are hoping the Federal Government will buy their ruined homes so they can relocate. While they still talk reverently of the inmates working with sandbags, they are too anxious about their own futures to be in a position to try to help Greg Yance, or anyone else.
Jobs that Mr. Yance might once have got in Chicago -- driving a truck, say, or a bus, or working in a factory -- seem beyond his imagination. Thinking wistfully of last summer, he said he would like to work with his hands. "That's what I'm best at," he said. "Backbreaking work."
The next morning he went downtown again, still searching. In a telephone call that night, his voice was flat. "One of my friends got killed today," he said. "He was out there selling drugs. Somebody drove by and shot him in the head. I seen the ambulance when I was coming home."
No, Mr. Yance said, he did not cry. "Same old thing," he said. "Another life wasted."
He didn't find a job last week. He plans to continue his search this morning.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: Flatbush;
Citing Image, Group Resists Aid for Poor

BYLINE: By Lynette Holloway

 BODY:
After a restructuring of the city's anti-poverty program, 11 more communities began receiving a share of $13 million in city and Federal money last week intended to finance programs to combat problems like unemployment and school dropouts.
Most of the communities welcome the money, but in one, East Flatbush, the designation has prompted serious opposition. 
 The East Flatbush Coalition, an association of about 300 homeowners, has hired a lawyer to have the designation -- and the $230,000 it would bring them -- withdrawn, on the grounds that it would taint the image of their neighborhood and promote red-lining among banks and insurance companies.
"There is nothing positive about this designation," said Edward Bryant, chairman of the coalition. "They will have us lined up for social services. We don't want that."
But Gladys Carrion, commissioner of the Community Development Agency, which administers the anti-poverty program, maintains that the neighborhood needs the money. She characterized the opposition as a small but vocal group that does not represent the interests of the 30,000 people living in poverty in the area.
"There is poverty in Flatbush," she said. "The people protesting this designation own homes and rent the basement out to poor people, usually newly arrived immigrants, who receive public assistance. Who do they think they are trying to fool?"
Flatbush, where more than 30 percent of the residents are of West Indian ancestry, is an attractive community of quiet side streets with brick row houses and handsome brownstones. This is not the first time the community has fought the city's poverty designation.
In 1979, when East Flatbush was first designated, residents met with Mayor Edward I. Koch and other city officials and lobbied to have the money turned back, saying they did not need or want it. They won.
But 18 months ago, after reviewing census data, Ms. Carrion and Mayor Dinkins concluded that poverty had increased citywide and announced the restructuring of the city's 27-year-old Community Action Program.
The restructuring increased the number of communities served from 33 to 44 and expanded the eligibility standard to meet the Federal Government's poverty guidelines. The program, which now serves 1.45 million residents, receives city tax money and Federal Community Service Block Grants.
Under the old program, areas were designated solely on the number of people receiving public assistance and supplemental security income within a community board's district. Now, communities are designated if 30,000 or more people, or 30 percent of the population, within one community board district live at or below the Federal poverty line.
In addition, the new standards gauge income levels in groupings of census tracts with total populations of at least 8,000, allowing for small poverty clusters to be identified within larger, overall more affluent community boards.
The program allocates money to community-based organizations that provide a variety of services ranging from youth leadership and drug prevention programs to adult job readiness and housing assistance. In Flatbush, four agencies will receive the money. The groups are the Flatbush Development Corporation, the Italian-American Civil Rights League, the Flatbush Haitian Center and the Myriad Association Inc.
"Just because there is a large block of middle-class homeowners in Flatbush, they shouldn't dictate who gets services," said Jose Velez, executive director of the Flatbush Development Corporation.
"There's no harm in this. The agency is here and this additional money helps to stabilize the needy population."
Mr. Bryant said his group's lawyer, Lynn Terrelonge, plans to bring the case to court after Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Guiliani formally takes office, hoping that the new administration will be critical of the Dinkins-era designation.
 LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: Red Hook;
Community Court Planned

BYLINE: By Lynette Holloway

 BODY:
A community-based court, the city's latest approach to coping with misdemeanor cases, will arrive in Red Hook next spring, and it will be tailored to the particular needs of this fading waterfront community.
The first community court was set up in Manhattan eight weeks ago and deals mainly with transient criminals in the Times Square area. The Brooklyn version is also a three-year pilot project, but it is geared to hometown criminals, especially to those in and around the Red Hook Houses. Fear, drugs and guns have long been part of the landscape of these apartments. 
 The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said last week that the exact site of the new court was still being scouted. Its location in Red Hook is certain, though, and it will be dedicated to Patrick Daly, a revered elementary school principal who was gunned down about this time last year as he searched for a missing student at the Red Hook Houses.
"There is no question that the shooting of Patrick Daly was the precipitous moment when we said we have to do something about the Red Hook Houses," Mr. Hynes said. "Before then we had been talking about the court and where we would put it, but the incident decided the location for us."
Like its counterpart in Manhattan, the Brooklyn court will primarily handle misdemeanors like prostitution and low-level drug possession. But it will have a wider range of services, including a night court for nonjury criminal trials and civil and family courts. The accused will be arraigned at precinct houses using video monitors, and a team of defenders will be assigned to the court so that they will become familiar with the Red Hook area and its residents.
A goal of the community courts is to mete out public service sentences as alternatives to jail time -- assigning graffiti writers to a number of hours spent cleaning up graffiti, for example.
Besides finding a building to renovate for the Brooklyn court's use, officials are looking for additional financing. Assistant District Attorney Gene Lopez said that the United States Justice Department had provided a $150,000 grant to help organize the court, and the office has also applied for a $125,000 grant from the New York City Housing Authority to develop construction plans.
Other public and private funds are being sought. Officials would not estimate the annual cost of running the new court; the Manhattan court's annual budget is $1.1 million.
"We're always searching for innovative ways to address low-level persistent crimes that eat away at the quality of life at all of our developments, and this court offers a different approach," said Alan Aviles, the New York City Housing Authority's General Counsel. "We're willing to do what we can to make it work."
It is unclear how many cases outside Red Hook would be diverted to the court from the Kings County Courthouse.
Community-based courts were once the rule in New York; they disappeared in 1962 when the courts were centralized.
 LYNETTE HOLLOWAY
