HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Marketing Meat in the Age of Tofu

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
IT is 9:30 A.M., and most of New York is lurching into a normal business morning, but the meat market district, after another busy all-nighter, is just winding down. James Ortenzio -- known as Mr. Meat on the bustling cobblestone streets just below West 14th Street -- is holding court in his office, eager to explain the intricacies of this little world, which struggles daily to fill regular and rush orders from dining rooms, hospital kitchens, school cafeterias, grocery stores and butchers' shops across the city.
"Every day is a different surprise," he said as he flipped through orders from Gallagher's steak house, the Four Seasons Hotel, Brooklyn Hospital, the Federal Reserve and the Manhattan Chili Company. "Today's surprises included a guy who wanted a large quantity of veal tenderloin we didn't expect. Somebody else didn't ship turkey because a truck broke down, so we had to go around the corner. Another place wanted venison saddle; all we had was venison rack." 
 As chairman of the Greater New York Meat Trade Institute, the 48-year-old Mr. Ortenzio, who owns several businesses himself, is the meat market's biggest champion, a kind of mayor of the district. He also advises foreign governments and international companies on trade, and exports to 17 countries, supplying embassies and royalty. Trained as a lawyer at night school, he holds master's degrees in philology, linguistics and business administration and sprinkles through his conversation references to Stanford's econometric forecasting model, Ghiberti's doors in Florence and discussions with B. F. Skinner, the late behaviorist.
Yet in his crumpled fedora he moves easily through the market near the waterfront, where raw flesh hanging from shiny steel spikes is flung across loading docks and burly men in long white coats with pink stains dart out of frigid brick warehouses breathing frosty little clouds.
"I'm not interested in living in the sophisticated uptown world," he says.
Buffeted by changing eating habits and economic forces, the meat market has needed navigators in recent decades. The age of tofu has been unkind. Red-meat consumption fell nationwide from 132 pounds a person in 1970 to 114 last year. At the same time, new distribution trends hurt the wholesale market, with supermarkets and fast-food chains developing their own supplies and competition from modern markets, like Hunts Point in the Bronx, a major rival. Developers, too, cast covetous eyes on the market in the late 1980's, trying to ride the real-estate boom westward in Greenwich Village. The district's rail spur, which once brought meat cars directly into a warehouse, closed and the building was converted into the West Coast apartments.
Figures are hard to come by, but there is no question that the West Side market has shrunk since the mid-1970's, said George Puchta, an area supervisor for the United States Department of Agriculture.
Still, the district, whose roots date back more than a century, when farmers in horse-drawn wagons carted produce to it, has adapted and survived. The market profited from the soaring popularity of poultry, as national consumption jumped from 34 pounds a person in 1970 to 60 pounds last year. Suppliers learned to cater to new ethnic tastes, culinary trends and demands for convenience. One of Mr. Ortenzio's companies offers 30 varieties of ready-made kebabs.
There were experiments, too. For example, Mr. Ortenzio rose to the complaint of buyers for nursing homes who said lamb was expensive and tough for the elderly to chew. Enter the "lambette." Mr. Ortenzio said: "We take the lamb breast, a cheap cut, remove the fat, cut a pocket, stuff it with ground lean trimmings, deep-freeze to minus-30 to kill microbes, mold it like a chop and cut it on a saw. It costs 40 cents for four ounces, and they like it."
Now 75 companies remain, employing 2,300 people and selling $1 billion worth of meat a year -- about 600 million pounds. More butchering is done out of town, with cuts delivered to the district in compact boxes. To keep the district full, Mr. Ortenzio is recruiting food companies that do not deal in meat. The latest are the Petrossian caviar company and Lanciani Patisserie.
"There's a lot of vitality," said Mr. Ortenzio.
Mr. Ortenzio started as a truck driver. Along the way he became a master butcher, raised cattle, was a chef and ran a restaurant. With a $5,000 down payment, in 1979 he bought Long Island Beef, where his father was a supervisor -- "a case of reverse nepotism." From that $2-million-a-year business, he built a network of firms grossing more than $100 million.
As chairman of the institute, Mr. Ortenzio has helped negotiate labor contracts, assisted in compliance with food inspections and arranged credit and health insurance. He even persuaded the bakers to vent their exhaust to the street to fill the air with the ovens' aromas.
He also dabbles in politics. A Democrat, he broke ranks to serve as finance chairman of a committee that raised $1 million for Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign.
Amid a recent morning mist and drizzle, he strolled the district, whose warehouses are still centrally cooled by brine pumped through iron pipes installed in the 1800's. Chain-smoking and zigzagging across the sidewalks, he bantered with supervisors in cubbyhole offices and slapped the backs of workers hauling dollies. Never lingering, he mixed small talk with handshake deals, wended his way past large upright scales and band saws and pushed though floppy rubber-flapped doors that keep the indoors cold.
Steve Yip, whose company Mr. Ortenzio helped move from Chinatown, asked to have some chicken business thrown his way. Mr. Ortenzio agreed to "take care of it." Minutes later, chatting with contractors about what they said were unavoidable cost overruns on a refrigeration project, he promised to "work something out." Next, a curbstone debate on the city's best lemon tart. Then he paused near a conveyor belt, which fed chunks of meat into a giant grinding machine, to hear a worker's complaints about his boss.
Breaking at Frank's Restaurant up on 14th Street, Mr. Ortenzio headed for the rear table permanently reserved for him. His lunch: linguine with white clam sauce -- and an appetizer of prosciutto.
Even as he relaxed, the business of the market went on around him. Throughout the district, clerks and answering machines took urgent calls from all over town placing orders for overnight deliveries.
"It's a commando job every day," Mr. Ortenzio said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Fresh Food, Fresh Ideas at a Market

BYLINE: By Emily M. Bernstein

 BODY:
On Jan. 2, an old meat-packing plant in a stretch of old warehouses along the Hudson River at 125th Street will get a new tenant: an enormous discount fresh-food market called By Choice.
Sandwiched between the river and the abandoned and partly dismantled West Side Highway, the store is the first arrival in an area that has been the focus of a long-delayed development plan called Harlem-on-the-Hudson. 
 By Choice, opening in a brightly painted building between 132d and 133d Streets, will offer "everything from pigs' feet to caviar" at prices 30 percent to 40 percent lower than the average Manhattan supermarket, said Joseph Fedele, the store's president.
Within a year, he said, the store hopes to bring grocery shopping into the computer age, with a cutting-edge plan involving terminals, like automatic cash machines, scattered around Manhattan. Customers would punch in their shopping list and specify an evening delivery time.
Mr. Fedele and his partners, Anthony Frazier, Adam Berkey and Ken Schwarz, plan to keep prices low by buying directly from producers and to do their own butchering and processing at the market.
"Because we cut four distributive levels out, it's a much fresher product," Mr. Fedele said. "It's much closer to where it would be if you cut it out of the ground or slaughtered it at the plant."
The building is 43,000 square feet, 24,000 of which will be used for sales. That will include a produce area, a small dry-goods section, vast butcher and fish counters and a deli. The store, which is modeled in part on Stew Leonard's in Connecticut and similar markets around the country, will also include videos to entertain children and to educate buyers about food and cooking.
The store would be the first of its kind in Manhattan. Many Upper West Side residents now drive to warehouse-style stores in New Jersey or Connecticut.
The store will hire 75 workers for its opening and plans to increase that to 200 by the end of the year. Mr. Fedele said employees would be trained by the company and would be given an ownership stake in the store.
Mr. Fedele said the store's location made it convenient to large numbers of people, and that market studies show an income range of $5,000 to $500,000 within a one-mile radius.
The market should also appeal to many neighborhood residents forced to depend on small stores with little selection and high prices, he said.
"Because you live in a lower socio-economic area, you should not be forced to eat day-old bread," Mr. Fedele said. "Everything is overpriced and old up here, and you have to buy it in a disgusting environment."
 EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: Melrose;
Melrose Commons Nearer Start

BYLINE: By Raymond Hernandez

 BODY:
Plans for Melrose Commons, a 30-square-block development, came closer to reality when the City Planning Department certified it recently.
That decision has opened the way for a final review by residents and elected officials. Although the review process sometimes becomes a forum for enormous opposition, the plan for Melrose Commons may have already met its toughest challenge: an early public outcry that forced a major revision of the initial proposal. 
 Last year, when city planners first considered certifying a project for the area, plans called for a middle-income community of 3,000 new units to be built along the largest contiguous stretch of municipally owned land in the city -- a tract that sprawled through the area south of 161st Street, to the east of Yankee Stadium.
But when residents learned of the project after one bumped into a city worker taking notes on the street, the certification process was halted amid protests from people who feared that the plan would displace residents and businesses. Some of those fears were based in history: stretches of the borough were devastated in the late 1940's when Robert Moses built the Cross-Bronx Expressway.
But unlike the Cross-Bronx project, Melrose Commons began to incorporate its critics into the planning process. Residents, planners and officials from the office of Borough President Fernando Ferrer met regularly to redraw the plan.
"This is unique," said Kevin Nunn, a deputy director of planning in the Bronx Borough President's office.
"They have been involved in facets of planning that heretofore other communities have not been invited into."
Officials now predict that similar partnerships will increasingly determine the fate of large, publicly financed urban renewal projects.
The new plan has been scaled down to 2,000 units and is part of the Bronx Center, a proposal to revitalize 200 square blocks in the neighborhood with construction of new homes, apartments and businesses.
"This project is the shot in the arm that the Bronx needed," said Carlos Padilla, a member of the We Stay Committee, a group of residents and merchants that opposed the initial plan and helped outline the new one.
He said the group's main goals were to have a constant role in planning, limit relocation and give longtime residents who are relocated proper compensation for their property and priority for any new housing.
"We wanted the project to fit in our community, and it does," Mr. Padilla said. "Moving the people out would be just like what was done to the Indians."
 RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: Network Maps Way Out of Medical Maze

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THE feeling of being in a medical maze is familiar to any patient in a suburban hospital who has had to go to an acute-care medical center in Manhattan for surgery.
Under State Health Department regulations, community hospitals, like the United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester, can offer patients only primary care and routine surgical procedures. Havva S. Idriss, president and chief executive officer of the 294-bed United, said: 
 "Traditionally, when our patients needed sophisticated treatment such as bypass heart surgery, our physicians had to send them down to a tertiary medical center, such as New York Hospital." Tertiary medical centers, she added, are designated by the state "to deal with serious illnesses that require more sophisticated, complex procedures."
 
First Member of New Network
 To be admitted to a tertiary hospital, the patient, with sheaves of X-rays and medical records in hand, traditionally deals with a whole new cast of medical practitioners.
"It has been a very stressful occurrence," Ms. Idriss said. "Often tests that have already been done on the patient have been repeated as ordered by a doctor at the new hospital. The truth is that duplication is not uncommon. It is very hard on the patient." To say nothing, she added, of the added cost and time wasted on the duplicated tests.
Such overlapping procedures should soon be a thing of the past now that United has affiliated with the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan as part of an alliance known as the New York Hospital Care Network, Ms. Idriss said.
"On Oct. 29, United became the first suburban hospital to join the New York Hospital Network," she said. "The strategic planning process, which involves the medical board's staff and heads of both hospitals, has been in the planning stages for almost three years, and we are very pleased with the outcome. It is a win-win for everyone concerned: doctors, patients and hospital administrators alike."
Dr. David B. Skinner, president of New York Hospital, said: "One of our major goals is to have one-stop medical shopping for patients. Overall, the New York Hospital Care Network's mission is to maintain excellence in the delivery of health-care services and medical-education programs through an integrated health-care system.
"The alliance puts us in a competitive position to deliver health-care services much in the same way envisioned in the managed competition at the heart of the Clinton or Cuomo plans." He added that the hospital now has the ability to enter into contracts with corporations, businesses, health-maintenance organizations and other groups "to deliver cost-effective health care."
 
Access to Other Institutions
 In anticipation of changes in the health-care industry, George A. Vecchione, executive vice president and director of New York Hospital, said corporations with employees who live in several different locations will someday routinely contract with health alliances to deliver services to their employees through groups like the New York Hospital Health Care Network.
United Hospital's affiliation with New York Hospital, which has 922 beds in Manhattan and a 326-bed psychiatric division in White Plains, means that patients at United will also have access to a dozen other institutions that are part of the network, which includes nursing-care establishments, specialty hospitals like the prestigious Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan and outpatient services in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.
In turn, United, as part of the network, will now make its nursing-care pavilion, its outpatient clinic and other services and programs available to New York Hospital patients.
 
Aided by Computers
 Ms. Idriss offered an example of how the new arrangement might work. "If a patient who, let's say, lives in Rye, comes home after an operation at New York Hospital and needs cardiac rehabilitation, instead of having the patient going back to New York Hospital for rehabilitation, we can supply it," she said.
Describing the network as a "private initiative on the part of New York Hospital to address the issues of escalating health costs in lieu of changes in the health-care industry," Ms. Idriss said, "It is a very sensible arrangement because it makes the best use of every hospital's resources, which leads to economy of scale and operational efficiencies.
"There should be significant savings realized through integrated and consolidated services, with the end result of offering more health-care choices at lower costs to the 100,000 consumers in our area. And as an added benefit, our physicians at United will have access to the latest discoveries and medical research and technology through New York Hospital's vast research and education institutions."
What makes sharing information viable is the computer. In the pilot program in effect at United Hospital, all patient information is computerized at bedside.
Dr. Edward V. Gundy, an orthopedic surgeon in private practice and vice president of United's medical board, said that the computer will give network affiliates access not only to patients' charts but also to their laboratory work, X-rays, medical work, other charts and recommendations from doctors -- in short, a total patient profile.
 
More Services Available
 "It is a tremendous boon for doctors and patients alike and so much more efficient," Dr. Gundy said. "The information that nurses put on a patient's chart is computerized and when the system goes on line, all vital information about a patient will be coordinated and transmitted electronically to other institutions in the network, which means, for instance, that when I send one of my patients down to the Hospital for Special Surgery I can do it quickly.
"What is more, all the patient has to do is show up at Special Surgery without worrying about picking up numerous X-rays and medical records first."
The alliance, Dr. Gundy added, will not only increase the number of health-care services for residents but will also help consolidate such overlapping operations as rehabilitation services, nursing-home and home-health-care services and inpatient and outpatient psychiatric programs.
"I see alliances such as this one playing a big part in the solution to the problem of delivering affordable quality health care," Dr. Gundy said. "It will surely help hospitals contain costs through sharing services instead of duplicating their facilities. And the services of doctors will also be shared. Doctors will have more time to do what they were trained to do. Everyone should benefit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dolores Arbucci, a nurse, checking patient information with the new computer system at United Hospital Medical Center. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fast Boat to Manhattan May Sail From Yonkers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
WITHIN two years, Westchester residents may have another way to travel to Manhattan: a 30-minute ferry ride from a Hudson River pier here to 38th Street. Mayor Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers announced late last month that he was negotiating with the Port Imperial Ferry Corporation of Weehawken, N.J., to start the commuter service as early as 1995.
Arthur Imperatore, owner and president of the ferry company, said that a new generation of high-speed boats traveling at 35 miles an hour -- more than twice the speed of his present fleet -- would be used for the Yonkers run. 
 Mr. Imperatore's company operates other ferry services, including two from Weehawken to midtown and downtown sites and another from Hoboken, N.J., to Battery Park City. The company is planning another run from Hunter's Point in Queens to a terminal at 34th Street on the East River. Port Imperial Ferry also operates a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor and an excursion from midtown to Tarrytown from spring to fall.
In addition, Port Imperial Ferry operates buses to take travelers from ferry terminals to other locations in New York City, a service included in the price of the ferry ticket.
 
Nyack Also Under Consideration
 The cost of the half-hour, one-way ferry ride from Yonkers to Manhattan would be $7, and monthly commutation tickets would be available.
The commute from the city pier here could tie into a similar service planned out of Nyack in Rockland County, where the state recently awarded a route to Port Imperial, Mr. Imperatore said.
The emphasis on ferry service is a result of the High-Speed Ferry Task Force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo earlier this year to study ways to relieve congestion on highways, bridges and tunnels leading into New York City.
The Governor has called ferry transportation a key element of his New, New York economic revitalization program for the metropolitan area and has described the boats as an "environmentally sound means of travel" and "a great way to get to and from work."
 
A Private Deal
 The service from Nyack and Yonkers to Manhattan would operate during the morning and evening rush hours, from 6:30 A.M. to 10 A.M. and from 4 to 7 P.M., said Vince Baglivo, a spokesman for Port Imperial. More runs would be offered if the number of riders increased, he said.
While the state is backing the principle of ferry service out of Nyack and Yonkers, implementation of the commuter lines "will be essentially a private deal" between the municipalities and the ferry company, said Robert Weber, a spokesman for Mayor Zaleski. Some state or Federal money may be used by the city for developing parking or renovating a pier, he said.
Mr. Baglivo said: "Essentially, the state has invited a private company with private funding to negotiate the deal as opposed to the way subsidized mass transit works."
Yonkers's plans are part of the city's latest effort to revitalize its waterfront area. Some of the revitalization projects, but not the ferry service, will be paid for with county funds.
 
It's No Longer Arthur's Folly
 For the ferry service, Yonkers will conduct a study to determine if a ramp or an additional parking structure is needed at the terminal. Also, the negotiations with Mr. Imperatore have focused on who will be responsible for providing security at the pier, Mr. Weber said.
Mr. Imperatore, 68, formed the company in 1986 and now carries about 20,000 ferry passengers a year. "In the beginning, when I started, they called it Arthur's folly, but it has proved not to be a joke," he said. "It is quite profitable now."
He estimated that he would need five more boats for the Yonkers and Nyack routes and that each boat would cost about $3.2 million and would be capable of carrying up to 350 passengers, compared with the older boats, which seat up to 400 people.
The new ferries have glass tops, bars and refreshment services and are heated and air-conditioned. "They are quite beautiful, very upscale," Mr. Imperatore said. "And once people take our boats, they get hooked on the enjoyment of it. It's not the subway or the train."

HEADLINE: 2 Senators Take 2 Approaches On Health: 'Now!' vs. 'Now?'

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
One Irish-American grew up in Hell's Kitchen and became an intellectual. The other was raised in privileged surroundings and went straight into politics.
The first has written hundreds of books and articles as the Senate's only working scholar. The second has written hundreds of laws, more than anyone else in the Senate's 204 years. 
 Pat Moynihan of New York and Ted Kennedy of Massachusetts are the Senate chairmen who will have dominant roles on health care next year. Each is a sponsor of President Clinton's plan, but the two Democrats' approaches are as different as their careers.
 
Impatience and Caution
 Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Committee on Labor and Human Resources, has been pushing national health insurance since 1969. He wanted to do it then. He wanted to do it last summer. He wants to do it now.
Daniel Patrick Moynihan, chairman of the Committee on Finance, will go ahead and do it, all right. But he wonders if this is the right time, and the right social problem to tackle.
Even so, they are friends who appreciate each other's talents and resist the urging of allies to seize the prime role on health care, to defend those Senate verities of turf and procedure.
 
Republican Motives
 Republicans who would prefer to work in the more conservative confines of the Finance Committee fanned that issue, titillating a capital that thrives on such disputes, and the health bill was ultimately referred to neither committee as Congress rushed home last month.
In the long run, this procedural roadblock will either be cleared or prove irrelevant. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said last week that he expected the bill to go to the two committees. And even if it does not, Mr. Kennedy said, "it doesn't make any difference; we can each originate new bills."
This Senate tiff -- the House has somehow avoided such wrangles for the time being -- is a token of how much health care is now a Congressional issue, with Congressional customs and characters a major influence on its future. The jurisdictional issue is a marker for the future, over who has charge of the inevitable, but less noticed, revisions.
Even Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who stepped forward to block part of the bill from going to the Labor Committee, acknowledges that whatever emerges next year will not be one committee's product, but "a collective bill."
In that collective, expect Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Moynihan to work together, as they did when the New Yorker first came to the Senate in 1977. The two of them joined the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and Gov. Hugh L. Carey of New York in a St. Patrick's Day appeal, renewed in subsequent years, urging Americans to stop arming the Irish Republican Army.
A picture of the four of them as football's Four Horsemen of Notre Dame, hangs by Mr. Kennedy's desk in his Senate office. The broad humor of that picture is more Mr. Kennedy's style; Mr. Moynihan's brand of wit is drier.
They have known each other since the 60's, vote alike about 90 percent of the time and respect each other's abilities, though in fact no past legislation has brought them to collaborate as closely as they acknowledge they must on health care.
 
Mutual Admiration
 Mr. Kennedy calls Mr. Moynihan "one of the giants in the Senate" and "an enormously significant, thoughtful and profound writer" with an intellectual breadth that reaches beyond details to concepts.
Mr. Kennedy, who has spent 31 of his 61 years in the Senate, said Mr. Moynihan was one of those rare colleagues who could "have a very interesting, personally satisfying life outside the Senate, and were sufficiently sure of themselves individually and personally to be able to maintain their basic integrity in the service of the Senate."
Mr. Moynihan, who deferred to Mr. Kennedy and let his committee have the first Senate hearing with Hillary Rodham Clinton, said, "I admire him hugely," especially his colleague's efforts to push his committee's liberal agenda in the Reagan-Bush era.
"He doesn't get frustrated and angry," Mr. Moynihan said. "He has soldiered very well through those 12 years. And he has been thinking about health for a generation."
 
Kennedy's Mission
 In the 80's, Mr. Kennedy was probably best known as the prime Congressional voice on civil rights, leading successful fights against Republican Administrations on voting rights, sanctions against South Africa and discrimination by employers.
But his efforts to maintain health and education programs in the face of Reagan Administration cuts were also accompanied by some new health legislation, including a 1986 measure allowing workers to maintain employer-based insurance by paying the premiums themselves when they leave their jobs.
Despite renewed efforts in the late 1980's, national health insurance, which he said in 1969 was "an idea whose time has been long in coming," has eluded him. Labor's unwillingness to compromise undercut his efforts in the early 1970's, and President Jimmy Carter's reluctance to move on insurance prompted Mr. Kennedy's ill-conceived 1980 campaign for the nomination.
This year, with a President for an ally, Mr. Kennedy has been eager for action. He lent 10 staff members to Mrs. Clinton's task force that developed the plan. He tried to get health care dealt with as part of the budget bill this summer, but failed. Then he said his committee could report out legislation before the end of this year. And he has been holding hearings here and in Massachusetts, two or three days a week, all fall.
 
More Recent Concern
 Mr. Moynihan comes lately to health care. In the 80's, he played major roles in assuring the solvency of Social Security and Medicare, in changing the tax system and in transforming Federal highway legislation into a program that promotes all varieties of surface transportation.
Last summer, when Mr. Kennedy was urging speed on health care, Mr. Moynihan was openly wondering if it would not be better to try to deal first with welfare. That has been his trademark issue since he first began writing about the decline of the black family in the 1960's.
It was also his major concern when he worked as a counselor to President Richard M. Nixon, the third President he served (after John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson and before Gerald R. Ford) in what he calls a gallimaufry of domestic and international positions.
Even now, while he says "we're going to go ahead" on health care, he finds much, both practical and philosophical, to worry about. He shook up the Administration in September by calling the financing of the health plan a "fantasy," but says he is now somewhat reassured by their revisions.
Still, "I have a question," Mr. Moynihan said on Friday after returning from trade talks in Geneva. "It's very abstract. And that is, in economic theory there is a sort of a literature on 'point of entry.' At what point is it too late to go into a particular sector? For example, you would not start an automobile company today."
 
Both Underestimated
 Mr. Moynihan, 66, says that medicine has advanced so far that the task of providing national health insurance will be immensely more difficult than it would have been when President Harry S. Truman first urged it, or even when Senator Kennedy did.
Mr. Moynihan's caution and Mr. Kennedy's impatience on health care reflect the Senators' obvious differences.
But they have something very important in common as they approach health care. Each has been vastly underestimated in the Capitol.
Mr. Kennedy's upholstered route to the Senate, which he entered at the constitutional minimum age of 30 while his brother was in the White House, plus his often mangled sentences and his having been thrown out of Harvard, led a lot of people in Washington to think he was dumb. They also thought he did not work hard.
But scholars whom he has brought in to help on legislation come away impressed that he asks the right questions and remembers the issues. Colleagues have found him indefatigable in preparation for a hearing or on a foreign trip, and relentless in building a political army, as when he worked to defeat the Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork in 1987.
His strategic skills are formidable. This summer, for example, he demanded that Clinton Administration officials retreat a bit on their student loan plan to satisfy Senator James M. Jeffords, a Vermont Republican. He said they would need Mr. Jeffords's help later on.
They reluctantly retreated. In September Mr. Jeffords became the only Republican to endorse the Clinton health care plan.
Mr. Moynihan's omnibus range of interests has lulled some people in Washington into doubting his seriousness as a lawmaker. But his persistence on politically premature issues, like the decay of the black family, has laid a foundation for influence now that he is the chairman.
Sometimes even he underestimates himself. He finds that ideas he has long championed, like banning some handgun ammunition, matter much more now that he is chairman, the first New Yorker to head the Finance Committee since 1849. After he proposed taxing the Winchester Black Talon bullet, which causes more injury than ordinary bullets, out of the market this fall, Winchester simply dropped production.
When Mr. Moynihan succeeded Lloyd Bentsen as chairman of the committee in January, some skeptics doubted he could handle its shifting coalitions. But with Republicans offering no votes at all, he worked with the 10 other Democrats on the 20-member committee to get the tax elements of Mr. Clinton's budget bill through last summer.
One critical knack the chairmen share is the ability to work with Republicans, something not often seen among natural partisans like Mr. Kennedy. That does not keep Finance Committee Republicans from working to keep the health bill out of Mr. Kennedy's Labor Committee, where his liberalism would have most influence.
But if the legislation advances toward passage, it will need Republican support, and in different ways, each man draws Republican allies. Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, who has collaborated at times with both of them, described the styles this way:
"Ted Kennedy is very earnest, very straightforward. There is never any doubt of where he stands. He is very good to work with, straightforward, no hidden ball. His word is his bond.
"Pat is very bipartisan, one of the favorite senators of Republicans, a person who is receptive to a whole variety of ideas. He likes ideas from wherever they come. If I have an idea, he is an audience for that idea."
Another Republican, Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, who serves on both committees, said, "Ted is 'we got to get it done, we got to get on.' You know this guy is in charge. Sometimes with Pat, you think it's both of you."

HEADLINE: Finland's Opera Now Has A Home

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 4

 BODY:
In recent years, Finland, with composers like Aulis Sallinen, Joonas Kookonen, Einojuhani Rautavaara and Erik Bergman, has produced more operas of international distinction than any other country. For a small nation on the northern fringes of Europe, that is a remarkable achievement.
Almost as remarkable has been the fact that up to this week, Finland has lacked a theater specifically designed for opera. The two most prominent operatic entities in the country played in makeshift spaces: the Finnish National Opera in the 500-seat Alexander Theater, built in 1879 for the amusement of the Russian garrison stationed in Helsinki, and the Savonlinna Opera Festival in the temporarily covered courtyard of the 500-year-old Olavinlinna Castle. 
 Now, that lack has been grandly rectified, and in a way that does belated honor to the country's modern-day tradition of operatic composition. On Tuesday night, the gleaming new Finnish National Opera on Toolonlahti Bay in the center of this city was inaugurated with Mr. Salinnen's gripping opera "Kullervo." The title role was sung by Jorma Hynninen, a world-renowned baritone who is also the former artistic director of the Finnish National Opera and the current director of the Savonlinna Opera Festival.
The opening was the beginning of a five-day celebration of the new theater, which was in fact completed in the spring and has seen various concert, operas and ballets since May in productions adapted from the Alexander Theater. These were intended to acclimate the company to its vastly expanded new home, nearly three times the size of the old theater although, at 1,385 seats, still only one third the size of the Metropolitan Opera in New York.
 
A Wide-Ranging Audience
 This week's festivities, which attracted dignitaries and critics from around the world, also included the first new production for the new theater by the Finnish National Ballet, "Swan Lake"; the first new production of a standard-repertory opera, "Carmen," a repeat of "Kullervo" and a concert on Saturday.
"Now we Finns can show the world we can be successful in our art on our own turf," said Walton Gronroos, the company's director. "We don't need any more to go around the world," he added, referring to the company's frequent tours. "Now, the world will come to us."
The reaction in the Finnish press was rapturous, and there was good reason for rapture. The new building won an architectural competition in 1977. But what one Finnish critic called "a lack of money and political will" delayed the start of construction until 1986, with further delays caused by the recession and the bankruptcy of several subcontractors. The "Kullervo" premiere took place in Los Angeles in early 1992, after it had become clear that the Helsinki theater for which it was intended would not be ready. The total cost of the construction was $135 million.
The design, by a three-member architectural team headed by Eero Hyvamaki, may lack the boldness of Alvar Aalto's Finlandia Hall on the same shore; to some, the exterior looks like dated corporate modernism. But its white walls and arched glass atriums blend well with the light-colored exteriors of both Finlandia Hall and the National Theater on the other side of the bay. The white walls look particularly striking flooded with artificial light on a long Finnish winter night, with the grounds and the bay itself covered in pristine snow.
Inside, the theater is more striking still, with the high-tech look of so much Nordic architecture softened by light gray marble and polished parquet floors of red beech. The auditorium -- there is also a flexible small hall seating between 200 and 500 -- may be intimate on American terms, with no seat farther than 100 feet from the stage. But backstage, everything is spiffily up to date, and company members have pronounced the acoustics first rate.
The stage size is up to international standards, too, permitting the company to assay Wagner and other large-scale scores for the first time. Mr. Gronroos, who is still an ensemble member at the Deutsche Oper of Berlin, will sing Wolfram when that company presents Wagner's "Tannhauser" here in April, and there will be a Finnish production of "Lohengrin" in June.
"Kullervo," which was warmly received at its Los Angeles premiere with the same production and much the same cast as this week in Helsinki, made a somber yet symbolically appropriate opening opera. That was partly because this tale of a cursed destroyer of all that he loves comes from the "Kalevala," the national epic of Finland.
Sibelius wrote a "Kullervo" Symphony, but shied away from opera. Mr. Sallinen's score continues a compositional line from Wagner through Sibelius to modernity; its debts are obvious but so is its originality. The composer uses speech and electronic effects and dissonance where expressively appropriate. Yet his idiom has a gloomy Romantic breadth that appeals to international opera audiences. Certainly the performance, with not only Mr. Hynninen but also a supporting cast headed by Jorma Silvasti, a strong young tenor, and the veteran conductor Ulf Soderblum, did Mr. Sallinen's opera full justice.
 
Out of the Mainstream
 Given the overtly mythical nature of "Kullervo," there was some discussion at a symposium on new Finnish operas on Wednesday as to just what the Finnish opera "boom" represents and how internationally appealing it can be. While the Finnish National Opera has performed several new operas widely, and while there have been a few notable foreign productions, new Finnish opera has hardly joined the mainstream repertory.
Partly, said Pekka Hako of the Finnish Music Information Center, that is because "it is hard to whistle Finnish national values." Seppo Heikinheimo, the chief music critic for the leading Helsinki newspaper, The Helsinki News, went so far as to suggest that the entire phenomenon had been artificially created by the Finnish Government's sponsoring tours and subsidizing critics to come to Helsinki. This accusation of impropriety was met with shocked harrumphing, since most of the assembled critics had indeed participated in a Government junket to attend the opening.
On the other hand, such payments are accepted practice in Europe, and Finnish opera has a truly wide appeal, proven by its solid sales on compact disks, especially in the United States. One might even suggest that Finnish composers have followed the same practice as Andrew Lloyd Webber, who has built anticipation for his musicals by first releasing recordings. "Kullervo" was available for months before its Finnish premiere, and Mr. Bergman's "Singing Tree," not scheduled for its world premiere until 1995, is already in the record stores.
For the future, Mr. Gronroos said the main immediate need was for the company to adjust technically and psychologically to its spacious new surroundings, and to get used to presenting 200 opera and ballet performances in repertory over a 10-month season. "The small house is still in the brains of our people," he said.
The "Swan Lake" production was a re-creation of Vladimir Bourmeister's version of the Petipa-Ivanov model by Josette Amiel of the Paris Opera Ballet School. The dancing was appealing but provincial, despite the 22-year-old Nina Nyvarinen's convincing Odette/Odile. Just how effective the company will be in a wide range of standard repertory remains to be seen, although the Finns' success in such repertory at Savonlinna bodes well.
Mr. Gronroos, who has been accused of plotting too conservative a course, said he intended to sustain the company's commitment to Finnish operas, with a new production of Mr. Kokkonen's "Last Temptations" in September, "The Singing Tree" the following season and a world premiere in 1996-7.
He conceded that the very grandeur of the company's new home might daunt composers comfortable in less imposing circumstances, but he remained optimistic that the theater would ultimately benefit Finnish opera.
"I believe that our artistic level will be higher now," he said. "I hope everything will be easier for us, and that the creative power will still be very strong."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Finnish National Opera in Helsinki had its inaugural performance on Tuesday night. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SPLIT ON STRATEGY AT A.M.A. MEETING

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Top officials of the American Medical Association appealed to doctors today to show restraint in criticizing President Clinton's plan to overhaul the nation's health care system, even as members of the group vowed to seek major changes in the proposal.
At a meeting that displayed the group's divisions over tactics and strategy in the coming battle over the nation's health care system, Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the association, said, "We want to make policy, not politics." 
 "We have everything to gain and oh so much to lose if we start drawing lines in the sand while the ship of reform is still at sea," Dr. Todd told more than 500 doctors gathered here for the semiannual meeting of the group's policy-making body, the house of delegates.
 
Employer Mandate Questioned
 But leaders of the doctors' organization found anxiety, frustration and discontent among the members. Several state delegations, including those from New York, Florida, Indiana, Virginia and Texas, said the A.M.A. should re-examine its support of a Federal law to require employers to provide health insurance for their employees.
President Clinton's plan, like a policy the association adopted in 1990, endorses such a requirement, known as an employer mandate. But some doctors, echoing Republicans and conservative Democrats in Congress, are now suggesting that such a requirement may be unwise.
Dr. Ed L. Calhoon, a general practitioner from Beaver, Okla., said the A.M.A. policy on this issue was misguided, and he asserted, "Employer mandates will drive many small companies out of business."
By contrast, Dr. Rebecca J. Patchin, an anesthesiologist from Orange County, Calif., said she supported an employer mandate. "It's the only way" to achieve insurance coverage for all, she said.
American Medical News, the weekly newspaper of the association, said this week that there was a serious split in the organization because "it represents an impossibly diverse membership with conflicting economic interests."
As a result, it said, the A.M.A. and other medical societies have sent mixed signals to the White House and Congress. While endorsing President Clinton's goal of health insurance coverage for all Americans, the association has harshly criticized many of the proposed means to that end.
 
Fighting Caps on Premiums
 The trustees of the group today affirmed their desire to be "a constructive agent of change," working closely with the White House.
But at the same time, the trustees denounced Mr. Clinton's proposal for Government regulation of health insurance premiums. They said that participation in Mr. Clinton's "health alliances" should be voluntary, not mandatory. They objected to the White House proposal to set quotas for the training of medical specialists, and they expressed disappointment with Mr. Clinton's proposals on medical malpractice suits.
To redress such grievances, Dr. Todd suggested a strategy of cooperation, which he said that he had already used with some success. For example, he said, Mr. Clinton agreed that all consumers should have access to "fee for service" health plans, in which consumers can choose any doctor and pay separately for each service, as an alternative to health maintenance organizations with a limited roster of doctors.
In addition, Dr. Todd said, the package of health benefits that would be guaranteed to all Americans under Mr. Clinton's plan is similar to the one proposed by the A.M.A.
 
Note of Apprehension
 While Dr. Todd and other officers of the association struck conciliatory notes in their public remarks, the written reports from the board of trustees were full of apprehension. The A.M.A. has a membership of 290,000, fewer than half the doctors in the nation.
The trustees accepted the idea that spending on health care should be predictable, but urged Congress to reject the type of "budget enforcement techniques contained in the President's plan." Specifically, the trustees resisted Mr. Clinton's proposal for a new Government agency, the National Health Board, that would set limits on premiums.
Under the Clinton plan, all employers with 5,000 or fewer employees would have to get insurance coverage through large purchasing pools known as health alliances. The A.M.A. trustees said this number should be reduced to the range of 100 to 500 employees.
And in a report to the house of delegates, the trustees said: "For employers beneath the threshold, participation in the alliance should be voluntary. Employers above the threshold should remain out of the alliances to create true competition."
The Administration says such a proposal would defeat the purpose of the alliances, which is to concentrate the purchasing power of consumers in the marketplace for health care.

HEADLINE: A Surprise: Blue-Collar Jobs Rebound

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 5

 BODY:
After Terry Ochs got out of the Marine Corps last spring after eight years as a helicopter crewman and aircraft mechanic, he journeyed up and down the West Coast and throughout the Midwest searching fruitlessly for maintenance work with an airline.
Finally, he returned home with his wife and 4-year-old son to live with his parents in Fond du Lac, Wis., and widened his search to include, among others, the Brunswick Corporation's outboard engine factory there. 
 Two weeks ago, the 26-year-old Mr. Ochs became one of about 175 people Brunswick has hired in recent months. He is joining a second shift Brunswick added to its production schedule last week to meet a rebound in demand for pleasure boats.
"It takes a load off my mind," Mr. Ochs said over the telephone from his new employer's factory Friday.
 
Role of Manufacturing
 Mr. Ochs's good fortune reflects the manufacturing sector's part in the surprisingly strong economic statistics released by the Federal Government last week, including Friday's announcement of a sharp drop in overall unemployment in November that took 534,000 people off the unemployment rolls.
New service-sector jobs accounted for the vast majority of those who found employment. The job figures also declined because more than 80,000 people who did not find work on a regular payroll quit looking. But the figures also included a gain of 30,000 workers at manufacturing companies like Brunswick.
It was the second consecutive monthly increase in manufacturing employment, a heartening rebound for blue-collar America that could persist and even accelerate in the next few months, according to economists and labor experts. But they also warn that it is not likely to last.
"This uptick is real, but it does not change the underlying currents," said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert teaching at the University of California in Berkeley. Downward pressures include automation and a trend among manufacturers to move jobs overseas, not just in search of lower wages but also to be closer to foreign markets.
 
Expanding Output Needed
 Indeed, the most recent long-range projection by the Bureau of Labor Statistics concludes that output will have to expand at an average rate of 2.4 percent through 2005 to keep manufacturing employment, now just over 17.7 million, from falling below 17.5 million. That is far above the 1.1 percent growth rate from 1979 through 1992, a period when more than three million manufacturing jobs were lost.
Still, there is no denying that companies like Brunswick are making it a cheerier Christmas for thousands of blue-collar workers. And Brunswick has company, especially in the Midwest.
"On the basis of the latest survey by the National Tooling and Machining Association, I'd say our industry has a minimum of 4,000 openings, and 10,000 is probably more realistic," said Harry Moser, president of Charmilles Technologies in Lincolnshire, Ill., a distributor of equipment used in making molds and dies that other manufacturers need to make plastic parts. "We are hiring engineers as fast as we can find them. We're busy because our customers are."
 
More Chrysler Workers
 Those customers include the Chrysler Corporation, which recently added a second shift to its Belvidere, Ill., factory, bringing to more than 3,000 the number of workers added in recent weeks at that plant, which makes Chrysler's new compact car, the Neon.
There are midsized companies like the privately held MacLean-Fogg Company in Mundelein, Ill., which supplies hardware to telephone and power companies and plastic fasteners to auto makers. It expects to add about 50 employees in the next year to its work force of 1,000 to cope with sales growth of 15 percent.
Small manufacturers are chipping in, too, especially those like Perceptron Inc. of Farmington Hills, Mich., that supply the auto industry.
"We have added about 10 people since the beginning of November to bring us up to about 85 employees," said Dwight Carlson, chief executive of the company, which makes laser-based inspection systems for auto makers that cost up to $250,000 each. "We added a second shift and there's a lot more overtime."
 
Some Executives Skeptical
 Federal data suggest that the manufacturing employment rebound began in October, when a net gain of 12,000 jobs was reported. The 42,000 jobs added in the last two months do not come close to compensating for the 256,000 lost from March through September.
Many in industry have a hard time believing that manufacturing employment is actually expanding. The most recent survey of the National Assoication of Purchasing Managers, which focuses on 300 industrial companies, concluded that manufacturing employment actually fell last month. And some executives are openly skeptical.
"We may add a person or two, but I'm being very careful," said Brad Roller, president of Swiger Coil Systems Inc., a privately held company in Cleveland that makes electrical coils used in mass transit motors and in rebuilding industrial motors.
In addition, when a manufacturing company and other agencies contract out anything from cleaning to data management, the statistical result is a manufacturing job lost and a service-sector job gained. Thus, manufacturing-related employment might be rebounding at a healthier clip than surveys show.
At any rate, data released last week suggest that pressure to hire new employees is growing because the current work force is being stretched to its limit. The average workweek edged up six minutes in November to 41.7 hours, the longest since the end of World War II. And overtime was running at 4.4 hours, the highest since the Government began tracking such data in 1956.
In the real world, such figures are reflected by the decision of Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction equipment, to add 350 people to factories in Illinois from September through the end of this month and to project hiring 320 more early next year. Last spring, the company was meeting most of the growing demand for its products by piling on overtime.
A variety of forces are contributing to American manufacturing job opportunities. There are new products, like Lumitex Inc.'s recent expansion of its fiber optic display lighting technology from electronic instruments into shoes made by L.A. Gear and bike helmets made by Bell. The privately held company, based in the Cleveland suburb of Strongsville, expects to add slowly to its work force of 80 for the next few months and then hire more rapidly in the spring, said Peter Broer, its president.
There is also new popularity for old products. Surging domestic demand for pretzels is creating new jobs at pretzel machine makers like the Reading Pretzel Machinery Corporation in Robesonia, Pa.
In a few cases, companies are bringing overseas production home. Brunswick has moved engine production from a joint venture in Japan to Fond du Lac and this week at its Tulsa, Okla., factory, Brunswick will start making a new model fishing reel, a product typically made in Asia.
Of course, nothing helps like general economic growth. That is what has allowed Georgia-Pacific to add second shifts at building-products plants in Russellville, S.C., and Madison, Ga., increasing employment at each of them by 135 workers. It is also encouraging steelmakers like the Nucor Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and the Roanoke Electric Steel Corporation of Roanoke, Va., to take on new employees.
The most noticeable increases occur when innovation and general economic growth are pushing in the same direction. Morton International Inc.'s automotive group is racing to keep up with demand for its airbags, which are going into more car models at the same time car sales in general are growing.
Morton, which expects airbag sales to be close to $1 billion this year, double last year's total, has hired 625 employees at four plants in Utah since July and expects to hire that many more in the next seven months.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New F.C.C. Chief Looks Beyond the Corporations

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Reed E. Hundt got a sobering lesson in tough challenges in June. As part of a group hiking to the 14,410-foot summit of Mount Rainier in Washington State, Mr. Hundt found himself exhausted and gasping for oxygen at 12,800 feet. The guide told him he had reached his "personal summit," and ordered him to sit tight while the rest of the group went on to the top.
Now Mr. Hundt is pursuing a new "personal summit," and says he has no idea yet how far he will get. Last Monday, he was sworn in as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, becoming chief regulator of the nation's airwaves and a central figure in shaping the broader revolution in telecommunications. 
 He arrives during a time of great change in media and telecommunications. Digital technology is blurring the lines between television and telephones, while wireless services are changing the nature of local phone calls. Under the old rules, these businesses were separate realms.
But now Congress and the Clinton Administration are weighing ideas to overhaul the nation's communications laws, amid growing support for a more free-wheeling regulatory policy that permits greater rivalry between industries.
 
How to Regulate
 In an interview this week, Mr. Hundt made it clear he favors that kind of approach. "Come here and look at this," he said, pointing to an old, yellowing globe that he inherited along with his office. The globe showed French West Africa instead of Senegal, Mali and Mauritania; part of China was carved out as Manchukuo, a name imposed by Japan during World War II.
"Think of this as the Communications Act of 1934," Mr. Hundt said of the globe. "It's not an object of ridicule -- it's an historic artifact."
That stance echoes the view of Mr. Hundt's two predecessors, Alfred C. Sikes and James H. Quello. But the shadings of emphasis are different, in that Mr. Hundt argues that government must step in to promote broader social goals.
"There are thousands of buildings in this country, with millions of people in them who have no telephones, no cable television and no reasonable prospect of broadband services," he noted. "They're called schools."
Relying only on corporate decisions, he said, will not insure that the benefits of advanced communications reach into the schools and to masses of ordinary Americans.
"Corporations will build networks to the point that they are economically optimal," he said. "But market mechanisms will not lead to networks being built to the optimal social point."
Mr. Hundt offered few clues about how he would achieve these broader social objectives. But his stance is sure to rattle many industry figures who want to eliminate current regulations rather than add new ones.
Mr. Hundt, 45 years old, will take over the agency as something of an outsider. A Washington lawyer, he has represented a few communications companies before the F.C.C. and in court. But he is primarily a generalist, better known for his work in antitrust law.
He has been a close friend of Vice President Al Gore ever since the two attended St. Albans preparatory school in Washington, and he went to Yale Law School with the Clintons. He worked on Mr. Gore's Senate campaigns and his Presidential bid in 1988, and on the Clinton Presidential campaign of 1992.
Those who know Mr. Hundt describe him as an intensely energetic man with a keen intellect. For months, he has been meeting with F.C.C. and outside experts to absorb as much as possible about the issues.
His plate will be full. Congress is demanding that the F.C.C. straighten out the confusion over cable television rate regulations, which have produced unexpected price increases for many customers. The F.C.C. has also been ordered to write new rules by June to auction thousands of new radio licenses for wireless "personal communications services.".
Eli Noam, director of Columbia University's Institute for Tele-Information and one of the people Mr. Hundt sought out for advice, said Mr. Hundt's generalist background offered some advantages. "He's more likely to be open-minded and bring a fresh perspective, and not associated with any industry dogfight," Mr. Noam said. "He goes in there with a lot of good will."
Communications lawyers noted that the F.C.C.'s agenda tends to be nonpartisan and that generally favors easing barriers to competition. "There has come to be something of a consensus about what constitutes good policy," Philip Verveer, a communications lawyer and longtime Democrat, said. "Good policy favors open entry, full use of facilities, no restrictions on output. It doesn't really matter whether you're a Republican or a Democrat."
Mr. Hundt seems to have taken that view as well. Discussing legislation that would lift many restrictions on telephone companies while attacking their monopolies, Mr. Hundt said he had been struck by the wide range of support. "The message that was coming back to me, from all kinds of people, was that this is not simply a Democratic idea or a Republican idea -- it's just good legislation."
That does not mean his job will be free of disputes. There will inevitably be huge arguments over tiny details that greatly affect industry groups.
"The honeymoon won't last long," Mr. Noam of Columbia said. "There are more toes to step on here than at a centipede convention."

HEADLINE: A Plan for Gates, a Call for Pickets;
Bordering Newark, Maplewood Finds Proposal Causes a Rift

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 2

 BODY:
No wall or fence or gate stands between this pretty suburb and Newark, not yet anyway.
But the rift that seemed to develop between them last week is real and growing with each new report about a proposal to build several gates that many people thought were intended to separate Maplewood from the state's largest city. 
 While Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and Mayor Robert H. Grasmere of Maplewood attribute the situation to a lack of communication, the two are slugging it out in the media. On Thanksgiving Day, it was the "Today" show. On Dec. 9, "Donahue." In between the two have been interviewed by dozens of television, radio and print reporters.
As a result, what residents of Maplewood say began as a traffic problem is now a story about the affluent suburb versus the impoverished city and whites trying to barricade themselves from blacks with gates on selected streets. And Hillcrest, a racially and economically diverse neighborhood in Maplewood abutting Vailsburg, a similar community in Newark, is fending off charges of racism and elitism from all corners of the globe.
"It was never about keeping people out," lamented David Chavis, a founder of the Hillcrest Neighborhood Association, who expects another firestorm of publicity when a public hearing on the proposed gates is held Tuesday night.
 
'We've Talked About Organizing Pickets'
 But critics of the plan are unmoved say they plan to organize Newark residents to attend the hearing. "The proposal is extremely offensive," said Luis Quintana, a Newark deputy mayor. "We've talked about organizing pickets."
The proposal for gates, Hillcrest residents say, came out of a long process of figuring out what to do with a worrisome problem: cars careering through the neighborhood's narrow streets to avoid three traffic lights.
Residents, after complaining for years that the cars were a danger to their children, came up with the idea of installing five ornamental gates that would create cul-de-sacs so that cars could not cut through. The State Department of Transportation granted preliminary approval to the plan and on Nov. 22, so did the Maplewood Township Committee.
The next day, a 193-word item in The Star-Ledger in Newark described a proposal to install five steel gates along the Newark border as a crime-prevention tactic that would keep all traffic from Newark out.
 
Gates of Iron and Brick
 Mayor James reacted in a fashion that could have been predicted of his city's fiercest defender: he was outraged. Recalling a proposal in Elizabeth a few years ago that would have built a wall in a neighborhood facing a Newark housing project, he fired off an irate letter to Mayor Grasmere.
The letter said, in part, "I am extremely disturbed by the elitist mentality Maplewood has demonstrated that says that certain municipalities like Maplewood have no crime, while other municipalities, like Newark, breed criminals." And Mr. James had copies of his letter faxed to reporters.
Maplewood officials said the article misstated the where and why of the plan. First, they say, the issue is not crime, but traffic. Second, of the five gates (which will not be steel but scrolled iron and brick), four will stand not on the Newark border but in the interior of Hillcrest, facing the rest of Maplewood.
The fifth gate is to face Irvington Avenue, a main thoroughfare that separates Maplewood and Newark, on a blocklong street constantly trammeled as a short cut.
[Mort Pye, the editor of The Star-Ledger, said in a statement yesterday: "We received complaints about the crime emphasis in the story. In subsequent stories we took pains to explain this was a long-considered plan to help solve traffic problems in the neighborhood."]
But it is too late for Maplewood to contemplate the symbolism of gates or publicize the plan to avoid any misunderstanding.
Picking up on Mayor James's reaction, dozens of reporters descended on Hillcrest. On "Today," Katie Couric introduced the story as one about one town in New Jersey wanting to erect gates to keep out the other. "Donahue," taped last Thursday afternoon packaged the story as a racial issue. It was broadcast in 20 markets and will be broadcast locally on WNBC-TV Channel 4 on Thursday.
A producer prepped the audience for a controversy where "those constructing the fences are white middle class, those on the other side of the fence are mostly minority poor."
The audience was shown a video of Maplewood that panned through its quaint downtown and most exclusive residential streets. It did not show Hillcrest -- eight blocks of tidy tract houses (selling for about $150,000) on compact (40-foot-by-100-foot) lots. A video of Newark showed streets with "for sale" signs on sorry-looking buildings, not bordering Vailsburg, which has both private houses and condominium developments.
 
Mayors Blame Each Other
 Until this incident, relations between Newark, a city of 275,000, most of them black, and Maplewood, with about 21,000 residents, about 12 per cent black, were cordial. Many Maplewoodians work in Newark, come from Newark and have relatives in Newark, residents of both places say. Before a movie theater opened in Newark two years ago, Newark teen-agers went to Maplewood's theater.
The mayors blame each other for the brouhaha. Mr. James said he had reason to be confused about the plan because no one in Maplewood told him about it. "At a time when Arafat and Rabin are talking, when the Berlin wall has come down, we should be talking," he said.
Mr. Grasmere said there was nothing to say about the plan since it was considered a neighborhood matter. And he is angry with Mayor James for comparing the issue to world events. "It does not have any impact on Newark," he said.
Meanwhile, the founders of the Hillcrest Neighborhood Association, Mr. Chavis and Kenneth Pettis, say the real story of Hillcrest, of a neighborhood united to improve itself, has been subverted.
"Two years ago, Hillcrest didn't exist," Mr. Chavis said. "It was just another area in Maplewood." The association was formed after the township decided to institute one-way streets in Hillcrest, Mr. Chavis said, which the residents beat back.
 
Rejected Speed Bumps
 From there, residents banded together, creating block associations and instituting a neighborhood newsletter, to form their own solutions, Mr. Pettis said.
"On 'Donahue,' people said why not try speed bumps or other things," Mr. Chavis said. " We thought of speed bumps, but snow plows wouldn't be able to get through. We thought of ornamental planters or something like that, but we realized we needed something that could be opened if necessary in an emergency. So we came up with the gates."
The paradox of being called elitist and racist does not escape Mr. Pettis, who is black, or Mr. Chavis, a white civil rights advocate who directs the Center for Social and Community Development at Rutgers University and works organizing communities in Newark and Camden.
"Hillcrest is 50 percent black," said Mr. Pettis, a New York banker who has lived in the neighborhood for more than seven years. "And it's not upper middle-class by any stretch of the imagination."
It doesn't help, he said, that the situation between Maplewood and Newark is being lumped with other controversies. On "Donahue," he said, he felt uncomfortable on a panel that included residents and officials from two communities in Long Beach, Calif. -- one affluent and white, the other Mexican -- feuding over a proposed wall. "Racism and elitism do exist," he said. "But that's not what we've been about."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirrors Family Ties Fade

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Management changes announced last week at the Times Mirror Company accelerated an evolution that is changing one of the largest family-dominated media empires in the country.
The company's president, David Laventhol, said he was stepping down and two senior vice presidents were given new responsibilities and titles in what was widely seen as the start of a competition over who will succeed the company's chairman, Robert F. Erburu, who is 63 and is expected to retire in two years. 
 Mr. Erburu, a longtime adviser and intimate of Times Mirror's founding Chandler family, is likely to be the last chairman with such close ties to the Chandlers. The transformation is likely to leave the company with a cadre of professional managers who are less concerned with the influence of the family and more concerned with hard numbers.
For generations since 1882, the Chandler stewardship of the company's flagship, The Los Angeles Times, virtually defined the power that can go with control of an important newspaper. Times Mirror sold shares to the public beginning in 1964.
 
The Signs of Change
 Chandler family members remain on the company's board and own about one-third of the company, though they control 54 percent of shareholder voting power. Still, the "corporatization" of Times Mirror has been under way for years as the company has grown, felt shareholder pressure and, more recently, been pushed to control costs because of sagging advertising revenues.
After this next step in the transformation, the new generation of managers will be measured against a family standard that for decades has included a commitment to journalistic excellence.
In addition to The Los Angeles Times, the company owns Newsday on Long Island and in New York City and newspapers in Baltimore, Hartford and elsewhere. The company, which derives about half its $3.7 billion in revenues from newspapers, has been enormously influential in helping to define the future format of newspapers.
The emerging group of managers will also be watched for decisions that could affect newspapers nationally. In Baltimore, for example, the company has long been toying with whether to preserve that city's valued Evening Sun as well as its morning sister publication. In New York, some analysts say, new managers might be tempted to review the company's resolve to support its expensive nine-year effort to make New York Newsday a financial success.
Mr. Laventhol, who is suffering from Parkinson's disease, is stepping down on Jan. 1 as president of Times Mirror and as publisher of The Los Angeles Times. He is to remain a member of the board.
Because of the types of managers now rising within the company, his departure is likely to be seen as the final phase in the company's move away from the Chandler family's direct involvement in management. Otis Chandler, the last of the Chandlers to be so involved, stepped down as chairman in 1986.
 
Experience From Outside
 The two men who are said to be in the running for the top job are both 49 years old -- Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, an executive for many years at small newspaper companies who has recently been running Times Mirror's Eastern newspapers, and Curtis A. Hessler, a former vice chairman of the Unisys Corporation who joined Times Mirror in 1991.
What may be more significant than their relative youth, however, is the broad experience both men bring from places other than Times Mirror. Mr. Schlosberg is seen as ahead in the competition because he was named to take over Mr. Laventhol's high-visibility responsibilities as publisher of The Los Angeles Times.
But some securities analysts said it was possible that Times Mirror could turn to a complete outsider. Analysts said last week that the emergence of a new generation of professional managers was welcome at a company that has come under criticism in recent years for weak financial performance. Last year, Times Mirror reported a loss of $67 million after one-time charges that included employee buyouts. Largely because of the recession, it has seen operating profit from its newspapers shrink from a high of $377 million in 1987 to $126 million last year.
Kenneth T. Berents, an analyst at Wheat, First Securities, said Times Mirror had been known as a company with excellent properties but, recently, not excellent financial results. As it shifts toward the first group of managers without family links, Mr. Berents said, the financial community expects a more cold-blooded management style.
"You will see this company much more focused on the bottom line, whoever replaces the current management," he said.
 
A Source of Success
 Some in the industry do not welcome such changes. They say the historical success of family-dominated newspaper companies came partly from the managers' ability to separate the drive for profit from the drive for quality. Some of those strengths are lost, they say, if professional managers, struggling to meet traditional business benchmarks, lose sight of journalistic values.
The Los Angeles Times, sharply conservative and stridently anti-union through most of its history, is often cited as an example of the success of family management. Otis Chandler, who was its publisher from 1960 to 1980, was widely credited with turning what had been a financially successful but parochial publication into a world-class newspaper.
It has often been said that Mr. Chandler was driven largely by a personal sense of ambition for the newspaper. He had the confidence to try to improve The Los Angeles Times, some writers have said, because his family's place in California and American history was so closely linked to the newspaper's success.
Mr. Erburu, the current chairman, was a lawyer at a firm that has long represented Chandler interests. Since 1961, he has been a top executive at the company, helping design a strategy to diversify by buying major media properties across the country. Some analysts say Mr. Erburu has governed in the style of a family member.
Mr. Erburu is active, for example, on a host of civic and charity boards. Among his moves was the promotion of Mr. Laventhol, a unique figure in American newspapering, to the second-highest position in the company.
 
New Definitions of News
 In a long career as a respected editor at such newspapers as Newsday and The New York Herald Tribune, Mr. Laventhol pioneered new approaches to news that are now widely accepted.
Know as a believer in articles about life style issues, he helped redefine newspaper coverage that by the 1950's was considered dry and predictable. In 1968, he designed The Washington Post's Style section, which had broad influence nationally and is still a much-praised "soft news" element of The Post's coverage.
In a time when few former editors reach the top ranks of newspaper corporations, Mr. Laventhol is finishing his career near the top. Among other jobs, he has been Newsday's publisher, a Times Mirror corporate executive and its president since 1987.
"Laventhol," said Gerald D. Reilly, a newspaper consultant, "is one of the few left at that level who is really from an editorial background." Some in the industry say the increasing power of executives with little experience in the news side of newspapers is one result of the growing control by big corporations.
Mr. Laventhol, who has supervised cutbacks that have shrunk The Los Angeles Times staff by 23 percent over three years and closed its San Diego edition, is no sentimentalist. But he is known for a keen sense of the journalistic ambitions that make news organizations work.
 
Newsday's Big Move
 The ambition he is most closely associated with was the decision during the 1980's to move Newsday, the highly successful Long Island newspaper, into competition with New York City newspapers by starting New York Newsday, in essence a separate newspaper.
New York Newsday loses millions of dollars a year. As soon as the news of Mr. Laventhol's departure from the company presidency spread last week, newspaper people were speculating about whether the company might now take a harder view of the New York losses.
Robert M. Johnson, Newsday's publisher, quickly said the impact of Mr. Laventhol's departure was "none." Mr. Johnson, 48, was one of those whose chances for a top Times Mirror position appeared to be stalled by the new corporate responsibilities parceled out last week to Mr. Schlosberg and Mr. Hessler. Both were named executive vice presidents. Mr. Erburu is to assume Mr. Laventhol's title of president.
In recent interviews, both Mr. Erburu and Mr. Schlosberg said in the strongest terms that they would not consider withdrawing from New York. "We're committed to New York Newsday. Period," Mr. Erburu said.
But, in answer to a question about Times Mirror's financial results recently, Mr. Erburu acknowledged that the company had been feeling pressure. "When you go through a period like this, it's very disconcerting and no one is very happy about it," he said. "But the fundamentals are very sound."
The issue for Times Mirror is whether the next person who sits in Mr. Erburu's chair will agree.
