HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A survey says that cause-oriented campaigns don't just make people feel good, they work, too.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
CONSUMERS consider advertising and promotional campaigns that try to do well by doing good to be believable and effective, according to the results of what is thought to be the first comprehensive survey of public attitudes about this increasingly popular marketing trend.
Among the 1,981 people interviewed for the national survey, 66 percent said it was somewhat or very acceptable for companies to participate in what is known as cause-related marketing or point-of-purchase politics. By contrast, 17 percent said it was not very, or not at all, acceptable; the remaining 17 percent said it depended or they did not know. 
 The practice encompasses a broad range of programs by which companies seek to sell their goods and services by also offering to help social, charitable and political organizations. Usually, the causes being benefited are widely supported, like fighting homelessness, crime, pollution and hunger. Sometimes, though, the campaigns take sides on hotly disputed issues like abortion, gay rights and gun control. Among the best-known cause-related marketers are American Express, Ben & Jerry's Homemade, Body Shop International and Members Only.
The survey was conducted in August by the Roper Starch Worldwide market research company in New York for Cone Communications, a marketing and public relations agency based in Boston that specializes in cause-related campaigns for clients like Avon Products, which sponsors a program called the Breast Cancer Awareness Crusade, and Ryka Inc., a footwear company with a foundation to combat violence against women.
"We were talking to companies about cause-related marketing," Carol L. Cone, the chief executive of Cone, recalled during an interview last week, "and they wanted to know: 'Will it create brand loyalty? Will it cause people to switch brands?' We didn't have the answers."
Edward B. Keller, an executive vice president at Roper Starch, said: "It's a coming issue that needed to be better understood and documented. And we wanted to get some benchmark figures, so we can track this over time."
Ms. Cone said the survey's "most surprising factor" was the relative strength of corporate social responsibility as a reason people gave when asked what they considered when buying brands.
"It's now in the second tier of important purchase influences," she added, though reasons like past experience, price and quality remained far more important. In response to questions asking about the likelihood to switch if price and quality were equal, 66 percent said they were somewhat or very likely to switch brands "based on a good cause," while 62 percent said they were somewhat or very likely to switch retail stores.
Ms. Cone said she was "pleasantly amazed" at the relative lack of cynicism about the motives of marketers who practice point-of-purchase politics. Seventy-one percent of the respondents agreed somewhat or strongly that it "is a good way to help solve social problems," and 64 percent agreed somewhat or strongly that it "should be a standard part of a company's activities."
Twenty percent said they bought something in the last year "because it was associated with a cause or issue." That figure doubled among so-called influentials -- trend-setting, socially active consumers.
Still, there was some skepticism. When asked whether cause-related marketing was "just for show to improve the company's image," 58 percent agreed somewhat or strongly.
And 62 percent said marketers should demonstrate they actually believed in the causes and issues they embraced by becoming involved for more than a year or by making similarly long-term commitments. Ms. Cone termed that significant because such campaigns were often short-term promotions.
While the survey explored the aspects of what Mr. Keller called "standing for something your customers stand for, to let them feel buying your product is an expression of their commitment," one intriguing topic that went unmeasured was whether people shun marketers that take stances on issues at odds with their own opinions. He said he hoped to address that in the next survey, which he and Ms. Cone plan to conduct in two years.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Traders Shrug Off Job Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With its response to the stronger- than-expected November job data reported on Friday, the bond market seemed to be saying, "O.K., we already know that the fourth quarter is going to be strong."
The increase in nonfarm payroll jobs of 208,000 was more than the consensus forecast of 180,000. In addition, the factory workweek rose to 41.7 hours, a post-World War II high; construction jobs increased, and manufacturing jobs rose for a second month. 
 These factors suggested that there would be a good jump in industrial production this month and added support for a forecast of a 4 percent or more growth rate in the gross domestic product for the last three months of this year.
Despite the job news -- a strong economy worries bond traders about the risk of inflation -- bond prices closed higher on Friday, after an initial round of selling. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ended the day at 6.23 percent, down from 6.28 percent on Thursday.
 
News May Have Been Digested
 "People are finding that the economy is picking up, but the news does not tell them that the economy is picking up more than their expectations," said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
If traders and investors have finally accepted that outlook, a moderate jump of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index, due out Thursday, and a similar increase in the Consumer Price Index, due Friday, should allow the market to hold its own or even rally a bit.
But the data on new jobs did not provide much insight into next year and, therefore, did not dampen the fears that a firm first quarter of 1994 could force the Federal Reserve Board to quickly raise its short-term interest rate target, which has been 3 percent for more than a year.
Other data released on Friday might cause additional concern along this line. Car and truck sales showed that the strong pace of October was sustained in November. In the last 10 days of November, car sales were at an annual rate of 7.5 million, while truck sales were at 5.9 million. For the month of November, cars sold at an annual rate of 7.1 million, matching October, and trucks were at 5.6 million, up from 5.4 million.
This pace means that the production schedule in the first quarter of 1994 may not be high enough to keep car and truck inventories from falling too low. If the car makers increase production, all other things left unchanged, current economic forecasts would have to be raised. Because many forecasters are betting on a slowdown in the first quarter from the pace in the fourth quarter, such an increase in automobile production could cause problems by making it more likely that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates.
This concern seems clear in current short-term interest rate levels. The yield on the two-year Treasury note, which is sensitive to Federal Reserve possibilities, finished at 4.20 percent on Friday, its highest level since the summer.
The discount rates on three- and six-month Treasury bills are near their highest levels since the end of last year, when traders and investors were worried that strong growth in the fourth quarter would spill over into 1993 (which, of course, it did not). On Friday, the discount rate was 3.10 percent on the three-month bill and 3.26 percent on the six-month bill.
One measure of expectations for short-term interest rates compares the three-month and six-month bill rates. With a current three-month rate of 3.10 percent, a 3.42 percent rate is needed in the second three months of a six-month bill to pull the rate for the entire six months up to 3.26 percent. That implied 3.42 percent rate three months from now is more than a quarter of a percentage point higher than current three-month rates. So, traders concluded that buyers were assuming that the Fed would raise its 3 percent interest rate target.
 
Not Always Clairvoyant
 Treasury bill rates are being pushed higher by other factors, including the Government's increased reliance on short-term borrowing to cover the budget deficit, as the end of the year nears. But the levels are still a good barometer of market concern, even if they are often wrong as an indication of what the Federal Reserve actually winds up doing.
"The sentiment has moved to the side that it will be sooner than later," said Darwin L. Beck, director of the economics department at CS First Boston Corporation. "If the economy moves up to 3-percent-to-4-percent growth rates next year, the Fed will not hold off."
With such concerns in the market, the inflation reports this week are more important for shorter maturities. Mr. Beck forecasts a one-tenth of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index, over all, and a still moderate two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the so-called core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices.
Such a report would surely ease inflation concerns on the heels of a jump of four-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index in October. With 11 months of the year counted, inflation would be up just 2.7 percent at an annual rate, still below the 2.9 pace of 1992. But another tick up -- an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent -- could intensify fears of Fed action.
"A big C.P.I. number would reinforce the view of a Fed tightening sooner rather than later," Mr. Beck said.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Wisconsin Is on Top a World Away

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 5

 BODY:
For Wisconsin, the road to the Rose Bowl wound through the back streets of the Ginza and redefined Big 10 football's idea of an away game.
As vendors sold sushi in the stands, Wisconsin pushed through Michigan State's weak defensive line today and won a fairly painless victory, 41-20. The triumph gave Wisconsin a 9-1-1 record for the season and a place in the Rose Bowl against U.C.L.A., the first trip to Pasadena, Calif., for the Badgers in 31 years. 
 Wisconsin's long drought actually served as a Big Ten tie breaker. Wisconsin and Ohio State finished with identical records and played to a tie during the season. But under Big Ten rules, it is Wisconsin's turn to play in the Rose Bowl because Ohio State went to Pasadena more recently, in 1985.
Tokyo is not the ordinary venue for decisive games; ask most Japanese about the Big Ten and they will tick off the world's largest electronics firms. But the game, the annual Coca-Cola Bowl here, was scheduled more than two years ago, when the $400,000 gate guarantee and an offer to pay the teams' way over sounded particularly good to a mediocre Wisconsin squad.
 
Governor Makes the Trip
 By game time, some Wisconsin fans began to complain that the biggest matchup in a generation would be played half a world away. But hundreds of others flew here to watch the game, including Wisconsin's Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who, mindful of where he was visiting, brought a trade mission in tow. With a surprisingly stiff recession still gripping Japan, the trade team seems likely to run into a significantly better-organized defensive line in Japan than the Badgers did.
"Coming to Tokyo actually worked to our benefit," said Barry Alvarez, Wisconsin's coach, who had the team practicing at 11:30 P.M. back in Madison, Wis., in an attempt to combat jet lag. "There were fewer distractions than at home where everybody was already looking past this game to the Rose Bowl. We were able to control our kids, and focus on this game first."
The two who focused best were Brent Moss and Terrell Fletcher, who ran for two touchdowns each. Moss rushed for 152 yards in the game, and Fletcher picked up 133. Meanwhile, Darrell Bevell, the Wisconsin quarterback, completed 14 of the 19 passes as Wisconsin piled up more than 500 yards in offense.
The Badgers' only trouble came in the first quarter, when Michigan grabbed an early 7-3 lead on a 33-yard touchdown pass from Jim Miller to Mill Coleman.
 
The Tide Turns
 Michigan State threatened again, but Wisconsin's Scott Nelson picked off a Miller pass and the tide quickly turned, with Fletcher's 1-yard touchdown run putting the Badgers ahead, 10-7, with 9 minutes 21 seconds left in the first half.
By halftime, Wisconsin had a 17-point lead, 24-7. In the fourth quarter, Michigan State put a brief scare into the Badgers by closing the gap to 14 points, 34-20, on a 33-yard field goal and then recovered a well-executed onside kick. But on the next play, a pass by Miller was intercepted by the Badgers' Ken Gales. Wisconsin then marched 92 yards for a the game's final score.
"That interception late in the game iced it all for us," Alvarez said.
 
Some Japanese Badgers
 Wisconsin, it turned out, enjoys a surprisingly large following in Tokyo. The Tokyo Dome, usually the home of the Yomiuri Giants, Japan's most famous baseball team, was sold out, with a crowd of 51,000. Among them were several hundred Japanese who have graduated from Wisconsin and some of the more than 30,000 American expatriates living here.
"The year I graduated, 1953, was the first time Wisconsin ever went to the Rose Bowl," said Keith G. Johnson, who now runs one of the largest American-Japanese joint ventures, Shin Caterpillar Mitsubishi.
Wisconsin lost that game, 7-0, to Southern Cal. It lost in Pasadena again, in 1960, to Washington by a score of 44-8 and then fell to Southern Cal, 42-37, in 1963. Now, after 31 years, the Badgers get another chance. "It's been a long, long time," said Johnson.
Not that that fact was foremost on everyone's mind. At today's game, fans could try one of Japan's best, and least publicized, technological innovations: the portable beer keg.
Then there was the play by play, which came over the loudspeaker in two languages, and the Wisconsin fans, themselves, who walked around Tokyo's biggest stadium wearing styrofoam hats that looked like giant blocks of cheddar cheese -- the famous cheeseheads.
Such exuberance is rare in Japan, especially in public stadiums, and the natives were a little mystified. But now they know: Wisconsin is going to the Rose Bowl.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mad City Goes Bonkers
 MADISON, Wis., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two police cars were damaged after thousands of Wisconsin football fans surged into the streets early today in a wild celebration of their team's Rose Bowl-clinching victory in Tokyo.
Fans poured out of bars, restaurants and dormitories onto nearby State Street, the main drag between the Wisconsin campus and State Capitol building, for a raucous demonstration that included the repeated singing of "On, Wisconsin," the school's fight song, and shouts of "Rose Bowl! Rose Bowl!"
But less innocent forms of celebration led to 14 arrests, the police said.
About 3,000 fans made their way to Camp Randall Stadium, where one group tried to bring down the goal posts. Fans at the stadium said the specter of the Oct. 30 post-game stampede, in which dozens were hurt after a Badger victory, kept today's celebration from being even wilder.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Reaches for Iron Rule

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It has been suggested that the elections for Parliament and a new constitution in Russia on Dec. 12 will provide the democratic legitimacy needed by President Boris N. Yeltsin and his economic advisers to take the tough decisions necessary to revitalize the Russian economy ("Runaway Rubles," by Anders Aslund, Op-Ed, Nov. 24). 
 But the circumstances under which these elections are being carried out, and the nature of the constitution to be approved, indicate that what is really in the making is a new form of authoritarian rule in Russia. This is no surprise, for it is not the absence but the presence of democracy that constitutes the greater obstacle to Mr. Yeltsin's strategy of radical economic reform.
This strategy calls for strict government budgetary austerity and rapid liquidation of unprofitable enterprises, which would have the predictable consequence of generating mass unemployment and even greater social and economic distress than the Russians are experiencing. This kind of economic "shock therapy" is extremely unpopular, especially among workers, retirees and all those women and men who are already suffering and would be hardest hit by accelerated dislocation.
Any Russian government responsive to the democratically expressed preferences of its citizenry would search far and wide for an alternative strategy of transition that would not impose such huge immediate costs on so many people. The opposition that the Yeltsin administration has encountered in trying to implement its economic reforms thus has far deeper roots than some obstreperous old Communist elites and their allies in the disbanded Parliament.
Contrary to Mr. Aslund's view, the only way in which President Yeltsin and his economic advisers will be able to impose their radical economic reform policies is by taking advantage of their current political hegemony and by wielding the enormous power afforded to the executive by their proposed new constitution.
Those Westerners who believe that shock therapy is indispensable for the long-run health of the Russian economy, whatever the short-run pain it causes, may take some comfort from the new political order in Russia; but they should honestly admit (as do some of their Russian counterparts) that what they are getting is a Russian General Pinochet.
As for those of us who believe in the potential for democracy and for an alternative -- more gradual and more humane -- transition to a mar
ket economy in Russia, we can only lament what is happening now, and hope against hope that it does not permanently set back the cause of democracy and economic revitalization in that long-troubled country.
 
THOMAS E. WEISSKOPF
Prof. of Economics, U. of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Mich., Nov. 29, 1993

HEADLINE: Essay;
Looking Beyond Peace

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PARK RIDGE, N.J.

 BODY:
"There's a story behind every one of those ornaments," said Richard Nixon, looking more robust than he has in years, showing me the Christmas tree in his home. Lest sentiment intrude, he quickly turned to the purpose of my annual visit: a review, parts on the record, of what's ahead.
Stacked on his desk is the manuscript of his latest book. On the 20th of next month (the 25th anniversary of his first Inaugural Address), the 37th President, who will then be 81, will bring out "Beyond Peace." The theme of this 150-pager -- likely to be his eighth nonfiction best seller, a publishing record -- is: "After peace breaks out, we usually have periods of stagnation; we must find challenges as stimulating as war." 
 Nixon, in his nonpartisan years, has not lurched leftward: "When the rest of the world is turning away from big government, we shouldn't be turning toward it. The problem with 'reinventing government' is that they want government to be doing better the things that government shouldn't be doing in the first place."
He hopes that Bill Clinton keeps his centrist Nafta coalition together, dropping the McGovernite left over the side. But do voters really care about foreign economic policy? That's not the point: "The public's interest in Nafta was not in the issue, but in the battle."
Though the battlefield on which Clinton feels most at home is domestic affairs, Nixon -- the old Moscow summiteer -- thinks this President should not hesitate to share what he has recently learned in the Nafta fight with Boris Yeltsin at next month's Moscow summit.
"Clinton could give Yeltsin good counsel," says Nixon, "on how to deal within a multi-party system. It's the kind of hard-earned advice that Yeltsin can use now."
Can we help relieve the tension building between Russia and Ukraine? "Our line to Ukraine should not be to deal with them just because they have nuclear weapons, but because they have 55 million people and you don't want a rogue state." He's high on Ukraine's Kravchuk, and thinks the U.S could be a broker in the delicate nuclear disarmament.
Nixon has urged Yeltsin to press ahead on privatization. "To paraphrase Churchill, the free market is the worst economic system except for all the others. But the central question in Russia is: Can democratic capitalism provide progress better than Communist capitalism, the kind they have in China?"
He gave me a mock-suspicious look. "Weren't you the one who put me up to saying 'We are all Keynesians now'? Well, we are all capitalists now. If democratic capitalism fails in Russia, that will be water on China's wheels." That's why we should encourage reform, a movement greater than individual reformers, in Russia.
What about India, a democratic nation, where capitalism is lagging? "India, which will be more populous than China in the next century, must ask itself this question: Can democratic socialism compete with Communist capitalism?" To pose the question is to answer it -- only capitalism, however modified, can compete with capitalism -- but I had never heard it posed before.
Nixon is too much the pragmatist on China, preferring quiet diplomacy and bonds of trade to public pressure on human rights: "Economic freedom will open up any closed society."
But his newer theme is "there isn't any third world anymore. Only two worlds, rich and poor. Wealth divides China, East and West Europe, the north and south nations."
On hot-button issues at home, he remains progressive. Abortion: "The state should stay out; don't subsidize and don't prohibit." Gun control: "I'd go further than the Brady bill. Guns are an abomination." (From this I deduce he is not running in '96.)
On TV violence: "Hollywood thinks America is sick -- hunh! They're the sick ones." He's against the balanced budget amendment -- "a meat ax when you need a stiletto, but it'll probably pass" -- and in favor of term limits: "incumbents have asked for it."
Assessments of the Clinton Presidency and the Republican field, as well as his views on initiatives on health, education and welfare, await appearances at publication time. For now, it's inspiring to see the old warrior using every minute as a golden bullet, staying well by staying productive -- never, never quitting.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
School Meals

 BODY:
The number of free or reduced-price lunches served in the region's schools continues to climb, and breakfast programs for pupils are expanding as part of the federal government's $4 billion-a-year National School Lunch Program. At the same time, the number of paid lunches has fallen, in what state officials call a sign of families' economic struggles. In total, the number of breakfasts served has jumped 35 percent in four years, propelled by heightened concerns about nutrition and educators' belief that it's hard for children to do well if they haven't had something to eat.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2130 words

HEADLINE: A Deal Done in U.S. Style Dazes an Ex-Soviet State

 BODY:
This article is based on reporting by Barry Meier in New York and Raymond Bonner in Tbilisi, Georgia, and was written by Mr. Meier.
Three years ago, a fledgling New York company persuaded officials in the former Soviet republic of Georgia to give it an exclusive 25-year contract to erect an elaborate international telephone system that would bring the world a dial tone away. 
 What Georgia has received so far is a system that lets only six people call internationally at once. There are also stacks of telecommunications equipment sitting on the lawn of the nation's parliament building.
After the Georgian Government changed hands last year, officials there concluded that the Videotel Think Tank Corporation of Hempstead, L.I., was not up to the task. So they terminated the contract, which the company has valued at $45 million, they sued it for fraud and they opened talks with American Telephone and Telegraph and other companies.
 
Enlisting Help
 But Videotel, which denied any wrongdoing and blamed Georgia's civil war for its problems, was not ready to give up. The company, which is co-owned by a longtime political associate of Republican Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and a man with a criminal record, has unleashed a counterattack led by advocates ranging from Caspar Weinberger, the former Defense Secretary, to Harold M. Ickes, an adviser to President Clinton, and a prestigious New York Law firm.
As a result, in the midst of Georgia's war, the United States Ambassador to Georgia, Kent Brown, flew to the front last month to visit Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Georgia's leader, and asked him to restore the company's satellite link.
 
Favoritism Is Denied
 "We want to make sure that foreign markets are open to American companies and contracts are respected," said Strobe Talbott, Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet republics. He and other American Government officials insist that they took no special action on Videotel's behalf.
The dispute over Videotel, a tiny company of seven employees, which has never installed a public telephone system and has no profits or sizable office of its own, reflects the rough-and-tumble nature of doing business in former Communist countries.
Along with producing lawsuits worldwide, the fight has engulfed the World Bank. Last year, the bank described Videotel in a memo as a "bottleneck" to Georgia's future and indicated concerns about its exclusive telephone contract. But Videotel has since lobbied the bank to withhold a $40 million loan to upgrade Georgia's telephone service until officials there honor the company's pact.
"We are caught in a whirlwind between a company and a Government," said a World Bank official who insisted on not being identified. The loan, which could provide a bonanza to tiny Videotel, is still pending.
That a company like Videotel could muster such legal and lobbying barrage might appear surprising. But then, the owners of Videotel -- Easa Easa and Joseph L. Schwartz -- are unusual men.
 
The Partners
No Strangers To Controversy
 Until his retirement a year ago, Mr. Easa, 63, had served for 18 years as head of Nassau County's Regional Offtrack Betting Corporation, a political patronage plum with flexible hours and an annual salary of $139,000. A lawyer, Mr. Easa, who declined to be interviewed, is a longtime Republican leader in the town of West Hempstead and an old friend of Senator D'Amato.
Mr. Schwartz, a computer consultant, said in an interview that he met Mr. Easa in the late 1970's while developing data transmission networks for OTB operations. He said that Videotel was formed in 1988 to build computer networks, but changed gears after learning of Georgia's interest in a telephone system. The technologies used to transmit voice and data are similar, he said.
Neither of Videotel's owners is any stranger to controversy. In 1989, Mr. Easa, who is also a real estate developer, agreed to settle a complaint by the New York State Attorney General that he failed to give condominium buyers required disclosures about his business activities.
 
Problems With Checks
 Public records show that Mr. Schwartz, who is Videotel's chief executive, was indicted three times in New York City in 1974 on grand larcency charges involving accusations that he passed more than $300,000 in bad and forged checks.
In separate interviews with two reporters, Mr. Schwartz initially denied that he had a criminal record. But when confronted by court records, he said that he believed that the cases had been sealed and that he would never have to discuss them.
Mr. Schwartz, who pleaded guilty under an agreement to two indictments, said he served two months of a one-year prison sentence. "It was a long time ago and I was a fool," he said.
More recently, both Videotel and Georgian Intelcom, its joint venture with the Georgian Government, have had financial problems. Last month, as part of a lawsuit, Videotel agreed to pay $46,000 to IDB Communications Group Inc., of Culver City, Calif., for telecommunications equipment Videotel ordered in 1991.
Videotel stopped payment on a initial $25,000 check for the equipment after it was shipped, said Thomas McDermott, an attorney for IDB. For his part, Mr. Schwartz said the check was stopped because the order never reached Georgia. Others with claims pending against Videotel or its joint venture include Austrian Post, Telephone and Telegraph, which relays Georgian Intelcom's calls, and the Russian Satellite Communications Company, which carried those calls.
 
Georgia's Worry
Who Will Control A Vital Service?
 For Georgian officials, the issue is not simply money but regaining control over a basic service at favorable terms. Videotel's pact gives it 80 percent of any profits from Georgian Intelcom, which provides international phone, telegraph, fax and mail service. Videotel invested $240,000 in the venture and Georgia added $60,000. Five of the seven board seats went to Mr. Schwartz, Mr. Easa, their wives and Jack Easa, Mr. Easa's brother and law partner.
"This means that we had lost control of a strategic industry," said Nodar Kharatishvili, the First Deputy in the Georgian Ministry of Communication, which oversees phone service. As did Mr. Kharatishvili, Mr. Shevardnadze said he believed that bribery might have been involved.
"It is either ignorance, huge ignorance, or there is some dirt" Mr. Shevardnadze said in an interview.
Mr. Schwartz rejected such suggestions and said Georgian officials had broken the deal because Videotel would not bribe them. He also said the contract was fair because Videotel had assumed the project's risks. He also said Videotel had recently delivered equipment he estimated to be worth $1 million but Georgian officials had refused to install it.
"I feel like it is a place that is in chaos and everyone does what is best for them and not what is best for the country," Mr. Schwartz said.
 
Expression of Little Confidence
 Last year, when a World Bank team visited Georgia to lay the groundwork for the $40 million loan, it concluded that Videotel appeared to lack the experience and financial backing to fulfill it promises. And the team told Georgian officials to "consider as a matter of urgency their options for the future," according to a bank memo written in October 1992.
In March, the Georgian Government sued Videotel in Federal court in Hempstead, accusing the company of fraud, saying it delivered faulty equipment, siphoned off thousands of the joint venture's dollars to its own bank account and submitted phony invoices. Videotel, which denied the claims, responded with a breach-of-contract lawsuit against Georgia.
Videotel has also sued one of the Georgian Government's American lawyers, saying he had slandered Videotel, and has sued Deutsche Telekom, a German telephone company, contending that it had tried to steal the Georgian business. That case, which was decided against Videotel, is on appeal, Mr. Schwartz said. The suit against the lawyer, Paul Dietrich, is pending; Mr. Dietrich has denied any wrongdoing.
 
Influential Help
Applying Pressure In U.S. and Abroad
 The Park Avenue law firm of Rogers & Wells has represented Videotel, assigning Mr. Weinberger and several other lawyers to the matter. It has also hired Harold M. Ickes, an adviser to President Clinton, and Richard L. Armitage, who, until May, headed the State Department's humanitarian aid programs to the former Soviet republics.
The aim of Videotel was a simple one: to persuade the Georgian Government to restore its valuable contract. The effort's price tag to date is some $2 million in legal and lobbying costs, according to Mr. Schwartz.
United States Embassy officials in Georgia, who initally viewed the matter as a minor fracas, were among those caught in the crossfire. In a recent interview, Ambassador Kent Brown, who visited Mr. Shevardnadze last month on the battlefield, confirmed that he had received a letter about Videotel from Mr. Armitage, who now heads Armitage Associates, a consulting firm. Frederic C. Hof, a member of Mr. Armitage's firm, also contacted embassy officials enclosing letters from his boss to the Georgian leader.
Mr. Hof said Mr. Armitage's firm had not sought to lobby embassy officials. Mr. Ickes's office said he was traveling and unavailable to comment.
 
Getting a Senator's Ear
 The growing interest among Federal officials may also have been stimulated by a call from Easa Easa to Senator D'Amato. Mr. Easa told the Senator that the company's lawyers thought it would be helpful if State and Treasury Department officials were aware of Videotel's problems, according to Frank Coleman, a spokesman for Senator D'Amato.
It is not exactly clear what happened next. But in mid-August, Senator D'Amato wrote to both Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen thanking them for taking an interest in Videotel. Mr. Coleman said the letters were the only action taken by the Senator and were similar to those he would write for any constituent.
"The continuing efforts of this Administration in relation to this matter is very much appreciated," Senator D'Amato wrote.
 
Difficult Position
Loan Quandary For World Bank
 World Bank officials perhaps soon felt the greatest pressure because of the stakes involved with its loan. The $40 million loan is expected to greatly improve Georgia's antiquated domestic telephone service, benefiting Videotel if it retains exclusive international rights to the system.
Videotel's lawyers said they went to the World Bank because they believed that an initial $450,000 lent by the bank to Georgia was being improperly used to, among other things, finance that Government's lawsuit in the United States against Videotel.
The problem soon landed in the lap of Ernest Stern, the World Bank's acting president. On Aug. 12, Mr. Weinberger wrote to Mr. Stern, suggesting that if Georgia nullified Videotel's contract then the member of the bank's board from the Treasury Department would, under Federal law, be required to oppose any future loans to Georgia.
"I am sure that we can agree that Georgia's abrogation of a binding contract with an American company would have severe ramifications," Mr. Weinberger wrote on Aug. 12. Mr. Weinberger did not respond to requests for comment.
In late September, bank officials wrote to Mr. Shevardnadze stating that their position on Videotel's skills and future in Georgia was "neutral." But a bank executive, who insisted on remaining anonymous, said Videotel's lobbying had not influenced its position.
"We are not anti-Videotel," that official said. "It's just that the telecommunications' environment in Georgia would benefit from a more competitive approach."
Despite the warnings of Videotel's well-connected advocates, more competition is likely. Companies including A.T.& T. have recently agreed to nonexclusive contracts with the Georgian Government that will provide international phone service at far lower rates to consumers and bigger returns to the Government.
Mr. Schwartz has said that Videotel is open to negotiating with Georgian officials.
For his part, Mr. Shevardnadze said the company would have to operate without its exclusive contract.
All may not be lost for Videotel's owners, Mr. Easa and Mr. Schwartz. Should the Georgian Government have to buy out Videotel's contract, they could profit handsomely. While the two sides fight in court, Mr. Shevardnadze said that in deference to American officials, he had decided not to investigate the company.
"I did not want to create a scandal, because this company is associated with America and they are our great friend," Mr. Shevardnadze said.

HEADLINE: PITTSBURGH BANK IS BUYING DREYFUS FOR $1.85 BILLION

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Dreyfus Corporation, the country's sixth-largest mutual fund company, for $1.85 billion in stock.
Like many big banks, Pittsburgh-based Mellon is trying to move away from the traditional business of taking deposits and making loans, which represents a declining share of the nation's financial activity. This year, for the first time, the nearly $2 trillion in mutual funds equals the amount on deposit at the nation's banks. 
 "Lending is a no-growth business," said Livia S. Asher, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "If you look at demographics, what's growing is managing money for the aging population."
 
Banks Have Started Funds
 Many large banks have started mutual funds to lure customers discouraged by the low interest rates earned on savings accounts and money market funds. But Mellon, which is paying a steep price for Dreyfus, is being more aggressive than most. Other banks, including Chase Manhattan, have bought smaller mutual fund companies to add to their product lines. And some, like Nationsbank, have formed joint ventures with securities companies.
But no other bank company has more than $20 billion in mutual fund assets under management. Dreyfus manages $80 billion in more than 130 mutual funds. The PNC Bank Corporation, also of Pittsburgh, will be a distant second in mutual fund assets under management, with $18.8 billion.
Frank V. Cahouet, Mellon's chairman, said he hoped that after the acquisition, 60 percent of Mellon's $3 billion in revenue would come from fees rather than from interest payments on loans. That compares with less than one-third at most banks.
Mellon already manages $135 billion in assets, mostly in the form of pension funds. Last year, it bought the Boston Company, which provides administrative services to mutual funds, from American Express for $1.45 billion in cash and stock. And Mellon has also recently acquired more than $8 billion in mortgage portfolios and a finance company.
 
Industry Is Called 'Mature'
 "The pure banking industry is mature and undergoing consolidation, yet the rest of the financial services industry is growing rapidly," Mr. Cahouet said.
While Depression-era laws are meant to keep banks out of the securities business, regulators have allowed them to use a legal loophole to offer their own mutual funds.
For its part, Dreyfus has been a leader in money market funds but has been slow to tap into the explosive growth of stock funds. It is one of the few mutual fund companies whose assets have declined in recent years. Moreover, Howard Stein, Dreyfus's chairman, is 67, which may be a reason why he decided to sell now.
The move by banks into mutual funds is in some ways reminiscent of the trend a decade ago to create "financial supermarkets," when companies like American Express, Prudential Insurance and Sears, Roebuck bought brokerage firms. Those deals generally did not produce the synergies their sponsors hoped for.
Mellon and Dreyfus executives did speak of offering credit cards and mortgages to Dreyfus customers and selling Dreyfus funds in Mellon branches. Nonetheless, in many ways this transaction is aimed less at synergies and is more an effort by Mellon to diversify away from banking.
Executives of the two companies predicted little in the way of efficiencies from the merger. Dreyfus has contracts with the Bank of New York and First Data Resources to provide custody and administrative services for its funds. It will be several years before those functions can be moved into Mellon operations.
"Both organizatons are growing and we can hold costs flat and grow revenues," Mr. Cahouet said.
Mellon approached Dreyfus with a merger proposal four or five months ago, and entered intense negotiations last month. On Nov. 11, however, Dreyfus cut off the discussion, largely because its management was concerned about how much autonomy it would have after the merger. Last week, Mr. Cahouet met with Mr. Stein, who was on vacation in California, and reassured him that Dreyfus management would remain largely independent. The deal was struck last Friday and announced yesterday morning.
 
Mellon Stock Falls
 Mellon estimated that its earnings per share would be reduced 9 percent next year and that the transaction would not increase earnings per share until 1996. Many investors were skeptical that the company would be able to meet even those projections. Mellon's stock yesterday closed down $2.375, at $53, while Dreyfus's shares gained $1.875, to $46.375.
"The market will need a lot more confidence that they can find the cost savings and revenue enhancements," said Joseph Duwan of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a brokerage firm that specializes in banks.
An unusual feature of the transaction is that Dreyfus has accumulated $750 million in cash, which will be added to Mellon's capital. The bank said that its financial projections require that it earn an 11 percent return on that capital, a level that struck many analysts as high.
"A conservative figure would be half that," said Ms. Asher of Merrill Lynch. Nonetheless, Ms. Asher said the overall deal should produce an average return for Mellon. "It's not a home run, but it doesn't destroy their value," she said.
Moreover, many analysts praised Mellon's effort to expand out of traditional lending. "Ten years ago, Mellon was mainly a corporate lender," Ms. Asher said. "Mellon has made great strides in moving away from traditional banking."
The transaction involves some fancy legal footwork, because the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act prohibits banks from sponsoring a mutual fund. But since banks can choose investments, sell funds and provide computer support to funds, all Mellon will have to do is use an independent company yet to be chosen to provide the largely ceremonial function of sponsoring the funds. Banks typically pay one-tenth of 1 percent to one-fifth of 1 percent of the funds' assets a year to the firm that acts as a sponsor.
Federal regulators generally accept banks' entry into the mutual fund business, but have grown increasingly concerned that bank customers may not fully understand the risks of the funds in which they invest and may think that the funds are insured by the Federal Government, which they are not.
To meet these concerns, Mellon expects to propose a strict code of conduct for its sales activities.
The acquisition is expected to have little effect on Dreyfus or Mellon customers, other than to fill their mailboxes with more financial offers. Mellon already offers its own family of funds in its 450 branches.

HEADLINE: Zuckerman Is Given Deadline of 90 Days To Deal for Coliseum

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins joined with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday in giving the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman 90 days to close on his deal to buy and build on the New York Coliseum site at Columbus Circle or forfeit his $33.8 million down payment.
City officials said the move was an attempt to prompt serious negotiations for a development there, though not necessarily one as large or as expensive as the contract specifies. Under the 1989 contract, Mr. Zuckerman is required to pay $338 million for the site and build a 2.1 million-square-foot office and retail complex. 
 An aide to Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized Mr. Dinkins for trying to force Mr. Zuckerman's hand in the waning days of the Mayor's term. Although Mr. Giuliani will be unable to stop the 90-day clock, his administration will take over before the 90-day limit runs out and, therefore, may be able to negotiate with Mr. Zuckerman over the project.
The Mayor-elect may be more favorably inclined to accommodate the developer, as Mr. Zuckerman's newspaper, The Daily News, endorsed Mr. Giuliani in the mayoral race.
Mr. Dinkins's move was the latest in a brewing feud with Mr. Giuliani on the Mayor's attempts to wrap up major pieces of unfinished city business in the last weeks of his term.
"It is another needless irritant," said Richard Breyers, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, "and an example of decisions that bind our options. We would have rather that negotiations continue than put a 90-day time clock on the discussions."
For more than a year, the Dinkins administration has had the ability to force Mr. Zuckerman's hand on the matter, as the transportation authority has tried to do since the last legal obstacle to the project was removed in September 1992. But until Mr. Dinkins lost the mayoral race, he had argued for continued negotiations with Mr. Zuckerman.
Yesterday, in announcing the 90-day closing notice, Mr. Dinkins said he now agreed with the M.T.A. that the 90-day deadline was the best way to force serious negotiations. Dinkins administration officials denied that the move was an act of retribution because of the Daily News endorsement of Mr. Giuliani.
 
Refers to Revised Plan
 Mr. Zuckerman, speaking from Washington, said he would meet with lawyers to review the closing notice and assess its implications. In recent weeks his partner, Edward Linde, has said that a closing notice would surely lead to a lawsuit by the company so that Mr. Zuckerman would not lose his deposit.
"We are ready to build a development at Columbus Circle that is consistent with the revised plan," said Mr. Zuckerman, referring to yet another revision on his original design that he submitted to the M.T.A. on Nov. 30 in an effort to put off the closing notice.
The new design calls for the project to be much smaller than under the original contract. It would preserve the existing office tower at 10 Columbus Circle and would replace the coliseum itself with about one million square feet of office and retail space.
Without rejecting the latest design proposal outright, the transportation authority and the Economic Development Corporation, which is negotiating on behalf of the city, said the plan did not offer a price for the property and did not give a development timetable.
Under the 1989 contract with the city, Mr. Zuckerman's company, Boston Properties, agreed with the M.T.A. to build a 2.1 million-square-foot complex at the site near the southwest corner of Central Park. But for nearly a year Mr. Zuckerman has maintained that the project was no longer feasible because of the city's depressed real-estate market.
 
Modified Plan Possible
 Both city officials and M.T.A. representatives have acknowledged that the coliseum site is probably no longer worth its original $338 million price tag. Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said it was entirely possible that Boston Properties could present a modified plan that would be acceptable to all parties.
When asked whether Mr. Dinkins was exacting revenge upon Mr. Zuckerman in joining the M.T.A. in issuing the closing notice, Mr. Sullivan said: "We never talked about that. We talked about how to get the site developed."
The closing notice, hand delivered yesterday to the New York offices of Boston Properties, was issued just hours after the M.T.A. and the Dinkins administration reached an agreement that would make the city equal partners in long-term plans for the site. The agreement means that if Mr. Zuckerman fails to close, the city still stands to make millions from the site.
If Mr. Zuckerman does close on the current contract, half the $338 million would be redirected by the city to the M.T.A. for mass-transit improvements, with the balance going to the transportation agency over five years. The agreement also establishes a timetable for discussions among the M.T.A., Boston Properties and the city to try to decide whether an alternative to the existing plan is possible.
Should Boston Properties not close during the 90 days and Mr. Zuckerman is forced to forfeit his $33.8 million down payment, the money would go to the city and then be redirected to the M.T.A. over two years. Moreover, the city would benefit from any revenues the M.T.A. gets from the site, including revenues from the office space, garage and coliseum itself. This income would come after the M.T.A. breaks even on its operating expenses.
Also, Mr. Dinkins yesterday committed $750,000 of city funds for improvements to the coliseum plaza. This amount would be matched by the M.T.A.
Mr. Zuckerman was first named developer of the coliseum site in September 1985. But almost from the moment he unveiled his plans for the 3.4-acre property, the city was hit with a barrage of lawsuits over the plan. Neighborhood residents, environmentalists and others argued that it was too big, and delayed the project through a series of lawsuits.
In 1987 Mr. Zuckerman lost his main office tenant and partner when Salomon Brothers backed out. But the last legal obstacle to the project was put aside in September 1992 when a Federal Appeals Court said the development would not violate Federal Clean Air rules.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "REAL ESTATE: The Four Phases of the New York Coliseum"

1993: On Nov. 30, Mr. Zuckerman submits a new proposal that cuts the amount of space to about one million square feet and preserves the existing office building. The Coliseum would be demolished.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cray Research Does Poorly In Computer Sales to Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Cray Research Inc., America's largest supercomputer company, has fared poorly in recent supercomputer procurements by Japan's Government.
"Cray has sort of been blown out of the water," said Raul Mendez, president of International Systems Research, a supercomputer consulting firm in Tokyo. He said Japanese companies had "bid incredibly low." 
 Japan's Government is now buying 11 supercomputers as part of an effort to stimulate the nation's slumping economy through increased public spending. The United States Government, which has complained that Japanese Government procurements are not fair, has said it is watching the bidding very carefully.
Already seven of the 11 contracts have been announced, and three of the winning machines are American-made. But the results show a pattern that Washington has expressed disapproval of in the past, in which American machines are bought only when there is no Japanese competition.
Cray won one contract for its C-90 machine in which it was the only bidder. The two other American computers were selected in cases that specified massively parallel processing, a new technology in which Japanese companies barely compete.
 
Japanese Bids Win
 But in four cases in which Cray's conventional supercomputers competed directly against Japanese machines, Fujitsu won three times and Hitachi Ltd. once.
Tak Kato, manager of strategic marketing for Cray's Japanese subsidiary, said the Japanese companies had been "cutting their prices very substantially."
Mr. Kato said that Tsukuba University, for instance, had budgeted four billion yen, or about $37 million, for its procurement, but Fujitsu won with an offer of less than two billion yen. A similar pattern occurred in the bidding for the Angstrom Technology Partnership, a Government-affiliated research project, he said. Cray, however, has not lodged any complaints about the procurements.
Fujitsu officials said they were not allowed to discuss their prices, since that information could be disclosed only by the buyer. But they insisted the company competed fairly and won because of the innovative design of its VPP-500 computer, which combines aspects of parallel processing with a more conventional technique known as vector processing.
Since a 1990 supercomputer trade agreement was signed by the United States and Japan, American companies have won three bids out of 15 from Japan's Government, not counting the latest procurements. But all the victories were uncontested.
Still, the NEC Corporation, one of Japan's three supercomputer companies, has fared even worse than Cray, winning no bids so far. And American companies are virtually guaranteed several sales of massively parallel machines, in which hundreds or thousands of processors work on a problem together to increase speed.
 
No Competing Bids
 An agricultural research institute is buying a computer sold by the Digital Equipment Corporation and designed by the Maspar Computer Corporation. The institute required software that was available only on the Digital Equipment machine, so there were no competing bids.
The third winning American machine is made by the Thinking Machines Corporation.
Japanese officials have long complained that the American supercomputer market is closed. Indeed, the United States Government has never bought a Japanese supercomputer.

HEADLINE: Premier of Haiti Is Seeking Talks To End Impasse

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Groping for a way out of the political impasse that has resulted in crippling sanctions on his country, the Prime Minister of the Government of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide today invited representatives of a cross section of Haiti's society to a new round of negotiations intended to restore democratic rule.
But the Prime Minister, Robert Malval, said that he has yet to receive any assurances from Haiti's military leaders that they will send representatives to this new conference or abide by its decisions. Indeed, Mr. Malval said he did not sense in the country's military leaders a new willingness to compromise on the return of Father Aristide, the exiled president. 
 Mr. Malval also said that he has agreed to stay on in an acting capacity after his resignation, which he announced last week, takes effect on Dec. 15. That news produced a flicker of optimism from Clinton Administration officials, who have been stymied in their efforts to find some way of breaking the impasse. The Administration had worried that if Mr. Malval left office, the Government of Haiti would be left entirely in the hands of the military, which ousted Father Aristide in 1991.
Mr. Malval and Father Aristide later met with President Clinton in the White House, where the President expressed his relief that the Prime Minister had decided to stay on.
 
More Flexibility
 One knowledgeable Administration official said that Mr. Malval's resignation was also intended to free him from the sway of President Aristide in order to be more flexible in negotiations with military leaders.
Having moved from Prime Minister to Acting Prime Minister, Mr. Malval is technically no longer an Aristide appointee and therefore feels that he could take more of an initiative to propose solutions in talks with military leaders.
State Department officials say that Mr. Malval's threat to resign has also frightened elements of Haiti's upper class and provided the impetus for the new round of talks.
At a news conference today, Mr. Malval stressed that the new talks would be held to carry out an accord worked out during the summer on Governors Island in New York. The agreement is aimed at restoring Father Aristide to power. The Prime Minister said he would not engage in any rewriting of the agreements.
 
'End of the Rope'
 Mr. Malval, who has been in the United States since last week, said that "everybody is becoming increasingly conscious that we have reached the end of the rope," and that he hopes that "we can sit and try to find an acceptable way out of the crisis for all the parties involved."
Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, is reeling under the weight of United Nations-imposed economic sanctions that are intended to force the military leadership to hand over power to Father Aristide. In the Governors Island accord, Haiti's military leaders pledged to accept Father Aristide's return. But they have since reneged on that pledge, prompting the imposition of the trade embargo.
"All we know is that the country is desperate," Mr. Malval said. "The country is bankrupt. The central bank has no exchange, no reserves. The country will soon be out of oil, and more important, the country will have no more hope to go on."

HEADLINE: On Congress's Home Front, Faith That All Politics Is Indeed Local

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Fla. Dec. 5

 BODY:
The Congressman knocked at the door of Everett Quint, a 64-year-old retired cabinetmaker.
Mr. Quint peered through the crack and immediately recognized Representative Jim Bacchus. "I know how you voted on Nafta!" Mr. Quint growled. 
 "I think you'll think about it differently a year from now," Mr. Bacchus said with a smile.
"I don't think so," Mr. Quint snapped back.
Welcome to the other side of Congress, the home front far from the marble stairways and ornate caucus rooms where legislative deals are struck. After adjourning in a blaze of headlines last month, most representatives headed home, not for a break but to plunge into the kind of meat-and-potatoes service to constituents that often has more to do with a lawmaker's political success or failure than a vote on a highly contentious bill.
 
'Citizen Saturday'
 On Saturday, Mr. Bacchus, a Democrat and an earnest man who neither smokes nor drinks nor plays sports, gathered up a dozen supporters for a visit to Sherwood Forest, a sun-splashed neighborhood in this conservative, largely Republican city on Florida's Space Coast. They were on a food drive for a local soup kitchen and homeless shelter. On other of Mr. Bacchus's "Citizen Saturdays," he and his group have built ramps for the disabled to watch liftoffs at the Kennedy Space Center and marched for breast cancer research.
Many officeholders count on local actions, like cutting through red tape for a veteran or interceding with the Small Business Administration on behalf of a local company, to heal wounds caused by the larger issues in Washington.
This is particularly true for Mr. Bacchus, a second-term Congressman who supported President Clinton on the budget and the North American Free Trade Agreement despite overwhelming mail and phone calls urging him to vote the other way.
 
One by One
 "The campaign never ends," said the 44-year-old Congressman, who came to politics as a political reporter for the Orlando Sentinel. "I'm in the district in which Bill Clinton got the lowest percentage of the vote of any Democrat in Congress. I win by reaching out to people one by one, through relentless retail politics."
In other words, Mr. Bacchus is betting his congressional career on the adage that all politics is local.
Mr. Bacchus won re-election in 1992 by a mere 3,555 votes out of 161,300 cast even though he had spent three times more on his campaign than his Republican opponent. Local Republicans and supporters of Ross Perot say they will not let Mr. Bacchus escape from their cross hairs next time, and they hope Mr. Bacchus's vote in support of the free trade agreement will drain him of at least some of the campaign money donated by big labor.
"There's not much chance at all he will be re-elected," predicted Dennis Walter, district director of Mr. Perot's party, United We Stand America, noting that Mr. Perot won 26 percent of the vote here in the 1992 Presidential election, his largest share in any Florida district. "The 100 or so members I've spoken to in the last two weeks are very upset with him."
But Mr. Bacchus carries on.
A nonpolitician might have desisted politely after Mr. Quint's less-than-hearty welcome. But Mr. Bacchus is a schmoozer, and before long the two headed for the garage, where Mr. Quint showed off three antique automobiles that he is sanding down and patching into shape.
Mr. Quint did not bend on the trade agreement, but his wife filled two bags with corn flakes, bread and cans of fruit cocktail for the food drive. The Congressman thanked the couple and told them to call him whenever they needed help.
Down the street, Mr. Bacchus encountered Dick Rivers, a retired Air Force officer, who was angry about the Clinton Administration's handling of the United Nations-sponsored relief mission in Somalia. Mr. Rivers complained that his son, an Army platoon sergeant stationed in Mogadishu, gets only one hot meal a day and must sleep in his armored personnel carrier while, Mr. Rivers believes, the Somalis are being catered to.
"It's a waste of money," Mr. Rivers concluded.
Mr. Bacchus nodded sympathetically and pledged to make inquiries about the son's living conditions. An aide immediately followed up on the conversation and learned that Mr. Rivers was also having trouble with the Veterans Administration, which he said owed him a payment for a costly prescription. The aide promised he would do what he could.
 
Voter 'Heartburn'
 Political opponents deride such efforts as meaningless political gimmickry.
"It's all part of the media perception he is trying to produce that shows him as a neighbor who thinks like you and acts like you," said William R. Tolley, a business consultant who lost to Mr. Bacchus in the last two elections and is favored to win the Republican nomination again. "It has some impact, but it doesn't affect the heartburn of voters upset about his votes on Nafta and the budget."
Mr. Bacchus countered that he voted for the trade agreement because it would create many jobs for the high-tech manufacturing industries like the Harris Corporation that are situated in his district. And, he said, side agreements that he insisted on will protect citrus and vegetable growers in the area from surges in Mexican imports.
Mr. Bacchus said he was convinced that a strengthening economy would soften the anger and that constituents would remember him for his community services, his strong support of the NASA space station and his successful efforts to win financing for a new veterans hospital.
"I'll win my usual 51-point landslide," he predicted with a faint smile.
During two days traveling up and down his Atlantic coastal district, Mr. Bacchus also sponsored a jobs workshop that brought together business people and local and Federal officials, visited the home of a family whose son is recovering from brain surgery and needs Social Security disability assistance, and met with a local space contractor seeking to qualify for a $17 million contract for minority-owned businesses.
While executives from the contractor, Analex Space Systems, looked on, Mr. Bacchus called the Small Business Administration's Congressional liaison in Washington to ask for expeditious consideration of the company's bid. As he left the office, the Congressman asked the company's executives to let their employees know of his effort.
Between stops, Mr. Bacchus worked his car phone to nudge the Federal Aviation Administration to remove a huge radar station that his constituents around Patrick Air Force Base believe is the cause of a recent upsurge in cancer cases.
The Congressman then called to thank David Hinson, the administrator of the aviation agency, for agreeing to move the radar station in November 1995 -- and to ask that the date be moved up at least a year.
When Mr. Hinson agreed to look into the matter, Mr. Bacchus asked if he would mind if he told reporters about the conversation.
Mr. Hinson saw no problem.
"Anytime I can do anything for the F.A.A., let me know," the appreciative Congressman said. "I'm on the Science Committee."
As he hung up the phone, Mr. Bacchus mused, "I wouldn't mind if it were moved before the election."

HEADLINE: Venezuela Victor: Will Vows Be Kept?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 6

 BODY:
On the campaign trail, Rafael Caldera promised that gasoline prices would remain frozen at 22 cents a gallon, that a new national sales tax would be abolished, and that the deficit would be cut by asking foreign creditor banks for a break.
At the same time, Mr. Caldera's economic advisers quietly traveled to the United States and tried to reassure foreign business executives that the 77-year-old presidential candidate was just saying these things to get elected. 
 On Sunday, Mr. Caldera won a tight four-way race for the presidency. Now, many Venezuelans are wondering whether his campaign promises mean anything, knowing that the country has been shaken by two coup attempts and a presidential resignation over the last two years, and that any false steps by Mr. Caldera could renew political instability and cause inflation to leap above its current annual level of 45 percent.
The stakes for the United States are also clear. A coup would reintroduce military rule to South America, a continent that is now entirely governed by elected civilian presidents. Political chaos could choke the flow of oil from Venezuela, the United States' second largest source of imported oil after Saudi Arabia.
 
Political Agility Needed
 Elected with only 30 percent of the vote and facing a Congress split among five factions, Mr. Caldera will have to display political agility to guide Venezuela successfully over the next five years. Despite his appeals for "national understanding" during the campaign, the President-elect called his defeated opponents "immature" on Sunday night and proposed a constitutional amendment that would allow him to dissolve Congress "when it does not carry out the will of the people."
To his opponents, Mr. Caldera, who started his political career when Franklin D. Roosevelt was in his second term in the White House, is an aging, closed-minded autocrat.
"Caldera is mentally stuck 25 years back, to the time when he was President," said Oswaldo Alvarez Paz, the presidential candidate for the Copei party. "He will be a disaster for the country."
But for many people in Venezuela, where 75 percent of the population is under 35 years, Mr. Caldera is a reassuring grandfatherly figure who exudes experience and moral bearing. Unlike his predecessor, Carlos Andres Perez, who resigned in May because of a corruption scandal, Mr. Caldera has a reputation for personal honesty and he attends Roman Catholic Mass every Sunday.
Unlike his two predecessors, who openly lived with their mistresses, Mr. Caldera has been married to Alicia Pietri de Caldera for the last half century. On Sunday night, the platform at his victory party was crowded with most of his six children and 10 grandchildren.
 
Pragmatic Approach Predicted
 Mr. Caldera has run for the presidency six times, winning only twice, on Sunday and in 1968. A founder of the Copei Party in 1946, Mr. Caldera deserted it this year when it refused to nominate him. Running as an independent, he forged a diverse coalition of 17 small parties ranging from Communists to those who long for Venezuela's right-wing military Government of the 1950's.
To critics worried about Mr. Caldera's free-spending, populist reputation, his supporters cite his presidency in the early 1970's as a time of balanced budgets when oil was selling for $2 a barrel.
"Caldera has got a lot of double talk," Andres Duarte Vivas, the president of a trading company, said here today. "But circumstance will dictate that he take a very pragmatic approach. On privatization and economic reform, he is not going to backtrack."
Fernando Egana, an aide to Mr. Caldera, insisted in a recent interview that "the record of Caldera is completely opposed to the statist, populist image."
But with new foreign investment running at about half of last year's levels, business people appear to be waiting for clearer signals on Venezuela's future economic path.
 
Market Changes Attacked
 The campaign oratory was not very assuring to the business community. Attacking the free-market changes of his predecessor, Mr. Caldera promised to slow privatization, to scrutinize future foreign investment in energy areas and to cut the ballooning budget deficit through austerity, improved tax collection and renegotiation of the foreign debt. Budget austerity, he hastened to add, would not go so far as cutting state payrolls or salaries.
"I am against this epidemic of privatizations by people who consider that everything will be resolved by selling everything that we have," the President-elect said at a news conference today. Mr. Caldera, a lawyer by training, added that slumping world oil prices gave Venezuela "legal grounds" to renegotiate its foreign debt.
Currently, 23 percent of the $22 billion national budget goes for servicing the country's $27 billion foreign debt. But according to a Finance Ministry study, most of the debt is in the form of bonds, leaving only 10 percent of the debt subject to renegotiation.

HEADLINE: Guguletu Journal;
A Brutalized Generation Turns Its Rage on Whites

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUGULETU, South Africa, Dec. 2

 BODY:
"I can leave you here and go away and come back just now," Victor Mdekazi told a white guest in this black township. "When I come back I will find you so-o-o-o much in blood."
He sat in a parked car around the corner from the gas station where Amy Biehl, an American Fulbright scholar, was slashed to death in August by a taunting mob of young men for being a white in the wrong place. 
 Mr. Mdekazi, 18 years old and an organizer for a black nationalist student organization, intended no threat, merely basic instruction in an unpredictable factor of South African politics: the temper of the country's marginalized young blacks.
They are, to judge from a day among them in Guguletu, spirits calloused by apartheid and resistance. They scorn deals made in their name at negotiating tables. They anticipate the nation's first free elections either with bottomless cynicism, or with fantastic expectations. Even their leaders wonder if they can be led.
 
An Education in Hatred
 "We've got to be realistic and honest here," said Tsietsi Telite, the chairman of the Pan Africanist Student Organization, which comes closest to speaking for the hardened core of the generation. "That hatred, you grow up, it develops within you. It needs much political education to give it direction."
Since the killing of the American woman, Guguletu, an otherwise unexceptional black settlement foundering in the ocean of destitution that laps at the edge of idyllic Cape Town, has accepted its new notoriety without apology.
For local militants, the trial of seven local youngsters -- two of whom were freed after a witness said he was too terrified to testify -- has become an opportunity to demonstrate rejection of white authority.
They journey to the trial in downtown Cape Town, war-dancing outside the hedge of razor wire the police have put up for security, chanting "One settler, one bullet," hissing "Settler!" at white journalists who pass by, laughing from the public gallery as the witnesses testify.
The consensus among these young people is that Amy Biehl was at fault for coming where she was not wanted, and that the white courts have no right to judge the accused.
 
A Familiar Story
 The death is now part of the community lore. Residents call the slain woman Amy. Without being asked they will point out the spot where she was killed.
"It's the whole country, it's not only the few children," said Wowo Nofemela, 47, whose 22-year-old son, Mzikhona, is one of those on trial. "The environment is not right."
Guguletu's bleak environment has rapidly deteriorated under the migration of rural poor seeking work. The original dreary blocks of tiny homes have been swamped by squatter shacks, muddy warrens of smoke-stained sheds.
To Mr. Nofomela, a groundskeeper, the miracle is that Mzikhona is the first of his six children to get in trouble. They grew up without playgrounds, often without shoes. Four are now adults, and jobless.
For all his suffering, though, Mr. Nofomela defers to whites; his children do not.
 
'They Have Power'
 "Our parents, they are cowards for the Boer," said Linda Mayekiso, 21, the girlfriend of Mzikhona Nofomela and, like the arrested man, an ardent Pan Africanist. "The youth are not scared, and they have power."
Besides, she said, the adults had jobs to lose, however poor. The young have nothing to lose, even prospects.
The militant leaders who provide the political vocabulary for the anger say they discourage racial hatred by delicately avoiding the word "white" and describing the enemy as "settlers," or "oppressors." But they concede that such distinctions are often lost on the streets.
"You see a car of white people," said Simphewe Mfengu, 19. "You can't define, is it an American or what, is it an oppressor or what?"
Victor Mdekazi added, "There are people living in squatter camps, even if Joe Slovo can go to that squatter camp they will kill him." Mr. Slovo is the chairman of the Communist Party, an anti-apartheid champion so revered that many squatter camps are named for him.
As the apartheid barriers erode, familiarity seems to breed only more resentment.
Vusumzi Noge, an 11th grader who transferred this year to a newly integrated school in the prosperous white suburb of Mowbray, said he was heartbroken and wrathful to see the libraries and laboratories unimaginable in Guguletu. To the snubs of white students, he responded with steely defiance.
"I don't care," he said. "Because it's not their land, it's our land. It's all our land."
Among the angry young, the the scheduling of the first free elections has not diminished the bitterness.
 
Will Disillusion Set In?
 Some expect a quick and chilling disillusionment.
"It's going to get worse, because each and everybody, they have got visions," said Martha Holobo, 23, who runs a fruit stall at the edge of one of the squatter camps. "People think freedom means they will all move to the rich houses in Mowbray, and the whites in Mowbray will move here."
Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, has sought to dampen dreams of sudden economic equality. The Pan Africanists encourage such hopes as a birthright.
Whatever support these young blacks offer to a new president and his government, they say, will be conditional.
"As long as it's an African, we are going to respect him," Linda Mayekiso said. "As long as he delivers the goods."

The only heat to be found for these residents came from burning trash. (Guy Tillim for The New York Times)
