HEADLINE: Woman Is Penn President; The First in the Ivy League

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Judith Rodin, the provost of Yale University, has been chosen president of the University of Pennsylvania, becoming the first woman to head an Ivy League institution.
Dr. Rodin, 49, a behavioral psychologist who is a Philadelphia native and a Penn alumna, will assume the post next June and face a number of problems, including a relatively low endowment, the need for academic consolidation and issues of racial strife and free speech. 
 As provost of Yale, Dr. Rodin was a candidate for the Yale presidency after the resignation of Benno C. Schmidt Jr. She led the university during the difficult year after Mr. Schmidt resigned, instituting a system to reduce the budget deficit and calming the faculty members and students, who were concerned about cutbacks and layoffs.
 
'I'll Be Watched'
 Speaking by telephone from Philadelphia, Dr. Rodin said "the Ivy League's having a woman at the highest level is symbolic."
"I understand I'll be watched," she said.
While Yale and Penn both have had women as acting presidents, the appointment of Dr. Rodin is the first in the Ivy League, which comprises Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Penn, Princeton and Yale. Among the women at the highest level in major academic institutions are W. Ann Reynolds, chancellor of the City University of New York; Nannerl H. Keohane, who was installed as president of Duke University this fall, and Katherine Lyall, the president of the University of Wisconsin.
Dr. Rodin said her vision was "to make Pennsylvania a leading institution and a great university with a truly international perspective."
She will succeed Claire Fagin, the nursing department chairwoman who has been Penn's acting president since the resignation of Sheldon Hackney last June. Mr. Hackney is now chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.
 
'Exciting and Dynamic'
 Last fall, Dr. Fagin asked not to be considered as a candidate for the job; instead, she announced that she would lead the university during the search for a president and then return to teaching.
Alvin Shoemaker, chairman of the search committee and chairman of the board of trustees, said his committee interviewed more than 60 people and found Dr. Rodin "the most exciting and dynamic" of all the candidates. He said the search committee was particularly pleased at Dr. Rodin's connections to Philadelphia, where her mother still lives, and to Penn, where she received her bachelor's degree in 1966. She received her Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1970.
"We haven't had one of our graduates serve as president in about 50 years," Mr. Shoemaker said.
As to her ability to deal with a relatively low endowment, $1.35 billion, Mr. Shoemaker said that recent efforts to raise money had paid off and that "her main job will be to keep the momentum going." (By comparison, Harvard University's endowment is $5.8 billion, the largest in the Ivy League.)
Another challenge that Dr. Rodin faces is academic consolidation. Last October, to cope with relatively low income from its endowment, the university's School of Arts and Sciences eliminated religious studies, civilization and regional economic science departments, shifted the astronomy department into physics and brought in outside administrators to overhaul the Slavic languages department. Many faculty members were distressed by the action.
Mr. Shoemaker said he thought Dr. Rodin's experience at Yale would help her deal with these and other problems. Trouble developed at Yale last year after Mr. Schmidt announced a plan to close a budget gap by cutting nearly 11 percent of the faculty members of arts and sciences and by cutting programs and departments. The faculty members and students rebelled, leading to Mr. Schmidt's departure.
Richard Levin, the new Yale president, said yesterday, "Thanks to her skillful leadership, the faculty was quite satisfied with the outcome of restructuring."
Dr. Rodin said: "The actual change at Yale was carried out by me. We engaged the faculty. With the necessary discussion and participation, they can be made to feel good about consolidation even if the outcome is difficult and results in a closed department."
 
Problem of Racial Tension
 At Penn, Dr. Rodin will also face problems arising from campus racial tension and the issue of free speech.
In one incident last year, a white student called five blacks students "water buffaloes" after they refused to break up a party in front of his dormitory. The blacks students complained to a university panel that he used the word "black" in his remark; he denied this.
In a second incident, a group of students organized by the Black Student League destroyed about 14,000 copies of The Daily Pennsylvanian, a student-run newspaper. The black students said they were protesting what they believed to be a racist slant of the newspaper.
In the first case, the complaint was eventually withdrawn, and in the second, university officials dismissed disciplinary proceedings against the black students.
Nevertheless, Mr. Hackney, who was then president, was widely criticized for the university's code regulating offensive speech and for his handling of the two incidents.
Last month, Dr. Fagin rescinded the speech code as unworkable and appointed a commission, composed of faculty, students and trustees, to recommend how to handle the matter to the new president.
Dr. Rodin joined the psychology department of Yale in 1972, became chairwoman of the department in 1989 and was appointed in 1991 by Mr. Schmidt as the dean of the graduate school. Less than a year later, after the provost quit in the midst of the faculty revolt, Mr. Schmidt promoted her to provost.
As a behavioral psychologist, Dr. Rodin did research on eating disorders, establishing a link between a mother's behavior and the daughter's. She also has studied obesity and jealousy.

HEADLINE: IN NOTING ABSENCE, A.M.A. SEES A SNUB

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Struggling to quell a revolt within their ranks, leaders of the American Medical Association criticized the Clinton Administration today for not sending any high-ranking officials to their convention here to defend the President's plan to overhaul the nation's health care system.
The association supports Mr. Clinton's goal of guaranteeing health insurance coverage for all Americans. But with many elements of the Clinton plan coming under fire from doctors, there was no one here to speak for the White House, to rebut the critics or to defend the President's proposal to require all employers to provide insurance for their employees. 
 Doctors said that the absence of high-ranking Administration officials was notable because the position of the association itself was in flux, and that there was a lot of misinformation circulating about the President's plan. Moreover, officials of the association said that they told the White House last week that they expected a groundswell of opposition to parts of the Clinton plan, and that they suggested that the President or his aides hold a meeting for doctors here to allay their concerns.
 
Some See Signs of Drift
 Hillary Rodham Clinton got an enthusiastic reception when she spoke to the medical association six months ago in Chicago. But since then, the White House seems to have lost political control of the health care issue, and Democrats in Congress say they detect ominous signs of drift in the Administration's campaign. Rival proposals to revamp the health care system are being taken more seriously. And the White House, after searching for several months, has still not named anyone to coordinate efforts by the Administration and its allies to secure passage of comprehensive health care legislation.
"We blocked out time for a discussion of health care reform this afternoon, in case there was some senior official from the Administration, but that just did not materialize," said Dr. Daniel H. Johnson Jr., speaker of the house of delegates of the medical association, the group's policy-making body.
Dr. Joycelyn Elders, the Surgeon General, has a seat in the house of delegates by virtue of her Government position. But she is not here. By contrast, Dr. C. Everett Koop used to attend regularly when he was Surgeon General in the Reagan Administration.
The highest-ranking Administration official in attendance at the association's convention here was Dr. Philip R. Lee, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, who flew in for the day on Saturday to discuss the training of doctors. But the debate today involved bigger questions about the political and economic feasibility of the Clinton plan.
 
Clinton Aides 'Booked Up'
 The association has more than 290,000 members, accounting for nearly half of the nation's doctors, and runs an influential, well-financed lobbying operation in Washington. The house of delegates includes doctors from every state and from more than 80 medical specialty societies.
In Washington, Jeffrey L. Eller, a White House spokesman, said today that the President, Mrs. Clinton and their aides were "booked up" and did not have time to attend the association's convention. But he said the Administration intended to continue working with the association.
Leaders of the medical group say they are trying to be helpful to the Administration and need all the help they can get from the White House. The doctors are considering a significant change in policy: backing away from their position in support of a Federal law requiring employers to provide health insurance for their employees. The proposal for such an employer mandate is a central element of Mr. Clinton's plan to guarantee insurance coverage for all Americans.
Dr. Raymond Scalettar, former chairman of the association, said today: "It would have been useful for Administration officials to express themselves at this meeting and to explain why they view an employer mandate as the only way to go. If Administration spokesmen had appeared, they would have been welcomed, ushered in and given the opportunity to speak."
In the absence of such spokesmen from the Administration, "many doctors are beginning to have second thoughts about the employer mandate," Dr. Scalettar said. "As they deal with patients who have small businesses, they are being asked to reconsider."
 
'Intolerable Burden'
 Doctors from nearly a dozen states have endorsed resolutions saying that an employer mandate would, in the words of the Indiana delegation, "place an intolerable burden on small businesses."
Some doctors say this is a pocketbook issue for the doctors, because they themselves run small businesses and would have to provide comprehensive insurance coverage for all their office workers under the Clinton plan. Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the association, said he believed most doctors provided insurance for their employees, although he had no data to confirm this.
Mr. Eller, the White House spokesman, expressed no great concern about the possibility of a change in association's policy. "If there is a better way to reach the ultimate goal of universal coverage with comprehensive benefits but no employer mandate," he said, "we will seriously consider it."

HEADLINE: Reactor Passes Point of No Return In Uphill Path to Fusion Energy

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO, N.J.

 BODY:
THE promise of cheap, clean fusion energy is about to undergo an acid test as tritium fuel flows for the first time into America's most advanced fusion test reactor here.
A landmark series of experiments, scheduled to begin before Christmas and end next September, when the test reactor will be dismantled, could be either a giant step toward the dream of unlimited fusion energy or a blow that hobbles progress indefinitely. 
 The physicists supervising the experiment hope they have correctly predicted what will happen, and that the thorniest problems have been overcome. "But this is a time of great anxiety for all of us," said Dr. Ronald C. Davidson, director of the Princeton University Plasma Physics Laboratory. A successful run during the next few months could encourage significant financing for future fusion research, but major snags could obstruct financial support and thwart American participation in an ambitious international fusion program.
A hydrogen fusion reaction of the type scientists are hoping to create at the Princeton reactor yields immense amounts of energy and produces negligible amounts of radioactive waste; unlike a conventional nuclear fission reactor, a fusion reactor could not melt down or release dangerous fission products, nor would it produce highly radioactive spent fuel.
Over the last decade, supported by $1.4 billion in Federal funds, the Princeton laboratory has run many thousands of physics experiments with its big Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor, but all were dry runs, using a heavy isotope of hydrogen called deuterium as the test fuel. To initiate a high-power reaction, a tokamak reactor needs tritium, a still heavier hydrogen isotope. (Tokamak is a Russian acronym for "toroidal magnetic chamber.") Trials with tritium were delayed until this essential testing phase was completed because once tritium enters the reactor the machine becomes radioactive and cannot be used again for deuterium experiments. Last month the moment of truth arrived as full-strength, tritium-laced reactor fuel began to replace the deuterium surrogate.
Tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen commonly used in minute quantities in luminous watch dials and exit signs, is essential to the high-power fusion reaction the scientists hope to achieve. After the tokamak has completed its tritium runs, it will be left to cool down for at least a year to allow its radioactivity to subside to levels safe enough for workers to dismantle it.
If all goes as planned, the five grams, or about one-sixth of an ounce, of tritium fuel now being trickled into the 50-foot-high reactor will produce a reaction temperature six times that of the Sun's core, which is about 27 million degrees, and will yield power of about 10 million watts. Although this will be somewhat less than half the power the machine consumes to produce it, the yield will be the best that any experimental fusion reactor has yet achieved, and it will provide vital information needed for the design and construction of future reactors.
In a fusion reaction, the nuclei of hydrogen atoms, including ordinary hydrogen as well as its deuterium or tritium isotopes, are forced to merge. The single proton in each hydrogen nucleus joins with the proton of another hydrogen nucleus to produce an element with two protons in its nucleus -- helium.
Although ordinary hydrogen atoms can be made to undergo fusion, the conditions needed to start a fusion reaction are much less demanding if deuterium atoms, which contain one neutron as well as a proton, are used. A mixture of tritium, with one proton and two neutrons in its nucleus, with deuterium, undergoes fusion even more easily.
If all goes well during the planned tests, and if Congress subsequently makes a long-term commitment to support a continuing fusion research program, scientists believe a commercial fusion power plant could begin operating by the year 2040. But much will depend on the willingness of many governments -- those of the United States, Japan, Russia and Western Europe -- to cooperate in financing an advanced fusion reactor prototype called the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor, which scientists like to abbreviate as ITER, pronounced "eat air." If it works, the project would demonstrate the feasibility of igniting fuel in a sustained fusion reaction at 100 million degrees and producing far more electric power than the machine consumes.
Estimates of the cost of this international machine range up to $11 billion, roughly the same as that of the superconducting supercollider, the huge proton accelerator that Congress voted to kill in October on the ground that it was too expensive. Although a source of vast fusion power would have much greater economic impact than the pure research the supercollider would have made possible, Congress has been wary of fusion research in recent years. In 1991 it killed Princeton's projected $1.8 billion Burning Plasma Experiment, which was intended to ignite a sustained fusion reaction.
"We ourselves may not live to see a commercial fusion reactor in operation," said Dr. Dale M. Meade, deputy director of the Princeton laboratory. "But we have a chance of leaving fusion energy technology to our grandchildren. It would be nice if they could inherit something besides deficits in energy and the Federal budget."
Scientists know that the principle of fusion is valid because they have applied it in thermonuclear explosions. But the principle is much harder to exploit when the goal is a controlled fusion reaction that goes on continuously in a tightly confined chamber in which the reactants are heated to about 180 million degrees. Scientists have spent billions of dollars since World War II trying to achieve controlled fusion.
For example, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in Livermore, Calif., has long been trying to prove that microscopic glass capsules filled with hydrogen isotopes -- essentially, miniature hydrogen bombs -- could be fired by crushing the capsules with barrages of intense laser beams. But this method, known as inertial confinement, has so far failed to produce the desired result, partly because the imploding glass capsules mixed with the thermonuclear fuel instead of merely compressing it, and greatly impeded fusion.
An approach that most scientists now regard as more promising is called magnetic confinement fusion, the system embodied in the Princeton tokamak. The fuel, a half-and-half mixture of deuterium and tritium gas, is stripped of its electrons by heat, and each atom thereby acquires a positive electric charge. In this form, the gas is called a "plasma." By surrounding the electrically charged plasma with powerful interlocking magnetic fields, it can be confined and compressed at a high enough temperature to induce fusion.
 
Work Pioneered by Sakharov
 A magnetic "bottle" must be used to confine the plasma because the plasma's stellar heat would vaporize any material surface it touched; in a thermonuclear reactor, plasma fuel that accidentally came into contact with a metal wall would instantly cool down and squelch the fusion reaction, scientists say.
Most of the devices built to experiment with magnetic confinement are doughnut-shaped tokamaks, descendants of a design pioneered during the 1950's by the late Dr. Andrei Sakharov and Dr. Igor Tamm, both Russian physicists. Physicists have continued to develop the tokamak design because it is particularly suited to "bottling" plasma in a favorable shape as the plasma undergoes fusion.
The Princeton research tokamak operates in pulses lasting only a few seconds at a time, but a fusion-power reactor would presumably make the reaction continuous. Eighty percent of the energy produced in such a reactor would be carried out of the reaction vessel by neutrons released in the reaction. Those neutrons, lacking electric charges, could escape the magnetic confinement bottle, allowing them to hit a lithium "blanket" and heat it up. The hot blanket would in turn heat a gas, and the high-temperature gas could be used to drive a turbine and generate electricity.
As a byproduct, the fusion reaction would produce tritium, which would be re-used in helping to maintain the fusion cycle. (The commercial price of tritium, which is also an ingredient of hydrogen bombs, is about $30,000 per gram.)
But the reaction will also form alpha particles, nuclei of helium atoms, and one of the uncertainties in the forthcoming tests, scientists here say, is their behavior. Since these particles are electrically charged, they will remain trapped inside the tokamak's magnetic field, mixing with the deuterium-tritium plasma fuel. Roughly 20 percent of the fusion energy will be transferred to the alpha particles. Physicists hope that the alpha particles will perform an important service by transferring most of their energy back to the fuel, thereby maintaining the essential fusion temperature.
 
Unanswered Questions
 But the alpha particles could also pose a serious problem because they move at enormous speeds. Scientists are concerned that the impact of these particles on the magnetically confined plasma could destabilize its shape and make the plasma wiggle, spoiling the geometry needed for confinement and fusion. If this effect proves to be strong enough, it could be a serious obstacle to future fusion research.
"We have carried out many tests using deuterium alone," said Dr. Richard J. Hawryluk, manager of the Princeton tokamak, "and we believe that what we learned will more or less apply to deuterium-tritium plasma as well. But we can't be sure until we try it."
Another large research tokamak, the Joint European Torus, or JET, in Abingdon, England, ran a successful test two years ago using a plasma fuel containing tritium -- the first tritium fusion experiment ever attempted in a tokamak. But the tritium content was only about 10 percent of the deuterium-tritium mixture, and the much more potent 50-50 mixture in the Princeton tokamak is likely to behave somewhat differently.
Princeton physicists hope to persuade Congress to spend some $600 million on a new research reactor called the Tokamak Physics Experiment, designed to run continuously rather than in pulses. The experiments it could perform, the scientists believe, would be important steps toward the realization of the international ITER project.
A dozen smaller tokamaks in different countries are accumulating data vital to the working of future large machines. One of these is at Columbia University. "Dr. Michael Mauel and his team at Columbia are doing wonderful physics experiments with their smaller tokamak, and the results are shaping designs for future high-power tokamaks," Dr. Davidson said.
If thermonuclear fusion power is to become a reality, he believes, the talents, effort and money of many nations and many research organizations will be needed. "There's bound to be heated competition among nations -- and within nations -- in the selection of a site for ITER, a working fusion reactor," he said. "But ultimately, cooperation among everyone will be the key to realizing this great dream."

HEADLINE: Discount With a Vengeance;
A New Wrinkle in Retailing Hits the Metropolitan Region

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I.

 BODY:
Patty Menges is the kind of shopper who makes mall retailers nervous.
"I don't like malls; I don't go to malls," she said, standing outside the Price Club, a floor-to-ceiling serve-yourself retailer of just about everything in bulk. Ms. Menges doesn't feel safe in the vast acreage of a mall parking lot and doesn't care for the prices either. "It's not discount," she said. 
 Shoppers like Ms. Menges are the driving force behind a new phenomenon for the New York metropolitan region, the "power mall," being developed here on a congested stretch of Old Country Road. It is discount with a vengeance, a place of brawny no-frills shopping, where the mantra is "value," and where the upscale shops and cinnamon-scented ambiance of the traditional mall are dismissed as frivolous affectations of a bygone era.
Certainly, discount shopping is nothing new. Smaller "power centers" -- usually two or three off-price stores like Home Depot or Price Club clustered together -- are increasingly common. What is new is a mall-sized conglomeration of such stores.
The $180 million project here, called the Source, a combination of enclosed mall and strip shopping center, is about one-third built, with a Kmart, a Sports Authority and a Marshalls open, in addition to Price Club. Groundbreaking for the mall section is months away and a list of tenants has yet to be announced.
But retailing and real-estate experts say the bottom line has already emerged: few traditional shopping malls are being built, their allure overtaken by changes in everything from land values to household budgets. Mall-sized properties in the new era might not all be like the Source, they say, but all will have to find a niche. For some, like the Mall of America, in a suburb of Minneapolis, that means emphasizing sheer size and entertainment. Others, like Short Hills Mall in Essex County, N.J., are pushing the outer edge of luxury shopping. But by far the most popular niche is discount shopping.
"The customer for whom they built malls 20 years ago is not the customer that comes today, and every retailer will have to face that fact," Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Consulting Group, said, noting both a change in tastes and a decline in leisure time. "Malls have lost some of their luster, and virtually all of their entertainment value."
James W. Hughes, a professor of Urban Planning at Rutgers University who has studied malls, says flatly that if an ordinary shopping mall has not been built by now, it probably won't be. "For the most part, the regional mall infrastructure of the next century is in the ground," he said.
The recession revealed all this, experts say, and the unfolding story of Westbury's power mall underlined it.
As manufacturing declined and land prices fell, large swaths of land opened up at prices that could squeeze into the razor-thin profit margins of discounters like Kmart and the Sports Authority, both of which are anchor tenants here.
At the same time, many of the big-name department stores that usually anchor malls stumbled into bankruptcy or changed their names, eroding consumer loyalty. In Connecticut, for example, G. Fox & Company, the state's oldest retail name and one of its most trusted, which anchored malls throughout the state, was erased in a corporate reorganization to become Filene's.
Meanwhile, baby boomers who shopped through the 1980's had children and changed their priorities. Tighter economics meant more two-income households, with both earners looking for bargains and less likely to spend their time browsing in the mall. Perhaps most important, experts say, the malls became too familiar.
"There's just not a whole lot of people who spend two to three hours walking around a mall anymore," said Donald L. Hoffenkamp, development director for Homart Development Company, one of the nation's largest retail developers.
Four years ago, all of his company's capital spending was on malls. Now it's 50 percent malls, 50 percent power centers. "Homart is giving consumers what they want," he said.
 
'Almost a Rebellion'
 Although industrywide sales and traffic figures are unavailable to compare traditional malls with newer rivals, investors and developers are betting on the upstarts.
Since 1989, 14 power centers have opened in the tri-state region -- nearly doubling the total, according to figures from the National Research Bureau, a private research company. Of the 48 major enclosed malls in the 31-county metropolitan region, by contrast, all but two opened more than five years ago, and 30 were built before 1975. Only one is on the drawing board and approved for construction, the Westchester Mall in White Plains.
"Most of the malls have become so homogenized and the same that people are bored with it," said Peter N. Schaeffer, a partner at Johnson Redbook Service, a research firm that tracks retail trends for investors. "There's almost a rebellion."
Many malls, to be sure, are still profitable, and some developers have raised caution flags that discount shopping centers could cool off if consumer tastes turn again. In fact, some discounters have already stumbled badly. But the difference from ordinary mall retailing is also stark: Malls, with their emphasis on fashion, are becoming more and more dependent on the year-end holiday season, while power centers exist not for fashion, but price, with a year-round steady state business that appeals to many investors.
"The malls still will do the volume of business they need to do, but 70 to 80 percent of their business is in December," said Mr. Hoffenkamp, the shopping center builder. "It's spread out at power centers."
 
Concept Seen Around Country
 Already 401,000 square feet of the 1.2 million-square-foot project here is open, in one open-air strip. Inside at stores like the Sports Authority and Price Club, the feel is somewhere between a warehouse and an open-air bazaar, with aisles and sections laid out all on one level. The inventory is deep, with the Sports Authority, for instance, stocking one whole aisle of tennis rackets.
The next phase of the Source, about 816,000 square feet, is being assembled by Fortunoff, a department store that is promising to advance the spirit of Price Club into a previously unheard of scale of "value-oriented shopping." Tenants in that section are expected to be announced early next year.
The concept is echoed elsewhere around the region and the nation, from Scottsdale, Ariz., where a 1.2 million square foot power mall opened this year, to the power retailers clustering around Buckland Hills Mall in Manchester, Conn., to the new, sprawling "value malls" in Washington, Philadelphia and elsewhere.
Here in Nassau County, the trend has particular resonance. Nassau pioneered mall construction in the 1950's -- with three malls up and running by 1956, when the entire state of New Jersey had but one. It still has by far the biggest concentration of malls in the region, with 6.4 million square feet of malls in only 287 square miles, a density higher than even Bergen County, N.J., home of the cheek-by-jowl malls of Paramus.
 
Not the First Choice
 Not to give the deep thinkers at Fortunoff too much credit, they admit that a power mall was not their first choice. The company set out to build a traditional 1.6 million-square-foot mall called the Galleria in the late 1980's only to see residents object and the economy head south at the same time. Nearby Roosevelt Field, one of the region's oldest malls, also decided to pour millions of dollars into a redesign and upgrade. In the end, the opulent-sounding "Galleria" took on a punchier identity as "the Source."
"It is obvious that the revised formula was the correct one," said a spokesman for Fortunoff, Gary Lewi. "The Price Club and the Price Club Plaza are examples of what the public has come to demand."
Retailing industry experts, urban planners and real-estate professionals say that what happened to Fortunoff on the way to its mall illustrates the economic and demographic trends that are roiling retail shelves.
"The malls are under pressure because they're the highest cost operators, made technologically obsolete by discounters with lower costs," said George Rosenbaum, chief executive officer of Leo J. Shapiro and Associates, a Chicago-based market research company.
Still, retailers say the relationship between ordinary malls and power malls is interdependent, and ultimately, nurturing.
"Malls kind of have their own place and power centers can be compatible with malls," said Charles J. Miller, a group vice president at Kmart Corporation, which owns the Sports Authority and Borders Books, all three of which will be part of the Westbury project. "We tend to gravitate toward regional malls, and the better the mall, the more we like to be in the vicinity."
A spokesman for the corporate owners of Roosevelt Field, Kevin Ryan, said the mall would only benefit from the presence of a power mall nearby.
"The retail mix is not the same," Mr. Ryan said. "If the Fortunoff project attracts more people to the area, we'll get some fallout from that -- they complement each other."
The Nassau County Board of Supervisors tightened the relationship between the two this week, designating a circular area around the two sites as the county's transportation hub. The distinction will affect transportation decisions, county officials said, focusing things like bus routing and future Federal mass-transit grants on these properties.
 
Scale and Congestion
 Transportation and congestion are also considered the biggest risks for the Source. One of the main appeals of ordinary power centers, beyond the prices, is that shoppers can generally park in front of the store they want. At the size of a power mall, however, that immediacy may be lost.
Professor Hughes at Rutgers said he believed new questions about scale and congestion not encountered at smaller power centers will require new answers.
"This is more evolution that revolution," he said. "They are in the process of adapting and maybe mutating into this new form."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1016 words

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Still Eludes Negotiators

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The United States and the European Community struggled into the early morning hours today to bridge differences that are holding up a world trade agreement, now divided mainly by a bitter dispute over access for American movies and television programs in the European market.
Despite more than 19 hours of talks between the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and the European Community's chief negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, officials on both sides reported little progress. 
 "What we have up to now is unacceptable," the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, said.
[An identified European Community official said an agreement was closer, Reuters reported early Tuesday. "They are not far off," the official was quoted as saying, referring to Sir Leon and Mr. Kantor. But the official added that there were "still some things to sort out" and did not elaborate.]
 
 
Meeting Postponed
 The community's foreign ministers postponed a meeting that had been scheduled on Monday to review and outline an agreement on trade issues that had been framed last week. Instead, they decided to meet after the talks between Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon ended.
"We hope that discussions through the night will bring some progress," Mr. Juppe said late Monday. "At the moment we cannot accept the position of the American side."
A trade agreement between the United States and the European Community is an essential prelude for completion of long-stalled world trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs on Trade, which began seven years ago in Uruguay and now faces a Dec. 15 deadline agreed to by all sides.
If there is no accord by then, the attempt to update and broaden world trade rules, and so encourage international commerce, will be badly set back, perhaps abandoned for now.
 
 
Authority May Run Out
 What is more, President Clinton's special trade negotiating authority will expire and the Administration would have to ask Congress next year for an extension, something that could be politically ticklish after the bruising fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The special powers allow the President to sign a GATT agreement by next spring and submit it to Congress for a vote without amendments.
A failure would also dent world economic confidence and place new strains on an Atlantic alliance still seeking a new purpose with the end of the cold war.
It is possible that trade negotiators will dicker through this week and into next week, even up to the last hours, over difficult issues, and still make the Dec. 15 deadline.
The difficulties in the talks Monday stemmed from the complex variety of issues being confronted. Although the outline of an agreement has been reached on what had long been the most contentious issue, agricultural trade, neither side was prepared to ratify that while other questions still hung in the balance.
"Nobody wants to lose any negotiating leverage," a community official said. "There will be an agreement on everything or on nothing."
On farm-export issues, Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy emerged beaming from a meeting on Monday with the community's farm commissioner, Rene Steichen, and said his expression reflected the progress in the talks. Community officials said the outline of a farm accord -- under which the Europeans would cut back their subsidized food and grain exports more slowly than previously agreed to, while the United States gained improved access to the European market for a range of agricultural and industrial goods -- had relegated these issues to a secondary place in the negotiations.
"There is a farm agreement," Mr. Steichen said, "but it is a question of getting an overall agreement that is now a difficult task."
French officials contested this view, saying that Prime Minister Edouard Balladur's Government wanted further concessions on farm trade. But it seemed clear that whatever differences remained on this issue were narrow.
At the forefront of the talks, a battle raged over demands by the American movie and entertainment industries. An exhausted European delegate, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the two sides had been negotiating solidly since Saturday in Geneva on this matter, and "neither side has budged an inch."
Mr. Kantor, who knows the American film industry intimately from his days as a lawyer representing the business, wants all European restrictions on American television programs removed and also wants assurances that American technologies now being developed -- involving interaction among cable, computers and entertainment -- will not be held back by European restrictions.
"If the audio-visual question is not settled to our satisfaction, there will be no GATT agreement," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, the American representative to the European Community.
A great deal is at stake here. American entertainment products are the nation's second-largest export area, behind aerospace. In 1992, sales in Europe totaled $3.7 billion.
 
Fear of American Culture
 But France and some other countries now restrict United States-made programs to a maximum of 50 percent of total television broadcasts. In addition, France wants the right to subsidize its movie industry, to protect it, it says, from an overwhelming Hollywood cultural onslaught.
Under GATT rules, subsidies are generally regarded as a form of unfair competitive practice, and their elimination is encouraged.
But a European official involved in the talks said: "Not only in France, but throughout the community, there is a feeling that we must have some protection" for the European entertainment industry, or, the official said, "it will simply disappear. This is not a question on which we can make many concessions."
French officials said differences also remained over the question of anti-dumping duties -- levies imposed when goods are found to have been exported at prices lower than those charged in domestic markets.
The United States insists that its right to impose such duties should not be limited by any GATT agreement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "What we have up to now is unacceptable," said Alain Juppe, the French Foreign Minister. "We have scarcely made headway." Mr. Juppe left a meeting of French Cabinet ministers yesterday in Paris, where they reviewed their position on the GATT negotiations. (Reuters)(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Former White House Aide Will Run Hill & Knowlton

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD LEVY

 BODY:
Hill & Knowlton Inc., the troubled public relations giant, yesterday named Howard Paster, who recently resigned as President Clinton's chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill, to be its new chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Paster, 48, will take over a firm that has been buffeted in recent years by declining billings, turmoil in senior management, staff cutbacks and criticism that it has shown poor judgment in its choice of clients. And its parent company, WPP Group P.L.C. of Britain, has struggled with heavy debt amassed during a takeover binge in the 1980's that included the purchase of Hill & Knowlton. 
 Hill & Knowlton has not had a chief executive since Thomas E. Eidson was stripped of that post in June by Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP, who apparently stepped in after growing increasingly concerned about the public relation firm's financial performance.
Mr. Paster, a veteran Washington insider known for his no-nonsense style, came under fire in the early days of the Clinton Administration from some in Congress who contended that he had failed to reach out to Republicans and had fumbled the President's effort to pass an economic stimulus package.
But he earned plaudits in recent months, particularly for his role in the grueling, come-from-behind campaign that successfully navigated the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement by the House of Representatives.
Shortly after the accord passed the House on Nov. 17, Mr. Paster announced that he would leave the Government, saying that he had tired of the pace in a White House that seems to thrive on late-night, heavily caffeinated strategy sessions led by a President with a sweeping agenda.
When Mr. Paster resigned, he said he would not work as a lobbyist, and he reiterated yesterday that he would excuse himself from Hill & Knowlton business that involved lobbying the Government. But he pointed out that less than 5 percent of the firm's billings involved Washington lobbying.
President Clinton has barred top executive-branch officials from lobbying their old offices for five years after leaving the Government.
Hill & Knowlton -- whose clients include Boeing, Exxon, Pfizer and Mazda -- has 55 offices in 27 countries.
Mr. Paster, who worked briefly in 1992 as head of Hill & Knowlton's Washington office, acknowledged that the firm had been facing difficulties. In 1991, for example, it was assailed by abortion-rights advocates for directing an anti-abortion campaign for the National Council of Catholic Bishops, and by others for representing the Church of Scientology.
The firm was also accused of orchestrating testimony before Congress about allegations of Iraqi atrocities during the Persian Gulf war on behalf of its client, the Kuwaiti Government. Those disputes contributed to the abrupt departure of the firm's chief executive, Robert Dilenschneider, in September 1991 and the ascension of Mr. Eidson, then the firm's chief operating officer.
 
 
'A Difficult Run'
 "Everyone knows that the public relations industry has had a difficult run in the last several years," Mr. Paster said in an interview. "I want to re-establish Hill & Knowlton's primacy as the best in the business. It has a large number of very able people and I think it can again be at the top of the industry."
Jack O'Dwyer, editor of Jack O'Dwyer's Newsletter, which covers the public relations industry, said the appointment of Mr. Paster might give a much-needed boost to Hill & Knowlton's reputation.
"He could be the person who will reinvigorate Hill & Knowlton, which does need new leadership," Mr. O'Dwyer said. "Eidson was a little more introverted. He's a very intelligent person, but he does not have a big persona. Paster has a much bigger public persona and image. And maybe what they need is someone with more public stature. It attracts clients. Paster knows Clinton, is used to power and is out there in the public's eye."
 
 
Three Divisions
 When Mr. Sorrell reorganized Hill & Knowlton in June, he created three divisions -- in the United States, Europe and Asia. Mr. Eidson was essentially demoted to chairman and chief executive of the United States division and chairman of the executive committee overseeing the whole firm.
Mr. Paster, who is to take office on Jan. 1, would now become chairman of the executive committee, the firm said.
In addition to his previous stint at Hill & Knowlton, Mr. Paster worked for 12 years for Timmons & Company, a Washington lobbying and public relations concern also owned by WPP, rising to the post of chairman. He was also a lobbyist for the United Automobile Workers.
In his new job, he will live in Washington and maintain offices in both Washington and New York, where Hill & Knowlton is based.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain Modestly, With Dow Up 6.14

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Optimism fueled by Friday's employment report, and the bond market's failure to wilt despite the report's contents, led to modest gains in stock prices yesterday.
The Labor Department report showed that unemployment fell to a three-year low in November, and led a number of analysts to raise their economic growth forecasts for the coming year. 
 But the bond market, which normally recoils from signs of stronger growth on fears it will generate higher inflation, shrugged off the news on Friday and prices rallied yesterday on a further softening in oil prices. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.16 percent, from 6.23 percent Friday.
"As much psychologically as practically, bonds have been driving the market today," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., money management and equity research firm.
 
Computer-Generated Programs
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 6.14 to close at 3,710.21, one-half point below its record close of 3,710.77 set Nov. 16. A late round of computer-generated sell programs pushed the Dow off what had been a record intraday high of 3,721.39.
On the Big Board, volume was a healthy 292.4 million shares, compared with 268.9 million on Friday. Blue-chip issues led the advance. Of the Dow stocks, I.B.M. rose1/4, to 53 3/4; Merck was up 1/4, to 34 1/4, and Kodak was up 5/8, to 62 7/8.
The market is "pretty decent," said John Shaughnessy, director of research at Advest Inc., "and I'm looking for a pretty strong December. The economy is picking up steam and there seems to be sufficient slack in capacity to keep inflation under control."
For yesterday at least, the bond market's performance helped ease worries that the run-up in interest rates that has taken place since mid-November would not only raise borrowing costs for companies, but also possibly dampen the economic recovery.
Among other stock market averages, the S.& P. 500 index rose 1.54, to 466.43. But the Nasdaq's combined composite index, which has outperformed both the Dow and the S.& P. 500 this year, fell by 1.13, to 771.09.
Thomas Kurlak, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, had a good bit to do with the drop in the Nasdaq index, which is heavily represented with technology issues.
Investors dumped semiconductor shares after Mr. Kurlak said he had cut his 1994 earnings estimates on Intel and Motorola, two of the industry's giants, on concern about a projected slowdown in semiconductor sales.
Intel, one of the most active issues traded yesterday and one of the biggest Nasdaq issues, fell 4, to 59 1/2, on the news.
Motorola was down 2, at 94 1/8, while Applied Materials dropped 2, to 35 3/4, and Micron Technology lost 1 3/8, to 46 5/8.
"The slump in technology stocks has caused a bit of concern, because technology has been a big part of the economy's overall growth," said Joseph DeMarco, a managing director at Marinvest, a subsidiary of the HongKong and Shanghai Bank.
Other decliners included Mellon Bank, which fell 4 3/8, to 53, after it announced it had agreed to buy the Dreyfus Corporation for $1.85 billion. Some analysts said the deal could be dilutive to Mellon's earnings if the company does not buy back some of its shares after the merger.
Meanwhile, shares of the big mutual fund company rose 1 7/8, to 46 3/8, on the news.
Airline stocks were hammered on news of additional fare cuts, causing the Dow Jones transportation index to slump by more than 7 points, to 1,756.35.
The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, dropped 1 1/2, to 150 7/8, and American Airline's parent, AMR, fell 1 1/8, to 65 7/8.

HEADLINE: Once Dull, GATT Enters Realm of Pop Culture

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 2

 BODY:
In the days when the world focused on the number of warheads in East and West, rather than the number of tons of subsidized beef the European Community can export, the bureaucrats at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade labored in peaceful anonymity.
Asked how many calls he would receive a day when he became GATT's chief spokesman 10 years ago, David Woods replied: "A day? You must mean a week. A couple at most. The place was asleep -- depressed, actually." 
 But that was the time of Soviet-American surrogate wars, rather than French-American battles over the production of vegetable oil. Now, as nations have moved from military buildups to contretemps over commerce, GATT has moved to center stage -- at a time when NATO, an organization with a more famous four-letter acronym, casts around somewhat haplessly for a new role.
 
'An Amazing Evolution'
 "It has been an amazing evolution," said Tom Kay, a former Agriculture Department official who has long followed trade issues. "I am still somewhat taken aback by it."
GATT is also adjusting, scurrying to keep up with its booming fortunes. Its main meeting hall still looks more like a corporate board room than the gathering place for decisions the world hangs on. Security checks at the trade organization's headquarters here were introduced for the first time two months ago because, an official said, "it just seemed stupid to have people strolling in with no security when we'd become such a focus of international attention."
Cameras whirl without let-up in the entrance hall as dignitaries file in. Two calls a week to the press department have become several hundred a day. An ad displayed in the headquarters building for a T-shirt with the words "Uruguay Round" urges prospective buyers to "wear the letters that are making headlines." It refers not to a soccer tournament, but to the negotiations on updating and broadening world trade rules that began seven years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and will either be concluded or crash over the next several days.
Sales of the T-shirt, at $13 each, have been brisk, said Leslie Berkowitz, an American who helps run the store at the trade group's headquarters. Sweatshirts saying just "GATT" are also selling well. But other offerings -- studies on "The World Market for Dairy Products," for instance, or "Anti-Dumping And Countervailing Measures Legislation" -- attract a limited clientele.
As the relative appeal of the shirts and the publications suggest, GATT is trendy but also dispiritingly complicated. With the world trade talks facing a Dec. 15 deadline, and the hotly disputed North American Free Trade Agreement now approved, hordes of folks are traipsing into GATT headquarters to press their particular concerns and to try to unearth what is really at stake.
Recently, it was the turn of Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, propelled across the Atlantic by concerns that a GATT accord would limit American industry's ability to protect itself against unfair competition through anti-dumping duties. He was followed by Augusto Bocchini, president of the main European agricultural association, an Italian who quickly demolishes any notion that work on the farm and a Gucci look are incompatible.
Dignitaries are whisked into the headquarters and received by GATT's Director General, Peter Sutherland, an Irish lawyer who took office on July 1 and has managed to bludgeon the world's governments into serious negotiations with a much-repeated message: Failure could lead to anything from a prolonged world economic slump to a gradual unraveling of the Atlantic alliance.
 
Outraged Farmers
 Europe's nine million farmers, whose ability to off-load tons of subsidized food on the world market would be limited by an accord, naturally have a different view. Their representatives say that a GATT agreement, as now envisioned, would be disastrous for them.
The farmers' idea of cataclysm to come was described by Andre Herlitska, Mr. Bocchini's sidekick, a Belgian with a more typically rural air than his boss.
"One-third of full-time agricultural jobs would be lost," Mr. Herlitska declared. "Farm income would fall by about 50 percent. More than 11 million hectares of agricultural land would be idled. It would be an economic disaster for Europe."
All this, the farmers argue, would stem from what is known as the Blair House agreement, concluded late last year between representatives of the European Community and the United States at Blair House in Washington. They agreed to reduce subsidized grain and other food exports from the European Community by 21 percent over the next six years. This provision is supposed to be integrated into a final GATT accord.
How is this possible, Mr. Herlitska was asked. Well, he said, take European cheese.
Worldwide sales of cheese from European countries have been exceedingly good in recent years. But the Blair House agreement stipulates that the reference point for the 21 percent cutback would be average sales in the 1988-90 period. Therefore, Mr. Herlitska said, in the first year an overall GATT accord was in effect, European cheese sales would have to be reduced 22 percent -- 18.5 percent as a result of going back to the 1988-90 reference point from current sales levels, and 3.5 percent more as the first stage toward the 21 percent goal.
 
Cheese Is Harder to Handle
 Like much else in the growing lexicon of GATT data and interpretation, the validity of such an argument is not easy to determine. A few years ago, warheads were warheads, identifiable and limited in number -- but cheese is all over the place.
Might Brie and Camembert really disappear from the supermarkets of Singapore or Manila if the Blair House provision were not changed? Will $274 billion in fact be added to world economic output over the next decade as a result of an accord, as some economists estimate? Do Hollywood movies like "Jurassic Park" in fact threaten the future of the French cinema, necessitating subsidies from Paris for French movies and quotas for United States productions on French television?
No one can definitively answer questions like these. But as Mr. Sutherland continues to receive members of the United States Congress and European lobbyists over the next two weeks in his spacious office overlooking the lake and the distant Alps, he will have a basic message:
For 45 years, the 96-page set of basic rules for international commerce known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has underlay a huge increase in international commerce and wealth, while cutting average tariffs from 40 percent to less than 10 percent.
So, updating, broadening and clarifying those rules can only be beneficial for the world's nations, many of them now economically stagnant, and all of them threatened by dislocation into separate European, Asian and North American trading blocs.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The economy may be improving, but Madison Avenue isn't ready to celebrate just yet.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
ASKEIN of recent statistics indicates the economy may finally be improving. But a leading forecaster is warning Madison Avenue not to break out the Champagne and confetti just yet.
Robert J. Coen, in his semiannual presentation of the outlook for ad spending worldwide, said yesterday that he had reduced his estimates for domestic results this year a third time in addition to trimming his expectations for 1994. 
 "People are skittish about being too optimistic," Mr. Coen, the senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., said after his remarks to the opening session of the 21st annual Paine Webber media conference in Manhattan.
"There are still areas of the country, like the West Coast and metropolitan New York, where retailers and consumers are still kind of traumatized," he added.
Mr. Coen, who has been tracking ad trends for 45 years, said that 1993 domestic spending would total $138.1 billion, up 5.2 percent from $131.3 billion in 1992. By comparison, in June 1992 he predicted 1993 at $143 billion, cut it to $141.2 billion last December and sliced it again to $139.3 billion in June.
And in looking ahead to 1994, he revised downward his June estimate of $149 billion, to $146.8 billion. That means ad spending next year will grow only 6.3 percent from 1993 instead of 7 percent.
"After being on the high side two, three years running," Mr. Coen said, "I'm getting nervous and going on the low side." Still, the 5.2 percent rise he now sees for 1993 would be the most since a 7.7 percent gain in 1988. And his estimates mean that ad spending growth should exceed inflation, because consensus forecasts expect the Consumer Price Index to rise 3 percent in 1993 and 1994.
Mr. Coen's predictions are more closely followed than, say, the correlation between hemlines and stock prices because the rise and fall of ad spending often predicts, and sometimes foretells, the direction of the American economy.
Yet while the overall economic outlook has been glowing more rosily, marketers' enthusiasm for growing ad budgets seems to be lagging.
"Caution suggests that instead of a boom next year," Mr. Coen wrote in a report that accompanied his forecast, "we should more realistically look for moderately better results than those of this year."
A primary reason ad spending apparently would rebound more slowly, he said, despite benefiting from the 1994 Winter Olympics and midterm elections, is "the downsizing process" at many consumer-product companies.
"To make sure profits keep moving up," he said, "they're not supporting marginal brands that in the past they were supporting heavily."
Zenith Media Worldwide, the media services company owned by Saatchi & Saatchi, made a similar point in a report it released yesterday with its own advertising spending forecasts.
"We have been hearing more and more industry leaders asking the formerly unthinkable," the Zenith report said. "Even when consumer confidence, employment and the economy in general improves, will advertising rebound?"
Zenith predicted that American advertising spending would end 1993 at $141.5 billion, up 3.9 percent from $136.2 billion in 1992. And Zenith's prognostication for 1994 is for only a 3.8 percent increase from this year, to $146.9 billion.
The advertising industry has been behaving for some time as if the hatches must remain battened. For instance, Saatchi & Saatchi said yesterday that it would take a $14.9 million charge for additional severance costs, beyond a previously expected charge of $7.45 million, because of reductions in client spending and the losses of its Jeep-Eagle and Helene Curtis accounts. It also plans to vacate its luxurious office in Berkeley Square in London to save an additional $1.8 million.
Outside the United States, Mr. Coen's estimates were slashed, too. Instead of the $169.6 billion he forecast in June, up 4 percent from $163.1 billion in 1992, he now expects, as a result of the stronger dollar, a decline of 1.5 percent, to $163 billion.
That would result in 1993 total worldwide ad spending of $301.1 billion, up 1.5 percent from last year -- a smaller gain than the minuscule 2.1 percent in the recession and war year of 1991. Zenith also reduced its worldwide estimate for 1993, to $312.6 billion, up 4.2 percent from $299.9 billion in 1992.
And Mr. Coen cut his estimate for ad spending overseas in 1994 to $171 billion, up 4.9 percent, from a forecast of $181 billion, up 6.5 percent, that he made in June. That would bring his 1994 total worldwide ad spending prediction to $317.8 billion, up 5.5 percent, compared with his June figure of $330 billion, up 6.7 percent. Zenith, likewise, pared its worldwide estimate for 1994 to $329.6 billion, up 5.4 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Decline As Gold Prices Turn Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday as investors extended a selloff that began Friday when the dollar ran out of stamina despite positive economic news.
Gold prices rose overseas and fell in the United States. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, fell 80 cents, to $377.80 an ounce. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put spot gold at $376.30 an ounce, down 65 cents from Friday. 
 Traders said the dollar continued its fall from Friday, when it was unable to maintain upward momentum despite a strong Labor Department report on employment for November.
"We're going through a position reversal," said Robert Ryan, a vice president at the Bank of New York. "People who have been trading long for a month have decided to take profits."
David Gilmore, an analyst at MCM Currencywatch, said that after the market had received a stream of positive numbers on the economy, it was no longer pushing up the dollar with each new figure.
He said the dollar's price had already taken account of a strong fourth quarter and that it was now "pricing in a slow first quarter."
 
Swiss Franc Is Beneficiary
 Traders said the Swiss franc was the main beneficiary of the dollar's fall. "The Swiss economy might be showing stronger signs of life than the German economy," Mr. Gilmore said, explaining the Swiss franc's appeal. Germany, Europe's largest economy, has suffered from the huge costs of reunification.
In Tokyo, where the trading day began, the dollar closed at 108.18 yen, down 0.67 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, it rose to 108.24 yen. In New York, the dollar finished at 107.96 yen, down from 108.60 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4995, from $1.4905 late Friday. In New York, the pound ended at $1.5039, more expensive than $1.4905 on Friday.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $376.55 a troy ounce, from $375.90 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a late bid of $377.10 vs. $377.00 late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.65 to close at a bid $376.56.
On the New York Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $4.817 a troy ounce, up six-tenths of a cent from Friday.

HEADLINE: Market Place Commonwealth Edison Is Liked Despite Its Debt and High Rates

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
COMMONWEALTH EDISON has embraced nuclear power more fervently than any other electric utility in the nation, and it is best known on Wall Street for the resulting troubles with regulators, consumer groups and environmentalists.
So why then do many Wall Street analysts like the stock? 
 The Chicago-based utility has "some challenges that aren't going to go away but we don't see any significant downside," said Barry M. Abramson, who follows power companies for Prudential Securities in New York. "The difference of opinion on Wall Street now is over how much upside it has for the patient investor."
The heavy investments to build 12 nuclear plants piled up debts and saddled customers with some of the highest rates in the nation. The company also paid dearly for long-term coal contracts signed in the 1970's that linked prices to the general rate of inflation, leaving it with higher fuel bills than its neighbors when coal prices declined.
Because of its blunders, Commonwealth Edison found it difficult to persuade the Illinois Commerce Commission to approve rate increases. The increases won by the utility usually got tied up in court, where they were further whittled down. By last year, Commonwealth Edison had been forced to cut its dividend to $1.60, from $3, and six different rate cases were in various stages of dispute.
Still, the sense that the utility was undervalued began forming last spring. The utility had been cutting operating costs more aggressively. It also won praise for hiring a high-profile outsider, Samuel Skinner, a former chief of staff for President George Bush, as president.
The outlook became substantially clearer in September when the utility and its opponents in the rate cases reached a blanket compromise to settle all of the disputes. The cost to the company was a record $1.34 billion refund to be paid out over the next year, the equivalent of a temporary rate cut of more than 25 percent.
No one on Wall Street called the expensive settlement a victory, but analysts were glad to see the potential for even greater liabilities removed.
In addition, the settlement gave the utility the green light to file another rate increase request as early as the end of this month, which could lead to higher rates in late 1994. Now, the degree of bullishness among analysts stems mostly from how much they expect the company can get from that request.
"The commission really stiffed them in the last case," said Edward J. Tirello Jr. of NatWest Securities in New York. He rates it as one of the few buys in the group. "They should get the rest of their nuclear plants into the rate base this time if the commission follows its own guidelines."
Similarly, Kit Konolige at CS First Boston expects a "significant" rate increase to lift the stock to $38 in 12 to 18 months. The stock closed yesterday at $28.25, up 25 cents. Any increase would come with a safe dividend, currently yielding 5.66 percent, about average for the electric utility group.
Moreover, it would add little to costs to generate surplus power at the nuclear plants for sale to other utilities.
Skeptics say history makes it hard to be optimistic about the rate cases. They also wonder if the company can maintain the downward trend in maintenance spending it began this year, noting that six of the nuclear plants are about two decades old.
Continued operating savings are vital, especially if competition forces Commonwealth Edison to cut prices to major customers, because the fixed expenses stemming from past investments will be high for years to come.

HEADLINE: Latin Nations Set Trade Pact

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Colombia, Venezuela and Mexico have worked out details of a free trade pact, which will be signed in January, according to reports issued on Sunday.
The agreement, intended to create a $373 billion economic market encompassing some 145 million people is the latest in a series of trade pacts by Latin American countries seeking to open their once-protectionist economies. 
 After three days of intense negotiations, representatives agreed on Saturday that trade ministers of the three nations would sign the agreement the week of Jan. 10, the daily newspaper El Tiempo said. The agreement must also be signed by the presidents of the three countries.
Last month, lawmakers in the United States and Mexico gave final approval to the North American Free Trade Agreement, under which the United States, Canada and Mexico will lower barriers to trade with one another.

President Clinton was not the only out-of-town draw on the party circuit in Hollywood during the weekend: RUSH LIMBAUGH, the outspoken talk show host, did admirably considering that the cocktail party given by Pocket Books to celebrate the publication of his second book, "See, I Told You So," was held the same evening that the President was at an exclusive ($25,000 a couple) fund-raiser at the home of Marvin Davis. HEADLINE: Italy's Great Red Hope?

 BODY:
In municipal elections on Sunday, voters in five major Italian cities chose the more moderate alternative -- the candidates backed by the former Communist Party, now known as the Democratic Party of the Left.
The former Communists now plausibly, though paradoxically, offer themselves as the strongest remaining champion of a unified, democratic and European-oriented Italy in the months leading up to next year's national parliamentary elections. 
 With the scandal-ridden centrist parties eliminated in first-round voting two weeks ago, coalition candidates backed by the former Communists stood head-to-head against neo-Fascists in Rome and Naples and regional separatists in Genoa, Venice and Trieste. Though the rightists and regionalists emerged as the largest parties in their respective strongholds, the left coalitions captured the mayors' jobs.
Italy's Communists were among the first anywhere to proclaim their full acceptance of parliamentary democracy. They have long held power at local and regional levels and their nationwide vote of between 20 and 30 percent made them a kind of silent partner in several national governments.
What's different now is that the seismic corruption scandals of the past few years have shattered all their main national competitors. That leaves the former Communists, at least for now, as the main standard-bearer against the radical right.
For years, Washington actively promoted Italy's Christian Democratic and Socialist parties and their smaller centrist allies as a strategic bulwark against the largest Communist Party in the West. On its own cold-war terms, American policy succeeded. Italy remained a member of NATO and enjoyed decades of impressive economic growth.
But Italians paid a price. Payoffs inflated the cost of local government and paralyzed the administration of impartial justice. And the centrist coalition became entrenched as a permanent government, stifling any realistic possibility of healthy democratic renewal.
The collapse of Soviet power theoretically opened the possibility of change. But it took the prosecution of top Christian Democratic and Socialist leaders and their business allies to smash the existing political system.
The post-Communists, as the only major national party not deeply implicated in the scandals, were one beneficiary. So were the previously marginal neo-Fascists of the Italian Social Movement and the regionalists of the recently organized Northern League. The democratic credentials of all three are open to suspicion. But the post-Communists have gone furthest to dispel the doubts.

HEADLINE: McCall Seeks Repayments For Pensions

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 6

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said today that he would give New York State and its local governments at least 12 years to make restitution for a $4 billion raid on the state pension system that was ruled illegal last month.
His reimbursement plan will allow the state and local governments to repay relatively small sums in the next few years, including the 1994 election year, and much larger sums near the turn of the century. 
 The plan, which could be challenged in court, brought sharp criticism today from Mr. McCall's political opponents, who asserted that the Comptroller was giving an election-year gift to his mentor, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. It also was condemned by the state employees' unions that challenged the pension raid in court.
 
Sopping Up Red Ink
 Mr. Cuomo and the State Legislature devised the pension gimmick in 1990 as a desperate measure to fill a $2 billion gap in the 1990-91 state budget. It was one of several fiscal maneuvers, including the sale of state roads and prisons to quasi-public authorities, that New York used to sop up red ink at the height of the recession.
By changing the pension system's actuarial requirements, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature made possible a huge reduction in annual payments to the pension fund by employers, meaning the state and the hundreds of local governments and police and fire departments that use the state's retirement system. As a result of the change, the state's contributions to the pension system dropped to $3.1 million in 1991 from $470 million in 1990.
Last month the state's top court, the Court of Appeals, ruled that the change was illegal because it abrogated the Comptroller's authority as sole trustee of the pension fund. The 6-0 decision also said the actions of the Governor and the Legislature had impaired the fund's security. The court ordered that the pension system return to its old accounting method and be compensated for its losses, which will amount to $4 billion by March.
As the sole trustee of the $56 billion pension system, which includes 860,000 active members and retirees, Mr. McCall has the unilateral authority to devise a repayment schedule for the state and local governments. New York City has its own pension system and is not affected by Mr. McCall's decision.
 
Arbitrary Formula
 The plan Mr. McCall unveiled, which is based on an arbitrary formula, requires that small sums be paid back in the coming fiscal year. The state, which has a $60 billion budget, will pay $30 million above its previously anticipated pension payments.
Local governments and police and fire departments will be charged a total of $60 million above their anticipated payments. The town of Oyster Bay, L.I., for instance, will pay an additional $147,230, while the city of Yonkers will pay an additional $277,674.
The reimbursement amounts will increase gradually through the rest of the decade. But not until 1999 will the state and local governments have to make larger payments than they would have if the pension accounting change had not been struck down.
Mr. McCall defended his decision by saying it would help local governments avoid budgetary chaos. Although the state's fiscal year begins on April 1, many local governments already have adopted budgets for fiscal years that begin on Jan. 1.
"An immediate charge-back of the money owed would have severe financial ramifications on some local governments in the state, possibly forcing layoffs of the very employees I'm trying to help," Mr. McCall said. "A pension doesn't matter if you don't have a job."
 
Postponing Budgetary Pain
 But the repayment schedule also gives significant help to Mr. Cuomo by postponing most of the budgetary pain for the state until after the 1994 election. Mr. Cuomo may be running for a fourth four-year term then, leading a Democratic ticket that will almost certainly include Mr. McCall.
Mr. McCall was Mr. Cuomo's running-mate choice in his 1982 election as governor, but Mr. McCall lost in the Democratic primary. Mr. Cuomo supported the Legislature's selection of him as comptroller this year after Edward V. Regan resigned.
Mr. Cuomo, who will propose his 1994-95 budget next month, has said he hopes to enact tax cuts and reductions in various fees next year, and he already is committed to increasing spending on mental health and the environment. A significant new pension cost, like the extra $241 million the state will owe in 1999, would make it difficult to afford such politically popular initiatives.
A Republican legislator who may run against Mr. McCall next year harshly criticized the plan. "Sadly, it appears that the schedule to pay back the absconded pension money is dictated more by Governor Cuomo's political calendar than actuarial prudence," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Columbia County Republican who has announced his campaign for comptroller.
Mr. McCall said the plan's impact on Mr. Cuomo "was never a consideration."
 
Criticized by Union Leaders
 Leaders of the largest unions of state workers said today that they recognized that it would be irresponsible to require the state and local governments to repay the full $4 billion immediately.
But they said Mr. McCall's plan "doesn't go far enough fast enough," in the words of Joseph McDermott, president of the Civil Service Employees Association.
"He had an opportunity to show leadership but instead took the expedient route," Mr. McDermott said.
Spokesmen for Mr. McDermott and for Howard A. Shafer, president of the Public Employees Federation, said their unions would explore whether to return to court to challenge Mr. McCall's plan.
Mr. McCall said he "understood how union leaders have to make statements that impress their members."
He said the unions were trying to use the pension-repayment issue as leverage to persuade the Governor and Legislature to supplement pension payments with a cost-of-living adjustment or other increase.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's plan for New York State to repay money that it diverted illegally from the state's pension system misstated one effect of the plan. Because the former accounting system for the pension fund is being phased back in, it will not be until the 1999 fiscal year that state and local governments' annual contributions to the fund are greater than if Mr. McCall had required a return to the former accounting method immediately. The 1999 comparison in the article was drawn, incorrectly, with a method struck down last month by the Court of Appeals. That new accounting method was approved by the Governor and Legislature in 1990 and enabled a $4 billion raid on the pension fund.
