HEADLINE: Culture Dispute With Paris Now Snags World Accord

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
With arguments resolved over wheat and corn subsidies, as well as exports of pig meat and skimmed milk powder, the world trade talks came down to this today: Can the United States tolerate France's determination to go on protecting and subsidizing its movie industry in order to stave off a perceived Hollywood onslaught from the likes of "Jurassic Park" and "Terminator 2?"
After almost 23 hours of negotiations with the European Community's chief negotiator on Monday and today, the answer from Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, was no. 
 He then left Brussels to explain his views to world trade negotiators in Geneva, before returning to Washington. Mr. Kantor intended to continue talks in Europe, but it was not immediately clear when they would resume.
Although Mr. Kantor said there was still sufficient time to wrap up an accord, the former Hollywood lawyer said he would stand firm on trying to abolish France's box-office levies on foreign-made movies, which it uses to subsidize French film making.
His declaration came after the marathon negotiations with the Europeans had engineered a settlement on the long-divisive agriculture issues that the French, long intransigent on farm issues, had finally approved.
There was one clear victory for Mr. Kantor today. After years of a Japanese ban on rice imports, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa said he would reluctantly open the market to foreign rice, removing a big stumbling block to the conclusion of the talks by the Dec. 15 deadline. [Page D1.]
 
Hopes Raised for Accord
 The agreement on farm trade had significantly raised hopes that the European Community and the United States would declare a trade peace, substantially clearing the way for successful completion of the seven-year-long world trade talks, which are intended to lift tariffs and revive the international economy. On Dec. 15, President Clinton's special authority to frame an accord and send it to Congress for an up-or-down, no-amendments vote expires.
But with the differences between Europeans and Americans persisting, uncertainty hovered around the negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, even though powerful momentum appeared to have gathered on both sides of the Atlantic to insure an accord by the deadline.
 
'So Much is at Stake'
 "We have made so much progress and so much is at stake, it simply can't be possible that a deal of this magnitude will not be finalized," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's negotiator, said after briefing community foreign ministers on his talks with Mr. Kantor.
Long overshadowed by the fight over farm issues in the world trade talks, the simmering conflict over movies, television programs and musical recordings is gaining prominence here.
A variety of French resentments and doubts have coalesced around a dark vision of Hollywood's dinosaurs gobbling up the last vestiges of cultural independence in Europe.
The issue has contrived to channel old French convictions about the crassness of American movies and television, and new French economic and cultural insecurity, into a single crusade, the theme of which was bluntly expressed by the actor and singer Renaud: "It's 'Dallas' or French creativity."
The United States, in turn, has become increasingly angry at what it sees as France's attempt to provide unfair protection and financing for its film industry while indulging in a wave of anti-Americanism thinly disguised behind pious expressions of concern for European culture.
Daniel Toscan de Plantier, president of Unifrance, the association that promotes French films, acknowledged that Hollywood in effect supported the French movie industry, but he argued that this was justified.
"We receive 100 percent of the tax and U.S. movies account for 57 percent of the box-office return, so Hollywood supports us," he said. "What is good for France is good for France because it is not good for the United States and other countries."
However, he added, Hollywood effectively barred French movies from wide distribution in the United States. "When he have 10 percent of the U.S. market," he said, "we will suppress our taxes and levies."
 
American States the Essential
 Mr. Kantor was firm, as well. "No Uruguay Round of trade talks will be finalized," he insisted, "unless this issue is resolved." He referred specifically to the way that audio-visual material would be bought and sold under the new trade rules, on which negotiations began in 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay.
Looking tired after the negotiating marathon, the American representative added that he was "disappointed but not discouraged, whatsoever" that a complete settlement of trade problems with Europe had proved elusive. And he said the outlines of "the most sweeping trade agreement in history" were visible. "There is absolutely and without a doubt enough time," Mr. Kantor said, to meet the Dec. 15 deadline.
Sir Leon, while declaring that he "repudiated entirely" the American arguments over the movie trade that led to the breakdown of talks, also said that an accord was within reach.
On the issue of the movie tax, Mr. Kantor argued that because 57 percent of box-office receipts in France came from American movies, money that was rightfully American was being diverted into French hands to pay for film subsidies. Similarly, the levies on television movies, most of them American, and on videocassettes, amounted to a way of milking American talent to support the French.
Resolving this dispute -- which has emerged because the current talks are aimed for the first time at extending GATT rules to services -- is certain to be arduous.
The conflict brings two very big things face to face: a huge American export industry -- the nation's second largest after aerospace with sales in Europe alone of $3.7 billion last year -- and a huge dose of Gallic pride, viscerally attached to the notion that France is the sanctuary of serious cinema.
"We have a formal commitment from Prime Minister Edouard Balladur not to yield on this issue," said Mr. Toscan de Plantier, the French movie-industry official. "The livelihoods of 70,000 people in the French film industry depend on this."
Besides the foreign film tax, which amounts to 11 percent on a ticket, American objections to current French practice have centered on a quota system used to limit the amount of American programming on television. The levies apply to TV movies and to videocassettes, and they raised about $350 million last year. This money, in turn, was distributed by a Government group to subsidized production of about 150 French films.
The quota system stems from a European Community directive adopted in 1989 that calls on television stations in the European Community's 12 countries to reserve a majority of air time for European-produced material. France has interpreted this directive the most assiduously, insisting that 60 percent of programs be reserved for European material, the bulk of it French.
The issue has become particularly thorny now that several United States media companies want to provide cable- or satellite-delivered services like cartoon channels that would clearly violate the quotas.
"These quotas will be a serious threat to the future of American movies and TV programs unless they are halted or phased out over a number of years," the American Motion Picture Association said in a statement. "Moreover, the new technology -- satellite-delivered programs, pay-per-view, premium subscription channels on cable, all the magic of new ways to hurl programs all over Europe at the speed of light -- this new technology cannot be restricted by artificial barriers planted by parliaments."
 
A Deal, but Not Any Deal
 Mr. Kantor indicated that a compromise on quotas could be found, but he was firm in rejecting the French system of taxes and other charges used to subsidize its movie industry, the most substantial film business left in Europe.
"We are willing to try to deal with broadcast quotas and to work on the question of subsidies," he said, "but we are not willing to sell out the rights of hard-working individuals to collect their royalties. American producers and actors are not getting their full royalties."
His tone suggested that President Clinton had drawn a line at this issue and that there would be little room for negotiation as the deadline for a GATT accord approached. The President has a vital electoral base in California and declared in October on the audio-visual products question that "this is a vital jobs issue as well as a fairness issue for America."
Alain Juppe, the French Foreign Minister, summed up national sentiment in declaring today that "America has shown intransigence over the audio-visual question."
He also listed other issues -- especially a need to toughen European trade legislation to make it as effective as American laws, and continuing differences over subsidies to the civil aircraft industry -- as standing in the way of a GATT agreement.

HEADLINE: After Stern Lecture, Man in Riot Beating Gets Maximum Term

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
With a stern lecture and a final, silent showing of the brutal videotapes with which the case began, a judge today sentenced Damian M. Williams to a maximum 10-year term for a series of beatings that have come to symbolize the Los Angeles riots 19 months ago. Under California law he is likely to serve about three and a half years.
"Mr. Williams, it is intolerable in this society to attack and maim people because of their race," said Judge John Ouderkirk of Superior Court, referring to attacks by the black defendant that included the beating of three Hispanic victims, an Asian and a white truck driver, Reginald O. Denny. 
 Mr. Williams, who was acquitted in October of a series of charges that could have sent him to prison for life, was sentenced to eight years for felony mayhem on Mr. Denny and four consecutive six-month sentences for misdemeanor assault on the other victims.
Mr. Williams, who is now 20 years old, frowned as his sentence was pronounced, then smiled and gave a thumbs-up sign. His lawyer, Edi M. O. Faal, said later that Mr. Williams had expected the maximum sentence and that he was demonstrating feelings of relief at the end of the proceedings.
In an interview with the Wave Newspaper Group, a newspaper chain that mainly serves a black readership, Mr. Williams said of the riots, "People were just out of control like a pack of rats running after cheese." He added, "I was just caught up in the rapture."
"What we did was wrong," he went on in the interview. "It was unjustified, even though it was in the heat of the moment. Being in jail has caused me to mature a lot and I see that." The interview is to be published Wednesday.
The District Attorney's Office said that with good behavior, Mr. Williams was likely to spend only the next three years and eight months in prison given the time he has already spent in jail, 18 months, and a pattern in California in which prisoners normally serve half their terms. Mr. Faal said he would appeal the convictions and hoped that his client would be free sooner.
Judge Ouderkirk today also confirmed a plea bargain for Mr. Williams's co-defendant, Henry K. Watson, 29. He will remain free on probation following a conviction on one count of misdemeanor assault and a guilty plea to a felony assault on which the jury had been deadlocked.
 
Some See Bias in System
 Today's sentencing brought to a close more than two years of criminal proceedings that have created turmoil in Los Angeles following the videotaped beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King, by white police officers in March 1991.
Mr. Williams's crimes were part of a storm of violence that swept the city on April 29, 1992, when four officers were acquitted of assault charges in a state trial. Two of the officers were later convicted in a Federal trial of violating Mr. King's civil rights; they are now serving 30-month sentences in prison.
Supporters of Mr. Williams say they believe he is being treated more harshly than the officers because of a racial bias in the criminal justice system.
The Rev. Cecil Murray of the First A.M.E. Church, one of the city's most influential black ministers, said: "Some say these cases are legally different, but contextually this says to blacks that the pattern of history continues. If you are going to have mercy, let's be consistent."
 
'He Represents Violence'
 Judge Ouderkirk made a point of explicating the legal bases of his sentencing today and of emphasizing the extent of Mr. Williams's violence, the helplessness of his victims and what he described as his lack of remorse. "It is hard to credit the statement of remorse given by Mr. Williams to his probation officer, given the defendant's spitting on Mr. Denny and his victory dance performed in the intersection within a few feet of Mr. Denny's bloody body," the judge said.
Deputy District Attorney Janet Moore, whose prosecution case was rejected almost entirely by the jury, told a news conference: "I hate what Mr. Williams did. I hate what Mr. Williams represents. He represents violence. He represents brutality."
Peter Arenella, a law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who has been following the case, said: "In any sentencing decision there's a balance drawn between the needs of the community and the culpability of the individual defendant. In this case, Judge Ouderkirk clearly focused almost exclusively on the needs of the community to send a stern message about what will happen to individuals who engage in violent criminal behavior during a riot."
Among those who disagreed with the judge was Carolyn Walters, the forewoman of the jury, who is an unemployed legal secretary. Outside the courtroom today, she said she believed that Mr. Williams should have received a sentence of two years, which would have allowed him to walk free because of the time he has already served.
"I'm sure politics had a lot to do with the sentence," she said. "I would have to say the procedures themselves were not fair. The charges were excessive, and I believe this sentence is not fair. It is too harsh."
Mr. Williams is the most visible of a dozen men tried in connection with the scores of beatings that were captured on videotape at the intersection of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central Los Angeles during the first hours of the riots. The replaying of portions of videotapes in the courtroom were a reminder of the brutality of that day, during which crowds of men swept through the intersection, chasing down and attacking motorists. Most of the attackers have never been identified or brought to trial.
Though the trial was over and the sentence passed, debate continued in this divided city over race and judicial fairness. Melanie Lomax, a black lawyer and former member of the city's Police Commission, said, "My head tells me that there was something right in this sentence because the judge utterly rejected the notion that Damian Williams was not responsible for his actions."
But Roy Evans, who is black and the president of Bridge Back, a work furlough program for juvenile offenders, said of the sentencing, "This is an excellent example of the kind of dual justice we have in Southern California, one for blacks and one for whites."
Stephen Clark, president of the New Frontier Democratic Club, the oldest black political club in the city, said, "I'm just glad that the episode is over." Mr. Clark said he hoped that attention would now turn from court proceedings to the social and economic issues that underlie the city's divisions and violence.

HEADLINE: Japanese Reluctantly Agree to Open Rice Market

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
After decades of declarations that rice farmers hold a sacred place in Japan that must be protected from foreign incursions, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa said today that Japan would reluctantly open its rice market to imports, removing a major stumbling block to the conclusion of world trade talks by the middle of next week.
In South Korea, which also has a highly protected rice market, farmers and politicians took to the streets today when it became clear that President Kim Young Sam had secretly agreed to a deal almost identical to Japan's. 
 More than 30,000 protesters gathered in front of the main railroad station in Seoul, and there were violent clashes as thousands surged toward the American Embassy carrying signs, condemning the United States for bringing ruin to the country's 5.7 million farmers.
 
Political Turmoil in Japan
 In Japan, the Socialist Party, the biggest component of the eight-party coalition Government that came to power this year, and the most steadfast defender of Japanese farmers, threatened to leave the coalition, an event that would likely cause the Government's collapse.
In addition, the opposition Liberal Democrats, who had long governed the country, were maneuvering to use the rice issue to derail Mr. Hosokawa's political reform efforts and bring an end to the 70 percent approval rating he has enjoyed.
California growers, who specialize in the short-grain rice favored in Japan, would benefit from an opening of the Japanese market. If Japan were to turn to California for just 5 percent of its annual rice consumption of about 10 million metric tons, it would absorb one-quarter of the state's maximum crop of about two million metric tons.
Gulf Coast growers, who raise long-grain rice, America's dominant rice crop, would be unlikely to win a big stake of the Japanese market, but would still benefit if the move had the effect of raising world rice prices.
"This is an extremely significant, very positive development for the California rice industry and for rice growers everywhere," said John W. Kenward of the Rice Growers Association in West Sacramento, Calif.
In Japan, Mr. Hosokawa is expected to make the landmark announcement, whose symbolism and political importance here outweigh its economic impact, in a speech to the nation on Friday, members of his Cabinet said today.
Given the obvious political sensitivities, Mr. Hosokawa's Government has carefully stage-managed the rice debate for months. It waited until the last moment to agree to the opening of the market so that it would appear that Japan was cornered by its trading partners who are struggling to complete a world accord by Dec. 15.
Government leaders publicly insisted that they would never open the market, but in private acknowledged that it was inevitable and said the real task was to prepare the groundwork so that they could keep the political backlash to a minimum.
The draft accord that was "sent" to Japan today by trade negotiators in Geneva, who are arguing over crucial late changes under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, was actually worked out by Japan and the United States several weeks ago and has been circulating in Tokyo for some time.
Even before Mr. Hosokawa's declaration, however, the political rebellion threatened many of the economic and anti-corruption reforms at the center of Japan's slow-burning political revolution.
While Mr. Hosokawa's political lieutenants seemed relatively sure that the Socialists' threat to walk out was a bluff, staged for the benefit of their farmer constituents, they were clearly concerned that whatever magic seemed to surround the first 100 days of his premiership was quickly wearing off.
In the last week, Mr. Hosokawa has issued contradictory statements on how and when he would announce an economic stimulus package to rescue Japan's troubled economy and all but abandoned his commitment to pass a political reform bill by the end of the year. He also dismissed his Defense Minister for speaking openly about amending the Japanese Constitution.
 
Face-Saving Formula
 "This has not been our finest few days," one of his political operatives said tonight. In the end Mr. Hosokawa worked out a face-saving formula that allowed him to claim at least the smallest victory. But Japanese industrialists, who have long called for dismantling the rice lobby, were ecstatic, saying they favored any move that would lead to freer world trade and expanded markets for their goods.
For years, Japan has resisted calls that every participant in GATT move to an "all tariffs" system that would have swept away rules like the one barring the import of foreign rice. Japan won agreement to a six-year moratorium on tariffs, in return for a formula in which foreign producers are given "minimum access" to the market, in this case 4 percent to 8 percent.
One year before the grace period ends, Japan is supposed to enter another negotiation over whether to extend the moratorium. Mr. Hosokawa's aides strongly denied today that the draft agreement required Japan to accept a tariff system after six years, but it appeared to do exactly that.
Given the fact that the rice agreement had been settled with the Japanese and GATT negotiators several weeks ago, Tsutomu Hata, Japan's Foreign Minister, made it clear that the Government would not press for further changes.
"This proposal is virtually the final one," Mr. Hata said, To ease the way, Finance Minister Hirohisa Fujii hinted today that the Government would compensate farmers hurt by the new trade rules.
For decades, Japan has cast its refusal to open the rice market as an issue of both national security and cultural identity. Though Japanese rice consumption has plummeted as the country has grown more affluent, the Government insisted for years that Japanese must be able to be self-sufficient rice producers, even if it meant that consumers had to pay six to eight times the world price.
Moreover, Japanese are taught from earliest youth that the crop is one with the national soul. Rice is harvested every year by the Emperor in a palace ritual, and offered to the gods at Shinto shrines. Each grain is regarded as a kami, or deity, in the Shinto religion. At one time, rice was the currency in which Japanese paid taxes.
But oddly enough it did not become a major part of Japanese cuisine until 150 years ago. And Japan has imported rice before, particularly from Korea when it was still Japanese territory from 1905 to the end of World War II.
The cultural aura surrounding rice has also served a critical political end: Sustaining the powerful rice farmers and assuring their prosperity. For years, as voters moved to the cities, farmers maintained a disproportionate share of the vote in Japanese elections. And although they are among the most inefficient producers of rice in the world, they became the symbol of how the interests of producers took precedence over those of urban consumers.
Rice's sacred standing in society here bred resentments, and fed into the calls for political change that Mr. Hosokawa capitalized on earlier this year when the long-dominant Liberal Democrats were swept from office. He was clearly delighted when a rice shortage this year forced Japan to set aside its rules and import limited quantities, and he suggested to foreign correspondents several months ago that those events would ease the way for permanent liberalization.

HEADLINE: Fed Official In Warning On Inflation

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
A top Federal Reserve official cautioned today that there were early signs that inflation might be picking up and that the central bank should make sure that did not happen.
"This is an important time for monetary policy," the Fed's vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., told a forum sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute. "We're at an important crossroads." 
 But the Fed official told reporters after his speech that he was not arguing for a pre-emptive strike against inflation.
"There is no compelling evidence at this time that inflationary pressures are building," Mr. Mullins told the forum. But he added that "there are some other early warning signals that are twitching, or starting to twitch." Among them were higher gold and commodity prices and increasing bond yields, which often advance as expectations of inflation mount.
"The increase in long bond rates needs to be a special concern," Mr. Mullins said. "If inflation starts moving, and long rates move up, this hurts not only long-term growth prospects but it likely hurts near-term growth prospects."
He was generally upbeat, however, about the outlook for the economy.
"We're having a strong fourth quarter," he said. But it was unclear, he said, whether it would be as strong as the corresponding period of 1992, when the economy grew at a rate of 5.7 percent. He saw modest growth ahead, of 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent.
 
Survey of Buyers
 A similar economic assessment came today from the National Association of Purchasing Management, an organization of the nation's wholesale buyers.
In its semiannual survey of its members, the group predicted 1994 economic growth of 4.7 percent, before adjusting for inflation of 2.1 percent.
The most upbeat industries were paper, electronics, jewelry, toys, sporting goods, musical instruments, food and beverages, printing and publishing, wood and apparel.
The trade group also said holiday retail sales this year promised to be the strongest in 10 years. But the survey warned that employment would decline next year because corporations would continue to lay off workers.
In the survey, 59 percent of the respondents said they thought President Clinton's health care plan would hurt their companies.

HEADLINE: 5 Research Teams to Hunt for New Drugs in Nature, Gently

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Government today announced the first awards under a program to find and produce new drugs from plants and animals in the developing world while preserving endangered species.
Five groups, each representing unusual collaborations among university researchers, environmental organizations, pharmaceutical companies, museums and government agencies, will share $2.5 million a year for five years. 
 Developing new drugs from natural products not only may produce treatments for diseases like cancer and AIDS; it could also promote economic growth in emerging nations through sustainable harvesting instead of clearing forests for conventional farming or other land uses that can wipe out species, officials said.
Reversing conventional development trends requires solutions that will benefit not only the environment but also populations that need economic alternatives, said Dr. Philip E. Schambra, director of the Fogarty International Center. The center is the international arm of the National Institutes of Health, a sponsor of the program.
 
Counterparts in Six Nations
 The five awards under the International Cooperative Biodiversity Groups Program unite American scientists and institutions with their counterparts in Argentina, Cameroon, Chile, Costa Rica, Mexico and Suriname.
More than 20 research institutions and organizations worldwide are to be involved in the effort, which is sponsored by the United States Agency for International Development and the National Science Foundation, along with the health institutes.
Dr. Francesca Grifo, who manages the program for the Fogarty center, said each of the winning projects calls for gathering data on conventional medicines, prospecting for biological chemicals active against disease and testing them, training native people to do the work, and sharing the patents and royalties from any commercial products with people from the region where the material was found.
 
Five Teams Named
 Dr. David G. I. Kingston of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, Va., leads a team that is studying rain forest plants in Suriname. Together with Conservation International, the Missouri Botanical Garden and Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceutical Research Institute, researchers are working with forest people to identify traditional plant medicines that have drug potential.
A team headed by Dr. Walter Lewis of Washington University in St. Louis, which included the Monsanto Company, is to look at medicinal plants used in the Andean rain forests of Peru.
Dr. Jerrold Meinwald of Cornell University, working with Bristol-Myers Squibb, leads a team that will go to Costa Rica and look at insects and related species as potential sources of drugs. In addition, Costa Rican scientists and students will train at Cornell on how to isolate potentially useful chemicals from insects.
Dr. Brian G. Schuster of the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, working with the Smithsonian Institution and two drug companies, will study rain forest plants in Nigeria and Cameroon for treatments for parasitic diseases.
Researchers led by Dr. Barbara N. Timmermann of the University of Arizona is to look for drugs and crop-protection agents that might be found in plants from arid and semi-arid areas of Latin America. The American Cyanamid Company, along with Louisiana State University and Purdue University, will assist in looking at plants from Mexico, Chile and Argentina.

HEADLINE: Consumer Installment Debt Jumps

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Increasingly confident consumers took on an unexpectedly large $8.1 billion more of new installment debt in October than they paid off, a tally by the Federal Reserve showed today.
Even though previously published figures had shown hefty gains in sales of automotive and other retail goods during October, analysts said today that they were impressed by the degree to which consumers were willing to take on fresh debt. 
 "It's a barometer of consumer confidence," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, calling the Fed's report a "very good precursor" for the holiday season. "The consumer's willing to borrow again -- and borrow confidently."
 
Mortgage Refinancings Help
 The October increase was believed to be the biggest gain since January 1988, except for a big jump a year later that reflected technical changes in compilation. A main reason for consumers' willingness to take on new debt, Mr. Platt said, is that many households have taken advantage of the lowest long-term interest rates in two decades to refinance mortgages, sometimes more than once, sharply lowering their monthly payments.
A second report today by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America showed mortgage delinquencies fell to a 19-year low during the third quarter. All geographic regions and all loan types and categories of delinquency showed improvement.
"With employment and incomes firming up across the board, fewer people are struggling to make their mortgage payments," Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the trade group, said.
Only 4.21 percent of homeowners were behind in making mortgage payments in the July-September period, a reversal following a second-quarter jump that carried the delinquency rate to 4.39 percent from 4.29 percent.
The Mortgage Bankers Association found that 30-day delinquencies fell 12 basis points, to 2.78 percent. The two more serious categories also declined. Sixty-day delinquencies were down 4 basis points, to 0.65 percent, while 90-day delinquencies improved 2 basis points, to 0.78 percent.
The Fed's report on installment debt was marked by a $3.9 billion rise in outstanding automotive credit and included a very substantial $3.2 billion advance for revolving credit, a widely watched component that includes credit cards.
The rest of the gain, $1 billion, was in the "other" category, which covers such things as loans for mobile homes, tuition, boats and travel.
"The ability to take on debt is still very favorable," said Susan M. Sterne, a student of consumer behavior and president of Economic Analysis Associates in Stowe, Vt., in reaction to today's report. "It's a big positive for the fourth quarter."
Ms. Sterne cautioned, however, that consumers might have reached the limits of their spending and borrowing and that some other source of strength would probably be needed if the economy is to keep moving smartly ahead in 1994, when upper-income taxpayers are faced with paying 1993 tax increases that took effect retroactively.
The $8.1 billion rise in October debt outstanding was well above the $5 billion that had been generally expected and also exceeded September's advance, which the Fed revised downward to $6.1 billion. The October rise was at a 12.7 percent annual rate, compared with a 9.6 percent rate of increase in September, to bring the seasonally adjusted total to $776.71 billion.
The installment debt figures are rougher than many provided by the Government because the breakdown of extensions and liquidations was dropped years ago for unreliability and because they do not include such fast-growing substitutes as automobile leasing and home equity loans.
"But still, the revolving credit component is important to watch from the standpoint of helping to boost consumption," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
The Fed's report today also showed that interest rates charged by commercial banks on four-year new car loans averaged 7.63 percent in November, down from 7.98 percent in August. Two-year personal loans were 13.22 percent, down from 13.45 percent, and credit cards were 16.30 percent, down from 16.59 percent.

HEADLINE: Texas County Retreats Over Apple's Gay Policy

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Tex., Dec. 7

 BODY:
A Texas county beat a clear retreat today in its battle over Apple Computer's policy of granting health benefits to homosexual couples. Williamson County, eager to attract high-tech jobs, offered new tax breaks that the company quickly accepted, calling them equal to those the county commissioners turned down last week in protest of that policy.
As he did last week, Commissioner David Hays provided the swing vote at a jammed meeting at the courthouse in Georgetown, the county seat. After arm-twisting by Gov. Ann W. Richards, who had lobbied to keep Apple from going to another state, Mr. Hays joined two other commissioners to approve nearly $1 million in tax incentives to Apple in return for the company's agreeing to build an office complex in this suburban county a few miles north of Austin. Apple said it planned a ground-breaking next spring on the $80 million customer support center. 
 Explaining the difference between the package rejected last week and the one ratified today required a bit of semantic legerdemain. In the first case, Apple would have received a formal tax abatement; now, it will pay full taxes but receive a reimbursement from the county for the costs of road construction and other work it will undertake near the 128-acre site.
Apple Computer Inc. was delighted. "To us, it's essentially the same agreement we had before," said Lisa Byrne, a spokeswoman.
 
Different Bookkeeping
 Nonetheless, Mr. Hays insisted that the county was no longer giving public money to Apple, instead only returning Apple's own money to the company, and he said he stood by both of his votes.
"Last week I was asked to vote to use taxpayer dollars to subsidize, and therefore tacitly endorse, a benefits policy with which I disagree," he explained to the crowd at this morning's county meeting. "Today's vote does nothing of the kind."
Despite his explanation, gay-rights organizations hailed the vote as a victory and local opponents of gay rights denounced Mr. Hays as a traitor.
"Yesterday, David Hays was a statesman," said Mike East, a radio talk-show host in Austin who had helped lead the move to deny the tax breaks. "Today, he became a politician."
Mr. East and dozens of his fellow Williamson County residents wore tags pinned on their shirts that read: "Just Say, No! An Apple today will take family values away." A roughly equal number of others in the crowd had stickers proclaiming, "Keep Apple in Williamson County" or "Hate is not a family value."
One man circulated through the crowd, handing out a religious tract, "This Was Your Life!" about Judgment Day. He attached mimeographed pages of the Bible with verses pertaining to homosexuality highlighted in a yellow pen.
 
Unwanted Attention
 After achieving a moment of largely unexpected and unwanted national fame as the place willing to kick away 1,500 high-tech jobs by standing up against Apple over the benefits issue, community leaders here seemed relieved by today's vote and hoped the controversy was behind them.
"Lord, we confide to you that these last seven days have felt like seven years," said the Rev. Jim Chandler, pastor of the First United Methodist Church of Round Rock, in an invocation shortly before the commissioners' vote. "Lord, lift us above this controversy, out of this whirlwind."
Ever since the first vote last Tuesday, the county has become the focus of controversy around the nation, with many gay and lesbian groups vilifying it as a symbol of anti-gay bigotry while some conservative and religious leaders groups had praised the commissioners for taking such a clear stand in defense of "family values."
 
Subject for Campaign
 Even if Apple's relocation is now resolved with the reversal today, the earlier action may wind up as a political issue in next year's statewide elections. Over the weekend, for instance, the state Republican executive committee in Texas formally praised Williamson County for its courage in denying Apple the tax breaks.
With Governor Richards having acted so forcefully to help keep Apple in Texas, her views on the matter are clear enough. What is unclear is whether her likely Republican opponent, George W. Bush, son of the former President, will press the issue by staking out any differences with her.
Some gay-rights activists had argued that Apple should teach the county a lesson by taking its high-tech, high-wage jobs elsewhere. The company said it had been besieged by communities, in Texas and elsewhere, begging Apple to consider them for relocation.
But many more argued that the county was a good place to force a discussion of gay issues and that there would be a symbolic loss if Apple gave up on its plans to come there.
"Williamson County has gotten a good education in Gay 101," said David M. Smith, director of public education for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, standing on the county courthouse steps just after the vote. "The bottom line is, jobs triumphed over prejudice."
But many in the county, including Commissioner Hays and the two commissioners who voted against Apple for a second time today, said they were still offended by the company's policy. And each of the commissioners said they resented suggestions that the county was intolerant, one of them noting that the courthouse where everyone was watching today's vote was the same place where a local prosecutor had "broken the back of the Ku Klux Klan" in the area during the 1920's.
One commissioner, Jerry Mehevec, has questioned whether it might even be illegal to grant Apple a tax break, since Texas has a law prohibiting homosexual acts. The law has been declared unconstitutional by lower state courts, and an appeal is pending.
Perhaps the principal architect of the second vote was a pro-Apple commissioner, Mike Heiligenstein, who managed to get Mr. Hays and Apple officials back to the table over the weekend and who also met with Governor Richards. He noted that the tax breaks were roughly equal in value to those the county had granted another big company, the Dell Computer Corporation, to locate in Williamson County.
But the star of the show, willingly or not, was Mr. Hays, who said today that "until last Tuesday I never had to choose between economic development and traditional family values."
Mr. Hays, a father of four who resigned his position with his family-owned title company to become a $42,000-a-year commissioner, said he remained proud of the way the county had debated Apple's policy.
"We expressed to a national forum our views on values," he said in an interview after the vote this morning. "We made a very strong statement about what we felt on that issue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Before changing his vote yesterday in favor of tax breaks for Apple Computer, David Hays, center, a Commissioner of Williamson County in Texas, listened to a proposal by Commissioner Mike Heiligenstein. (Associated Press)
